1168455_11_ITEM7_P193_S7	These advances also must be collateralized.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P194_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P194_S1	Total deposits were $424.9 million as of December 31, 2010, a decrease of $8.4 million, or 2%, from the December 31, 2009 balance of $433.3 million.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P195_S0	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P195_S1	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P195_S2	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_11_ITEM7_P195_S3	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.
1168455_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	As a smaller reporting company we are not required to provide the information required by this item.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	The following consolidated financial statements of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary, and report of the independent registered public accounting firm are included in the Annual Report of Plumas Bancorp to its shareholders for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 and the related consolidated statements of operation, stockholders equity and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P2_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	During 2002, Plumas Bancorp (the Company ) was incorporated as a bank holding company for the purpose of acquiring Plumas Bank (the Bank ) in a one bank holding company reorganization.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P9_S1	This corporate structure gives the Company and the Bank greater flexibility in terms of operation expansion and diversification.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust I ( Trust I ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 26, 2002.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P10_S1	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust II ( Trust II ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 28, 2005.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	The Bank operates eleven branches in California, including branches in Alturas, Chester, Fall River Mills, Greenville, Kings Beach, Portola, Quincy, Redding, Susanville, Tahoe City, and Truckee.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	In addition to its branch network, the Bank operates an administrative office in Reno, Nevada and a lending office specializing in government-guaranteed lending in Auburn, California.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	The Bank s primary source of revenue is generated from providing loans to customers who are predominately small and middle market businesses and individuals residing in the surrounding areas.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	The Bank s deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) up to applicable legal limits.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	The Bank is participating in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) Transaction Account Guarantee Program.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P14_S1	Under the program, through December 31, 2010, all noninterest-bearing transaction accounts were fully guaranteed by the FDIC for the entire amount in the account.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	On July 21, 2010, President Barack Obama signed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ), which, in part, permanently raises the current standard maximum deposit insurance amount to $250,000.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P15_S1	Amendments related to the enactment of the Dodd-Frank Act now provide full deposit insurance coverage for noninterest bearing deposit transaction accounts beginning December 31, 2010 for an additional two year period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	Effective March 16, 2011, in connection with the Bank s regularly scheduled 2010 Joint FDIC and California Department of Financial Institutions ( DFI ) examination, the Bank entered into a Consent Order ( Order ) with the FDIC and the DFI.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	The FDIC and DFI in the Consent Order, require certain actions to be taken by the Bank including among others:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	Not pay cash dividends to Plumas Bancorp without the prior written consent of the FDIC and DFI.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	One of Management s top priorities has and will continue to be to reduce its problem assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	The order serves to formalize and reinforce the Company s on-going plans to strengthen the Company s operations and to implement the Bank s strategic plan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P18_S2	Currently the Bank has exceeded the Order s total risk-based capital ratio goal of 13% and Management expects to achieve the leverage ratio target of 10% by year-end without the injection of any new capital.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P18_S3	As of December 31, 2010, the Bank s leverage ratio was 8.9% and total risk-based capital ratio was 14.0%.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the consolidated accounts of its wholly-owned subsidiary, Plumas Bank.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P19_S1	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and Trust II are not consolidated into the Company s consolidated financial statements and, accordingly, are accounted for under the equity method.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company s investment in Trust I of $275,000 and Trust II of $152,000 are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P20_S2	The junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures issued and guaranteed by the Company and held by Trust I and Trust II are reflected as debt on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	The accounting and reporting policies of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary conform with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America and prevailing practices within the banking industry.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	Certain reclassifications have been made to prior years balances to conform to the classifications used in 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	Management has determined that since all of the banking products and services offered by the Company are available in each branch of the Bank, all branches are located within the same economic environment and management does not allocate resources based on the performance of different lending or transaction activities, it is appropriate to aggregate the Bank branches and report them as a single operating segment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	No customer accounts for more than 10 percent of revenues for the Company or the Bank.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	These estimates and assumptions affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P25_S2	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, cash and due from banks and Federal funds sold are considered to be cash equivalents.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	Generally, Federal funds are sold for one day periods.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P26_S2	As of December 31, 2010 all cash held with other federally insured institutions was fully insured by the FDIC.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	Investments are classified into one of the following categories:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	Available-for-sale securities reported at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported, net of taxes, as accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) within shareholders equity.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	Held-to-maturity securities, which management has the positive intent and ability to hold, reported at amortized cost, adjusted for the accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of its investments at the time of purchase and may only change the classification in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	During 2009, management determined they no longer had the positive intent to hold their held-to-maturity securities and transferred their held-to-maturity securities to available- for-sale (see note 5).
1168455_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	This transfer increases the Company s flexibility in managing its investment portfolio allowing the investments to be sold in implementing its asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P31_S2	All transfers between categories are accounted for at fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P31_S3	There were no transfers between categories during 2010 or 2008.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as trading and gains or losses on the sale of securities are computed on the specific identification method.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P32_S1	Interest earned on investment securities is reported in interest income, net of applicable adjustments for accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	An investment security is impaired when its carrying value is greater than its fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S1	Investment securities that are impaired are evaluated on at least a quarterly basis and more frequently when economic or market conditions warrant such an evaluation to determine whether such a decline in their fair value is other than temporary.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S2	Management utilizes criteria such as the magnitude and duration of the decline and the intent and ability of the Company to retain its investment in the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery in fair value, in addition to the reasons underlying the decline, to determine whether the loss in value is other than temporary.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S3	The term other than temporary is not intended to indicate that the decline is permanent, but indicates that the prospects for a near-term recovery of value is not necessarily favorable, or that there is a lack of evidence to support a realizable value equal to or greater than the carrying value of the investment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S4	Once a decline in value is determined to be other than temporary, and management does not intend to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery, only the portion of the impairment loss representing credit exposure is recognized as a charge to earnings, with the balance recognized as a charge to other comprehensive income.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P33_S5	If management intends to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the security before recovering its forecasted cost, the entire impairment loss is recognized as a charge to earnings.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	As a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, the Bank is required to maintain an investment in the capital stock of the Federal Home Loan Bank.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	The investment is carried at cost.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) stock totaled $2,188,000 and $1,933,000, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	On the consolidated balance sheet, Federal Home Loan Bank stock is included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	Included in the portfolio are loans which are 75% to 90% guaranteed by the Small Business Administration (SBA), US Department of Agriculture Rural Business Cooperative Service (RBS) and Farm Services Agency (FSA).
1168455_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	The guaranteed portion of these loans may be sold to a third party, with the Bank retaining the unguaranteed portion.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P36_S2	The Company can receive a premium in excess of the adjusted carrying value of the loan at the time of sale.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P36_S3	In the case of SBA loans, the Company may be required to refund a portion of the sales premium if the borrower defaults or prepays within ninety days of the settlement date.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	In accordance with new accounting standards for the sale of a portion of a loan, as more fully described in the Adoption of New Financial Accounting Standards section of this note, we have recorded the proceeds from the sale of the guaranteed portions of SBA loans that are subject to a premium refund obligation, which totaled $4,284,000, as a secured borrowing and included such secured borrowings in other liabilities on the balance sheet.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	Once the premium refund obligation has elapsed the transaction will be recorded as a sale with the guaranteed portions of loans and the secured borrowing removed from the balance sheet and the resulting gain on sale recorded.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	Included in commercial loans at December 31, 2010 is $4,284,000 in guaranteed portions of SBA loans sold subject to a 90-day premium refund obligation.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P38_S1	In February 2011, the SBA eliminated the refund obligation period and the Company will no longer be required to defer gain recognition.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	As of December 31, 2010 the Company had $5,208,000 in government guaranteed loans held for sale.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P39_S1	Loans held for sale are recorded at the lower of cost or fair vale and therefore maybe reported at fair value on a non-recurring basis.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P39_S2	The fair values for loans held for sale are based on either observable transactions of similar instruments or formally committed loan sale prices.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	Government guaranteed loans with unpaid balances of $33,686,000 and $18,512,000 were being serviced for others at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	The Company also serviced loans previously sold to the Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA) totaling $2,185,000 and $3,014,000 as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Company accounts for the transfer and servicing of financial assets based on the fair value of financial and servicing assets it controls and liabilities it has assumed, derecognizes financial assets when control has been surrendered, and derecognizes liabilities when extinguished.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	Servicing rights acquired through 1) a purchase or 2) the origination of loans which are sold or securitized with servicing rights retained are recognized as separate assets or liabilities.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	Servicing assets or liabilities are recorded at the difference between the contractual servicing fees and adequate compensation for performing the servicing, and are subsequently amortized in proportion to and over the period of the related net servicing income or expense.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P42_S2	Servicing assets are periodically evaluated for impairment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	Fair values are estimated using discounted cash flows based on current market interest rates.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	For purposes of measuring impairment, servicing assets are stratified based on note rate and term.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P43_S2	The amount of impairment recognized, if any is the amount by which the servicing assets for a stratum exceed their fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	The Company s investment in the loan is allocated between the retained portion of the loan, the servicing asset, the interest-only (IO) strip, and the sold portion of the loan based on their relative fair values on the date the loan is sold.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	The gain on the sold portion of the loan is recognized as income at the time of sale.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S2	The carrying value of the retained portion of the loan is discounted based on the estimated value of a comparable non-guaranteed loan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S3	The servicing asset is recognized and amortized over the estimated life of the related loan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S4	Assets (accounted for as interest-only (IO) strips) are recorded at the fair value of the difference between note rates and rates paid to purchasers (the interest spread) and contractual servicing fees, if applicable.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S5	IO strips are carried at fair value with gains or losses recorded as a component of shareholders equity, similar to available-for-sale investment securities.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P44_S6	Significant future prepayments of these loans will result in the recognition of additional amortization of related servicing assets and an adjustment to the carrying value of related IO strips.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	Loans are stated at principal balances outstanding, except for loans, if any, that are transferred from loans held for sale which are carried at the lower of principal balance or market value at the date of transfer, adjusted for accretion of discounts.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	Interest is accrued daily based upon outstanding loan balances.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P45_S2	However, when, in the opinion of management, loans are considered to be impaired and the future collectibility of interest and principal is in serious doubt, loans are placed on nonaccrual status and the accrual of interest income is suspended.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	Any interest accrued but unpaid is charged against income.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	Payments received are applied to reduce principal to the extent necessary to ensure collection.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P46_S2	Subsequent payments on these loans, or payments received on nonaccrual loans for which the ultimate collectibility of principal is not in doubt, are applied first to earned but unpaid interest and then to principal.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	Loan origination fees, commitment fees, direct loan origination costs and purchased premiums and discounts on loans are deferred and recognized as an adjustment of yield, to be amortized to interest income over the contractual term of the loan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	The unamortized balance of deferred fees and costs is reported as a component of net loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Company may acquire loans through a business combination or a purchase for which differences may exist between the contractual cash flows and the cash flows expected to be collected due, at least in part, to credit quality.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P48_S1	When the Company acquires such loans, the yield that may be accreted (accretable yield) is limited to the excess of the Company s estimate of undiscounted cash flows expected to be collected over the Company s initial investment in the loan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P48_S2	The excess of contractual cash flows over cash flows expected to be collected may not be recognized as an adjustment to yield, loss, or a valuation allowance.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P48_S3	Subsequent increases in cash flows expected to be collected generally should be recognized prospectively through adjustment of the loan s yield over its remaining life.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P48_S4	Decreases in cash flows expected to be collected should be recognized as an impairment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	The Company may not carry over or create a valuation allowance in the initial accounting for loans acquired under these circumstances.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P49_S1	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, there were no such loans being accounted for under this policy.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P50_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P50_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	Credit exposures determined to be uncollectible are charged against the allowance.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P51_S1	Cash received on previously charged off amounts is recorded as a recovery to the allowance.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are not impaired.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	A loan is considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect all amounts due, including principal and interest, according to the contractual terms of the original agreement.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P53_S1	Loans determined to be impaired are individually evaluated for impairment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P53_S2	When a loan is impaired, the Company measures impairment based on the present value of expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate, except that as a practical expedient, it may measure impairment based on a loan s observable market price, or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	A loan is collateral dependent if the repayment of the loan is expected to be provided solely by the underlying collateral.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	The determination of the general reserve for loans that are not impaired is based on estimates made by management, to include, but not limited to, consideration of historical losses by portfolio segment, internal asset classifications, and qualitative factors to include economic trends in the Company s service areas, industry experience and trends, geographic concentrations, estimated collateral values, the Company s underwriting policies, the character of the loan portfolio, and probable losses inherent in the portfolio taken as a whole.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	The Company s maintains a separate allowance for each portfolio segment (loan type).
1168455_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	These portfolio segments include commercial and industrial, agricultural, real estate construction (including land and development loans), commercial real estate mortgage, residential mortgage, home equity loans, installment loans, automobile loans and other loans primarily consisting of credit card receivables.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P59_S2	The allowance for loan losses attributable to each portfolio segment, which includes both impaired loans and loans that are not impaired, is combined to determine the Company s overall allowance, which is included on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	The Company assigns a risk rating to all loans and periodically performs detailed reviews of all such loans over a certain threshold to identify credit risks and to assess the overall collectability of the portfolio.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	These risk ratings are also subject to examination by independent specialists engaged by the Company and the Company s regulators.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P61_S0	During these internal reviews, management monitors and analyzes the financial condition of borrowers and guarantors, trends in the industries in which borrowers operate and the fair values of collateral securing these loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P62_S0	These credit quality indicators are used to assign a risk rating to each individual loan.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P62_S1	The risk ratings can be grouped into five major categories, defined as follows:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P63_S0	Pass A pass loan is a strong credit with no existing or known potential weaknesses deserving of management s close attention.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P64_S0	Watch A Watch loan has potential weaknesses that deserve management s close attention.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P64_S1	If left uncorrected, these potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the repayment prospects for the loan or in the Company s credit position at some future date.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P65_S0	Watch loans are not adversely classified and do not expose the Company to sufficient risk to warrant adverse classification.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P66_S0	Substandard A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P67_S0	Loans classified as substandard have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P67_S1	Well defined weaknesses include a project s lack of marketability, inadequate cash flow or collateral support, failure to complete construction on time or the project s failure to fulfill economic expectations.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P67_S2	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Company will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P68_S0	Doubtful Loans classified doubtful have all the weaknesses inherent in those classified as substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P69_S0	Loss Loans classified as loss are considered uncollectible and charged off immediately.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P70_S0	The general reserve component of the allowance for loan losses also consists of reserve factors that are based on management s assessment of the following for each portfolio segment: (1) historical losses and (2) other qualitative factors, including inherent credit risk.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P70_S1	These reserve factors are inherently subjective and are driven by the repayment risk associated with each portfolio segment described below.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P71_S0	Commercial Commercial loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than real estate portfolio segments because these loans are generally underwritten to existing cash flows of operating businesses.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P71_S1	Debt coverage is provided by business cash flows and economic trends influenced by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P72_S0	Agricultural Loans secured by crop production and livestock are especially vulnerable to two risk factors that are largely outside the control of Company and borrowers: commodity prices and weather conditions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P73_S0	Real estate Residential and Home Equity Lines of Credit The degree of risk in residential real estate lending depends primarily on the loan amount in relation to collateral value, the interest rate and the borrower s ability to repay in an orderly fashion.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P73_S1	These loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P73_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P73_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	Real estate Commercial Commercial real estate mortgage loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments, except land and construction loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P74_S1	Adverse economic developments or an overbuilt market impact commercial real estate projects and may result in troubled loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P74_S2	Trends in vacancy rates of commercial properties impact the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P74_S3	High vacancy rates reduce operating revenues and the ability for properties to produce sufficient cash flow to service debt obligations.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	Real estate Construction and Land Development Construction and land development loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	A major risk arises from the necessity to complete projects within specified cost and time lines.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P75_S2	Trends in the construction industry significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as demand drives construction activity.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P75_S3	In addition, trends in real estate values significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as property values determine the economic viability of construction projects.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P76_S0	Installment An installment loan portfolio is usually comprised of a large number of small loans scheduled to be amortized over a specific period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P76_S1	Most installment loans are made directly for consumer purchases, but business loans granted for the purchase of heavy equipment or industrial vehicles may also be included.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P76_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P76_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P77_S0	Other - Other loans primarily consist of automobile and credit card loans and are similar in nature to installment loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P78_S0	Although management believes the allowance to be adequate, ultimate losses may vary from its estimates.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P78_S1	At least quarterly, the Board of Directors reviews the adequacy of the allowance, including consideration of the relative risks in the portfolio, current economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P78_S2	If the Board of Directors and management determine that changes are warranted based on those reviews, the allowance is adjusted.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P78_S3	In addition, the Company s primary regulators, the FDIC and California Department of Financial Institutions, as an integral part of their examination process, review the adequacy of the allowance.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P78_S4	These regulatory agencies may require additions to the allowance based on their judgment about information available at the time of their examinations.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P79_S0	The Company also maintains a separate allowance for off-balance-sheet commitments.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P80_S0	Management estimates anticipated losses using historical data and utilization assumptions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P81_S0	December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively and is included in accrued interest payable and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	Other real estate relates to real estate acquired in full or partial settlement of loan obligations, which was $8,867,000 net of a valuation allowance of $4,188,000 at December 31, 2010 and $11,204,000 net of a valuation allowance of $5,066,000 at December 31, 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S1	Proceeds from sales of other real estate totaled $3,462,000 and $1,992,000 for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2010 the Company recorded a gain on sale of other real estate of $43,000.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S3	This compares to a loss on sale of $158,000 during 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S4	There were no sales of other real estate in 2008.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S5	When other real estate is acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair market value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S6	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S7	The allowance is established through a provision for losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P82_S8	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are recorded in other income or expenses as incurred.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P83_S0	Intangible assets consist of core deposit intangibles related to branch acquisitions and are amortized using the straight-line method over ten years.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P83_S1	The Company evaluates the recoverability and remaining useful life annually to determine whether events or circumstances warrant a revision to the intangible asset or the remaining period of amortization.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P83_S2	There were no such events or circumstances in 2010 or 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P84_S0	Premises and equipment are carried at cost.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P85_S0	Depreciation is determined using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P85_S1	The useful lives of premises are estimated to be twenty to thirty years.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P85_S2	The useful lives of furniture, fixtures and equipment are estimated to be two to ten years.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P86_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the life of the asset or the life of the related lease, whichever is shorter.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P86_S1	When assets are sold or otherwise disposed of, the cost and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts, and any resulting gain or loss is recognized in income for the period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P87_S0	The cost of maintenance and repairs is charged to expense as incurred.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P88_S0	The Company evaluates premises and equipment for financial impairment as events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be fully recoverable.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P89_S0	The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P89_S1	The allocation of income tax expense (benefit) represents each entity s proportionate share of the consolidated provision for income taxes.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P90_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P90_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are adjusted for the effects of changes in tax laws and rates on the date of enactment.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P90_S2	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P91_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P92_S0	When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P92_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P92_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P92_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P92_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P93_S0	Interest expense and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits, if any, are classified as income tax expense in the consolidated statement of operations.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P93_S1	There have been no significant changes to unrecognized tax benefits or accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P94_S0	Basic earnings (loss) per share (EPS), which excludes dilution, is computed by dividing income (loss) available to common stockholders (net income or (loss) less preferred dividends) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P94_S1	Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P94_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted EPS.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P95_S0	At December 31, 2010, the Company had two shareholder approved stock-based compensation plans, the Plumas Bank 2001 and 1991 Stock Option Plans (the Plans ) which are described more fully in Note 12.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P96_S0	Compensation expense, net of related tax benefits, recorded in 2010, 2009 and 2008 totaled $53,000, $237,000 and $269,000 or $0.01, $0.05 and $0.06 per diluted share, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P96_S1	Compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period on a straight line accounting basis.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P97_S0	The Company determines the fair value of the options previously granted on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model that uses assumptions based on expected option life, expected stock volatility and the risk-free interest rate.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P97_S1	The expected volatility assumptions used by the Company are based on the historical volatility of the Company s common stock over the most recent period commensurate with the estimated expected life of the Company s stock options.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P97_S2	The Company bases its expected life assumption on its historical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock options it grants to employees.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P97_S3	The risk-free rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve for the periods within the contractual life of the options in effect at the time of the grant.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P98_S0	The Company also makes assumptions regarding estimated forfeitures that will impact the total compensation expenses recognized under the Plans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P99_S0	The fair value of each option is estimated on the date of grant using the following assumptions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P100_S0	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S0	In June 2009, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued FASB Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2009-16 , Accounting for Transfers of Financial Assets (Statement 166) , which amends previously issued accounting guidance to enhance accounting and reporting for transfers of financial assets, including securitizations or continuing exposure to the risks related to transferred financial assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S1	Prior to the issuance of Statement 166, transfers under participation agreements and other partial loan sales fell under the general guidance for transfers of financial assets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S2	Statement 166 introduces a new definition for a participating interest along with the requirement for partial loan sales to meet the definition of a participating interest for sale treatment to occur.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S3	If a participation or other partial loan sale does not meet the definition, the portion sold should remain on the books and the proceeds recorded as a secured borrowing until the definition is met.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S4	Additionally, existing provisions that require the transferred assets to be isolated from the originating institution (transferor), that the transferor does not maintain effective control through certain agreements to repurchase or redeem the transferred assets and that the purchasing institution (transferee) has the right to pledge or exchange the assets acquired were retained.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S5	The new provisions became effective on January 1, 2010 and early adoption was not permitted.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S6	Under this new standard, the Company s loan participations were not affected, but the Company deferred approximately $340,000 of gains and recorded $4,284,000 of secured borrowings related to the sale of a portion of certain loans as of December 31, 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P101_S7	These gains will be recognized when the warranty periods that precluded the sales from meeting the participating interest standard expire.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P102_S0	In January 2010, the FASB issued FASB ASU 2010-06 , Improving Disclosures about Fair Value Measurements, which amends and clarifies existing standards to require additional disclosures regarding fair value measurements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P102_S1	Specifically, the standard requires disclosure of the amounts of significant transfers between Level 1 and Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy and the reasons for these transfers, the reasons for any transfers in or out of Level 3, and information in the reconciliation of recurring Level 3 measurements about purchases, sales, issuances and settlements on a gross basis.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P103_S0	This standard clarifies that reporting entities are required to provide fair value measurement disclosures for each class of assets and liabilities previously separate fair value disclosures were required for each major category of assets and liabilities.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P103_S1	This standard also clarifies the requirement to disclose information about both the valuation techniques and inputs used in estimating Level 2 and Level 3 fair value measurements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P103_S2	Except for the requirement to disclose information about purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements in the reconciliation of recurring Level 3 measurements on a gross basis, these disclosures are effective for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P103_S3	The requirement to separately disclose purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements of recurring Level 3 measurements becomes effective for the Company for the year beginning on January 1, 2011.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P103_S4	The Company adopted this new accounting standard as of January 1, 2010 and the impact of adoption was not material to the consolidated financial statements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P104_S0	In July 2010, the FASB issued FASB ASU 2010-20, Disclosures about the Credit Quality of Financing Receivables and the Allowance for Credit Losses .
1168455_11_ITEM8_P104_S1	ASU 2010-20 requires more robust and disaggregated disclosures about the credit quality of financing receivables (loans) and allowances for loan losses, including disclosure about credit quality indicators, past due information and modifications of finance receivables.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P104_S2	The disclosures as of the end of a reporting period are effective for interim and annual reporting periods ending on and after December 15, 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P104_S3	The disclosures about activity that occurs during a reporting period are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P104_S4	The adoption of this guidance has significantly expanded disclosure requirements related to accounting policies and disclosures related to the allowance for loan losses but did not have an impact on the Company s financial position, results of operation or cash flows.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P105_S0	The estimated fair values of the Company s financial instruments are as follows:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P106_S0	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated future business related to the instruments.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P106_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P107_S0	The following methods and assumptions were used by management to estimate the fair value of its financial instruments at December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P108_S0	Cash and cash equivalents: For cash and cash equivalents, the carrying amount is estimated to be fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P109_S0	Investment securities: For investment securities, fair values are based on quoted market prices, where available.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P109_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair values are estimated using quoted market prices for similar securities and indications of value provided by brokers.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P110_S0	Loans: For variable-rate loans that reprice frequently with no significant change in credit risk, fair values are based on carrying values.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P110_S1	Fair values of loans held for sale, if any, are estimated using quoted market prices for similar loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P110_S2	The fair values for other loans are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered at each reporting date for loans with similar terms to borrowers of comparable creditworthiness.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P110_S3	The fair value of loans is adjusted for the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P110_S4	The carrying value of accrued interest receivable approximates its fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P111_S0	The fair value of impaired loans is based on either the estimated fair value of underlying collateral or estimated cash flows, discounted at the loan s effective rate.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P111_S1	Assumptions regarding credit risk and cash flows are determined using available market information and specific borrower information.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P112_S0	The carrying amount of FHLB stock approximates its fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P112_S1	This investment is carried at cost and is redeemable at par with certain restrictions.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P113_S0	The fair values of bank owned life insurance policies are based on current cash surrender values at each reporting date provided by the insurers.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P114_S0	Deposits: The fair values for demand deposits are, by definition, equal to the amount payable on demand at the reporting date represented by their carrying amount.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P114_S1	Fair values for fixed-rate certificates of deposit are estimated using a discounted cash flow analysis using interest rates offered at each reporting date by the Bank for certificates with similar remaining maturities.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P114_S2	The carrying amount of accrued interest payable approximates its fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P115_S0	The carrying amount of the short-term borrowings approximates its fair value.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P116_S0	The fair values for long-term FHLB term advances are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered at each reporting date for FHLB advances with a similar maturity.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P117_S0	Junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures: The fair value of junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures was determined based on the current market value for like kind instruments of a similar maturity and structure.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P118_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit: The fair value of commitments are estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P118_S1	Commitments to extend credit are primarily for variable rate loans and letters of credit.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P119_S0	For these commitments, there is no significant difference between the committed amounts and their fair values and therefore, these items are not included in the table above.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P120_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments and other factors.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P120_S1	These estimates are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and therefore cannot be determined with precision.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P120_S2	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the fair values presented.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P121_S0	The Company measures fair value under the fair value hierarchy described below.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P122_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active exchange markets.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P123_S0	Level 2: Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-based valuation techniques for which all significant assumptions are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P124_S0	Level 3: Model based techniques that use one significant assumption not observable in the market.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P124_S1	These unobservable assumptions reflect the Company s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use on pricing the asset or liability.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P125_S0	Valuation techniques include management judgment and estimation which may be significant.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P126_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P126_S1	In such cases, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P126_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P127_S0	Management monitors the availability of observable market data to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P128_S0	Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value level to another.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P128_S1	In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P129_S0	Management evaluates the significance of transfers between levels based upon the nature of the financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total assets, total liabilities or total earnings.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P130_S0	The following tables present information about the Company s assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non recurring basis as of December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, and indicates the fair value hierarchy of the valuation techniques utilized by the Company to determine such fair value:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P131_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized below:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P132_S0	The fair value of securities available-for-sale equals quoted market price, if available.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P132_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair value is determined using quoted market prices for similar securities.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P132_S2	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2010 or 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P133_S0	Changes in fair market value are recorded in other comprehensive income.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P134_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis are summarized below:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P135_S0	The following methods were used to estimate the fair value of each class of assets above.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P136_S0	Impaired Loans: The fair value of impaired loans is based on the fair value of the collateral, if collateral dependent or the present value of the expected cash flows discounted at the loan s effective rate for those loans not collateral dependent.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P136_S1	If the Company determines that the value of an impaired loan is less than the recorded investment in the loan, the carrying value is adjusted through a charge-off recorded through the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P136_S2	Total losses of $1,356,000 and $5,127,000 represent impairment charges recognized during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively related to the above impaired loans.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P137_S0	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2010.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P138_S0	The fair value of other real estate is based on property appraisals at the time of transfer and as appropriate thereafter, less estimated costs to sell.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P138_S1	Estimated costs to sell other real estate were based on standard market factors.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P138_S2	Management periodically reviews other real estate to determine whether the property continues to be carried at the lower of its recorded book value or estimated fair value, net of estimated costs to sell.

1168455_11_ITEM8_P148_S0	When analyzing an issuer s financial condition, management considers the length of time and extent to which the market value has been less than cost; the historical and implied volatility of the security; the financial condition of the issuer of the security; and the Company s intent and ability to hold the security to recovery.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P148_S1	As of December 31, 2010, management does not have the intent to sell these securities nor does it believe it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell these securities before the recovery of its amortized cost basis.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P148_S2	Based on the Company s evaluation of the above and other relevant factors, the Company does not believe the securities that are in an unrealized loss position as of December 31, 2010 are other than temporarily impaired.

1168455_11_ITEM8_P152_S0	Changes in the allowance for loan losses were as follows:
1168455_11_ITEM8_P153_S0	The recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $28,755,000 and $19,228,000 at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P153_S1	The Company had specific allowances for loan losses of $1,903,000 on impaired loans of $11,292,000 at December 31, 2010 as compared to specific allowances for loan losses of $4,281,000 on impaired loans of $13,716,000 at December 31, 2009.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P153_S2	The average recorded investment in impaired loans for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $20,833,000, $25,092,000 and $5,243,000, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P153_S3	The Company recognized $608,000, $369,000 and $74,000 in interest income on a cash basis for impaired loans during the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P154_S0	Included in impaired loans are troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P154_S1	A troubled debt restructuring is a formal restructure of a loan where the Company for economic or legal reasons related to the borrower s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the borrower.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P154_S2	The concessions may be granted in various forms, including reduction in the standard interest rate, reduction in the loan balance or accrued interest, and extension of the maturity date.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P155_S0	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, nonaccrual loans totaled $25,313,000 and $14,263,000, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P155_S1	Interest foregone on nonaccrual loans totaled $1,021,000, $568,000 and $576,000 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P155_S2	Loans past due 90 days or more and on accrual status were $45,000 and $28,000 at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_11_ITEM8_P156_S0	Salaries and employee benefits totaling $638,000, $708,000 and $868,000 have been deferred as loan origination costs during the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
