1168455_12_ITEM2_P3_S0	The Company maintains insurance coverage on its premises, leaseholds and equipment, including business interruption and record reconstruction coverage.
1168455_12_ITEM2_P3_S1	The branch properties and non-branch offices are adequate, suitable, in good condition and have adequate parking facilities for customers and employees.
1168455_12_ITEM2_P4_S0	The Company and Bank are limited in their investments in real property under Federal and state banking laws.
1168455_12_ITEM2_P4_S1	Generally, investments in real property are either for the Company and Bank use or are in real property and real property interests in the ordinary course of the Bank s business.
1168455_12_ITEM3_P0_S0	time to time, the Company and/or its subsidiary are a party to claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
1168455_12_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of the Company s management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to such proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on the financial condition or results of operations of the Company taken as a whole.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock is quoted on the NASDAQ Capital Market under the ticker symbol PLBC .
1168455_12_ITEM5_P0_S1	As of December 31, 2011, there were 4,776,339 shares of the Company s stock outstanding held by approximately 1,640 shareholders of record as of the same date.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P0_S2	The following table shows the high and low sales prices for the common stock, for each quarter as reported by Yahoo Finance.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P1_S0	Dividends paid to shareholders by the Company are subject to restrictions set forth in California General Corporation Law, which provides that a corporation may make a distribution to its shareholders if retained earnings immediately prior to the dividend payout are at least equal to the amount of the proposed distribution.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P2_S0	As a bank holding company without significant assets other than its equity position in the Bank, the Company s ability to pay dividends to its shareholders depends primarily upon dividends it receives from the Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P2_S1	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P2_S2	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P3_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_12_ITEM5_P3_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule and in accordance with regulatory restrictions, if any, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P3_S2	No common cash dividends were paid in 2010 or 2011 and none are anticipated to be paid in 2012.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P4_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P4_S1	See Note 2 Regulatory Matters and Note 13 Shareholders Equity Dividend Restrictions of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K. On January 30, 2009, under the Capital Purchase Program, the Company entered into a Letter Agreement (the Purchase Agreement ) with the United States Department of the Treasury ( Treasury ), pursuant to which the Company issued and sold (i) 11,949 shares of the Company s Fixed Rate Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A (the Preferred Shares ) and (ii) a ten-year warrant to purchase up to 237,712 shares of the Company s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $7.54 per share, for an aggregate purchase price of $11,949,000 in cash.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P4_S2	The Series A Preferred Stock and the Warrant were issued in a private placement exempt from registration pursuant to Section 4(2) of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P5_S0	As described in the following paragraph the Purchase Agreement contains provisions that restrict the payment of dividends on Plumas Bancorp common stock and restrict the Company s ability to repurchase Plumas Bancorp common stock.
1168455_12_ITEM5_P6_S0	Under the Purchase Agreement, prior to January 30, 2012, unless the Company has redeemed the Preferred Shares, or the Treasury has transferred the Preferred Shares to a third party, the consent of the Treasury will be required for the Company to: (1) declare or pay any dividend or make any distribution on shares of the Common Stock (other than regular quarterly cash dividends of not more than $0.04 per share or regular semi-annual cash dividends of not more than $0.08 per share); or (2) redeem, purchase or acquire any shares of Common Stock or other equity or capital securities, other than in connection with benefit plans consistent with past practice and certain other circumstances specified in the Purchase Agreement.

1168455_12_ITEM5_P9_S0	The following table presents a summary of selected financial data and should be read in conjunction with the Company s consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included under Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	General We are a bank holding company for Plumas Bank, a California state-chartered commercial bank.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	We derive our income primarily from interest received on real estate related, commercial and consumer loans and, to a lesser extent, interest on investment securities, fees received in connection with servicing deposit and loan customers and fees from the sale of loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our major operating expenses are the interest we pay on deposits and borrowings and general operating expenses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	We rely on locally-generated deposits to provide us with funds for making loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P1_S2	We are subject to competition from other financial institutions and our operating results, like those of other financial institutions operating in California, are significantly influenced by economic conditions in California, including the strength of the real estate market.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P1_S3	In addition, both the fiscal and regulatory policies of the federal and state government and regulatory authorities that govern financial institutions and market interest rates also impact the Bank s financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our accounting policies are integral to understanding the financial results reported.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	Our most complex accounting policies require management s judgment to ascertain the valuation of assets, liabilities, commitments and contingencies.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	We have established detailed policies and internal control procedures that are intended to ensure valuation methods are applied in an environment that is designed and operating effectively and applied consistently from period to period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	The following is a brief description of our current accounting policies involving significant management valuation judgments.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	Credit exposures determined to be uncollectible are charged against the allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	Cash received on previously charged off amounts is recorded as a recovery to the allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	We evaluate our allowance for loan losses quarterly.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	We believe that the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting estimate because it is based upon management s assessment of various factors affecting the collectibility of the loans, including current economic conditions, past credit experience, delinquency status, the value of the underlying collateral, if any, and a continuing review of the portfolio of loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	We cannot provide you with any assurance that economic difficulties or other circumstances which would adversely affect our borrowers and their ability to repay outstanding loans will not occur which would be reflected in increased losses in our loan portfolio, which could result in actual losses that exceed reserves previously established.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	Other real estate owned (OREO) represents properties acquired through foreclosure or physical possession.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	OREO is initially recorded at fair value less costs to sell when acquired.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	Write-downs to fair value at the time of transfer to OREO is charged to allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	Subsequent to foreclosure, we periodically evaluate the value of OREO held for sale and record a valuation allowance for any subsequent declines in fair value less selling costs.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	Subsequent declines in value are charged to operations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	Fair value is based on our assessment of information available to us at the end of a reporting period and depends upon a number of factors, including our historical experience, economic conditions, and issues specific to individual properties.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Our evaluation of these factors involves subjective estimates and judgments that may change.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	The allocation of income tax expense (benefit) represents each entity s proportionate share of the consolidated provision for income taxes.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Deferred income taxes reflect the estimated future tax effects of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and such amounts as measured by tax laws and regulations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	We use an estimate of future earnings to support our position that the benefit of our deferred tax assets will be realized.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P11_S3	If future income should prove non-existent or less than the amount of the deferred tax assets within the tax years to which they may be applied, the asset may not be realized and our net income will be reduced.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P12_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P12_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	The following discussion is designed to provide a better understanding of significant trends related to the Company s financial condition, results of operations, liquidity and capital.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	It pertains to the Company s financial condition, changes in financial condition and results of operations as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 and for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	The discussion should be read in conjunction with the Company s audited consolidated financial statements and notes thereto and the other financial information appearing elsewhere herein.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	Overview The Company recorded net income of $941 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2011, a slight decrease from net income of $971 thousand during the year ended December 31, 2010 but up $10.1 million over 2009 s net loss of $9.1 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	Excluding a $1.4 million gain ($0.8 million net of tax) in 2010 on sale of the Bank s merchant card portfolio, net income would have increased by $0.8 million over 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	Net interest income declined by $713 thousand from $17.5 million during 2010 to $16.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	This decrease in net interest income was mostly related to a $21 million decline in average loan balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2011 non-interest income decreased by $1.3 million to $7.2 million, from $8.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S5	This decrease was related to a $1.4 million gain on the sale of our merchant processing portfolio in 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S6	Additionally, gain on sale of investment securities declined by $494 thousand from $1.2 million in 2010 to $0.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S7	Partially offsetting these declines in non-interest income was an $884 thousand increase in gain on sale of government guaranteed loans from $1.1 million in 2010 to $1.9 million in 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S8	Non-interest expense increased by $105 thousand from $19.1 million during the year ended December 31, 2010 to $19.2 million during the current twelve month period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S9	While we have achieved savings in many categories of non-interest expense these were offset in the current year by an increase of $649 thousand in loss on sale of OREO.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S10	The most significant expense reduction was a $2.0 million decrease in our provision for loan losses from $5.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 to $3.5 million during 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S11	The $3.5 million provision recorded for the year ended December 31, 2011 primarily relates to net charge-offs during the twelve month period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S12	We have experienced a $3.8 million decrease in net charge-offs during the comparison years.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S13	Net charge-offs declined from $7.7 million during 2010 to $3.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S14	Net charge-offs as percentage of average loans decreased significantly from 2.39% during the twelve months ended December 31, 2010 to 1.29% during the current year.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S15	The provision for income taxes declined from $389 thousand in 2010 to $295 thousand during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P14_S16	Net income allocable to common shareholders decreased slightly from $287 thousand during the year ended December 31, 2010 to $257 thousand during 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	Income allocable to common shareholders is calculated by subtracting dividends and discount amortized on preferred stock from net income.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	Total assets at December 31, 2011 decreased $29.1 million, or 6% to $455 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	Decreases include $5.1 million in investment securities, $19.7 million in net loans, $1.6 million in cash and due from banks and $2.7 million in all other assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P16_S2	Net loans decreased by 6% from $307 million at December 31, 2010 to $287 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P16_S3	This decline in net loans was mostly related to normal pay downs and prepayments, loan charge-offs, real estate acquired through foreclosure and our continued efforts to reduce the level of construction and land development loan balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	At December 31, 2011 investment securities totaled $57.9 million compared to $63.0 million at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	Investment securities are composed of debt securities issued by agencies sponsored by the U.S. Government.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	Total deposits were $391 million as of December 31, 2011, a decrease of $33.7 million, or 8%, from the December 31, 2010 balance of $425 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	The decline in deposits was primarily related to maturities from a higher rate promotional time deposit product we began offering in June, 2009 and continued to offer until April 30, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S3	Core deposit growth was strong with increases in non-interest bearing deposits of $14.1 million and savings deposits of $10.8 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S4	Non-interest bearing deposits as a percentage of total deposits increased from 26.3% at December 31, 2010 to 32.2% at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S5	Shareholders equity as of December 31, 2011 increased by $1.6 million to $39.6 million up from $38.0 million as of December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S6	This increase was mostly related to earnings during the period, the reversal of $524 thousand in accrued preferred stock dividends and an increase of $210 thousand in accumulated other comprehensive income/loss from a loss of $52 thousand at December 31, 2010 to accumulated other comprehensive income of $158 thousand at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S7	The return on average assets was 0.20% for 2011, up from 0.19% for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P18_S8	The return on average common equity was 0.9% for 2011, down from 1.1% for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	The following table presents, for the years indicated, the distribution of consolidated average assets, liabilities and shareholders equity.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Average balances are based on average daily balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	It also presents the amounts of interest income from interest-earning assets and the resultant yields expressed in both dollars and yield percentages, as well as the amounts of interest expense on interest-bearing liabilities and the resultant cost expressed in both dollars and rate percentages.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P20_S2	Nonaccrual loans are included in the calculation of average loans while nonaccrued interest thereon is excluded from the computation of yields earned:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	(1) Interest income is reflected on an actual basis and is not computed on a tax-equivalent basis.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	(4) Net interest spread represents the average yield earned on interest-earning assets less the average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	(5) Net interest margin is computed by dividing net interest income by total average earning assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	The following table sets forth changes in interest income and interest expense, for the years indicated and the amount of change attributable to variances in volume, rates and the combination of volume and rates based on the relative changes of volume and rates:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	(1) The volume change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the previous year s rate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	(2) The rate change in net interest income represents the change in rate multiplied by the previous year s average balance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	(3) The mix change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the change in rate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	Net interest income is the difference between interest income and interest expense.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	Net interest income, on a nontax-equivalent basis, was $16.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, a decline of $0.7 million, or 4.1%, from $17.5 million for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S2	The overall change in net interest income was primarily a result of a decrease of $1.5 million in loan interest income and a decline of $628 thousand in interest income on investment securities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S3	The decline in interest on loans was mostly related to a decline in average loans outstanding.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S4	Interest on investments securities declined related to a decrease in both yield and average balance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S5	Partially offsetting these decreases in interest income was a decline in rates paid on the Company s deposits and a decline in the average balance of time deposits, interest bearing demand deposits and long-term borrowings.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S6	Interest income decreased $2.0 million, or 9.7%, to $18.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S7	Interest and fees on loans decreased by $1.5 million from $18.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 to $17.4 million for 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S8	The average loan balances were $302.8 million for 2011, down $21.1 million from the $323.9 million for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S9	This decline in loans was mostly related to normal pay downs and prepayments, loan charge-offs, real estate acquired through foreclosure and our on-going efforts to reduce the level of construction and land development loan balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S10	The average yields on loans were 5.75% for 2011 down from the 5.82% for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S11	Interest on investment securities decreased by $628 thousand resulting from a decrease in yield of 63 basis points and a decline in average investment securities of $9.9 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P28_S12	The decline in yield is primarily related to the replacement of matured and sold investment securities with new investments with market yields below those which they replaced.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	Interest income on other interest-earning assets, which totaled $124 thousand in 2011 and $48 thousand in 2010, relates to interest on cash balances held at the Federal Reserve.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P29_S1	Interest expense on deposits decreased by $1.2 million, or 46%, to $1.5 million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2011, down from $2.7 million in 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P29_S2	This decrease primarily relates to decreases in the average balance and rate paid on time deposits and a decline in the rate paid on demand deposit (NOW) and money market accounts.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	Interest on time deposits declined by $946 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	Average time deposits declined by $27.8 million from $124.8 million during 2010 to $97.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S2	The decrease in time deposits is mostly related to a promotional time deposit product we began offering in June, 2009 and continued to offer until April 30, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S3	These promotional time deposits have now fully matured.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S4	The average rate paid on these promotional deposits during 2011 was 2%.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S5	The average rate paid on time deposits decreased from 1.61% during 2010 to 1.09% during the current twelve month period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S6	This decrease primarily relates to a decline in market rates paid in the Company s service area and the maturity of the higher rate promotional deposits.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S7	Interest expense on NOW accounts declined by $195 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S8	Rates paid on NOW accounts declined by 18 basis points from 0.38% during 2010 to 0.20% during 2011, as we significantly lowered the rate paid on local public agencies NOW accounts.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S9	Although we lost deposits by lowering this rate; we continue to focus on the profitability of the public sweep accounts rather than growing public sweep balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S10	Interest expense on money market accounts decreased by $106 thousand related primarily to a decrease in rate paid on these accounts of 23 basis points from 0.52% during 2010 to 0.29% during 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S11	This was primarily related to a significant drop in the rates paid on our money market sweep product.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S12	We no longer offer the money market sweep account having replaced it with a product that utilizes repurchase agreements during the third quarter of 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S13	Interest on FHLB long term borrowings decreased by $130 thousand as there were no outstanding long term borrowings during 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S14	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which increased by $14 thousand from 2010, fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P30_S15	Interest on other borrowings in 2011 primarily relates to interest paid on repurchase agreements.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2011 decreased 16 basis points to 4.08%, from 4.24% for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S2	Net interest income, on a nontax-equivalent basis, was $17.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, a decline of $1.6 million, or 8.6%, from $19.2 million for 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S3	The overall change in net interest income was primarily a result of a decrease of $1.8 million in loan interest income, due to a decline in average loans outstanding.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S4	Additionally, interest on investments securities declined by $391 thousand, related to a decrease in yield.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S5	Partially offsetting these decreases in interest income was a decline in rates paid on the Company s deposits and borrowings.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S6	Interest income decreased $2.2 million, or 9.4%, to $20.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S7	Interest and fees on loans decreased by $1.8 million from $20.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 to $18.9 million for 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S8	The average loan balances were $323.9 million for 2010, down $30.6 million from the $354.5 million for 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S9	The decline in loan balances is consistent with the decrease in economic activity in the Company s service area and the Company s successful effort to reduce its exposure to real estate construction and land development loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S10	The average yields on loans were 5.82% for 2010 as compared to the 5.83% for 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S11	Interest on investment securities decreased by $391 thousand, as a decrease in yield of 83 basis points was partially offset by an increase in average investment securities of $5.3 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P31_S12	The decline in yield is primarily related to the replacement of matured and sold investment securities with new investments with market yields below those which they replaced.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	Deposit rates in the Bank s service area continued to decline in 2010 resulting in a decline in interest expense on deposits of $473 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2010, from $3.2 million for 2009 to $2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	All deposit products experienced rate declines in 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P32_S2	Interest expense on NOW accounts decreased by $289 thousand related to a decrease in the average rate paid on these accounts.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P32_S3	Rates paid on NOW accounts declined by 30 basis points from 0.68% during 2009 to 0.38% during 2010 as we significantly lowered the rate paid on local public agencies NOW accounts.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P32_S4	Although we lost some deposits by lowering this rate; we currently are more focused on the profitability of the public sweep accounts rather than the amount of deposits we can generate from this source.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	Interest expense on money market accounts decreased by $125 thousand related to a decrease in rate paid on these accounts of 31 basis points from 0.83% during the year ended December 31, 2009 to 0.52% during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S1	This was primarily related to a significantly drop in the rates paid on our money market sweep product.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S2	Interest on time deposits declined by $55 thousand as an increase in average balance was offset by a decline in rate paid.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to 2009, the Company s average time deposits increased by $19.5 million from $105.3 million for 2009 to $124.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S4	The increase in time deposits is related to a promotional time deposit product we began offering in June, 2009 and continued to offer until April 30, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S5	The average rate paid on time deposits decreased from 1.96% during 2009 to 1.61% during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S6	This decrease primarily relates to a decline in market rates in the Company s service area.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S7	Interest on borrowings increased by $28 thousand related to an increase in the rate paid on borrowings as we chose to extend the term of our borrowings; however, this was partially offset by a $59 thousand decline in interest paid on junior subordinated debentures.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S8	Interest expense on FHLB long-term borrowings increased by $103 thousand to $130 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S9	We chose to prepay these borrowings during July 2010 as we had significant excess liquidity and no longer projected a need for these long-term borrowings.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P33_S10	We incurred a $226 thousand prepayment penalty on these advances which we anticipate will be more than offset by future savings in interest expense.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	Interest on short-term borrowings decreased by $75 thousand to $5 thousand related to a decline in average balance of $23.3 million from $24.3 million during 2009 to $986 thousand during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P34_S1	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate, decreased by $59 thousand during 2010 as a result of a decrease in the LIBOR rate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P35_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2010 decreased 28 basis points to 4.24%, from 4.52% for 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P35_S2	Provision for Loan Losses During the year ended December 31, 2011 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $3.5 million down $2.0 million from the $5.5 million provision recorded during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P35_S3	See Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses for further discussion of loan quality trends and the provision for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that management believes will be appropriate to absorb inherent losses on existing loans based on an evaluation of the collectibility of the loans and prior loan loss experience.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	The evaluations take into consideration such factors as changes in the nature and volume of the portfolio, overall portfolio quality, review of specific problem loans, and current economic conditions that may affect the borrower s ability to repay their loan.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	The allowance for loan losses is based on estimates, and ultimate losses may vary from the current estimates.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P37_S1	These estimates are reviewed periodically and, as adjustments become necessary, they are reported in earnings in the periods in which they become known.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	Based on information currently available, management believes that the allowance for loan losses is appropriate to absorb potential risks in the portfolio.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	However, no assurance can be given that the Company may not sustain charge-offs which are in excess of the allowance in any given period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	The following table sets forth the components of non-interest income for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2011 non-interest income decreased by $1.3 million to $7.2 million, from $8.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P40_S1	This decrease was related to the sale of our merchant processing portfolio in 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	During June 2010 we entered into an alliance with a world-wide merchant processing leader.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S1	In conjunction with this alliance we sold our merchant processing business, recording a one-time gain of $1.4 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S2	Related to this sale we experienced a decrease in merchant processing income of $126 thousand during the comparison periods.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S3	Service charges on deposit accounts declined by $165 thousand primarily related to a decline in overdraft fees as new regulations placed additional restrictions on the Bank in charging overdraft fees on ATM and Point of Sale transactions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S4	Gain on sale of investments declined by $494 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S5	During the year ended December 31, 2011 we sold twenty-seven investment securities classified as available-for-sale for $29.4 million recognizing a $0.7 million gain on sale.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S6	During the 2010 period we sold sixty-five investment securities classified as available-for sale for $40.9 million and recorded a $1.2 million gain on sale.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S7	We chose to sell some of the securities in our investment portfolio in order to lock in gains; this had the additional benefit of partially offsetting some nonrecurring expense items such as losses on sale of OREO.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P41_S8	Partially offsetting these declines in income was a $884 thousand increase in gain on sale of government guaranteed loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S0	Gains on sale in 2011 were particularly strong related to two factors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S1	First, during the first quarter of 2011 the SBA eliminated the recourse provision related to loan sales allowing us to record both gains on sales from loans sold during the fourth quarter of 2010 and the first quarter of 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S2	In addition, many loans sold in 2011 were 90% guaranteed related to a temporary increase in guarantee percentage enacted on February 17, 2009 as part of the Recovery Act.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S3	Currently loans made through the SBA 7(a) program carry a 75% to 85% guarantee.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S4	The production and sale of government guaranteed loans has become an important component of the Company s core business.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P42_S5	We expect government guaranteed lending activity to remain strong in 2012; however, we anticipate a reduction in gains on sale during 2012.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	Loan servicing fees increased by $24 thousand to $219 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	Loan servicing fees are primarily related to fees earned for servicing the sold portion of SBA loans and the increase in this category is consistent with the increase in sold SBA loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2010 non-interest income increased by $2.8 million to $8.6 million, from $5.8 million during 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S1	This increase was primarily related to three items, the largest of which was a $1.4 million gain on the sale of our merchant processing portfolio.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S2	Additionally we sold securities having a book value of $39.7 million, recording a gain on sale of $1.2 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S3	We chose to sell substantially our entire municipal securities portfolio as part of our overall asset/liability management strategy and related to the favorable market price for these securities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S4	In addition, we sold $28.9 million in U.S. government agency securities to lock in significant gains that were available on these securities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S5	Finally, we recorded a gain on sale of government guaranteed loans of $1.1 million representing the sale of $13.6 million in loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S6	Additional SBA government guaranteed loans totaling $4.3 million were sold during the fourth quarter; however, the gain on sale generated was not recorded until the 90-day premium recourse period on SBA loan sales had expired.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P44_S7	During the first quarter of 2011, the Company recognized a gain on sale of approximately $338 thousand related to loans sold during the fourth quarter of 2010; however, this gain was partially offset by commission expense of approximately $106 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	Loan servicing fees increased by $56 thousand to $195 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P45_S1	Loan servicing fees are primarily related to fees earned for servicing the sold portion of SBA loans and the increase in this category is consistent with the increase in sold SBA loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P45_S2	Service charges on deposit accounts declined by $154 thousand primarily related to a decline in overdraft fees as new regulations placed additional restrictions on the Bank in charging overdraft fees on ATM and Point of Sale transactions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P45_S3	Merchant processing fees declined by $141 thousand related to the sale of our merchant processing portfolio in June, 2010.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P48_S8	This property is currently valued at approximately $1 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	OREO carrying costs declined by $151 thousand from $573 thousand during 2010 to $422 thousand during 2011.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S2	Insurance expense declined by $83 thousand primarily related to the forfeiture of retirement split dollar life insurance benefits by one of our executive officers who chose to terminate his employment during 2011 prior to age sixty-five.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S3	Other non-interest expense declined by $228 thousand related to a $226 thousand prepayment penalty incurred upon the prepayment of our long-term Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings during July, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S4	During the second quarter of 2010 we performed an extensive analysis of our personnel requirements throughout the organization and based on this analysis we were able to reduce our head count by approximately 10% which resulted in significant savings in salary and benefits during the second half of 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S5	During the year ended December 31, 2010, total non-interest expense decreased by $7.1 million, or 27%, to $19.2 million, down from $26.3 million for the comparable period in 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S6	This decrease in non-interest expense was primarily the result of savings in salaries and employee benefits, occupancy and equipment costs, professional fees, provision for OREO losses and a reduction in losses on the sale of OREO.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S7	These items and other reductions were partially offset by increases in outside service fees, OREO carrying expenses and insurance expense.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S10	While the Company reduced personnel in most functional areas, we increased staffing in our problem asset department to effectively manage our increased level of nonperforming assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P49_S11	Additionally, staffing in our government guaranteed lending department was increased to support opportunities for loan growth in this area.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	During the first quarter of 2010 we recorded an adjustment to the estimated forfeiture rate associated with option expense.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	The decline in occupancy and equipment expense primarily relates to the savings realized from the purchase of our Redding branch.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	On March 31, 2010 we purchased the building housing our Redding branch at a cost of $1.0 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S1	Previously we had leased this building.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S2	Under the terms of the lease agreement we were provided free rent for a period of time; however, in accordance with accounting principals we recognized monthly rent expense equal to the total payments required under the lease dividend by the term of the lease in months.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S3	At the time of the purchase we reversed this accrual recognizing a $184 thousand reduction in occupancy costs.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S4	In addition to the one-time savings from the reversal of accrued rent we benefit from reduced operating costs on this building as the owner rather than a renter.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S5	Occupancy costs also benefited from a milder winter resulting in reduced utility and snow removal costs.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S6	Equipment costs benefited from a $153 thousand reduction in depreciation expense.

1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S10	During 2009 we experienced a significant decline in the value of many of our OREO properties requiring a $4.8 million loss provision; however, this decline in value slowed significantly in 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S11	During 2010 our provision for OREO losses declined by $4.4 million to $356 thousand.
