1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S15	OREO carrying expenses increased by $203 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P52_S16	Insurance expense was abnormally low in 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	During the first quarter of 2009 our Chief Information and Technology officer retired from the Company.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	Because his retirement took place prior to the age of sixty-five he forfeited his benefits under his company provided split dollar life insurance plan.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P53_S2	To reflect this forfeiture we recorded a one-time reduction in insurance expense totaling $83 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $295 thousand, or 23.9% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	During 2010 the Company recorded an income tax provision of $389 thousand, or 28.6% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P54_S2	The percentages for 2011 and 2010 differ from the statutory rate as tax exempt income such as earnings on Bank owned life insurance, municipal loan interest, and in the state of California enterprise zone interest decrease taxable income.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P56_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is more likely than not that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P56_S2	More likely than not is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P56_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	As part of its analysis, the Company considered the following positive evidence:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company s 2009 net loss was also attributable to significant write-downs on foreclosed construction and land development real estate properties which represented the majority of its provision for losses on other real estate during 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	During 2010 other real estate write-downs decreased by $4.4 million from $4.8 million during the year ended December 31, 2009 to $356 thousand during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P58_S2	Write-downs on construction and land development real estate owned during 2011 totaled $440 thousand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company has a long history of earnings and profitability.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company was profitable in 2011 and 2010 and is projecting future taxable and book income will be generated by operations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	The size of loans in the Company s pipeline of potential problem loans has significantly decreased.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company does not have a history of net operating losses carry forwards or tax credits expiring unused.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	As part of its analysis, the Company also considered the following negative evidence:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company recorded a large net loss in 2009 and is in a cumulative loss position for the current and preceding two years.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	Based upon the analysis of available evidence, management has determined that it is more likely than not that all deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company continues to manage the mix of its loan portfolio consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financing needs of all sectors of the area it serves.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	Although the Company offers a broad array of financing options, it continues to concentrate its focus on small to medium sized commercial businesses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S2	These commercial loans offer diversification as to industries and types of businesses, thus limiting material exposure in any industry concentrations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S3	The Company offers both fixed and floating rate loans and obtains collateral in the form of real property, business assets and deposit accounts, but looks to business and personal cash flows as its primary source of repayment.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S4	The Company s largest lending categories are commercial real estate loans, residential real estate loans, and agricultural loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S5	These categories accounted for approximately 40.6%, 13.3% and 13.2%, respectively of the Company s total loan portfolio at December 31, 2011, and approximately 37.9%, 13.8% and 12.2%, respectively of the Company s total loan portfolio at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S6	Construction and land development loans continue to decline and represented 5.8% and 9.9% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S7	The construction and land development portfolio component has been identified by Management as a higher-risk loan category.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P64_S8	The quality of the construction and land development category is highly dependent on property values both in terms of the likelihood of repayment once the property is transacted by the current owner as well as the level of collateral the Company has securing the loan in the event of default.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	Loans in this category are characterized by the speculative nature of commercial and residential development properties and can include property in various stages of development from raw land to finished lots.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	The decline in these loans as a percentage of the Company s loan portfolio reflects management s continued efforts, which began in 2009, to reduce its exposure to construction and land development loans due to the severe valuation decrease in the real estate market.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	The Company s real estate related loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate comprised 81% and 80% of the total loan portfolio at December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S3	Moreover, the business activities of the Company currently are focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta, Sierra and in Washoe County in Northern Nevada.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S4	Consequently, the results of operations and financial condition of the Company are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P65_S5	In addition, the concentration of the Company s operations in these areas of Northeastern California and Northwestern Nevada exposes it to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	The rates of interest charged on variable rate loans are set at specific increments in relation to the Company s lending rate or other indexes such as the published prime interest rate or U.S. Treasury rates and vary with changes in these indexes.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	At December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, approximately 73% and 66%, respectively, of the Company s loan portfolio was comprised of variable rate loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	While real estate mortgage, commercial and consumer lending remain the foundation of the Company s historical loan mix, some changes in the mix have occurred due to the changing economic environment and the resulting change in demand for certain loan types.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	In addition, the Company remains committed to the agricultural industry in Northeastern California and will continue to pursue high quality agricultural loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	Agricultural loans include both commercial and commercial real estate loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P67_S3	The Company s agricultural loan balances totaled $39 million at December 31, 2011 and $38 million at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P67_S4	The following table sets forth the amounts of loans outstanding by category as of the dates indicated.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	(2) Includes agriculture real estate The following table sets forth the maturity of gross loan categories as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	Also provided with respect to such loans are the amounts due after one year, classified according to sensitivity to changes in interest rates: Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	The Company attempts to minimize credit risk through its underwriting and credit review policies.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S1	The Company s credit review process includes internally prepared credit reviews as well as contracting with an outside firm to conduct periodic credit reviews.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S2	The Company s management and lending officers evaluate the loss exposure of classified and impaired loans on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S3	The Management Asset Resolution Committee (MARC) reviews the asset quality of criticized loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S4	The Board s Loan Committee reviews the asset quality of new loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P69_S5	In management s opinion, this loan review system helps facilitate the early identification of potential criticized loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	The Company has implemented MARC to develop an action plan to significantly reduce nonperforming loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	It consists of members of executive management and credit administration management, and the activities are governed by a formal written charter.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	The MARC meets at least monthly and reports to the Board of Directors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S2	More specifically, a formal plan to effect repayment and/or disposition of every significant nonperforming loan relationship is developed and documented for review and on-going oversight by the MARC.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S3	Some of the strategies used include but are not limited to: 1) obtaining additional collateral, 2) obtaining additional investor cash infusion, 3) sale of the promissory note to an outside party, 4) proceeding with foreclosure on the underlying collateral, 5) legal action against borrower/guarantors to encourage settlement of debt and/or collect any deficiency balance owed.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S4	Each step includes a benchmark timeline to track progress.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P71_S5	MARC also provides guidance for the maintenance and timely disposition of OREO properties; including developing financing and marketing programs to incent individuals to purchase OREO.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	The allowance for loan losses is established through charges to earnings in the form of the provision for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	Loan losses are charged to and recoveries are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level deemed appropriate by management to provide for known and inherent risks in loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P72_S3	The adequacy of the allowance for loan losses is based upon management s continuing assessment of various factors affecting the collectibility of loans; including current economic conditions, maturity of the portfolio, size of the portfolio, industry concentrations, borrower credit history, collateral, the existing allowance for loan losses, independent credit reviews, current charges and recoveries to the allowance for loan losses and the overall quality of the portfolio as determined by management, regulatory agencies, and independent credit review consultants retained by the Company.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	There is no precise method of predicting specific losses or amounts which may ultimately be charged off on particular segments of the loan portfolio.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	The collectibility of a loan is subjective to some degree, but must relate to the borrower s financial condition, cash flow, quality of the borrower s management expertise, collateral and guarantees, and state of the local economy.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	The federal financial regulatory agencies in December 2006 issued a new interagency policy statement on the allowance for loan and lease losses along with supplemental frequently asked questions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P75_S1	When determining the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, the Company follows these guidelines.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	The policy statement revises and replaces a 1993 policy statement on the allowance for loan and lease losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	The agencies issued the revised policy statement in view of today s uncertain economic environment and the presence of concentrations in untested loan products in the loan portfolios of insured depository institutions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	The policy statement was also revised to conform with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ) and post-1993 supervisory guidance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S3	The policy statement reiterates that each institution has a responsibility for developing, maintaining and documenting a comprehensive, systematic, and consistently applied process appropriate to its size and the nature, scope, and risk of its lending activities for determining the amounts of the allowance for loan and lease losses and the provision for loan and lease losses and states that each institution should ensure controls are in place to consistently determine the allowance for loan and lease losses in accordance with GAAP, the institution s stated policies and procedures, management s best judgment and relevant supervisory guidance.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S4	The policy statement also restates that insured depository institutions must maintain an allowance for loan and lease losses at a level that is appropriate to cover estimated credit losses on individually evaluated loans determined to be impaired as well as estimated credit losses inherent in the remainder of the loan and lease portfolio, and that estimates of credit losses should reflect consideration of all significant factors that affect the collectibility of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P76_S5	The policy statement states that prudent, conservative, but not excessive, loan loss allowances that represent management s best estimate from within an acceptable range of estimated losses are appropriate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	No. 102, which represents the SEC staff s view related to methodologies and supporting documentation for the Allowance for Loan and Lease Losses that should be observed by all public companies in complying with the federal securities laws and the Commission s interpretations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	The Company s methodology for assessing the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses consists of several key elements, which include but are not limited to:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	specific allocation determined in accordance with ASC Topic 310 Receivables, based on probable losses on specific loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	general reserves determined in accordance with guidance in ASC Topic 450 Contingencies, based on historical loan loss experience adjusted for other qualitative risk factors both internal and external to the Company.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P80_S1	Specific allocations are established based on management s periodic evaluation of loss exposure inherent in classified, impaired, and other loans in which management believes that the collection of principal and interest under the original contractual terms of the loan agreement are in question.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P80_S2	For purposes of this analysis, loans are grouped by internal risk classifications which are watch , substandard , doubtful , and loss .
1168455_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	Watch loans are currently performing but are potentially weak, as the borrower has begun to exhibit deteriorating trends, which if not corrected, could jeopardize repayment of the loan and result in further downgrade.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	Substandard loans have well-defined weaknesses which, if not corrected, could jeopardize the full satisfaction of the debt.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P81_S2	A loan classified as doubtful has critical weaknesses that make full collection of the obligation improbable.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	Classified loans, as defined by the Company, include loans categorized as substandard and doubtful.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P82_S1	Loans classified as loss are immediately charged off.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P82_S2	Loans are consistently monitored against risk rating criteria.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P82_S3	As loans are identified that may warrant a classification change, they are discussed with the Company s credit administration officers and appropriate risk grades are assigned.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P82_S4	There are several times in the life of a loan that this occurs:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	If weaknesses (or improvements) are noted, a change in risk rating, if warranted by credit administration, will be made.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P83_S1	Loans classified Watch or below in an amount of $100,000 or more will be individually evaluated for impairment in accordance with the Bank s policy for determining and measuring impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	Formula allocations are calculated by applying loss factors to outstanding loans with similar characteristics.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P84_S1	Loss factors are based on the Company s historical loss experience as adjusted for changes in the business cycle and may be adjusted for significant factors that, in management s judgment, affect the collectibility of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	Effective for the third quarter of 2010, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for loans collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P85_S1	This modification incorporated historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter to identified pools of loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P85_S2	This modification did not have a material affect on the Company s allowance for loans losses or provision for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P85_S3	No modifications to the allowance for loan losses methodology were made in 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	The discretionary allocation is based upon management s evaluation of various loan segment conditions that are not directly measured in the determination of the formula and specific allowances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	The conditions may include, but are not limited to, general economic and business conditions affecting the key lending areas of the Company, credit quality trends, collateral values, loan volumes and concentrations, and other business conditions.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	The following table provides certain information for the years indicated with respect to the Company s allowance for loan losses as well as charge-off and recovery activity.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2011 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $3.5 million down $2.0 million from the $5.5 million provision recorded during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S2	Net charge-offs totaled $3.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2011 and $7.7 million during 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S3	Net charge-offs as a percentage of average loans decreased from 2.39% during 2010 to 1.29% during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S4	The following table provides a breakdown of the allowance for loan losses: The allowance for loan losses totaled $6.9 million at December 31, 2011 and $7.3 million at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S5	Specific reserves related to impaired loans increased from $1.9 million at December 31, 2010 to $2.1 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S6	At least quarterly the Company evaluates each specific reserve and if it determines that the loss represented by the specific reserve is uncollectable it reverses the specific reserve and takes a partial charge-off in its place.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S7	General reserves decreased by $579 thousand to $4.8 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S8	The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans increased slightly from 2.33% at December 31, 2010 to 2.35% at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P87_S9	The percentage of general reserves to unimpaired loans decreased from 1.90% at December 31, 2010 to 1.80% at December 31, 2011 primarily related to a decrease in charge-offs during the eight quarters ending December 31, 2011 as compared to the eight quarters ended December 31, 2010 which resulted in a lower loss rate applied to unimpaired loans.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company places loans 90 days or more past due on nonaccrual status unless the loan is well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P88_S1	A loan is considered to be in the process of collection if, based on a probable specific event, it is expected that the loan will be repaid or brought current.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P88_S2	Generally, this collection period would not exceed 90 days.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status the Company s general policy is to reverse and charge against current income previously accrued but unpaid interest.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	Interest income on such loans is subsequently recognized only to the extent that cash is received and future collection of principal is deemed by management to be probable.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P89_S2	Where the collectibility of the principal or interest on a loan is considered to be doubtful by management, it is placed on nonaccrual status prior to becoming 90 days delinquent.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P89_S3	Impaired loans are measured based on the present value of the expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P89_S4	The amount of impaired loans is not directly comparable to the amount of nonperforming loans disclosed later in this section.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	The primary difference between impaired loans and nonperforming loans is that impaired loan recognition considers not only loans 90 days or more past due, restructured loans and nonaccrual loans but also may include identified problem loans other than delinquent loans where it is considered probable that we will not collect all amounts due to us (including both principal and interest) in accordance with the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	Loans restructured and in compliance with modified terms totaled $8.4 million, $2.0 million and $3.4 million at December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P93_S2	There were no troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2008, or 2007.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P93_S3	For additional information related to restructured loans see Note 6 of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	The following table sets forth the amount of the Company s nonperforming assets as of the dates indicated.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	Nonperforming loans at December 31, 2011 were $16.8 million, a decrease of $8.5 million from the $25.3 million balance at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	The decline of $8.5 million includes $5.7 million in loans transferred to OREO, a $4.4 million loan that was returned to performing status and charge-offs and principal repayments on nonperforming loans partially offset by $9.1 million in additional loans placed on nonperforming status during the period.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P95_S2	Specific reserves on nonaccrual loans totaled $1.3 million at December 31, 2011 and $1.8 million at December 31, 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P95_S3	Performing loans past due thirty to eighty-nine days increased from $2.9 million at December 31, 2010 to $5.1 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S0	A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S1	Total substandard loans decreased by $9.4 million from $38.6 million at December 31, 2010 to $29.2 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S2	Loans classified as watch decreased as well from $14.2 million at December 31, 2010 to $10.7 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S3	At December 31, 2011, $13.9 million of performing loans were classified as substandard.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S4	Further deterioration in the credit quality of individual performing substandard loans or other adverse circumstances could result in the need to place these loans on nonperforming status.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S5	At December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, the Company s recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $24.4 million and $28.8 million, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S6	The specific allowance for loan losses related to impaired loans totaled $2.1 million and $1.9 million at December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P96_S7	Additionally, $940 thousand has been charged off against the impaired loans at December 31, 2011 and $2.8 million at December 31 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P97_S0	It is the policy of management to make additions to the allowance for loan losses so that it remains appropriate to absorb the inherent risk of loss in the portfolio.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P97_S1	Management believes that the allowance at December 31, 2011 is appropriate.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P97_S2	However, the determination of the amount of the allowance is judgmental and subject to economic conditions which cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P97_S3	Accordingly, the Company cannot predict whether charge-offs of loans in excess of the allowance may occur in future periods.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	OREO represents real property taken by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	Repossessed assets include vehicles and other commercial assets acquired under agreements with delinquent borrowers.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S2	Repossessed assets and OREO are carried at fair market value, less selling costs.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S3	OREO holdings represented forty-four properties totaling $8.6 million at December 31, 2011 and thirty-one properties totaling $8.9 million at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S4	During June, 2011 the Bank sold its largest OREO holding which represented $4.3 million, or 48% of the total balance in OREO at January 1, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S5	The Bank incurred a $617 thousand loss on sale; however, management believes the loss was prudent given the significant affect this transaction had in decreasing nonperforming assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S6	Nonperforming assets as a percentage of total assets were 5.60% at December 31, 2011 and 7.07% at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S7	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010: Investment Portfolio and Federal Funds Sold.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P98_S8	Total investment securities decreased by $5.1 million from $63.0 million at December 31, 2010 to $57.9 million as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	While investment securities decreased from December 31, 2010 levels, we anticipate adding to investment securities during the next three months.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P99_S1	The investment portfolio at December 31, 2011 was invested entirely in U.S. Government-sponsored agencies, at December 31, 2010 the investment portfolio consisted of 2% U.S. Treasuries and 98% U.S. Government-sponsored agencies.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P99_S2	There were no Federal funds sold at December 31, 2011 or 2010; however, the Bank maintained interest earning balances at the Federal Reserve Bank (FRB) totaling $47.8 million at December 31, 2011 and $52.3 million at December 31, 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P99_S3	These balances currently earn 25 basis points.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P100_S0	The Company classifies its investment securities as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P100_S1	Currently all securities are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P100_S2	Securities classified as available-for-sale may be sold to implement the Company s asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	The following tables summarize the values of the Company s investment securities held on the dates indicated: At December 31, 2009 the Company transferred all of its municipal securities from held-to-maturity to available-for-sale as it was determined that management no longer had the intent to hold these investments to maturity.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S1	The following table summarizes the maturities of the Company s securities at their carrying value and their weighted average tax equivalent yields at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S2	Total deposits were $391.1 million as of December 31, 2011, a decrease of $33.8 million, or 8%, from the December 31, 2010 balance of $424.9 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S3	The decline in deposits was mostly related to maturities from a higher rate promotional time deposit product we began offering in June, 2009 and continued to offer until April 30, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S4	Core deposit growth was strong with increases in non-interest bearing deposits of $14.1 million and an increase in savings accounts of $10.8 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S5	The Company continues to manage the mix of its deposits consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financial needs of its customers.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S6	The deposit mix changed slightly from December 31, 2010 as time deposits deceased and we had an increase in non-interest bearing demand deposits and savings accounts.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S7	Non-interest bearing demand deposits were 32% of total deposits at December 31, 2011 and 26% of total deposits at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S8	Interest bearing transaction accounts were 21% of total deposits at December 31, 2011 and 24% of total deposits at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S9	Money market and savings deposits totaled 26% of total deposits at December 31, 2011 and 22% at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S10	Time deposits were 21% of total deposits at December 31, 2011 and 28% of total deposits at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S11	Deposits represent the Bank s primary source of funds.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S12	Deposits are primarily core deposits in that they are demand, savings and time deposits generated from local businesses and individuals.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P101_S13	These sources are considered to be relatively stable, long-term relationships thereby enhancing steady growth of the deposit base without major fluctuations in overall deposit balances.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	The Company experiences, to a small degree, some seasonality with the slower growth period between November through April, and the higher growth period from May through October.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P102_S1	In order to assist in meeting any funding demands, the Company maintains a secured borrowing arrangement with the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P102_S2	Included in time deposits at December 31, 2010 were $2.0 million in CDARS reciprocal time deposits which, under regulatory guidelines, are classified as brokered deposits.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P102_S3	There were no brokered deposits at December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	The Company s time deposits of $100,000 or more had the following schedule of maturities at December 31, 2011:
1168455_12_ITEM7_P103_S1	Time deposits of $100,000 or more are generally from the Company s local business and individual customer base.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P103_S2	The potential impact on the Company s liquidity from the withdrawal of these deposits is discussed at the Company s asset and liability management committee meetings, and is considered to be minimal.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $86,388,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $178,987,000.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S2	At December 31, 2011, the Company held $2,043,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S3	At this level of stock holdings the Company can borrow up to $43,466,000.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S4	There were no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P104_S5	To borrow the $86,388,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,017,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P105_S0	Recently Plumas Bank introduced a new product for its larger business customers which use repurchase agreements as an alternative to interest-bearing deposits.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P105_S1	The balance in this product at December 31, 2011 was $8.3 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P105_S2	Interest paid on this product is similar to that which can be earned on the Bank s premium money market account; however, these are not deposits and are not FDIC insured.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P106_S0	Capital Resources Shareholders equity as of December 31, 2011 totaled $39.6 million up from $38.0 million as of December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P107_S0	On January 30, 2009, under the Capital Purchase Program, the Company sold (i) 11,949 shares of the Company s Fixed Rate Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A (the Preferred Shares ) and (ii) a ten-year warrant to purchase up to 237,712 shares of the Company s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $7.54 per share, for an aggregate purchase price of $11,949,000 in cash.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P107_S1	Ten million of the twelve million in proceeds from the sale of the Series A Preferred Stock was injected into Plumas Bank providing addition capital for the bank to support growth in loans and investment securities and strengthen its capital ratios.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P107_S2	The remainder provided funds for holding company activities and general corporate purposes.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P107_S3	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P107_S4	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P108_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_12_ITEM7_P108_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P109_S0	Banking regulations limit the amount of dividends that may be paid without prior approval of regulatory agencies.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P109_S1	No common cash dividends were paid in 2009, 2010 or 2011 and none are anticipated to be paid in 2012.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P110_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P110_S1	At the request of the FRB, Plumas Bancorp deferred its regularly scheduled quarterly interest payments on its outstanding junior subordinated debentures relating to its two trust preferred securities and suspended quarterly cash dividend payments on its Series A Preferred Stock.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P110_S2	Therefore, Plumas Bancorp is currently in arrears with the dividend payments on the Series A Preferred Stock and interest payments on the junior subordinated debentures as permitted by the related documentation.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P110_S3	As of December 31, 2011 the amount of the arrearage on the dividend payments of the Series A Preferred Stock is $1,046 thousand representing seven quarterly payments and the amount of the arrearage on the payments on the subordinated debt associated with the trust preferred securities is $569 thousand also representing seven quarterly payments.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P111_S0	The Company uses a variety of measures to evaluate its capital adequacy, with risk-based capital ratios calculated separately for the Company and the Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P111_S1	Management reviews these capital measurements on a monthly basis and takes appropriate action to ensure that they are within established internal and external guidelines.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P112_S0	The FDIC has promulgated risk-based capital guidelines for all state non-member banks such as the Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P112_S1	These guidelines establish a risk-adjusted ratio relating capital to different categories of assets and off-balance sheet exposures.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P112_S2	There are two categories of capital under the guidelines: Tier 1 capital includes common stockholders equity, and qualifying trust-preferred securities (including notes payable to unconsolidated special purpose entities that issue trust-preferred securities), less goodwill and certain other deductions, notably the unrealized net gains or losses (after tax adjustments) on available-for-sale investment securities carried at fair market value; Tier 2 capital can include qualifying subordinated debt and the allowance for loan losses, subject to certain limitations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P112_S3	The Series A Preferred Stock qualifies as Tier 1 capital for the Company.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P113_S0	As noted previously, the Company s junior subordinated debentures represent borrowings from its unconsolidated subsidiaries that have issued an aggregate $10 million in trust-preferred securities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P113_S1	These trust-preferred securities currently qualify for inclusion as Tier 1 capital for regulatory purposes as they do not exceed 25% of total Tier 1 capital, but are classified as long-term debt in accordance with GAAP.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P114_S0	On March 1, 2005, the Federal Reserve Board adopted a final rule that allows the continued inclusion of trust-preferred securities (and/or related subordinated debentures) in the Tier I capital of bank holding companies.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P115_S0	The following tables present the capital ratios for the Company and the Bank compared to the standards for bank holding companies and the regulatory minimum requirements for depository institutions as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 (amounts in thousands except percentage amounts).
1168455_12_ITEM7_P116_S0	Management believes that the Company and the Bank currently meet their entire capital adequacy requirements including a minimum 9% Tier 1 Leverage Ratio required under the Bank s informal agreement with the FDIC and DFI.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P116_S1	The current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P116_S2	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized leverage, Tier 1 risk-based and total risk-based capital ratios of 5%, 6% and 10%, respectively, at all times.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P117_S0	In the normal course of business, there are various commitments outstanding to extend credits that are not reflected in the financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S1	Annual review of commercial credit lines, letters of credit and ongoing monitoring of outstanding balances reduces the risk of loss associated with these commitments.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S2	As of December 31, 2011, the Company had $79.2 million in unfunded loan commitments and $50 thousand in letters of credit.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S3	This compares to $71.6 million in unfunded loan commitments and $164 thousand in letters of credit at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S4	Of the $79.2 million in unfunded loan commitments, $35.1 million and $44.1 million represented commitments to commercial and consumer customers, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S5	Of the total unfunded commitments at December 31, 2011, $36.1 million were secured by real estate, of which $8.8 million was secured by commercial real estate and $27.3 million was secured by residential real estate in the form of equity lines of credit.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S6	The commercial loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent business lines of credit, while the consumer loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent revolving credit card lines.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P118_S7	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S0	The Company leases one depository branch, one lending office and one loan administration office and two non branch automated teller machine locations.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S1	Total rental expenses under all operating leases, including premises, totaled $150,000 and $20,000, during the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S2	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2012 and the last such lease expiring during 2015.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S3	The reduced level of rental expense during 2010 resulted from the purchase of our Redding branch building on March 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S4	Previously we had leased this building.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S5	Under the terms of the lease agreement we were provided free rent for a period of time; however, in accordance with applicable accounting standards we recognized monthly rent expense equal to the total payments required under the lease dividend by the term of the lease in months.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P119_S6	At the time of the purchase we reversed this accrual recognizing a $184 thousand reduction in rental expense.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P120_S0	The Company manages its liquidity to provide the ability to generate funds to support asset growth, meet deposit withdrawals (both anticipated and unanticipated), fund customers borrowing needs, satisfy maturity of short-term borrowings and maintain reserve requirements.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P120_S1	The Company s liquidity needs are managed using assets or liabilities, or both.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P120_S2	On the asset side, in addition to cash and due from banks, the Company maintains an investment portfolio which includes unpledged U.S. Government-sponsored agency securities that are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P120_S3	On the liability side, liquidity needs are managed by charging competitive offering rates on deposit products and the use of established lines of credit.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $86,388,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $178,987,000.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S2	At December 31, 2011, the Company held $2,043,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S3	At this level of stock holdings the Company can borrow up to $43,466,000.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S4	There were no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P121_S5	To borrow the $86,388,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,017,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P122_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P122_S1	Total deposits were $391.1 million as of December 31, 2011, a decrease of $33.8 million, or 8%, from the December 31, 2010 balance of $424.9 million.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P123_S0	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P123_S1	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P123_S2	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_12_ITEM7_P123_S3	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.

1168455_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	As of the end of the period covered by this report, we conducted an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on this evaluation, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in Securities and Exchange Commission rules and forms.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P0_S2	There was no change in our internal control over financial reporting during our most recently completed fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	REPORT OF MANAGEMENT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING The management of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the Company ), is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Management, including the undersigned Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting presented in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S2	In conducting its assessment, management used the criteria established by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control Integrated Framework.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Based on this assessment, management concluded that, as of December 31, 2011, our internal control over financial reporting was effective based on those criteria.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S4	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s independent registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_12_ITEM9A_P1_S5	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s independent registered public accounting firm pursuant to the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.
