1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Shareholders Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary Quincy, California We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2011, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in shareholders equity and cash flows for the year then ended.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audit.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S5	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S6	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P17_S7	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P18_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P18_S1	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P18_S2	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2011, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the year then ended in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P19_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Shareholders Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary Quincy, California We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2010 and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in shareholders equity and cash flows for each of the years in the two year period ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P19_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P19_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P19_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P19_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P20_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P20_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P21_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P22_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P23_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P24_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P25_S0	THE BUSINESS OF PLUMAS BANCORP During 2002, Plumas Bancorp (the Company ) was incorporated as a bank holding company for the purpose of acquiring Plumas Bank (the Bank ) in a one bank holding company reorganization.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P25_S1	This corporate structure gives the Company and the Bank greater flexibility in terms of operation expansion and diversification.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P26_S0	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust I ( Trust I ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 26, 2002.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust II ( Trust II ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 28, 2005.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P27_S0	The Bank operates eleven branches in California, including branches in Alturas, Chester, Fall River Mills, Greenville, Kings Beach, Portola, Quincy, Redding, Susanville, Tahoe City, and Truckee.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P27_S1	The Bank s administrative headquarters is in Quincy, California.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P27_S2	In addition, the Bank operates a loan administrative office in Reno, Nevada and a lending office specializing in government-guaranteed lending in Auburn, California.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P28_S0	The Bank s primary source of revenue is generated from providing loans to customers who are predominately small and middle market businesses and individuals residing in the surrounding areas.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P29_S0	On July 21, 2010, President Barack Obama signed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ), which, in part, permanently raised the current standard maximum deposit insurance amount to $250,000.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P29_S1	Amendments related to the enactment of the Dodd-Frank Act provide full deposit insurance coverage for noninterest bearing deposit transaction accounts beginning December 31, 2010 for a two year period.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P30_S0	REGULATORY MATTERS On February 15, 2012, the Bank received notice from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the California Department of Financial Institutions ( DFI ) that the Consent Order with the FDIC and the DFI which was effective on March 16, 2011 had been terminated.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P30_S1	While the Bank is no longer subject to an Order, the Bank has entered into an informal agreement with the FDIC and DFI which, among other things, requests that the Bank continue to maintain a Tier 1 Leverage Capital Ratio of 9% which is in excess of that required for well capitalized institutions and continue to reduce its level of classified asset balances that were outstanding as of September 30, 2011 to not more than 50% of Tier 1 Capital plus the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P30_S2	At December 31, 2011 this ratio was 68%.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P31_S0	On July 28, 2011 the Company entered into an agreement with the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco (the FRB Agreement ).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P31_S1	Under the terms of the FRB Agreement, Plumas Bancorp has agreed to take certain actions that are designed to maintain its financial soundness so that it may continue to serve as a source of strength to the Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P31_S2	Among other things, the FRB Agreement requires prior written approval related to the payment or taking of dividends and distributions, making any distributions of interest, principal or other sums on subordinated debentures or trust preferred securities, incurrence of debt, and the purchase or redemption of stock.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P31_S3	In addition, the FRB Agreement requires Plumas Bancorp to submit, within 60 days of the FRB Agreement, a written statement of Plumas Bancorp s planned sources and uses of cash for debt service, operating expense and other purposes ( Cash Flow Statement ) for the remainder of 2011 and annually thereafter.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P31_S4	The Company submitted the Cash Flow Statements within the required time frames.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P32_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the consolidated accounts of its wholly-owned subsidiary, Plumas Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P32_S1	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P32_S2	Plumas Statutory Trust I and Trust II are not consolidated into the Company s consolidated financial statements and, accordingly, are accounted for under the equity method.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P32_S3	The Company s investment in Trust I of $283,000 and Trust II of $154,000 are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P32_S4	The junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures issued and guaranteed by the Company and held by Trust I and Trust II are reflected as debt on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P33_S0	The accounting and reporting policies of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary conform with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America and prevailing practices within the banking industry.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P33_S1	Certain reclassifications have been made to prior years balances to conform to the classifications used in 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P34_S0	Segment Information Management has determined that since all of the banking products and services offered by the Company are available in each branch of the Bank, all branches are located within the same economic environment and management does not allocate resources based on the performance of different lending or transaction activities, it is appropriate to aggregate the Bank branches and report them as a single operating segment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P35_S0	No customer accounts for more than 10 percent of revenues for the Company or the Bank.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P36_S0	Use of Estimates To prepare financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America management makes estimates and assumptions based on available information.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P36_S1	These estimates and assumptions affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and the disclosures provided, and actual results could differ.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P36_S2	The allowance for loan losses, loan servicing rights, deferred tax assets, and fair values of financial instruments are particularly subject to change.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P37_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, cash and due from banks and Federal funds sold are considered to be cash equivalents.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P37_S1	Generally, Federal funds are sold for one day periods.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P37_S2	As of December 31, 2011 all cash held with other federally insured institutions was fully insured by the FDIC.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P37_S3	Net cash flows are reported for customer loans and deposit transactions and repurchase agreements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P37_S4	Investment Securities Investments are classified into one of the following categories:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P38_S0	Available-for-sale securities reported at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported, net of taxes, as accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) within shareholders equity.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S0	Held-to-maturity securities, which management has the positive intent and ability to hold, reported at amortized cost, adjusted for the accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S1	Management determines the appropriate classification of its investments at the time of purchase and may only change the classification in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S2	During 2009, management determined they no longer had the positive intent to hold their held-to-maturity securities and transferred their held-to-maturity securities to available- for-sale (see note 5).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S3	This transfer increased the Company s flexibility in managing its investment portfolio allowing the investments to be sold in implementing its asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S4	All transfers between categories are accounted for at fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P39_S5	There were no transfers between categories during 2011 or 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P40_S0	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as trading and gains or losses on the sale of securities are computed on the specific identification method.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P40_S1	Interest earned on investment securities is reported in interest income, net of applicable adjustments for accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums accounted for by the level yield method with no pre-payment anticipated.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S0	An investment security is impaired when its carrying value is greater than its fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S1	Investment securities that are impaired are evaluated on at least a quarterly basis and more frequently when economic or market conditions warrant such an evaluation to determine whether such a decline in their fair value is other than temporary.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S2	Management utilizes criteria such as the magnitude and duration of the decline and the intent and ability of the Company to retain its investment in the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery in fair value, in addition to the reasons underlying the decline, to determine whether the loss in value is other than temporary.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S3	The term other than temporary is not intended to indicate that the decline is permanent, but indicates that the prospects for a near-term recovery of value is not necessarily favorable, or that there is a lack of evidence to support a realizable value equal to or greater than the carrying value of the investment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S4	Once a decline in value is determined to be other than temporary, and management does not intend to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery, only the portion of the impairment loss representing credit exposure is recognized as a charge to earnings, with the balance recognized as a charge to other comprehensive income.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P41_S5	If management intends to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the security before recovering its forecasted cost, the entire impairment loss is recognized as a charge to earnings.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P42_S0	Investment in Federal Home Loan Bank Stock As a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) System, the Bank is required to maintain an investment in the capital stock of the FHLB.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P42_S1	The investment is carried at cost classified as a restricted security, and periodically evaluated for impairment based on ultimate recovery of par value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P42_S2	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, FHLB stock totaled $2,043,000 and $2,188,000, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P42_S3	On the consolidated balance sheet, FHLB stock is included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P43_S0	Loans Held for Sale, Loan Sales and Servicing Included in the loan portfolio are loans which are 75% to 85% guaranteed by the Small Business Administration (SBA), US Department of Agriculture Rural Business Cooperative Service (RBS) and Farm Services Agency (FSA).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P43_S1	The guaranteed portion of these loans may be sold to a third party, with the Bank retaining the unguaranteed portion.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P43_S2	The Company can receive a premium in excess of the adjusted carrying value of the loan at the time of sale.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P43_S3	At December 31, 2010, we recorded the proceeds from the sale of the guaranteed portions of SBA loans that were subject to a premium refund obligation, which totaled $4,284,000, were recorded as a secured borrowing and such secured borrowings were included in other liabilities on the balance sheet.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P43_S4	Once the premium refund obligation elapsed the transaction was recorded as a sale with the guaranteed portions of loans and the secured borrowing removed from the balance sheet and the resulting gain on sale recorded.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P44_S0	Included in commercial loans at December 31, 2010 is $4,284,000 in guaranteed portions of SBA loans sold subject to a 90-day premium refund obligation.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P44_S1	In February 2011, the SBA eliminated the refund obligation period and the Company is no longer required to defer gain recognition.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P45_S0	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010 the Company had $3,091,000 and $5,208,000, respectively in government guaranteed loans held for sale.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P45_S1	Loans held for sale are recorded at the lower of cost or fair vale and therefore may be reported at fair value on a non-recurring basis.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P45_S2	The fair values for loans held for sale are based on either observable transactions of similar instruments or formally committed loan sale prices.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P46_S0	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES (Continued) Loans Held for Sale, Loan Sales and Servicing (continued) Government guaranteed loans with unpaid balances of $47,708,000 and $33,686,000 were being serviced for others at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P46_S1	The Company also services loans previously sold to the Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA) totaling $1,932,000 and $2,185,000 as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S0	The Company accounts for the transfer and servicing of financial assets based on the fair value of financial and servicing assets it controls and liabilities it has assumed, derecognizes financial assets when control has been surrendered, and derecognizes liabilities when extinguished.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S1	Servicing rights acquired through 1) a purchase or 2) the origination of loans which are sold or securitized with servicing rights retained are recognized as separate assets or liabilities.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S2	Servicing assets or liabilities are recorded at fair value and are subsequently amortized in proportion to and over the period of the related net servicing income or expense.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S3	Servicing rights are evaluated for impairment based upon the fair value of the rights as compared to carrying amount.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S4	Impairment is determined by stratifying rights into groupings based on predominant risk characteristics, such as interest rate, loan type and investor type.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S5	Impairment is recognized through a valuation allowance for an individual grouping, to the extent that fair value is less than the carrying amount.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S6	If the Company later determines that all or a portion of the impairment no longer exists for a particular grouping, a reduction of the allowance may be recorded as an increase to income.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S7	Changes in valuation allowances are reported with non-interest income on the statement of operations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P47_S8	The fair values of servicing rights are subject to significant fluctuations as a result of changes in estimated and actual prepayment speeds and default rates and losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S0	The Company s investment in the loan is allocated between the retained portion of the loan, the servicing asset, the interest-only (IO) strip, and the sold portion of the loan based on their fair values on the date the loan is sold.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S1	The gain on the sold portion of the loan is recognized as income at the time of sale.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S2	The carrying value of the retained portion of the loan is discounted based on the estimated value of a comparable non-guaranteed loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S3	The servicing asset is recognized and amortized over the estimated life of the related loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S4	Assets (accounted for as IO strips) are recorded at the fair value of the difference between note rates and rates paid to purchasers (the interest spread) and contractual servicing fees, if applicable.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S5	IO strips are carried at fair value with gains or losses recorded as a component of shareholders equity, similar to available-for-sale investment securities.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P48_S6	Significant future prepayments of these loans will result in the recognition of additional amortization of related servicing assets and an adjustment to the carrying value of related IO strips.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P49_S0	Loans Loans that management has the intent and ability to hold for foreseeable future or until maturity or payoff are reported at the principal balance outstanding, net of purchase premiums or discounts, deferred loan fees and costs, and an allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P49_S1	Loans, if any, that are transferred from loans held for sale are carried at the lower of principal balance or market value at the date of transfer, adjusted for accretion of discounts.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P49_S2	Interest is accrued daily based upon outstanding loan balances.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P49_S3	However, when, in the opinion of management, loans are considered to be impaired and the future collectibility of interest and principal is in serious doubt, loans are placed on nonaccrual status and the accrual of interest income is suspended.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P50_S0	Any interest accrued but unpaid is charged against income.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P50_S1	Payments received are applied to reduce principal to the extent necessary to ensure collection.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P51_S0	A loan is moved to non-accrual status in accordance with the Company s policy, typically after 90 days of non-payment unless well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P51_S1	Subsequent payments on these loans, or payments received on nonaccrual loans for which the ultimate collectibility of principal is not in doubt, are applied first to earned but unpaid interest and then to principal.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P52_S0	Loan origination fees, commitment fees, direct loan origination costs and purchased premiums and discounts on loans are deferred and recognized as an adjustment of yield, to be amortized to interest income over the contractual term of the loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P52_S1	The unamortized balance of deferred fees and costs is reported as a component of net loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S0	The Company may acquire loans through a business combination or a purchase for which differences may exist between the contractual cash flows and the cash flows expected to be collected due, at least in part, to credit quality.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S1	When the Company acquires such loans, the yield that may be accreted (accretable yield) is limited to the excess of the Company s estimate of undiscounted cash flows expected to be collected over the Company s initial investment in the loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S2	The excess of contractual cash flows over cash flows expected to be collected may not be recognized as an adjustment to yield, loss, or a valuation allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S3	Subsequent increases in cash flows expected to be collected generally should be recognized prospectively through adjustment of the loan s yield over its remaining life.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S4	Decreases in cash flows expected to be collected should be recognized as an impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S5	The Company may not carry over or create a valuation allowance in the initial accounting for loans acquired under these circumstances.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P53_S6	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, there were no such loans being accounted for under this policy.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P54_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P54_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P54_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P55_S0	Credit exposures determined to be uncollectible are charged against the allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P55_S1	Cash received on previously charged off amounts is recorded as a recovery to the allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P56_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are not impaired but collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P57_S0	A loan is considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect all amounts due, including principal and interest, according to the contractual terms of the original agreement.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P57_S1	Loans determined to be impaired are individually evaluated for impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P57_S2	When a loan is impaired, the Company measures impairment based on the present value of expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate, except that as a practical expedient, it may measure impairment based on a loan s observable market price, or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P58_S0	A loan is collateral dependent if the repayment of the loan is expected to be provided solely by the underlying collateral.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P59_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P60_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P61_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P61_S1	The determination of the general reserve for loans that are not impaired is based on estimates made by management, to include, but not limited to, consideration of historical losses over the past eight quarters by portfolio segment, internal asset classifications, and qualitative factors to include economic trends in the Company s service areas, industry experience and trends, geographic concentrations, estimated collateral values, the Company s underwriting policies, the character of the loan portfolio, and probable losses inherent in the portfolio taken as a whole.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P62_S0	Effective for the third quarter of 2010, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for loans collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P62_S1	This modification incorporated historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter to identified pools of loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P62_S2	This modification did not have a material affect on the Company s allowance for loans losses or provision for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P62_S3	No modifications to the allowance for loan losses methodology were made in 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P63_S0	The Company maintains a separate allowance for each portfolio segment (loan type).
1168455_12_ITEM15_P63_S1	These portfolio segments include commercial and industrial, agricultural, real estate construction (including land and development loans), commercial real estate mortgage, residential mortgage, home equity loans, installment loans, automobile loans and other loans primarily consisting of credit card receivables.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P63_S2	The allowance for loan losses attributable to each portfolio segment, which includes both impaired loans and loans that are not impaired, is combined to determine the Company s overall allowance, and is included as a component of loans on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P64_S0	The Company assigns a risk rating to all loans and periodically, but not less than annually, performs detailed reviews of all such loans over $100,000 to identify credit risks and to assess the overall collectability of the portfolio.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P64_S1	These risk ratings are also subject to examination by independent specialists engaged by the Company and the Company s regulators.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P65_S0	During these internal reviews, management monitors and analyzes the financial condition of borrowers and guarantors, trends in the industries in which borrowers operate and the fair values of collateral securing these loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P66_S0	These credit quality indicators are used to assign a risk rating to each individual loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P66_S1	The risk ratings can be grouped into five major categories, defined as follows: Pass A pass loan is a strong credit with no existing or known potential weaknesses deserving of management s close attention.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P66_S2	Watch A Watch loan has potential weaknesses that deserve management s close attention.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P66_S3	If left uncorrected, these potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the repayment prospects for the loan or in the Company s credit position at some future date.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P67_S0	Watch loans are not adversely classified and do not expose the Company to sufficient risk to warrant adverse classification.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P68_S0	Substandard A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P69_S0	Loans classified as substandard have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P69_S1	Well defined weaknesses include a project s lack of marketability, inadequate cash flow or collateral support, failure to complete construction on time or the project s failure to fulfill economic expectations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P69_S2	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Company will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P69_S3	Doubtful Loans classified doubtful have all the weaknesses inherent in those classified as substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P69_S4	Loss Loans classified as loss are considered uncollectible and charged off immediately.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P70_S0	The general reserve component of the allowance for loan losses associated with loans collectively evaluated for impairment also consists of reserve factors that are based on management s assessment of the following for each portfolio segment: (1) historical losses and (2) other qualitative factors, including inherent credit risk.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P70_S1	These reserve factors are inherently subjective and are driven by the repayment risk associated with each portfolio segment described below.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P71_S0	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES (Continued) Allowance for Loan Losses (continued) Commercial Commercial loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than real estate portfolio segments because these loans are generally underwritten to existing cash flows of operating businesses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P71_S1	Debt coverage is provided by business cash flows and economic trends influenced by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P72_S0	Agricultural Loans secured by crop production and livestock are especially vulnerable to two risk factors that are largely outside the control of Company and borrowers: commodity prices and weather conditions.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S0	The degree of risk in residential real estate lending depends primarily on the loan amount in relation to collateral value, the interest rate and the borrower s ability to repay in an orderly fashion.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S1	These loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S4	Real estate Commercial Commercial real estate mortgage loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments, except land and construction loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S5	Adverse economic developments or an overbuilt market impact commercial real estate projects and may result in troubled loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S6	Trends in vacancy rates of commercial properties impact the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P73_S7	High vacancy rates reduce operating revenues and the ability for properties to produce sufficient cash flow to service debt obligations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P74_S0	Real estate Construction and Land Development Construction and land development loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P74_S1	A major risk arises from the necessity to complete projects within specified cost and time lines.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P74_S2	Trends in the construction industry significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as demand drives construction activity.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P74_S3	In addition, trends in real estate values significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as property values determine the economic viability of construction projects.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P75_S0	Installment An installment loan portfolio is usually comprised of a large number of small loans scheduled to be amortized over a specific period.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P75_S1	Most installment loans are made directly for consumer purchases, but business loans granted for the purchase of heavy equipment or industrial vehicles may also be included.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P75_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P75_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P76_S0	Other Other loans primarily consist of automobile and credit card loans and are similar in nature to installment loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S0	Although management believes the allowance to be adequate, ultimate losses may vary from its estimates.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S1	At least quarterly, the Board of Directors and management review the adequacy of the allowance, including consideration of the relative risks in the portfolio, current economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S2	If the Board of Directors and management determine that changes are warranted based on those reviews, the allowance is adjusted.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S3	In addition, the Company s primary regulators, the FDIC and DFI, as an integral part of their examination process, review the adequacy of the allowance.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S4	These regulatory agencies may require additions to the allowance based on their judgment about information available at the time of their examinations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P77_S5	The Company also maintains a separate allowance for off-balance-sheet commitments.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S0	Management estimates anticipated losses using historical data and utilization assumptions.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S1	The allowance for these commitments totaled $141,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively and is included in accrued interest payable and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S2	Other Real Estate Other real estate owned relates to real estate acquired in full or partial settlement of loan obligations, which was $8,623,000 ($11,668,000 less a valuation allowance of $3,045,000) at December 31, 2011 and $8,867,000 ($13,056,000 less a valuation allowance of $4,188,000) at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S3	Proceeds from sales of other real estate owned totaled $4,937,000, $3,462,000 and $1,992,000 for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2011 the Company recorded a loss on sale of other real estate owned of $606,000.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S5	This compares to a gain on sale of $43,000 during 2010 and a loss on sale of $158,000 during 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S6	Other real estate owned is initially recorded at fair value less cost to sell when acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S7	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S8	The allowance is established through a provision for losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S9	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are recorded in other income or expenses as incurred.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P78_S10	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P79_S0	Intangible Assets Intangible assets consist of core deposit intangibles related to branch acquisitions and are amortized using the straight-line method over ten years.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P79_S1	The Company evaluates the recoverability and remaining useful life annually to determine whether events or circumstances warrant a revision to the intangible asset or the remaining period of amortization.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P79_S2	There were no such events or circumstances in 2011 or 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P80_S0	Premises and Equipment Premises and equipment are carried at cost.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P81_S0	Depreciation is determined using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P81_S1	The useful lives of premises are estimated to be twenty to thirty years.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P81_S2	The useful lives of furniture, fixtures and equipment are estimated to be two to ten years.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P82_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the life of the asset or the life of the related lease, whichever is shorter.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P82_S1	When assets are sold or otherwise disposed of, the cost and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts, and any resulting gain or loss is recognized in income for the period.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P83_S0	The cost of maintenance and repairs is charged to expense as incurred.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P84_S0	The Company evaluates premises and equipment for financial impairment as events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be fully recoverable.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P85_S0	The Company has purchased life insurance policies on certain key executives.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P86_S0	Bank owned life insurance is recorded at the amount that can be realized under the insurance contract at the balance sheet date, which is the cash surrender value adjusted for other charges or other amounts due that are probable at settlement.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P87_S0	Income Taxes The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P87_S1	Income tax expense is the total of current year income tax due or refundable and the change in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P87_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P87_S3	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are adjusted for the effects of changes in tax laws and rates on the date of enactment.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P87_S4	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P88_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S0	Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S5	Interest expense and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits, if any, are classified as income tax expense in the consolidated statement of operations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P89_S6	There have been no significant changes to unrecognized tax benefits or accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P90_S0	Basic earnings (loss) per share (EPS), which excludes dilution, is computed by dividing income (loss) available to common stockholders (net income or (loss) less preferred dividends) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P90_S1	Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P90_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted EPS.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P91_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P91_S1	Other comprehensive income includes unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale which are also recognized as separate components of equity.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P92_S0	Dividend Restrictions Banking regulations require maintaining certain capital levels and may limit the dividend paid by the bank to the holding company or by the holding company to shareholders.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P92_S1	In addition, the Bank and the Bancorp cannot currently pay dividends without the prior approval of their primary regulators.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P93_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Compensation expense related to the Company s Stock Option Plan, net of related tax (expense)/benefit, recorded in 2011, 2010 and 2009 totaled $(38,000), $53,000 and $237,000 or $(0.01), $0.01 and $0.05 per diluted share, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P94_S0	Compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period on a straight line accounting basis.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P95_S0	The Company determines the fair value of options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model that uses assumptions based on expected option life, expected stock volatility and the risk-free interest rate.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P95_S1	The expected volatility assumptions used by the Company are based on the historical volatility of the Company s common stock over the most recent period commensurate with the estimated expected life of the Company s stock options.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P95_S2	The Company bases its expected life assumption on its historical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock options it grants to employees.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P95_S3	The risk-free rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve for the periods within the contractual life of the options in effect at the time of the grant.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P96_S0	The Company also makes assumptions regarding estimated forfeitures that will impact the total compensation expenses recognized under the Plans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P96_S1	The fair value of each option is estimated on the date of grant using the following assumptions.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P96_S2	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P97_S0	In April 2011, the FASB amended existing guidance for assisting a creditor in determining whether a restructuring is a troubled debt restructuring.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P97_S1	The amendments clarify the guidance for a creditor s evaluation of whether it has granted a concession and whether a debtor is experiencing financial difficulties.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P98_S0	With regard to determining whether a concession has been granted, the ASU clarifies that creditors are precluded from using the effective interest method to determine whether a concession has been granted.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P98_S1	In the absence of using the effective interest method, a creditor must now focus on other considerations such as the value of the underlying collateral, evaluation of other collateral or guarantees, the debtor s ability to access other funds at market rates, interest rate increases and whether the restructuring results in a delay in payment that is insignificant.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P98_S2	This guidance is effective for interim and annual reporting periods ending after June 15, 2011, and should be applied retrospectively to the beginning of the annual period of adoption.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P98_S3	For purposes of measuring impairment on newly identified troubled debt restructurings, the amendments should be applied prospectively for the first interim or annual period beginning on or after June 15, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P99_S0	The effect of adopting this standard did not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S0	In May, 2011, the FASB issued an amendment to achieve common fair value measurement and disclosure requirements between U.S. and International accounting principles.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S1	Overall, the guidance is consistent with existing U.S. accounting principles; however, there are some amendments that change a particular principle or requirement for measuring fair value or for disclosing information about fair value measurements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S2	The amendments in this guidance are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this amendment on the consolidated financial statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S4	In June 2011, the FASB amended existing guidance and eliminated the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in shareholders equity.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S5	The amendment requires that comprehensive income be presented in either a single continuous statement or in two separate consecutive statements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S6	The amendments in this guidance are effective as of the beginning of a fiscal reporting year, and interim periods within that year, that begins after December 15, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P100_S7	The adoption of this amendment will change the presentation of the components of comprehensive income for the Company, as this presentation will no longer be included as part of the consolidated statement of shareholders equity.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P101_S0	The estimated fair values of the Company s financial instruments are as follows: These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated future business related to the instruments.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P101_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P102_S0	The following methods and assumptions were used by management to estimate the fair value of its financial instruments at December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010: Cash and cash equivalents: For cash and cash equivalents, the carrying amount is estimated to be fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P102_S1	Investment securities: For investment securities, fair values are based on quoted market prices, where available.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P102_S2	If quoted market prices are not available, fair values are estimated using quoted market prices for similar securities and indications of value provided by brokers.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P103_S0	Loans: For variable-rate loans that reprice frequently with no significant change in credit risk, fair values are based on carrying values.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P103_S1	Fair values of loans held for sale, if any, are estimated using quoted market prices for similar loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P103_S2	The fair values for other loans are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered at each reporting date for loans with similar terms to borrowers of comparable creditworthiness.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P103_S3	The fair value of loans is adjusted for the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P103_S4	The carrying value of accrued interest receivable approximates its fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P104_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) The fair value of impaired loans is based on either the estimated fair value of underlying collateral or estimated cash flows, discounted at the loan s effective rate.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P104_S1	Assumptions regarding credit risk and cash flows are determined using available market information and specific borrower information.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P105_S0	It was not practicable to determine the fair value of the FHLB stock due to restrictions placed on its transferability.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P106_S0	Deposits: The fair values for demand deposits are, by definition, equal to the amount payable on demand at the reporting date represented by their carrying amount.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P106_S1	Fair values for fixed-rate certificates of deposit are estimated using a discounted cash flow analysis using interest rates offered at each reporting date by the Bank for certificates with similar remaining maturities.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P106_S2	The carrying amount of accrued interest payable approximates its fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P107_S0	Repurchase agreements: The carrying amount of securities sold under repurchase agreements is estimated based on bid quotations received from brokers.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P107_S1	Junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures: The fair value of junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures was determined based on the current market value for like kind instruments of a similar maturity and structure.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P107_S2	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit: The fair value of commitments are estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P107_S3	Commitments to extend credit are primarily for variable rate loans and letters of credit.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P107_S4	For these commitments, there is no significant difference between the committed amounts and their fair values and therefore, these items are not included in the table above.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P108_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments and other factors.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P108_S1	These estimates are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and therefore cannot be determined with precision.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P108_S2	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the fair values presented.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P109_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) The Company measures fair value under the fair value hierarchy described below.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P110_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active exchange markets.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P110_S1	Level 2: Quoted prices (unadjusted) for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model- based valuation techniques for which all significant assumptions are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P110_S2	Level 3: Model based techniques that use one significant assumption not observable in the market.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P110_S3	These unobservable assumptions reflect the Company s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use on pricing the asset or liability.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P111_S0	Valuation techniques include management judgment and estimation which may be significant.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P112_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P112_S1	In such cases, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P112_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P112_S3	Management monitors the availability of observable market data to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P113_S0	Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value level to another.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P113_S1	In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P114_S0	Management evaluates the significance of transfers between levels based upon the nature of the financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total assets, total liabilities or total earnings.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P115_S0	The following tables present information about the Company s assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non recurring basis as of December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, and indicates the fair value hierarchy of the valuation techniques utilized by the Company to determine such fair value: Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized below:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P116_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) The fair value of securities available-for-sale equals quoted market price, if available.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P116_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair value is determined using quoted market prices for similar securities.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P116_S2	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2011 or 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P116_S3	There were no transfers between levels during the year ended December 31, 2011 or December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P117_S0	Changes in fair market value are recorded in other comprehensive income.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P118_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2011 are summarized below:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P119_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2010 are summarized below: The Company has no liabilities which are reported at fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P120_S0	The following methods were used to estimate the fair value of each class of assets above.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P121_S0	Impaired Loans: The fair value of impaired loans with specific allocations of the allowance for loan losses or loans that have been subject to partial charge-offs are generally based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P121_S1	These appraisals may utilize a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P121_S2	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P121_S3	Such adjustments are usually significant and typically result in a Level 3 classification of the inputs for determining fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P122_S0	Total losses of $1,417,000 and $1,356,000 represent impairment charges recognized during the years ended December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, respectively related to the above impaired loans.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P123_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Other Real Estate: Nonrecurring adjustments to certain commercial and residential real estate properties classified as other real estate owned (OREO) are measured at fair value, less costs to sell.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P123_S1	Fair values are based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P123_S2	These appraisals may use a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P123_S3	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P123_S4	Such adjustments are usually significant and typically result in a Level 3 classification of the inputs for determining fair value.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P124_S0	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of investment securities at December 31, 2011 and 2010 consisted of the following: Net unrealized gains on available-for-sale investment securities totaling $268,000 were recorded, net of $110,000 in tax expense, as accumulated other comprehensive income within shareholders equity at December 31, 2011.

1168455_12_ITEM15_P125_S5	Investment securities with unrealized losses at December 31, 2011 and 2010 are summarized and classified according to the duration of the loss period as follows:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P126_S0	There were no securities in a loss position for more than one year as of December 31, 2011 and 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P127_S0	At December 31, 2011, the Company held 47 securities of which 12 were in a loss position.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P127_S1	Of the securities in a loss position, all were in a loss position for less than twelve months.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P127_S2	Of the 12 securities 7 are U.S. government-sponsored agencies and 5 are U.S. Government-sponsored agencies collateralized by residential mortgage obligations.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P128_S0	The unrealized losses relate principally to market rate conditions.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P128_S1	All of the securities continue to pay as scheduled.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P129_S0	When analyzing an issuer s financial condition, management considers the length of time and extent to which the market value has been less than cost; the historical and implied volatility of the security; the financial condition of the issuer of the security; and the Company s intent and ability to hold the security to recovery.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P129_S1	As of December 31, 2011, management does not have the intent to sell these securities nor does it believe it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell these securities before the recovery of its amortized cost basis.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P129_S2	Based on the Company s evaluation of the above and other relevant factors, the Company does not believe the securities that are in an unrealized loss position as of December 31, 2011 are other than temporarily impaired.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P130_S0	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of investment securities at December 31, 2011 by contractual maturity are shown below.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P131_S0	Expected maturities will differ from contractual maturities because the issuers of the securities may have the right to call or prepay obligations with or without call or prepayment penalties.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P132_S0	Investment securities with amortized costs totaling $44,878,000 and $36,828,000 and estimated fair values totaling $45,149,000 and $36,814,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, were pledged to secure deposits and repurchase agreements.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P133_S0	6. LOANS AND THE ALLOWANCE FOR LOAN LOSSES Outstanding loans are summarized below:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P134_S0	Changes in the allowance for loan losses were as follows:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P135_S0	The recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $24,402,000 and $28,755,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P135_S1	The Company had specific allowances for loan losses of $2,066,000 on impaired loans of $14,130,000 at December 31, 2011 as compared to specific allowances for loan losses of $1,903,000 on impaired loans of $11,292,000 at December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P135_S2	The balance of impaired loans in which no specific reserves were required totaled $10,272,000 and $17,463,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P135_S3	The average recorded investment in impaired loans for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $25,536,000, $20,833,000 and $25,092,000, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P135_S4	The Company recognized $666,000, $608,000 and $369,000 in interest income on a cash basis for impaired loans during the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P136_S0	Included in impaired loans are troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P136_S1	A troubled debt restructuring is a formal restructure of a loan where the Company for economic or legal reasons related to the borrower s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the borrower.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P136_S2	The concessions may be granted in various forms, including reduction in the stated interest rate, reduction in the loan balance or accrued interest, and extension of the maturity date.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S0	The Company has allocated $1,164,000 and $271,000 of specific reserves to customers whose loan terms have been modified in troubled debt restructurings as of December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S1	The Company has not committed to lend additional amounts on loans classified as troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2011, the terms of certain loans were modified as troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S3	The modification of the terms of such loans included one or a combination of the following: a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan; an extension of the maturity date at a stated rate of interest lower than the current market rate for new debt with similar risk; or a permanent reduction of the recorded investment in the loan.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S4	Modifications involving a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan were for periods ranging from 1 month to 2 years.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S5	Modifications involving an extension of the maturity date were for periods ranging from 1 month to 10 years.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S6	The following table presents loans by class modified as troubled debt restructurings that occurred during the twelve months ending December 31, 2011:
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S7	The troubled debt restructurings described above increased the allowance for loan losses by $132,000 during the year ending December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P137_S8	The troubled debt restructurings described above did not result in charge offs during the year ending December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P138_S0	The following table presents loans by class modified as troubled debt restructurings for which there was a payment default within twelve months following the modification during the year ending December 31, 2011 A loan is considered to be in payment default once it is 90 days contractually past due under the modified terms.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P138_S1	The troubled debt restructurings that subsequently defaulted described above increased the allowance for loan losses by $81,000 and resulted in charge offs of $51,000 during the year ending December 31, 2011.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P139_S0	The terms of certain other loans were modified during the year ending December 31, 2011 that did not meet the definition of a troubled debt restructuring.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P139_S1	These loans have a total recorded investment as of December 31, 2011 of $13.5 million.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P139_S2	The modification of these loans involved either a modification of the terms of a loan to borrowers who were not experiencing financial difficulties or a delay in a payment that was considered to be insignificant.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P140_S0	In order to determine whether a borrower is experiencing financial difficulty, an evaluation is performed of the probability that the borrower will be in payment default on any of its debt in the foreseeable future without the modification.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P140_S1	This evaluation is performed under the company s internal underwriting policy.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P141_S0	Certain loans which were modified during the period ending December 31, 2011 and did not meet the definition of a troubled debt restructuring as the modification was a delay in a payment that was considered to be insignificant had delays in payment ranging from 30 days to 2 months.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P142_S0	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, nonaccrual loans totaled $16,757,000 and $25,313,000, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P142_S1	Interest foregone on nonaccrual loans totaled $510,000, $1,021,000 and $568,000 for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P142_S2	Loans past due 90 days or more and on accrual status were $72,000 and $45,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_12_ITEM15_P142_S3	Salaries and employee benefits totaling $706,000, $638,000 and $708,000 have been deferred as loan origination costs during the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
