1168455_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	(5) Net interest margin is computed by dividing net interest income by total average earning assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	The following table sets forth changes in interest income and interest expense, for the years indicated and the amount of change attributable to variances in volume, rates and the combination of volume and rates based on the relative changes of volume and rates:
1168455_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	(1) The volume change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the previous year s rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	(2) The rate change in net interest income represents the change in rate multiplied by the previous year s average balance.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	(3) The mix change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the change in rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	Net interest income is the difference between interest income and interest expense.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	Net interest income, on a nontax-equivalent basis, was $17.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, up $331 thousand, or 2%, from $16.8 million for 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S2	A decrease of $243 thousand, or 1.3% in interest income, from $18.7 million during 2011 to $18.4 million during the current year, was offset by a decline in interest expense of $574 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S3	Interest and fees on loans increased by $27 thousand; however, this was offset by a $252 thousand decline in interest on investment securities and an $18 thousand decline in interest on deposits.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S4	The increase in interest and fees on loans was related to an increase in yield partially offset by a decrease in average loan balances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S5	Interest on investments securities declined related to a decrease in yield partially offset by an increase in average balance.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S6	Interest and fees on loans was $17.4 million for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S7	The average loan balances were $301.8 million for 2012, down $1.0 million from the $302.8 million for 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S8	This decline in loans was mostly related to normal pay downs and prepayments, loan charge-offs and real estate acquired through foreclosure mostly offset by growth in our auto loan and commercial real estate loan portfolios.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S9	The average yields on loans were 5.77% for 2012 up from 5.75% for 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S10	As a result of a decrease in yield of 64 basis points from 1.92% during 2011 to 1.28% during 2012, interest on investment securities decreased by $252 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S11	The effect of the decrease in yield on interest income was partially offset by an increase in average investment securities of $10.2 million from $59.4 million during 2011 to $69.6 million during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P26_S12	The decline in yield is primarily related to the replacement of matured and sold investment securities with new investments with market yields below those which they replaced.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	Interest income on interest-bearing deposits, which totaled $106 thousand in 2012 and $124 thousand in 2011, mostly relates to interest on cash balances held at the Federal Reserve.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	Interest expense on deposits decreased by $622 thousand, or 42%, to $847 thousand for the twelve months ended December 31, 2012, down from $1.5 million in 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S1	This decrease primarily relates to decreases in the average balance and rate paid on time and interest bearing demand deposits (NOW) and a decline in the rate paid on money market accounts.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S2	Interest on time deposits declined by $548 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S3	Average time deposits declined by $20.9 million from $97.0 million during 2011 to $76.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S4	The decrease in average time deposits is mostly related to a promotional time deposit product we began offering in June, 2009 and continued to offer until April 30, 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S5	During 2011 the average balance of promotional deposits was $21.8 million; these promotional time deposits had all matured by December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S6	The average rate paid on promotional deposits during 2011 was 2%.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S7	In addition, the Bank has held down the rate paid on time deposits in 2012 as it has excess liquidity and does not need to pay for deposits at above market rates.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S8	The average rate paid on time deposits decreased from 1.09% during 2011 to 0.67% during the current twelve month period.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S9	This decrease primarily relates to a decline in market rates paid in the Company s service area and the maturity of the higher rate promotional deposits.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S10	Interest expense on NOW accounts declined by $76 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S11	Rates paid on NOW accounts declined by 7 basis points from 0.20% during 2011 to 0.13% during 2012, mostly related to a decline in market rates in the Company s service area.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S12	Average balances declined by $11.3 million from 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S13	During 2011 we significantly lowered the rate paid on local public agencies NOW accounts as we determined that the previous rate did not meet our profitability targets, as a result some of these deposits moved out of the Bank.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S14	During 2012 average public NOW accounts declined by $7.4 million from $24.3 million during 2011 to $16.9 million during the year ended December 21, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S15	At December 31, 2012 balances in this account type were $11.8 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S16	We do not expect significant additional declines in public NOW balances during 2013.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S17	Interest expense on money market accounts decreased by $24 thousand related to a decrease in rate paid on these accounts of 8 basis points from 0.29% during 2011 to 0.21% during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S18	This was primarily related to a money market sweep product we offered in 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S19	We no longer offer the money market sweep account having replaced it with a product that utilizes repurchase agreements during the third quarter of 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S20	Average money market balances increased by $2.9 million from $40.0 million during 2011 to $42.9 million in 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P28_S21	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which increased by $18 thousand from 2011, fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	Interest on other borrowings primarily relates to interest paid on repurchase agreements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2012 increased 10 basis points to 4.18%, from 4.08% for 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	Net interest income, on a nontax-equivalent basis, was $16.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, a decline of $0.7 million, or 4.1%, from $17.5 million for 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S3	The overall change in net interest income was primarily a result of a decrease of $1.5 million in loan interest income and a decline of $628 thousand in interest income on investment securities.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S4	The decline in interest on loans was mostly related to a decline in average loans outstanding.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S5	Interest on investment securities declined related to a decrease in both yield and average balance.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S6	Partially offsetting these decreases in interest income was a decline in rates paid on the Company s deposits and a decline in the average balance of time deposits, interest bearing demand deposits and long-term borrowings.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S7	Interest income decreased $2.0 million, or 9.7%, to $18.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S8	Interest and fees on loans decreased by $1.5 million from $18.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 to $17.4 million for 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S9	The average loan balances were $302.8 million for 2011, down $21.1 million from the $323.9 million for 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S10	This decline in loans was mostly related to normal pay downs and prepayments, loan charge-offs, real estate acquired through foreclosure and our efforts to reduce the level of construction and land development loan balances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P30_S11	The average yields on loans were 5.75% for 2011 down from the 5.82% for 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	Interest on investment securities decreased by $628 thousand resulting from a decrease in yield of 63 basis points and a decline in average investment securities of $9.9 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P31_S1	The decline in yield is primarily related to the replacement of matured and sold investment securities with new investments with market yields below those which they replaced.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	Interest income on other interest-earning assets, which totaled $124 thousand in 2011 and $48 thousand in 2010, relates to interest on cash balances held at the Federal Reserve.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	Interest expense on deposits decreased by $1.2 million, or 46%, to $1.5 million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2011, down from $2.7 million in 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S2	This decrease primarily relates to decreases in the average balance and rate paid on time deposits and a decline in the rate paid on demand deposit (NOW) and money market accounts.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S3	Interest on time deposits declined by $946 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S4	Average time deposits declined by $27.8 million from $124.8 million during 2010 to $97.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S5	The decrease in time deposits is mostly related to promotional time deposits as previously discussed.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S6	The average rate paid on these promotional deposits during 2011 was 2%.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S7	The average rate paid on time deposits decreased from 1.61% during 2010 to 1.09% during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S8	This decrease primarily relates to a decline in market rates paid in the Company s service area and the maturity of the higher rate promotional deposits.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S9	Interest expense on NOW accounts declined by $195 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S10	Rates paid on NOW accounts declined by 18 basis points from 0.38% during 2010 to 0.20% during 2011, as we significantly lowered the rate paid on local public agencies NOW accounts.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S11	Although we lost deposits by lowering this rate; we continue to focus on the profitability of the public sweep accounts rather than growing public sweep balances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S12	Interest expense on money market accounts decreased by $106 thousand related primarily to a decrease in rate paid on these accounts of 23 basis points from 0.52% during 2010 to 0.29% during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S13	This was primarily related to a significant drop in the rates paid on our money market sweep product.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S14	Interest on FHLB long term borrowings decreased by $130 thousand as there were no outstanding long term borrowings during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S15	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which increased by $14 thousand from 2010, fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P32_S16	Interest on other borrowings in 2011 primarily relates to interest paid on repurchase agreements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P33_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2011 decreased 16 basis points to 4.08%, from 4.24% for 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	Provision for Loan Losses During the year ended December 31, 2012 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $2.35 million down $1.15 million from the $3.50 million provision recorded during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P34_S1	See Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses for further discussion of loan quality trends and the provision for loan losses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that management believes will be appropriate to absorb inherent losses on existing loans based on an evaluation of the collectability of the loans and prior loan loss experience.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P35_S1	The evaluations take into consideration such factors as changes in the nature and volume of the portfolio, overall portfolio quality, review of specific problem loans, and current economic conditions that may affect the borrower's ability to repay their loan.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P36_S0	The allowance for loan losses is based on estimates, and ultimate losses may vary from the current estimates.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P36_S1	These estimates are reviewed periodically and, as adjustments become necessary, they are reported in earnings in the periods in which they become known.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P37_S0	Based on information currently available, management believes that the allowance for loan losses is appropriate to absorb potential risks in the portfolio.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P37_S1	However, no assurance can be given that the Company may not sustain charge-offs which are in excess of the allowance in any given period.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P38_S0	The following table sets forth the components of non-interest income for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P39_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 non-interest income decreased by $566 thousand to $6.6 million from $7.2 million during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P39_S1	The largest component of this decrease was a decrease of $615 thousand in gains on the sale of government guaranteed loans from $1.9 million during 2011 to $1.3 million during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S0	Beginning in the first quarter of 2011, related to a change in SBA requirements, guaranteed portions of SBA loans were no longer required to be sold with a 90 day premium recourse requirement.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S1	This resulted in recording gains on sales of loans during 2011 representing both loans sold during the twelve months ended December 31, 2011 and loans sold during the fourth quarter of 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S2	In addition, gain on sale of loans during 2011benefited from a government program temporarily increasing the government guarantee in order to stimulate small business lending.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S3	The remaining decrease in non-interest income was related to a decline in gains on sale of investment securities from $666 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2011 to $403 thousand during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S4	During the 2011 period proceeds of $29.4 million were generated on the sale of twenty-seven securities and during the 2012 proceeds of $20.8 million were received on the sale of twenty-five securities.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S5	Service charges on deposit accounts increased by $140 thousand primarily related to an increase in use of overdraft protection services.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S6	During the fourth quarter of 2011 we introduced a new overdraft protection (ODP) program which we made available to a larger portion of our customer base than the prior program, resulting in an increase in service fee income.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S7	This new program has enabled us to increase income while strengthening our regulatory compliance over the ODP function.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S8	The increase in other non-interest income mostly relates to a $99 thousand adjustment to accrued life insurance.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S9	During the year ended December 31, 2011 non-interest income decreased by $1.3 million to $7.2 million, from $8.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P40_S10	This decrease was related to the sale of our merchant processing portfolio in 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S0	During June 2010 we entered into an alliance with a world-wide merchant processing leader.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S1	In conjunction with this alliance we sold our merchant processing business, recording a one-time gain of $1.4 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S2	Related to this sale we experienced a decrease in merchant processing income of $126 thousand during the comparison periods.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S3	Service charges on deposit accounts declined by $165 thousand primarily related to a decline in overdraft fees as new regulations placed additional restrictions on the Bank in charging overdraft fees on ATM and Point of Sale transactions.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S4	Gain on sale of investments declined by $494 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S5	During the year ended December 31, 2011 we sold twenty-seven investment securities classified as available-for-sale for $29.4 million recognizing a $0.7 million gain on sale.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P41_S6	During the 2010 period we sold sixty-five investment securities classified as available-for sale for $40.9 million and recorded a $1.2 million gain on sale.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P42_S0	We chose to sell some of the securities in our investment portfolio in order to lock in gains; this had the additional benefit of partially offsetting some nonrecurring expense items such as losses on sale of OREO.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P42_S1	Partially offsetting these declines in income was an $884 thousand increase in gain on sale of government guaranteed loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P43_S0	Gains on sale in 2011 were particularly strong related to two factors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P43_S1	First, during the first quarter of 2011 the SBA eliminated the recourse provision related to loan sales allowing us to record both gains on sales from loans sold during the fourth quarter of 2010 and the first quarter of 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P43_S2	In addition, many loans sold in 2011 were 90% guaranteed related to a temporary increase in guarantee percentage enacted on February 17, 2009 as part of the Recovery Act.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P43_S3	Currently loans made through the SBA 7(a) program carry a 75% to 85% guarantee.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P44_S0	The following table sets forth the components of other non-interest expense for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S0	We continue to achieve savings in many categories of non-interest expense resulting in a reduction in non-interest expense of $869 thousand from $19.2 million during the twelve months ended December 31, 2011 to $18.4 million during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S1	Significant reductions in salary and benefits expense, FDIC insurance, loss on sale of OREO, OREO expense, and postage were partially offset by an increase in the provision for changes in valuation of OREO of $328 thousand, an increase in outside service fees of $233 thousand, an increase in professional fees of $145 thousand and an increase in insurance expense of $78 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S2	Salaries and employee benefits decreased by $227 thousand related to a decline of $80 thousand in commission expense, $88 thousand in medical and dental insurance expense (group insurance), $50 thousand in workers compensation expense and an increase of $247 thousand in deferred loan origination costs partially offset by an increase of $92 thousand in salary continuation expense and $131 thousand in stock compensation expense.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S3	Commission expense, which relates to government-guaranteed lending personnel, decreased by $80 thousand consistent with the decline in government-guaranteed loan sales during the comparison periods.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S4	The decrease in group insurance was mostly related to a decline in employees enrolled in the insurance plans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S5	The decrease in workers compensation was related to changing providers.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S6	Previously we were members of a small group plan and our premiums were adversely affected by claims within the group.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P45_S7	We have exited this plan and have seen a considerable reduction in workers compensation premiums.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P46_S0	Related to an increase in lending activity, the deferral of loan origination costs increased by $247 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S0	During 2012, related to a significant reduction in long term market interest rates, we reduced the discount rates used in calculating the present value of our salary continuation liabilities.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S1	This had the effect of increasing salary continuation expense by $195 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S2	Absent this adjustment salary continuation expense would have declined by $103 thousand, as salary continuation expense during 2011 included a one-time adjustment to reflect the early retirement of the Company s Chief Credit officer.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S3	Employee stock compensation expense increased by $131 thousand from a credit of $38 thousand during 2011 to expense of $93 thousand during the current period.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S4	The credit in stock compensation expense during the 2011 period was related to a revision in the estimated forfeiture rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S5	We expect a reduction in stock compensation expense in 2013 as the unamortized balance continues to decline.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S6	A decline of $486 thousand in FDIC insurance expense relates to a decline in the rate charged Plumas Bank by the FDIC.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S7	This decline in rate includes a change in the assessment base and assessment rate under new rules enacted pursuant to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P47_S8	These new rules changed the assessment base from total deposits to average total assets less tangible capital, but also significantly lowered the assessment rates, causing a net favorable impact on our FDIC insurance premiums.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S0	OREO represents real property taken by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S1	Loss on sale of OREO totaled $16 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012, a decrease of $590 thousand from the $606 thousand incurred in 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S2	In the second quarter of 2011 the Bank sold its largest OREO holding which represented approximately half of its OREO holdings at that time.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S3	The Bank incurred a $617 thousand loss on sale of this large OREO holding in 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S4	OREO expense declined by $235 thousand from $422 thousand during 2011 to $187 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S5	OREO expense benefited from a decline in OREO balances in 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S6	In addition, 2011 OREO expense was adversely affected by significant cleanup costs on one property and considerable legal costs related to another property.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S7	Both of these properties where sold during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S8	Postage declined by $86 thousand related to the outsourcing of our statement processing activities during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P48_S9	Effective with the outsourcing, the cost of mailing statements, notices and similar documents is included in outside service costs.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S0	When other real estate is acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair market value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S1	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S2	The allowance is established through a provision for subsequent losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S3	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are recorded in other income or expenses as incurred.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S4	The $907 thousand in OREO provision, an increase of $328 thousand from $579 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2011, was related to a decline in the value of twenty-one properties based on appraisals received during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S5	Of these twenty-one properties, seven have been sold and the remaining fourteen represent 61% of the Bank s OREO balance as of December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S6	The largest component of the $233 thousand increase in outside service costs was $112 thousand in costs related to the outsourcing of our statement processing operations in June, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S7	The Company anticipates meaningful savings, related to the statement outsourcing.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S8	During 2012 the Bank modernized its ATM network by purchasing new ATM machines which have the ability to accept currency and checks and provide an imaged receipt.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S9	A large portion of the remaining increase in outside service costs relates to maintaining these advanced machines which are considerably more complicated than our previous ATMs many of which were over ten years old.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S10	The $145 thousand increase in professional fees mostly relates to an increase in consulting costs in the Company s data processing and network administration functions.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P49_S11	Insurance expense was abnormally low during 2011 as it included the reversal of the accrual for split dollar life insurance for the Bank s former Chief Credit Officer who forfeited his right to this insurance when he left the Bank prior to reaching the age of sixty-five.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S0	While we have achieved savings in many categories of non-interest expense these were offset in 2011 by an increase of $649 thousand in loss on sale of OREO.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S1	Non-interest expense increased by $105 thousand from $19.1 million during the year ended December 31, 2010 to $19.2 million during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S2	Loss on sale of OREO totaled $606 thousand primarily related to the sale of one property.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S3	During June, 2011 the Bank sold its largest OREO holding which represented $4.3 million, or 48% of the total balance in OREO at January 1, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S4	The Bank incurred a $617 thousand loss on sale; however, management believes the loss was prudent given the significant affect this transaction had in decreasing nonperforming assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S5	Outside service fees increased by $58 thousand which mostly relates to our on-line banking and bill payment platform.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S6	FDIC insurance costs increased related to an increase in the rate the FDIC charges Plumas Bank.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P50_S7	Professional fees increased by $143 thousand the largest portion of which was related to an increase in consulting cost of $97 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S0	During the second half of 2011 we contracted with an outside party to provide assistance in the management of our nonperforming assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S1	Total costs incurred related to this consultant were $42 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S2	In addition we incurred $21 thousand in costs related to an outside management study.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S3	The largest reduction in expense was a decrease of $537 thousand in salaries and employee benefits.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S4	Salary expense, excluding commissions, declined by $667 thousand mostly related to a reduction in staffing, during the second quarter of 2010, which affected most functional areas with the exception of government guaranteed lending and problem assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S5	On a full-time equivalent basis, we employed 142 persons at December 31, 2011 down from 146 at December 31, 2010 and 163 at December 31, 2009.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S6	Commission expense, which relates to government guaranteed lending personnel and is included in salary expense, increased by $318 thousand resulting from the increase in government guaranteed loan gains.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S7	The provision for OREO losses increased by $223 thousand related to one land development property that, based on a 2011 appraisal, declined in value by $417 thousand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P51_S8	At December 31, 2011, this property had a value of approximately $1 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P52_S0	OREO carrying costs declined by $151 thousand from $573 thousand during 2010 to $422 thousand during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P52_S1	These savings were primarily related to property taxes on OREO properties and refunds on prior year tax payments related to some of our OREO properties being reassessed.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P52_S2	Insurance expense declined by $83 thousand primarily related to the forfeiture of retirement split dollar life insurance benefits by one of our executive officers who chose to terminate his employment during 2011 prior to age sixty-five.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P52_S3	Other non-interest expense declined by $228 thousand related to a $226 thousand prepayment penalty incurred upon the prepayment of our long-term Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings during July, 2010.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $1.1 million, or 35.4% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P53_S1	During 2011 the Company recorded an income tax provision of $295 thousand, or 23.9% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P53_S2	The percentages for 2012 and 2011 differ from the statutory rate as tax exempt income such as earnings on Bank owned life insurance, municipal loan interest, and in the state of California enterprise zone interest decrease taxable income.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P54_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P54_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P55_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P55_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is "more likely than not" that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P55_S2	"More likely than not" is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P55_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P56_S0	As part of its analysis, the Company considered the following positive evidence:
1168455_13_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company has a long history of earnings and profitability.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company has been profitable for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P58_S1	Additionally, the Company is projecting future taxable and book income will be generated by operations.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P59_S0	The volume of potential problem loans in the Company s loan portfolio has significantly decreased.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company does not have a history of net operating losses carry forwards or tax credits expiring unused.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P60_S1	Based upon the analysis of available evidence, management has determined that it is "more likely than not" that all deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company continues to manage the mix of its loan portfolio consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financing needs of all sectors of the area it serves.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S1	Although the Company offers a broad array of financing options, it continues to concentrate its focus on small to medium sized commercial businesses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S2	These commercial loans offer diversification as to industries and types of businesses, thus limiting material exposure in any industry concentrations.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S3	The Company offers both fixed and floating rate loans and obtains collateral in the form of real property, business assets and deposit accounts, but looks to business and personal cash flows as its primary source of repayment.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S4	The Company s largest lending categories are commercial real estate loans, agricultural loans and residential real estate loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S5	These categories accounted for approximately 44.3%, 11.1% and 11.0%, respectively of the Company's total loan portfolio at December 31, 2012, and approximately 40.6%, 13.2% and 13.3%, respectively of the Company's total loan portfolio at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S6	Construction and land development loans continue to decline and represented 5.0% and 5.8% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S7	The construction and land development portfolio component has been identified by Management as a higher-risk loan category.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P61_S8	The quality of the construction and land development category is highly dependent on property values both in terms of the likelihood of repayment once the property is transacted by the current owner as well as the level of collateral the Company has securing the loan in the event of default.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S0	Loans in this category are characterized by the speculative nature of commercial and residential development properties and can include property in various stages of development from raw land to finished lots.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S1	The decline in these loans as a percentage of the Company s loan portfolio reflects management s continued efforts, which began in 2009, to reduce its exposure to construction and land development loans due to the severe valuation decrease in the real estate market.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S2	The Company s real estate related loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate comprised 78% and 81% of the total loan portfolio at December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S3	Moreover, the business activities of the Company currently are focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta, Sierra and in Washoe County in Northern Nevada.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S4	Consequently, the results of operations and financial condition of the Company are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P62_S5	In addition, the concentration of the Company's operations in these areas of Northeastern California and Northwestern Nevada exposes it to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P63_S0	The rates of interest charged on variable rate loans are set at specific increments in relation to the Company's lending rate or other indexes such as the published prime interest rate or U.S. Treasury rates and vary with changes in these indexes.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P63_S1	At December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, approximately 73% of the Company's loan portfolio was comprised of variable rate loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P64_S0	While real estate mortgage, commercial and consumer lending remain the foundation of the Company's historical loan mix, some changes in the mix have occurred due to the changing economic environment and the resulting change in demand for certain loan types.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P64_S1	In addition, the Company remains committed to the agricultural industry in Northeastern California and will continue to pursue high quality agricultural loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P64_S2	Agricultural loans include both commercial and commercial real estate loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P64_S3	The Company s agricultural loan balances totaled $35 million at December 31, 2012 and $39 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P64_S4	The following table sets forth the amounts of loans outstanding by category as of the dates indicated.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P65_S0	(2) Includes agriculture real estate The following table sets forth the maturity of gross loan categories as of December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P65_S1	Also provided with respect to such loans are the amounts due after one year, classified according to sensitivity to changes in interest rates:
1168455_13_ITEM7_P66_S0	Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company attempts to minimize credit risk through its underwriting and credit review policies.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S1	The Company s credit review process includes internally prepared credit reviews as well as contracting with an outside firm to conduct periodic credit reviews.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S2	The Company s management and lending officers evaluate the loss exposure of classified and impaired loans on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S3	The Management Asset Resolution Committee (MARC) reviews the asset quality of criticized loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S4	The Board s Loan Committee reviews the asset quality of new loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P67_S5	In management's opinion, this loan review system helps facilitate the early identification of potential criticized loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company has implemented MARC to develop an action plan to significantly reduce nonperforming loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S0	It consists of members of executive management and credit administration management, and the activities are governed by a formal written charter.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S1	The MARC meets at least monthly and reports to the Board of Directors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S2	More specifically, a formal plan to effect repayment and/or disposition of every significant nonperforming loan relationship is developed and documented for review and on-going oversight by the MARC.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S3	Some of the strategies used include but are not limited to: 1) obtaining additional collateral, 2) obtaining additional investor cash infusion, 3) sale of the promissory note to an outside party, 4) proceeding with foreclosure on the underlying collateral, and 5) legal action against borrower/guarantors to encourage settlement of debt and/or collect any deficiency balance owed.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S4	Each step includes a benchmark timeline to track progress.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P69_S5	MARC also provides guidance for the maintenance and timely disposition of OREO properties; including developing financing and marketing programs to incent individuals to purchase OREO.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P70_S0	The allowance for loan losses is established through charges to earnings in the form of the provision for loan losses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P70_S1	Loan losses are charged to and recoveries are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P70_S2	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level deemed appropriate by management to provide for known and inherent risks in the loan portfolio.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P70_S3	The adequacy of the allowance for loan losses is based upon management's continuing assessment of various factors affecting the collectability of loans; including current economic conditions, maturity of the portfolio, size of the portfolio, industry concentrations, borrower credit history, collateral, the existing allowance for loan losses, independent credit reviews, current charges and recoveries to the allowance for loan losses and the overall quality of the portfolio as determined by management, regulatory agencies, and independent credit review consultants retained by the Company.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P71_S0	There is no precise method of predicting specific losses or amounts which may ultimately be charged off on particular segments of the loan portfolio.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P72_S0	The collectability of a loan is subjective to some degree, but must relate to the borrower s financial condition, cash flow, quality of the borrower s management expertise, collateral and guarantees, and state of the local economy.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P73_S0	Formula allocations are calculated by applying loss factors to outstanding loans with similar characteristics.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P73_S1	Loss factors are based on the Company s historical loss experience as adjusted for changes in the business cycle and may be adjusted for significant factors that, in management's judgment, affect the collectability of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P74_S0	Effective for the third quarter of 2012, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for non-impaired loans.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P74_S1	This modification incorporated historical losses from the beginning of the latest business cycle.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P74_S2	Previously we utilized historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P74_S3	This modification had the effect of increasing the required allowance by approximately $250,000 for 2012 related to the expanded historical loss period.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P74_S4	The Company believes that, given the recent trend in historical losses, it was prudent to increase the period examined and that a full business cycle was the appropriate period.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P75_S0	The discretionary allocation is based upon management s evaluation of various loan segment conditions that are not directly measured in the determination of the formula and specific allowances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P75_S1	The conditions may include, but are not limited to, general economic and business conditions affecting the key lending areas of the Company, credit quality trends, collateral values, loan volumes and concentrations, and other business conditions.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S0	The following table provides certain information for the years indicated with respect to the Company's allowance for loan losses as well as charge-off and recovery activity.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2012 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $2.35 million down $1.15 million from the $3.50 million provision recorded during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S2	Net charge-offs totaled $3.6 million during the year ended December 31, 2012 and $3.9 million during 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S3	Net charge-offs as a percentage of average loans decreased from 1.29% during 2011 to 1.18% during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S4	The following table provides a breakdown of the allowance for loan losses: The allowance for loan losses totaled $5.7 million at December 31, 2012 and $6.9 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S5	Specific reserves related to impaired loans decreased from $2.1 million at December 31, 2011 to $1.2 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S6	This decline in specific reserves is reflected in the $3.6 million in net charge-offs during 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S7	At least quarterly the Company evaluates each specific reserve and if it determines that the loss represented by the specific reserve is uncollectable it reverses the specific reserve and takes a partial charge-off in its place.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S8	General reserves decreased by $342 thousand to $4.5 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S9	Related to a decline in specific and general reserves, the allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans decreased from 2.35% at December 31, 2011 to 1.80% at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P76_S10	The percentage of general reserves to unimpaired loans decreased from 1.80% at December 31, 2011 to 1.52% at December 31, 2012 primarily related to a decrease in the historical charge-off rate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P77_S0	The Company places loans 90 days or more past due on nonaccrual status unless the loan is well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P77_S1	A loan is considered to be in the process of collection if, based on a probable specific event, it is expected that the loan will be repaid or brought current.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P77_S2	Generally, this collection period would not exceed 90 days.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status the Company's general policy is to reverse and charge against current income previously accrued but unpaid interest.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P78_S1	Interest income on such loans is subsequently recognized only to the extent that cash is received and future collection of principal is deemed by management to be probable.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P78_S2	Where the collectability of the principal or interest on a loan is considered to be doubtful by management, it is placed on nonaccrual status prior to becoming 90 days delinquent.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P78_S3	Impaired loans are measured based on the present value of the expected future cash flows discounted at the loan's effective interest rate or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P78_S4	The amount of impaired loans is not directly comparable to the amount of nonperforming loans disclosed later in this section.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	The primary difference between impaired loans and nonperforming loans is that impaired loan recognition considers not only loans 90 days or more past due, restructured loans and nonaccrual loans but also may include identified problem loans other than delinquent loans where it is considered probable that we will not collect all amounts due to us (including both principal and interest) in accordance with the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor's financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P82_S1	Loans restructured and in compliance with modified terms totaled $9.3 million, $8.4 million, $2.0 million and $3.4 million at December 31, 2012, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P82_S2	There were no troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2008.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P82_S3	For additional information related to restructured loans see Note 6 of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	The following table sets forth the amount of the Company's nonperforming assets as of the dates indicated.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	Nonperforming loans at December 31, 2012 were $13.7 million, a decrease of $3.1 million from the $16.8 million balance at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P84_S1	The decline of $3.1 million includes $1.3 million in loans transferred to OREO, charge-offs and principal repayments on nonperforming loans partially offset by $5.6 million in additional loans placed on nonperforming status.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P84_S2	Specific reserves on nonaccrual loans totaled $976 thousand at December 31, 2012 and $1.3 million at December 31, 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P84_S3	Performing loans past due thirty to eighty-nine days decreased from $5.1 million at December 31, 2011 to $2.8 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	Total substandard loans decreased by $10.6 million from $29.2 million at December 31, 2011 to $18.6 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S2	Loans classified as watch decreased as well from $10.7 million at December 31, 2011 to $6.7 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S3	At December 31, 2012, $8.4 million of performing loans were classified as substandard.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S4	Further deterioration in the credit quality of individual performing substandard loans or other adverse circumstances could result in the need to place these loans on nonperforming status.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S5	At December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, the Company's recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $18.8 million and $24.4 million, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S6	The specific allowance for loan losses related to impaired loans totaled $1.2 million and $2.1 million at December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P85_S7	Additionally, $3.0 million has been charged off against the impaired loans at December 31, 2012 and $940 thousand at December 31 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	It is the policy of management to make additions to the allowance for loan losses so that it remains appropriate to absorb the inherent risk of loss in the portfolio.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P86_S1	Management believes that the allowance at December 31, 2012 is appropriate.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P86_S2	However, the determination of the amount of the allowance is judgmental and subject to economic conditions which cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P86_S3	Accordingly, the Company cannot predict whether charge-offs of loans in excess of the allowance may occur in future periods.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	OREO represents real property taken by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S1	Repossessed assets include vehicles and other commercial assets acquired under agreements with delinquent borrowers.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S2	Repossessed assets and OREO are carried at fair market value, less selling costs.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S3	OREO holdings represented forty properties totaling $5.3 million at December 31, 2012 and forty-four properties totaling $8.6 million at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S4	During June, 2011 the Bank sold its largest OREO holding which represented $4.3 million, or 48% of the total balance in OREO at January 1, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S5	The Bank incurred a $617 thousand loss on this 2011sale; however, management believes the loss was prudent given the significant affect this transaction had in decreasing nonperforming assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S6	Nonperforming assets as a percentage of total assets were 3.98% at December 31, 2012 and 5.60% at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P87_S7	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011:
1168455_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	Investment Portfolio and Federal Funds Sold.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P88_S1	Total investment securities increased by $23.0 million from $57.9 million at December 31, 2011 to $80.9 million as of December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P88_S2	The increase in investment securities is consistent with our asset/liability management policy as we chose to reduce excess balances held at the FRB in order to increase our return on these balances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	The investment portfolio at December 31, 2012 and 2011 was invested entirely in U.S. Government-sponsored agencies.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P89_S1	There were no Federal funds sold at December 31, 2012 or 2011; however, the Bank maintained interest earning balances at the Federal Reserve Bank (FRB) totaling $24.5 million at December 31, 2012 and $47.8 million at December 31, 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P89_S2	These balances currently earn 25 basis points.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	The Company classifies its investment securities as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P90_S1	Currently all securities are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P90_S2	Securities classified as available-for-sale may be sold to implement the Company's asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	The following tables summarize the values of the Company's investment securities held on the dates indicated: The following table summarizes the maturities of the Company's securities at their carrying value, which represents fair value, and their weighted average tax equivalent yields at December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S1	Total deposits were $411.5 million as of December 31, 2012, up $20.4 million, or 5%, from the December 31, 2011 balance of $391.1 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S2	Non-interest bearing demand deposits increased by $17.7 million, interest bearing transaction accounts (NOW) increased by $1.4 million, savings accounts increased by $6.2 million and money market accounts increased by $4.9 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S3	Time deposits declined by $9.8 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S4	We attribute much of the reduction in time to the unusually low interest rate environment as we have seen a movement out of time into more liquid deposits types.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S5	The Company continues to manage the mix of its deposits consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financial needs of its customers.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S6	The deposit mix changed slightly from December 31, 2011 as time deposits and NOW accounts declined as a percentage of total deposits and we had an increase in other deposit types.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S7	Non-interest bearing demand deposits were 35% of total deposits at December 31, 2012 and 32% of total deposits at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S8	Interest bearing transaction accounts were 20% of total deposits at December 31, 2012 and 21% of total deposits at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S9	Money market and savings deposits totaled 28% of total deposits at December 31, 2012 and 26% at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S10	Time deposits were 17% of total deposits at December 31, 2012 and 21% of total deposits at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S11	Deposits represent the Bank's primary source of funds.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S12	Deposits are primarily core deposits in that they are demand, savings and time deposits generated from local businesses and individuals.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P91_S13	These sources are considered to be relatively stable, long-term relationships thereby enhancing steady growth of the deposit base without major fluctuations in overall deposit balances.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	The Company experiences, to a small degree, some seasonality with the slower growth period between November through April, and the higher growth period from May through October.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	In order to assist in meeting any funding demands, the Company maintains a secured borrowing arrangement with the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	There were no brokered deposits at December 31, 2012 or 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	The Company's time deposits of $100,000 or more had the following schedule of maturities at December 31, 2012:
1168455_13_ITEM7_P93_S1	Time deposits of $100,000 or more are generally from the Company's local business and individual customer base.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P93_S2	The potential impact on the Company's liquidity from the withdrawal of these deposits is discussed at the Company's asset and liability management committee meetings, and is considered to be minimal.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $98,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $191,000,000.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S2	At December 31, 2012, the Company held $1,950,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S3	At this level of stock holdings the Company can borrow up to $41,000,000.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S4	There were no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P94_S5	To borrow the $98,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,661,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P95_S0	In 2011 Plumas Bank introduced a new product for its larger business customers which use repurchase agreements as an alternative to interest-bearing deposits.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	The balance in this product at December 31, 2012 was $7.4 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P95_S2	Interest paid on this product is similar to that which can be earned on the Bank s premium money market account; however, these are not deposits and are not FDIC insured.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P96_S0	Capital Resources Shareholders' equity as of December 31, 2012 totaled $41.9 million up from $39.6 million as of December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P97_S0	On January 30, 2009, under the Capital Purchase Program, the Company sold (i) 11,949 shares of the Company s Fixed Rate Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A (the Preferred Shares ) and (ii) a ten-year warrant to purchase up to 237,712 shares of the Company s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $7.54 per share, for an aggregate purchase price of $11,949,000 in cash.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	Ten million of the twelve million in proceeds from the sale of the Series A Preferred Stock was injected into Plumas Bank providing addition capital for the bank to support growth in loans and investment securities and strengthen its capital ratios.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P97_S2	The remainder provided funds for holding company activities and general corporate purposes.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P97_S3	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P97_S4	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P98_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_13_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P99_S0	Banking regulations limit the amount of dividends that may be paid without prior approval of regulatory agencies.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P99_S1	No common cash dividends were paid in 2009, 2010, 2011, or 2012 and none are anticipated to be paid in 2013.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P100_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P101_S0	At the request of the FRB, Plumas Bancorp deferred its regularly scheduled quarterly interest payments on its outstanding junior subordinated debentures relating to its two trust preferred securities and suspended quarterly cash dividend payments on its Series A Preferred Stock.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P101_S1	Therefore, Plumas Bancorp is currently in arrears with the dividend payments on the Series A Preferred Stock and interest payments on the junior subordinated debentures as permitted by the related agreements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P101_S2	As of December 31, 2012 the amount of the arrearage on the dividend payments of the Series A Preferred Stock is $1,643 thousand representing eleven quarterly payments and the amount of the arrearage on the payments on the subordinated debt associated with the trust preferred securities is $906 thousand also representing eleven quarterly payments.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P102_S0	The Company uses a variety of measures to evaluate its capital adequacy, with risk-based capital ratios calculated separately for the Company and the Bank.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P102_S1	Management reviews these capital measurements on a monthly basis and takes appropriate action to ensure that they are within established internal and external guidelines.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P103_S0	The FDIC has promulgated risk-based capital guidelines for all state non-member banks such as the Bank.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P103_S1	These guidelines establish a risk-adjusted ratio relating capital to different categories of assets and off-balance sheet exposures.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P103_S2	There are two categories of capital under the guidelines: Tier 1 capital includes common stockholders equity, and qualifying trust-preferred securities (including notes payable to unconsolidated special purpose entities that issue trust-preferred securities), less goodwill and certain other deductions, notably the unrealized net gains or losses (after tax adjustments) on available-for-sale investment securities carried at fair market value; Tier 2 capital can include qualifying subordinated debt and the allowance for loan losses, subject to certain limitations.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P103_S3	The Series A Preferred Stock qualifies as Tier 1 capital for the Company.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P104_S0	As noted previously, the Company s junior subordinated debentures represent borrowings from its unconsolidated subsidiaries that have issued an aggregate $10 million in trust-preferred securities.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P104_S1	These trust-preferred securities currently qualify for inclusion as Tier 1 capital for regulatory purposes as they do not exceed 25% of total Tier 1 capital, but are classified as long-term debt in accordance with GAAP.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P105_S0	On March 1, 2005, the Federal Reserve Board adopted a final rule that allows the continued inclusion of trust-preferred securities (and/or related subordinated debentures) in the Tier I capital of bank holding companies.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P106_S0	The following tables present the capital ratios for the Company and the Bank compared to the standards for bank holding companies and the regulatory minimum requirements for depository institutions as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 (amounts in thousands except percentage amounts).
1168455_13_ITEM7_P107_S0	Management believes that the Company and the Bank currently meet their entire capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P107_S1	The current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P107_S2	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized leverage, Tier 1 risk-based and total risk-based capital ratios of 5%, 6% and 10%, respectively, at all times.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S0	During 2012 the federal bank regulatory agencies issued joint proposed rules that implement Basel III regulatory capital reforms and changes required by the Reform Act.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S1	"Basel III" refers to two consultative documents released by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision in December 2009, the rules text released in December 2010 and loss absorbency rules issued in January 2011, which include significant changes to bank capital, leverage and liquidity requirements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S2	The proposed rules received extensive comments.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S3	In a joint press release issued in November 2012, the agencies stated that they do not expect any of the proposed rules to become effective on the original target date of January 1, 2013.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S4	Industry participants are expecting further guidance in early 2013.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P108_S5	Management has completed a preliminary assessment of the impact of the proposed rules and believes Plumas Bank's ratios would be in compliance with the requirements of the proposed rules if they were presently in effect.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P109_S0	In the normal course of business, there are various commitments outstanding to extend credits that are not reflected in the financial statements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S1	Annual review of commercial credit lines, letters of credit and ongoing monitoring of outstanding balances reduces the risk of loss associated with these commitments.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S2	As of December 31, 2012, the Company had $76.0 million in unfunded loan commitments and $110 thousand in letters of credit.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S3	This compares to $79.2 million in unfunded loan commitments and $50 thousand in letters of credit at December 31, 2011.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S4	Of the $76.0 million in unfunded loan commitments, $34.3 million and $41.7 million represented commitments to commercial and consumer customers, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S5	Of the total unfunded commitments at December 31, 2012, $33.2 million were secured by real estate, of which $7.8 million was secured by commercial real estate and $25.4 million was secured by residential real estate in the form of equity lines of credit.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S6	The commercial loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent business lines of credit, while the consumer loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent revolving credit card lines and overdraft protection lines.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P110_S7	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P111_S0	The Company leases one depository branch, two lending offices and one loan administration office and two non-branch automated teller machine locations.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P111_S1	Total rental expenses under all operating leases were $153,000 and $150,000 during the years ended December, 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P111_S2	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2013 and the last such lease expiring during 2015.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P112_S0	The Company manages its liquidity to provide the ability to generate funds to support asset growth, meet deposit withdrawals (both anticipated and unanticipated), fund customers' borrowing needs, satisfy maturity of short-term borrowings and maintain reserve requirements.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P112_S1	The Company s liquidity needs are managed using assets or liabilities, or both.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P112_S2	On the asset side, in addition to cash and due from banks, the Company maintains an investment portfolio which includes unpledged U.S. Government-sponsored agency securities that are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P112_S3	On the liability side, liquidity needs are managed by charging competitive offering rates on deposit products and the use of established lines of credit.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $98,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $191,000,000.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S2	At December 31, 2012, the Company held $1,950,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S3	At this level of stock holdings the Company can borrow up to $41,000,000.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S4	There were no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P113_S5	To borrow the $98,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,661,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S1	Total deposits were $411.5 million as of December 31, 2012, up $20.4 million, or 5%, from the December 31, 2011 balance of $391.1 million.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S2	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S3	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S4	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_13_ITEM7_P114_S5	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.

1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Shareholders Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary Quincy, California We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the "Company") as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, changes in shareholders' equity and cash flows for each of the two years in the period ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S5	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S6	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P1_S7	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_13_ITEM8_P2_S3	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the two years in the period ended December 31, 2012, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.

1168455_13_ITEM8_P3_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
