1168455_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is more likely than not that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	More likely than not is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P56_S4	Based upon the analysis of available evidence, management has determined that it is more likely than not that all deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2013 and 2012 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Net loans increased by $24.1 million, or 8%, from $310.3 million at December 31, 2012 to $334.4 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	The increase in loan balances during the twelve month period ended December 31, 2013 mostly relates to growth in the Company s automobile and commercial real estate loan portfolios.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	The Company continues to manage the mix of its loan portfolio consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financing needs of all sectors of the area it serves.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S3	Although the Company offers a broad array of financing options, it continues to concentrate its focus on small to medium sized commercial businesses.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S4	These commercial loans offer diversification as to industries and types of businesses, thus limiting material exposure in any industry concentrations.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P57_S5	The Company offers both fixed and floating rate loans and obtains collateral in the form of real property, business assets and deposit accounts, but looks to business and personal cash flows as its primary source of repayment.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	As shown in the following table the Company s largest lending categories are commercial real estate loans, equity lines of credit, agricultural loans and residential real estate loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	Construction and land development loans represented 5.3% and 5.0% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P58_S2	The construction and land development portfolio component has been identified by Management as a higher-risk loan category.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P58_S3	The quality of the construction and land development category is highly dependent on property values both in terms of the likelihood of repayment once the property is transacted by the current owner as well as the level of collateral the Company has securing the loan in the event of default.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	Loans in this category are characterized by the speculative nature of commercial and residential development properties and can include property in various stages of development from raw land to finished lots.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	The decline in these loans as a percentage of the Company s loan portfolio from over 21% at December 31, 2007 to less than 6% during the last two years reflects management s continued efforts, which began in 2009, to reduce its exposure to construction and land development loans due to the severe valuation decrease in the real estate market.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	The Company s real estate related loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate comprised 76% and 78% of the total loan portfolio at December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S3	Moreover, the business activities of the Company currently are focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta, Sierra and in Washoe County in Northern Nevada.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S4	Consequently, the results of operations and financial condition of the Company are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P59_S5	In addition, the concentration of the Company s operations in these areas of Northeastern California and Northwestern Nevada exposes it to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	The rates of interest charged on variable rate loans are set at specific increments in relation to the Company s lending rate or other indexes such as the published prime interest rate or U.S. Treasury rates and vary with changes in these indexes.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P60_S1	At December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, approximately 73% of the Company s loan portfolio was comprised of variable rate loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P60_S2	At December 31, 2013, 40% of the variable loans were at their respective floor rate.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	While real estate mortgage, commercial and consumer lending remain the foundation of the Company s historical loan mix, some changes in the mix have occurred due to the changing economic environment and the resulting change in demand for certain loan types.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	In addition, the Company remains committed to the agricultural industry in Northeastern California and will continue to pursue high quality agricultural loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P61_S2	Agricultural loans include both commercial and commercial real estate loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P61_S3	The Company s agricultural loan balances totaled $31 million at December 31, 2013 and $35 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	The following table sets forth the amounts of loans outstanding by category as of the dates indicated.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	(2) Includes agriculture real estate The following table sets forth the maturity of gross loan categories as of December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P63_S1	Also provided with respect to such loans are the amounts due after one year, classified according to sensitivity to changes in interest rates: Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company attempts to minimize credit risk through its underwriting and credit review policies.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company s credit review process includes internally prepared credit reviews as well as contracting with an outside firm to conduct periodic credit reviews.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	The Company s management and lending officers evaluate the loss exposure of classified and impaired loans on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	The Management Asset Resolution Committee (MARC) reviews the asset quality of criticized and past due loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	The Board s Loan Committee reviews the asset quality of new loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P65_S2	In management s opinion, this loan review system helps facilitate the early identification of potential criticized loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company has implemented MARC to develop an action plan to significantly reduce nonperforming loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	It consists of members of executive management and credit administration management, and the activities are governed by a formal written charter.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P67_S1	The MARC meets at least monthly and reports to the Board of Directors.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P67_S2	More specifically, a formal plan to effect repayment and/or disposition of every significant nonperforming loan relationship is developed and documented for review and on-going oversight by the MARC.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P67_S3	Some of the strategies used include but are not limited to: 1) obtaining additional collateral, 2) obtaining additional investor cash infusion, 3) sale of the promissory note to an outside party, 4) proceeding with foreclosure on the underlying collateral, and 5) legal action against borrower/guarantors to encourage settlement of debt and/or collect any deficiency balance owed.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P67_S4	Each step includes a benchmark timeline to track progress.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P68_S0	MARC also provides guidance for the maintenance and timely disposition of OREO properties; including developing financing and marketing programs to incent individuals to purchase OREO.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P69_S0	The allowance for loan losses is established through charges to earnings in the form of the provision for loan losses.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P69_S1	Loan losses are charged to and recoveries are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P69_S2	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level deemed appropriate by management to provide for known and inherent risks in the loan portfolio.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P69_S3	The adequacy of the allowance for loan losses is based upon management s continuing assessment of various factors affecting the collectability of loans; including current economic conditions, maturity of the portfolio, size of the portfolio, industry concentrations, borrower credit history, collateral, the existing allowance for loan losses, independent credit reviews, current charges and recoveries to the allowance for loan losses and the overall quality of the portfolio as determined by management, regulatory agencies, and independent credit review consultants retained by the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P70_S0	There is no precise method of predicting specific losses or amounts which may ultimately be charged off on particular segments of the loan portfolio.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P71_S0	The collectability of a loan is subjective to some degree, but must relate to the borrower s financial condition, cash flow, quality of the borrower s management expertise, collateral and guarantees, and state of the local economy.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P72_S0	Formula allocations are calculated by applying loss factors to outstanding loans with similar characteristics.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P72_S1	Loss factors are based on the Company s historical loss experience as adjusted for changes in the business cycle and may be adjusted for significant factors that, in management s judgment, affect the collectability of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P73_S0	Effective for the third quarter of 2012, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for non-impaired loans.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P73_S1	This modification incorporated historical losses from the beginning of the latest business cycle.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P73_S2	Previously we utilized historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P73_S3	This modification had the effect of increasing the required allowance by approximately $250,000 for 2012 related to the expanded historical loss period.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P73_S4	The Company believes that, given the recent trend in historical losses, it was prudent to increase the period examined and that a full business cycle was the appropriate period.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	The discretionary allocation is based upon management s evaluation of various loan segment conditions that are not directly measured in the determination of the formula and specific allowances.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P74_S1	The conditions may include, but are not limited to, general economic and business conditions affecting the key lending areas of the Company, credit quality trends, collateral values, loan volumes and concentrations, and other business conditions.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	The following table provides certain information for the years indicated with respect to the Company s allowance for loan losses as well as charge-off and recovery activity.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $1.4 million down $950 thousand from the $2.4 million provision recorded during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	Net charge-offs totaled $1.6 million during the year ended December 31, 2013 down $2 million from $3.6 million during 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S2	Net charge-offs as a percentage of average loans decreased from 1.18% during 2012 to 0.49% during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S3	The following table provides a breakdown of the allowance for loan losses: The allowance for loan losses totaled $5.5 million at December 31, 2013 and $5.7 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S4	Specific reserves related to impaired loans decreased from $1.2 million at December 31, 2012 to $629 thousand at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S5	At least quarterly the Company evaluates each specific reserve and if it determines that the loss represented by the specific reserve is uncollectable it records a charge-off for the uncollectable portion.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S6	General reserves increased by $388 thousand to $4.9 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S7	Related to the decline in specific reserves, the allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans decreased from 1.80% at December 31, 2012 to 1.63% at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P76_S8	The percentage of general reserves to unimpaired loans decreased slightly from 1.52% at December 31, 2012 to 1.49% at December 31, 2013 primarily related to improvement in the overall credit quality of the portfolio including reductions in historical net charge-offs and declines in the volume of classified loan balances.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P77_S0	The Company places loans 90 days or more past due on nonaccrual status unless the loan is well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P77_S1	A loan is considered to be in the process of collection if, based on a probable specific event, it is expected that the loan will be repaid or brought current.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P77_S2	Generally, this collection period would not exceed 90 days.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P78_S0	When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status the Company s general policy is to reverse and charge against current income previously accrued but unpaid interest.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P78_S1	Interest income on such loans is subsequently recognized only to the extent that cash is received and future collection of principal is deemed by management to be probable.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P78_S2	Where the collectability of the principal or interest on a loan is considered to be doubtful by management, it is placed on nonaccrual status prior to becoming 90 days delinquent.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P78_S3	Impaired loans are measured based on the present value of the expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P78_S4	The amount of impaired loans is not directly comparable to the amount of nonperforming loans disclosed later in this section.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P79_S0	The primary difference between impaired loans and nonperforming loans is that impaired loan recognition considers not only loans 90 days or more past due, restructured loans and nonaccrual loans but also may include identified problem loans other than delinquent loans where it is considered probable that we will not collect all amounts due to us (including both principal and interest) in accordance with the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P80_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P82_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P83_S0	Loans restructured and in compliance with modified terms totaled $7.6 million, $9.3 million, $8.4 million, $2.0 million and $3.4 million at December 31, 2013, 2012, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P83_S1	For additional information related to restructured loans see Note 6 of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S0	The following table sets forth the amount of the Company s nonperforming assets as of the dates indicated.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S1	Nonperforming loans at December 31, 2013 were $5.5 million, a decrease of $8.2 million from the $13.7 million balance at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S2	The decline of $8.2 million includes $3.8 million in loans transferred to OREO, charge-offs and principal repayments on nonperforming loans partially offset by $2.0 million in additional loans placed on nonperforming status.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S3	Principal repayments on nonperforming loans include payments from the SBA related to $2.4 million in guaranteed portions of loans on nonaccrual at December 31 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S4	Included in the $3.8 million in loans transferred to OREO was a land development loan with a principal balance of $3.0 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S5	During 2013 a $0.7 million charge-off was recorded on this loan while the remaining balance of $2.3 million was transferred to OREO.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S6	Specific reserves on nonaccrual loans totaled $578 thousand at December 31, 2013 and $976 thousand at December 31, 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P84_S7	Performing loans past due thirty to eighty-nine days decreased from $2.8 million at December 31, 2012 to $1.5 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S0	A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S1	Total substandard loans decreased by $11.1 million from $18.6 million at December 31, 2012 to $7.5 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S2	Loans classified as watch decreased as well from $6.7 million at December 31, 2012 to $5.8 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S3	At December 31, 2013, $2.9 million of performing loans were classified as substandard.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S4	Further deterioration in the credit quality of individual performing substandard loans or other adverse circumstances could result in the need to place these loans on nonperforming status.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S5	At December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, the Company s recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $9.8 million and $18.8 million, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S6	The specific allowance for loan losses related to impaired loans totaled $629 thousand and $1.2 million at December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P85_S7	Additionally, $0.7 million has been charged off against the impaired loans at December 31, 2013 and $3.0 million at December 31 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P86_S0	It is the policy of management to make additions to the allowance for loan losses so that it remains appropriate to absorb the probable incurred losses in the portfolio.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P86_S1	Management believes that the allowance at December 31, 2013 is appropriate.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P86_S2	However, the determination of the amount of the allowance is judgmental and subject to economic conditions which cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P86_S3	Accordingly, the Company cannot predict whether charge-offs of loans in excess of the allowance may occur in future periods.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S0	OREO represents real property acquired by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S1	Repossessed assets include vehicles and other commercial assets acquired under agreements with delinquent borrowers.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S2	Repossessed assets and OREO are carried at fair market value, less selling costs.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S3	OREO holdings represented twenty-six properties totaling $6.4 million at December 31, 2013 and forty properties totaling $5.3 million at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S4	The largest property in OREO is a land development property with an OREO value of $2.3 million representing 36% of the total OREO balance.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S5	Nonperforming assets as a percentage of total assets were 2.33% at December 31, 2013 and 3.98% at December 31, 2012.

1168455_14_ITEM7_P87_S8	Included in the $90.4 million at December 31, 2013 were $89.0 million in securities of U.S. Government-sponsored agencies and six municipal securities totaling $1.4 million.

1168455_14_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company classifies its investment securities as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.

1168455_14_ITEM7_P88_S2	Securities classified as available-for-sale may be sold to implement the Company s asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.

1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S0	During 2013 we have experienced strong core deposit growth and have benefited from the closing of two branches of a large national bank in our service area.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S1	Total deposits increased by $37.9 million from $411 million at December 31, 2012 to $449 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S2	The increase in deposits included $19.2 million in demand deposits and $27.3 million in savings and money market accounts.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S3	Time deposits declined by $7.9 million, much of which we attribute to migration into other types of deposits given the low rates and lack of liquidity associated with time deposits.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S4	Interest-bearing transaction accounts (NOW) declined by $0.7 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S5	The Company continues to manage the mix of its deposits consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financial needs of its customers.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P94_S6	The following table shows the distribution of deposits by type at December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P95_S0	Deposits represent the Bank s primary source of funds.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P95_S1	Deposits are primarily core deposits in that they are demand, savings and time deposits generated from local businesses and individuals.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P95_S2	These sources are considered to be relatively stable, long-term relationships thereby enhancing steady growth of the deposit base without major fluctuations in overall deposit balances.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P96_S0	The Company experiences, to a small degree, some seasonality with the slower growth period between November through April, and the higher growth period from May through October.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P96_S1	In order to assist in meeting any funding demands, the Company maintains a secured borrowing arrangement with the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P96_S2	There were no brokered deposits at December 31, 2013 or 2012.
