1168455_14_ITEM7_P97_S1	Time deposits of $100,000 or more are generally from the Company s local business and individual customer base.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P97_S2	The potential impact on the Company s liquidity from the withdrawal of these deposits is discussed at the Company s asset and liability management committee meetings, and is considered to be minimal.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $104,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $193,000,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S2	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, the Company held $2,226,000 and $1,950,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S3	Based on this level of stock holdings at December 31, 2013, the Company can borrow up to $47,400,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S4	To borrow the $104,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,660,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S5	There were no outstanding borrowings under this agreement at December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P98_S6	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with two of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $11 million and $10 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P99_S0	On October 24, 2013 the Bancorp issued a $3 million promissory note (the Note ) payable to an unrelated commercial bank.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P99_S1	The note bears interest at the U.S. Prime Rate plus three-quarters percent per annum, 4.00% at December 31, 2013, has a term of 18 months and is secured by 100 shares of Plumas Bank stock representing the Company s 100% ownership interest in Plumas Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P99_S2	Interest expense related to this note for the year ended December 31, 2013 totaled $23,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P100_S0	Under the Note the Bank is required to maintain specified levels of capital and to meet or exceed certain capital and asset quality ratios.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P100_S1	The Bank was in compliance with all such requirements at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P101_S0	In 2011 Plumas Bank introduced a new product for their larger business customers which use repurchase agreements as an alternative to interest-bearing deposits.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P101_S1	The balance in this product at December 31, 2013 was $9.1 million an increase of $1.7 million from the December 31, 2012 balance of $7.4 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P101_S2	Interest paid on this product is similar to that which is paid on the Bank s premium money market account; however, these are not deposits and are not FDIC insured.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P102_S0	On April 15, 2013 the Bancorp issued $7.5 million in subordinated debentures ( subordinated debt ).
1168455_14_ITEM7_P102_S1	The subordinated debt was issued to an unrelated third-party ( Lender ) pursuant to a subordinated debenture purchase agreement, subordinated debenture note, and stock purchase warrant.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P103_S0	The subordinated debt agreement provides that in the event of default with respect to the subordinated debt, the Bancorp will be subject to certain restrictions on the payment of dividends and distributions to shareholders, repurchase or redemption of the Bancorp s securities and payment on certain debts or guarantees.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P103_S1	The subordinated debenture agreement also provides that in the event of default, Lender will have the right to appoint a director to the Bancorp s board of directors and/or the Plumas Bank board in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P104_S0	The interest only payments on the subordinated debt are based on an interest rate of 7.5% per annum.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P104_S1	Principal repayment is required at the conclusion of an 8 year term with no prepayment allowed during the first two years.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P105_S0	Issuance of the subordinated debt was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant (the Lender Warrant ) to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P105_S1	Under current capital guidelines the subordinated debt qualifies as Tier 2 capital.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P105_S2	Interest expense related to the subordinated debt for the year ended December 31, 2013 totaled $541,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P106_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and II are Connecticut business trusts formed by the Company with capital of $298,000 and $159,000, respectively, for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities fully and unconditionally guaranteed by the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P106_S1	Under applicable regulatory guidance, the amount of trust preferred securities that is eligible as Tier 1 capital is limited to twenty-five percent of the Company s Tier 1 capital, as defined, on a pro forma basis.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P106_S2	At December 31, 2013, all of the trust preferred securities that have been issued qualify as Tier 1 capital.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S0	During 2002, Plumas Statutory Trust I issued 6,000 Floating Rate Capital Trust Pass-Through Securities ( Trust Preferred Securities ), with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $6,000,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S1	During 2005, Plumas Statutory Trust II issued 4,000 Trust Preferred Securities with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $4,000,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S2	The entire proceeds were invested by Trust I in the amount of $6,186,000 and Trust II in the amount of $4,124,000 in Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures (the Subordinated Debentures ) issued by the Company, with identical maturity, repricing and payment terms as the Trust Preferred Securities.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S3	The Subordinated Debentures represent the sole assets of Trusts I and II.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S4	I s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 26, 2032, bear a current interest rate of 3.65% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S5	Trust II s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 28, 2035, bear a current interest rate of 1.72% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S6	The interest rate of the Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust I adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S7	The Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust II adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S8	Both Trusts I and II have the option to defer payment of the distributions for a period of up to five years, as long as the Company is not in default on the payment of interest on the Subordinated Debentures.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S9	Interest expense recognized by the Company for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 related to the junior subordinated debentures was $313,000, $344,000 and $326,000, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S10	Capital Resources Shareholders equity decreased by $11.2 million from $41.8 million at December 31, 2012 to $30.6 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S11	This decrease resulted from the redemption of the preferred stock, payment of preferred stock dividends and an increase in other comprehensive loss.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S12	These items were partially offset by earnings during the year, a $565 discount on redemption of the preferred stock and an increase in common stock totaling $156 thousand.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S13	Preferred stock declined by $11.8 million and during 2013 we paid $2 million in dividends on preferred stock which includes dividends that were deferred during the period from May of 2010 until May of 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S14	Other comprehensive loss relates to unrealized losses on available-for-sale investment securities, net of tax, which increased by $1.5 million from an unrealized gain of $329 thousand at December 31, 2012 to an unrealized loss of $1.2 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P107_S15	The increase in common stock includes $318,000 related to the issuance of a warrant to purchase 300,000 shares of stock at $5.25, $34 thousand related to the exercise of stock options representing 11,400 shares and stock based compensation expense of $38,000 partially offset by the repurchase of the outstanding warrant to purchase 237,712 shares of common stock at a cost of $234 thousand.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P108_S0	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P108_S1	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P109_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_14_ITEM7_P109_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P110_S0	Banking regulations limit the amount of dividends that may be paid without prior approval of regulatory agencies.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P110_S1	No common cash dividends were paid during the last five years and none are anticipated to be paid in 2014.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P111_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P112_S0	The Company uses a variety of measures to evaluate its capital adequacy, with risk-based capital ratios calculated separately for the Company and the Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P112_S1	Management reviews these capital measurements on a monthly basis and takes appropriate action to ensure that they are within established internal and external guidelines.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P113_S0	The FDIC has promulgated risk-based capital guidelines for all state non-member banks such as the Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P113_S1	These guidelines establish a risk-adjusted ratio relating capital to different categories of assets and off-balance sheet exposures.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P113_S2	There are two categories of capital under the guidelines: Tier 1 capital includes common stockholders equity, and qualifying trust-preferred securities (including notes payable to unconsolidated special purpose entities that issue trust-preferred securities), less goodwill and certain other deductions, notably the unrealized net gains or losses (after tax adjustments) on available-for-sale investment securities carried at fair market value; Tier 2 capital can include qualifying subordinated debt and the allowance for loan losses, subject to certain limitations.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P113_S3	The Series A Preferred Stock qualifies as Tier 1 capital for the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P114_S0	As noted previously, the Company s junior subordinated debentures represent borrowings from its unconsolidated subsidiaries that have issued an aggregate $10 million in trust-preferred securities.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P114_S1	These trust-preferred securities currently qualify for inclusion as Tier 1 capital for regulatory purposes as they do not exceed 25% of total Tier 1 capital, but are classified as long-term debt in accordance with GAAP.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P115_S0	On March 1, 2005, the Federal Reserve Board adopted a final rule that allows the continued inclusion of trust-preferred securities (and/or related subordinated debentures) in the Tier I capital of bank holding companies.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P116_S0	The following tables present the capital ratios for the Company and the Bank compared to the standards for bank holding companies and the regulatory minimum requirements for depository institutions as of December 31, 2013 and 2012 (amounts in thousands except percentage amounts).
1168455_14_ITEM7_P117_S0	Management believes that the Company and the Bank currently meet their entire capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P117_S1	The current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P117_S2	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized leverage, Tier 1 risk-based and total risk-based capital ratios of 5%, 6% and 10%, respectively, at all times.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S0	On July 2, 2013, the FRB approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S1	Under the final rules, minimum requirements will increase for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S2	The rules include a new common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets ratio of 4.5% and a common equity Tier 1 capital conservation buffer of 2.5% of risk-weighted assets.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S3	The final rules also raise the minimum ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets from 4.0% to 6.0% and require a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0%.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S4	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S5	On July 9, 2013, the FDIC also approved, as an interim final rule, the regulatory capital requirements for U.S. banks, following the actions of the FRB.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S6	The FDIC s rule is identical in substance to the final rules issued by the FRB.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S7	The phase-in period for the final rules will begin for the Company on January 1, 2015, with full compliance with all of the final rule s requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P118_S8	Management believes that as of December 31, 2013, the Company s capital levels would remain well-capitalized under the new rules.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P119_S0	In the normal course of business, there are various commitments outstanding to extend credits that are not reflected in the financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S1	Annual review of commercial credit lines, letters of credit and ongoing monitoring of outstanding balances reduces the risk of loss associated with these commitments.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S2	As of December 31, 2013, the Company had $84.2 million in unfunded loan commitments and $60 thousand in letters of credit.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S3	This compares to $76.0 million in unfunded loan commitments and $110 thousand in letters of credit at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S4	Of the $84.2 million in unfunded loan commitments, $42.8 million and $41.4 million represented commitments to commercial and consumer customers, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S5	Of the total unfunded commitments at December 31, 2013, $39.0 million were secured by real estate, of which $12.6 million was secured by commercial real estate and $26.4 million was secured by residential real estate in the form of equity lines of credit.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S6	The commercial loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent business lines of credit, while the consumer loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent revolving credit card lines and overdraft protection lines.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P120_S7	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P121_S0	The Company leases one depository branch, one lending office and one loan administration office and two non-branch automated teller machine locations.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P121_S1	Total rental expenses under all operating leases were $154,000 and $153,000 during the years ended December, 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P121_S2	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2015 and the last such lease expiring during 2016.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P122_S0	The Company manages its liquidity to provide the ability to generate funds to support asset growth, meet deposit withdrawals (both anticipated and unanticipated), fund customers borrowing needs, satisfy maturity of short-term borrowings and maintain reserve requirements.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P122_S1	The Company s liquidity needs are managed using assets or liabilities, or both.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P122_S2	On the asset side, in addition to cash and due from banks, the Company maintains an investment portfolio which includes unpledged U.S. Government-sponsored agency securities that are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P122_S3	On the liability side, liquidity needs are managed by charging competitive offering rates on deposit products and the use of established lines of credit.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $104,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $193,000,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S2	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, the Company held $2,226,000 and $1,950,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S3	Based on this level of stock holdings at December 31, 2013, the Company can borrow up to $47,400,000.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S4	To borrow the $104,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,660,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S5	There were no outstanding borrowings under this agreement at December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P123_S6	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with two of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $11 million and $10 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P124_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P124_S1	Total deposits were $449 million as of December 31, 2013, up $37.9 million, or 9%, from the December 31, 2012 balance of $411 million.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P125_S0	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P125_S1	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, Federal Home Loan Bank advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P125_S2	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_14_ITEM7_P125_S3	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.
1168455_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	required to provide the information required by this item.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	Bancorp and subsidiary, and report of the independent registered public accounting firm are included in the Annual Report of Plumas Bancorp to its shareholders for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Shareholders Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary Quincy, California We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, changes in shareholders equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S5	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S6	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P1_S7	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P2_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2013, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	THE BUSINESS OF PLUMAS BANCORP During 2002, Plumas Bancorp (the Company ) was incorporated as a bank holding company for the purpose of acquiring Plumas Bank (the Bank ) in a one bank holding company reorganization.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P8_S1	This corporate structure gives the Company and the Bank greater flexibility in terms of operation, expansion and diversification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust I ( Trust I ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 26, 2002.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust II ( Trust II ) for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 28, 2005.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	The Bank operates eleven branches in California, including branches in Alturas, Chester, Fall River Mills, Greenville, Kings Beach, Portola, Quincy, Redding, Susanville, Tahoe City, and Truckee.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	The Bank s administrative headquarters is in Quincy, California.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	In addition, the Bank operates a loan administrative office in Reno, Nevada and a lending office specializing in government-guaranteed lending in Auburn, California.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	The Bank s primary source of revenue is generated from providing loans to customers who are predominately small and middle market businesses and individuals residing in the surrounding areas.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	REGULATORY MATTERS On February 15, 2012, the Bank received notice from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the California Department of Financial Institutions ( DFI ) that the Consent Order with the FDIC and the DFI which was effective on March 16, 2011 had been terminated.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	Effective February 8, 2012, the Bank entered into an informal agreement with the FDIC and DFI which, among other things, requested that the Bank continue to maintain a Tier 1 Leverage Capital Ratio of 9% which is in excess of that required for well capitalized institutions and continue to reduce its level of classified asset balances that were outstanding as of September 30, 2011 to not more than 50% of Tier 1 Capital plus the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P12_S2	At December 31, 2012 this ratio was 32% and the Bank s Tier 1 Leverage Capital Ratio was 10.4%.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P12_S3	The FDIC and DFI terminated the informal agreement effective January 24, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P12_S4	Effective July 1, 2013, the California Department of Corporations and the DFI merged to form the Department of Business Oversight ( DBO ).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	On July 28, 2011 the Company entered into an agreement with the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco (the FRB Agreement ).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P13_S1	Under the terms of the FRB Agreement, Plumas Bancorp agreed to take certain actions that were designed to maintain its financial soundness so that it may continue to serve as a source of strength to the Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P13_S2	Among other things, the FRB Agreement required prior written approval related to the payment or taking of dividends and distributions, making any distributions of interest, principal or other sums on subordinated debentures or trust preferred securities, incurrence of debt, and the purchase or redemption of stock.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P13_S3	On April 19, 2013 the Company received notice that the FRB Agreement had been terminated.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the consolidated accounts of its wholly-owned subsidiary, Plumas Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P14_S2	Plumas Statutory Trust I and Trust II are not consolidated into the Company s consolidated financial statements and, accordingly, are accounted for under the equity method.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P14_S3	The Company s investment in Trust I of $298,000 and Trust II of $159,000 are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P14_S4	The junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures issued and guaranteed by the Company and held by Trust I and Trust II are reflected as debt on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	The accounting and reporting policies of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary conform with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America and prevailing practices within the banking industry.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P15_S1	Certain reclassifications have been made to prior years balances to conform to the classifications used in 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P15_S2	These reclassifications had no impact on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or net change in cash and cash equivalents.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	Segment Information Management has determined that since all of the banking products and services offered by the Company are available in each branch of the Bank, all branches are located within the same economic environment and management does not allocate resources based on the performance of different lending or transaction activities, it is appropriate to aggregate the Bank branches and report them as a single operating segment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	No customer accounts for more than 10 percent of revenues for the Company or the Bank.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	Use of Estimates To prepare financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America management makes estimates and assumptions based on available information.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	These estimates and assumptions affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and the disclosures provided, and actual results could differ.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P18_S2	The allowance for loan losses, loan servicing rights, deferred tax assets, and fair values of financial instruments are particularly subject to change.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, cash and due from banks and Federal funds sold are considered to be cash equivalents.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	Generally, Federal funds are sold for one day periods.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P19_S2	Cash held with other federally insured institutions in excess of FDIC limits as of December 31, 2013 was $7.3 million.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P19_S3	Net cash flows are reported for customer loans and deposit transactions and repurchase agreements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES (Continued) Investment Securities Investments are classified into one of the following categories:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	Available-for-sale securities reported at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported, net of taxes, as accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) within shareholders equity.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Held-to-maturity securities, which management has the positive intent and ability to hold, reported at amortized cost, adjusted for the accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as held-to-maturity.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P22_S2	Management determines the appropriate classification of its investments at the time of purchase and may only change the classification in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P22_S3	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as trading and gains or losses on the sale of securities are computed on the specific identification method.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P22_S4	Interest earned on investment securities is reported in interest income, net of applicable adjustments for accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums accounted for by the level yield method with no pre-payment anticipated.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	An investment security is impaired when its carrying value is greater than its fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S1	Investment securities that are impaired are evaluated on at least a quarterly basis and more frequently when economic or market conditions warrant such an evaluation to determine whether such a decline in their fair value is other than temporary.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S2	Management utilizes criteria such as the magnitude and duration of the decline and the intent and ability of the Company to retain its investment in the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery in fair value, in addition to the reasons underlying the decline, to determine whether the loss in value is other than temporary.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S3	The term other than temporary is not intended to indicate that the decline is permanent, but indicates that the prospects for a near-term recovery of value is not necessarily favorable, or that there is a lack of evidence to support a realizable value equal to or greater than the carrying value of the investment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S4	Once a decline in value is determined to be other than temporary, and management does not intend to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery, only the portion of the impairment loss representing credit exposure is recognized as a charge to earnings, with the balance recognized as a charge to other comprehensive income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P23_S5	If management intends to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the security before recovering its forecasted cost, the entire impairment loss is recognized as a charge to earnings.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES (Continued) Investment in Federal Home Loan Bank Stock As a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) System, the Bank is required to maintain an investment in the capital stock of the FHLB.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	The investment is carried at cost classified as a restricted security, and periodically evaluated for impairment based on ultimate recovery of par value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P24_S2	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, FHLB stock totaled $2,226,000 and $1,950,000, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P24_S3	On the consolidated balance sheet, FHLB stock is included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	Loans Held for Sale, Loan Sales and Servicing Included in the loan portfolio are loans which are 75% to 85% guaranteed by the Small Business Administration (SBA), US Department of Agriculture Rural Business Cooperative Service (RBS) and Farm Services Agency (FSA).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	The guaranteed portion of these loans may be sold to a third party, with the Bank retaining the unguaranteed portion.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S2	The Company can receive a premium in excess of the adjusted carrying value of the loan at the time of sale.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S3	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 the Company had $2,800,000 and $3,367,000, respectively in government guaranteed loans held for sale.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S4	Loans held for sale are recorded at the lower of cost or fair value and therefore may be reported at fair value on a non-recurring basis.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S5	The fair values for loans held for sale are based on either observable transactions of similar instruments or formally committed loan sale prices.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P25_S6	Government guaranteed loans with unpaid balances of $70,212,000 and $58,696,000 were being serviced for others at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	The Company accounts for the transfer and servicing of financial assets based on the fair value of financial and servicing assets it controls and liabilities it has assumed, derecognizes financial assets when control has been surrendered, and derecognizes liabilities when extinguished.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	Servicing rights acquired through 1) a purchase or 2) the origination of loans which are sold or securitized with servicing rights retained are recognized as separate assets or liabilities.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	Servicing assets or liabilities are recorded at fair value and are subsequently amortized in proportion to and over the period of the related net servicing income or expense.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S3	Servicing rights are evaluated for impairment based upon the fair value of the rights as compared to carrying amount.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S4	Impairment is determined by stratifying rights into groupings based on predominant risk characteristics, such as interest rate, loan type and investor type.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S5	Impairment is recognized through a valuation allowance for an individual grouping, to the extent that fair value is less than the carrying amount.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P26_S6	If the Company later determines that all or a portion of the impairment no longer exists for a particular grouping, a reduction of the allowance may be recorded as an increase to income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Changes in valuation allowances are reported with non-interest income on the statement of income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	The fair values of servicing rights are subject to significant fluctuations as a result of changes in estimated and actual prepayment speeds and default rates and losses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company s investment in the loan is allocated between the retained portion of the loan, the servicing asset, the interest-only (IO) strip, and the sold portion of the loan based on their fair values on the date the loan is sold.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	The gain on the sold portion of the loan is recognized as income at the time of sale.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S2	The carrying value of the retained portion of the loan is discounted based on the estimated value of a comparable non-guaranteed loan.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S3	The servicing asset is recognized and amortized over the estimated life of the related loan.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S4	Assets (accounted for as IO strips) are recorded at the fair value of the difference between note rates and rates paid to purchasers (the interest spread) and contractual servicing fees, if applicable.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S5	IO strips are carried at fair value with gains or losses recorded as a component of shareholders equity, similar to available-for-sale investment securities.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P28_S6	Significant future prepayments of these loans will result in the recognition of additional amortization of related servicing assets and an adjustment to the carrying value of related IO strips.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Loans Loans that management has the intent and ability to hold for foreseeable future or until maturity or payoff are reported at the principal balance outstanding, net of purchase premiums or discounts, deferred loan fees and costs, and an allowance for loan losses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	Loans, if any, that are transferred from loans held for sale are carried at the lower of principal balance or market value at the date of transfer, adjusted for accretion of discounts.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P29_S2	Interest is accrued daily based upon outstanding loan balances.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P29_S3	However, when, in the opinion of management, loans are considered to be impaired and the future collectability of interest and principal is in serious doubt, loans are placed on nonaccrual status and the accrual of interest income is suspended.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	Any interest accrued but unpaid is charged against income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	Payments received are applied to reduce principal to the extent necessary to ensure collection.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	A loan is moved to non-accrual status in accordance with the Company s policy, typically after 90 days of non-payment unless well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	Subsequent payments on these loans, or payments received on nonaccrual loans for which the ultimate collectability of principal is not in doubt, are applied first to earned but unpaid interest and then to principal.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	Loan origination fees, commitment fees, direct loan origination costs and purchased premiums and discounts on loans are deferred and recognized as an adjustment of yield, to be amortized to interest income over the contractual term of the loan.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	The unamortized balance of deferred fees and costs is reported as a component of net loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company may acquire loans through a business combination or a purchase for which differences may exist between the contractual cash flows and the cash flows expected to be collected due, at least in part, to credit quality.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	When the Company acquires such loans, the yield that may be accreted (accretable yield) is limited to the excess of the Company s estimate of undiscounted cash flows expected to be collected over the Company s initial investment in the loan.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S2	The excess of contractual cash flows over cash flows expected to be collected may not be recognized as an adjustment to yield, loss, or a valuation allowance.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S3	Subsequent increases in cash flows expected to be collected generally should be recognized prospectively through adjustment of the loan s yield over its remaining life.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S4	Decreases in cash flows expected to be collected should be recognized as an impairment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S5	The Company may not carry over or create a valuation allowance in the initial accounting for loans acquired under these circumstances.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P33_S6	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, there were no such loans being accounted for under this policy.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of probable incurred credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	Credit exposures determined to be uncollectible are charged against the allowance.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	Cash received on previously charged-off amounts is recorded as a recovery to the allowance.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are not impaired but collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	A loan is considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect all amounts due, including principal and interest, according to the contractual terms of the original agreement.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	Loans determined to be impaired are individually evaluated for impairment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P37_S2	When a loan is impaired, the Company measures impairment based on the present value of expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate, except that as a practical expedient, it may measure impairment based on a loan s observable market price, or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	A loan is collateral dependent if the repayment of the loan is expected to be provided solely by the underlying collateral.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	The determination of the general reserve for loans that are not impaired is based on estimates made by management, to include, but not limited to, consideration of historical losses by portfolio segment from January 1, 2008 (the beginning of the latest business cycle as determined by management) to the most current balance sheet date, internal asset classifications, and qualitative factors to include economic trends in the Company s service areas, industry experience and trends, geographic concentrations, estimated collateral values, the Company s underwriting policies, the character of the loan portfolio, and probable incurred losses inherent in the portfolio taken as a whole.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S1	During 2012, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for non-impaired loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S2	This modification incorporated historical losses from the beginning of the latest business cycle.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S3	Previously we utilized historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S4	This modification had the effect of increasing the required allowance related to the expanded historical loss period by $250,000.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P42_S5	The Company believes that, given the recent trend in historical losses, it was prudent to increase the period examined and that a full business cycle was the appropriate period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company maintains a separate allowance for each portfolio segment (loan type).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P43_S1	These portfolio segments include commercial, agricultural, real estate construction (including land and development loans), commercial real estate mortgage, residential mortgage, home equity loans, automobile loans and other loans primarily consisting of consumer installment loans and credit card receivables.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P43_S2	The allowance for loan losses attributable to each portfolio segment, which includes both impaired loans and loans that are not impaired, is combined to determine the Company s overall allowance, and is included as a component of loans on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	The Company assigns a risk rating to all loans, with the exception of automobile and other loans and periodically, but not less than annually, performs detailed reviews of all such loans over $100,000 to identify credit risks and to assess the overall collectability of the portfolio.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P44_S1	These risk ratings are also subject to examination by independent specialists engaged by the Company and the Company s regulators.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	During these internal reviews, management monitors and analyzes the financial condition of borrowers and guarantors, trends in the industries in which borrowers operate and the fair values of collateral securing these loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	These credit quality indicators are used to assign a risk rating to each individual loan.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	The risk ratings can be grouped into five major categories, defined as follows: Pass A pass loan is a strong credit with no existing or known potential weaknesses deserving of management s close attention.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P47_S1	Watch A Watch loan has potential weaknesses that deserve management s close attention.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P47_S2	If left uncorrected, these potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the repayment prospects for the loan or in the Company s credit position at some future date.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	Watch loans are not adversely classified and do not expose the Company to sufficient risk to warrant adverse classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	Substandard A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	Loans classified as substandard have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	Well defined weaknesses include a project s lack of marketability, inadequate cash flow or collateral support, failure to complete construction on time or the project s failure to fulfill economic expectations.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Company will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P50_S3	Doubtful Loans classified doubtful have all the weaknesses inherent in those classified as substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P50_S4	Loss Loans classified as loss are considered uncollectible and charged off immediately.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	The general reserve component of the allowance for loan losses associated with loans collectively evaluated for impairment also consists of reserve factors that are based on management s assessment of the following for each portfolio segment: (1) historical losses and (2) other qualitative factors, including inherent credit risk.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P51_S1	These reserve factors are inherently subjective and are driven by the repayment risk associated with each portfolio segment described on the next page.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Commercial Commercial loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than real estate portfolio segments because these loans are generally underwritten to existing cash flows of operating businesses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P52_S1	Debt coverage is provided by business cash flows and economic trends influenced by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	Agricultural Loans secured by crop production and livestock are especially vulnerable to two risk factors that are largely outside the control of Company and borrowers: commodity prices and weather conditions.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	The degree of risk in residential real estate lending depends primarily on the loan amount in relation to collateral value, the interest rate and the borrower s ability to repay in an orderly fashion.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	These loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S4	Real estate Commercial Commercial real estate mortgage loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments, except land and construction loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S5	Adverse economic developments or an overbuilt market impact commercial real estate projects and may result in troubled loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S6	Trends in vacancy rates of commercial properties impact the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P54_S7	High vacancy rates reduce operating revenues and the ability for properties to produce sufficient cash flow to service debt obligations.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	Real estate Construction and Land Development Construction and land development loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P55_S1	A major risk arises from the necessity to complete projects within specified cost and time lines.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P55_S2	Trends in the construction industry significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as demand drives construction activity.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P55_S3	In addition, trends in real estate values significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as property values determine the economic viability of construction projects.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	Automobile An automobile loan portfolio is usually comprised of a large number of smaller loans scheduled to be amortized over a specific period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P56_S1	Most automobile loans are made directly for consumer purchases, but business vehicles may also be included.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P56_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P56_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	Other Other loans primarily consist of consumer and credit card loans and are similar in nature to automobile loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	Although management believes the allowance to be adequate, ultimate losses may vary from its estimates.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S1	At least quarterly, the Board of Directors and management review the adequacy of the allowance, including consideration of the relative risks in the portfolio, current economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S2	If the Board of Directors and management determine that changes are warranted based on those reviews, the allowance is adjusted.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S3	In addition, the Company s primary regulators, the FDIC and DBO, as an integral part of their examination process, review the adequacy of the allowance.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S4	These regulatory agencies may require additions to the allowance based on their judgment about information available at the time of their examinations.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P58_S5	The Company also maintains a separate allowance for off-balance-sheet commitments.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	Management estimates anticipated losses using historical data and utilization assumptions.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S1	The allowance for these commitments totaled $141,000 at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively and is included in accrued interest payable and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S2	Other Real Estate Other real estate owned relates to real estate acquired in full or partial settlement of loan obligations, which was $6,399,000 ($9,065,000 less a valuation allowance of $2,666,000) at December 31, 2013 and $5,295,000 ($8,517,000 less a valuation allowance of $3,222,000) at December 31, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S3	Proceeds from sales of other real estate owned totaled $2,404,000, $3,714,000 and $4,937,000 for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2013 the Company recorded a gain on sale of other real estate owned of $171,000.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 the Company recorded a loss on sale of other real estate owned of $16,000 and $606,000, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S6	Other real estate owned is initially recorded at fair value less cost to sell when acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S7	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S8	The allowance is established through a provision for losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S9	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are also recorded in other expenses as incurred.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P59_S10	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	Intangible assets consist of core deposit intangibles related to branch acquisitions and are amortized using the straight-line method over ten years.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P60_S1	These assets were fully amortized as of December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P60_S2	The Company evaluates the recoverability and remaining useful life annually to determine whether events or circumstances warrant a revision to the intangible asset or the remaining period of amortization.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P60_S3	There were no such events or circumstances in 2013 or 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	Premises and Equipment Premises and equipment are carried at cost.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	Depreciation is determined using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P62_S1	The useful lives of premises are estimated to be twenty to thirty years.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P62_S2	The useful lives of furniture, fixtures and equipment are estimated to be two to ten years.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the life of the asset or the life of the related lease, whichever is shorter.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P63_S1	When assets are sold or otherwise disposed of, the cost and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts, and any resulting gain or loss is recognized in income for the period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	The cost of maintenance and repairs is charged to expense as incurred.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	The Company evaluates premises and equipment for financial impairment as events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be fully recoverable.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P66_S0	The Company has purchased life insurance policies on certain key executives.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	Bank owned life insurance is recorded at the amount that can be realized under the insurance contract at the balance sheet date, which is the cash surrender value adjusted for other charges or other amounts due that are probable at settlement.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	Income Taxes The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P68_S1	Income tax expense is the total of current year income tax due or refundable and the change in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P68_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P68_S3	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are adjusted for the effects of changes in tax laws and rates on the date of enactment.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P68_S4	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S0	When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S5	Interest expense and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits, if any, are classified as income tax expense in the consolidated income statement.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P70_S6	There have been no significant changes to unrecognized tax benefits or accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P71_S0	Basic earnings per share (EPS), which excludes dilution, is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders (net income plus discount on redemption of preferred stock less preferred dividends and accretion) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P71_S1	Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P71_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted EPS.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	Comprehensive Income Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P72_S1	Other comprehensive income includes unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale which are also recognized as separate components of equity.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P72_S2	There were no sales of available for sale investment securities during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P72_S3	The amount reclassified out of other accumulated comprehensive income relating to realized gains on securities available for sale was $403,000 and $666,000 for 2012 and 2011, with the related tax effect of $167,000 and $276,000 respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P73_S0	Banking regulations require maintaining certain capital levels and may limit the dividend paid by the bank to the holding company or by the holding company to shareholders.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments Fair values of financial instruments are estimated using relevant market information and other assumptions, as more fully disclosed in a separate note.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P74_S1	Fair value estimates involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment regarding interest rates, credit risk, prepayments, and other factors, especially in the absence of broad markets for particular items.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P74_S2	Changes in assumptions or in market conditions could significantly affect these estimates.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Compensation expense related to the Company s Stock Option Plan, net of related tax (expense)/benefit, recorded in 2013, 2012 and 2011 totaled $37,000, $93,000 and $(38,000) or $0.01, $0.02 and $(0.01) per diluted share, respectively.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	Compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period on a straight line accounting basis.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P77_S0	The Company determines the fair value of options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model that uses assumptions based on expected option life, expected stock volatility and the risk-free interest rate.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P77_S1	The expected volatility assumptions used by the Company are based on the historical volatility of the Company s common stock over the most recent period commensurate with the estimated expected life of the Company s stock options.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P77_S2	The Company bases its expected life assumption on its historical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock options it grants to employees.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P77_S3	The risk-free rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve for the periods within the contractual life of the options in effect at the time of the grant.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	The Company also makes assumptions regarding estimated forfeitures that will impact the total compensation expenses recognized under the Plans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	During 2011 the Company granted options to purchase 248,000 shares of common stock.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P79_S1	The fair value of each option was estimated on the date of grant using the following assumptions.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P79_S2	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to finalize the reporting requirements for reclassifications of amounts out of accumulated other comprehensive income ( AOCI ).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P80_S1	Items reclassified out of AOCI to net income in their entirety must have the effect of the reclassification disclosed according to the respective income statement line item.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P80_S2	This information must be provided either on the face of the financial statements by income statement line item, or in a footnote.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P80_S3	For public companies, the amendments in the update became effective for interim and annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P80_S4	As of December 31, 2013, the impact of this update on the Company s disclosures was minimal as the only changes to AOCI were changes in market values related to available for sale securities.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P81_S0	In July 2013, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued Accounting Standards Update 2013-11, Presentation of an Unrecognized Tax Benefit When a Net Operating Loss Carryforward, a Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists (ASU 2013-11).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P81_S1	Current GAAP does not include explicit guidance on the financial statement presentation of an unrecognized tax benefit when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward exists.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P81_S2	The adoption of ASU 2013-11 will require an unrecognized tax benefit, or a portion of an unrecognized tax benefit to be presented in the financial statements as a reduction to a deferred tax asset for a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward, unless an exception applies.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P81_S3	The amendments in this update are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2013.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P81_S4	The Company is currently evaluating the effect that the provisions of ASU 2013-11 will have on its financial statements.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P82_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS The Company measures fair value under the fair value hierarchy described below.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P83_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active exchange markets.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P83_S1	Level 2: Quoted prices (unadjusted) for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-based valuation techniques for which all significant assumptions are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P83_S2	Level 3: Model based techniques that use one significant assumption not observable in the market.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P83_S3	These unobservable assumptions reflect the Company s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use on pricing the asset or liability.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P84_S0	Valuation techniques include management judgment and estimation which may be significant.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P85_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P85_S1	In such cases, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P85_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P86_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Management monitors the availability of observable market data to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P87_S0	Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value level to another.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P87_S1	In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P88_S0	Management evaluates the significance of transfers between levels based upon the nature of the financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total assets, total liabilities or total earnings.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P89_S0	The carrying amounts and estimated fair values of financial instruments, at December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012 are as follows:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P90_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated future business related to the instruments.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P90_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P91_S0	The following methods and assumptions were used by management to estimate the fair value of its financial instruments: Cash and cash equivalents: The carrying amounts of cash and short-term instruments approximate fair values and are classified as Level 1.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P92_S0	Investment securities: Fair values for securities available for sale are generally determined by matrix pricing, which is a mathematical technique widely used in the industry to value debt securities without relying exclusively on quoted prices for the specific securities but rather by relying on the securities relationship to other benchmark quoted securities (Level 2).
1168455_14_ITEM8_P92_S1	Loans: Fair values of loans, excluding loans held for sale, are estimated as follows:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P92_S2	For variable rate loans that reprice frequently and with no significant change in credit risk, fair values are based on carrying values resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P92_S3	Fair values for other loans are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered for loans with similar terms to borrowers of similar credit quality resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P93_S0	Impaired loans are valued at the lower of cost or fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P94_S0	The methods utilized to estimate the fair value of loans do not necessarily represent an exit price.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P94_S1	It was not practicable to determine the fair value of the FHLB stock due to restrictions placed on its transferability.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P95_S0	Deposits: The fair values disclosed for demand deposits, including interest and non-interest demand accounts, savings, and certain types of money market accounts are, by definition, equal to the carrying amount at the reporting date resulting in a Level 1 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P95_S1	Fair values for fixed rate certificates of deposit are estimated using a discounted cash flow calculation that applies interest rates currently being offered on certificates to a schedule of aggregated expected monthly maturities on time deposits resulting in a Level 2 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P96_S0	Repurchase agreements: The fair value of securities sold under repurchase agreements is estimated based on bid quotations received from brokers using observable inputs and are included as Level 2.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P96_S1	The fair value of the Company s Note Payable is estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P97_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Subordinated debentures: The fair values of the Company s Subordinated Debentures are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P97_S1	Junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures: The fair values of the Company s Subordinated Debentures are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P97_S2	The carrying amounts of accrued interest approximate fair value and are considered to be linked in classification to the asset or liability for which they relate.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P98_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit: The fair value of commitments are estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements and are not significant and, therefore, not presented.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P98_S1	Commitments to extend credit are primarily for variable rate loans and letters of credit.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P99_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments and other factors.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P99_S1	Those estimates that are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and therefore cannot be determined with precision are included in Level 3.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P100_S0	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the fair values presented.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P101_S0	The following tables present information about the Company s assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non-recurring basis as of December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, and indicates the fair value hierarchy of the valuation techniques utilized by the Company to determine such fair value: Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at December 31, 2013 are summarized below:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P102_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at December 31, 2012 are summarized below: The fair value of securities available-for-sale equals quoted market price, if available.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P102_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair value is determined using quoted market prices for similar securities or matrix pricing.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P102_S2	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2013 or 2012.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P103_S0	Transfers between hierarchy measurement levels are recognized by the Company as of the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P104_S0	Changes in fair market value are recorded in other comprehensive income.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P105_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2013 are summarized below:
1168455_14_ITEM8_P106_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2012 are summarized below: The Company has no liabilities which are reported at fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P107_S0	The following methods were used to estimate fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P108_S0	Impaired Loans: The fair value of collateral dependent impaired loans with specific allocations of the allowance for loan losses or loans that have been subject to partial charge-offs are generally based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P108_S1	These appraisals may utilize a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P108_S2	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P108_S3	Such adjustments are usually significant and typically result in a Level 3 classification of the inputs for determining fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P109_S0	Total losses of $24,000 and $2,044,000 represent impairment charges recognized during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively, related to the above impaired loans.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS (Continued) Other Real Estate: Nonrecurring adjustments to certain commercial and residential real estate properties classified as other real estate owned (OREO) are measured at fair value, less costs to sell.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S1	Fair values are based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S2	These appraisals may use a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S3	Appraisals for both collateral-dependent impaired loans and other real estate are performed by certified general appraisers (for commercial properties) or certified residential appraisers (for residential properties) whose qualifications and licenses have been reviewed and verified by the Company.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S4	Once received, a member of the Loan Administration Department reviews the assumptions and approaches utilized in the appraisal as well as the overall resulting fair value in comparison with independent data sources such as recent market data or industry-wide statistics.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S5	On a quarterly basis, the Company compares the actual selling price of similar collateral that has been liquidated to the most recent appraised value for unsold properties to determine what additional adjustment, if any, should be made to the appraisal value to arrive at fair value.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P110_S6	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.
1168455_14_ITEM8_P111_S0	The following table presents quantitative information about Level 3 fair value measurements for financial instruments measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2013 and 2012 (dollars in thousands):
