1168455_15_ITEM7_P32_S1	The increase in interest and fees on loans was related to an increase in average loan balances partially offset by a decline in yield.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P32_S2	Interest on investments securities benefited from both an increase in yield and an increase in average balance.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	Interest and fees on loans was $19.5 million during 2014 and $18.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P33_S1	The average loan balances were $353.4 million for 2014, up $32.2 million from the $321.2 million for 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P33_S2	The following table compares loan balances by type at December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	The average yield on loans was 5.52% for 2014 down from 5.66% for 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P34_S1	We attribute much of the decrease in yield to price competition in our service area as well as an increase in lower yielding automobile loans as a percentage of total loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	Interest on investment securities increased by $353 thousand as a result of an increase in yield of 32 basis points from 1.40% during 2013 to 1.72% during 2014 and an increase in average balance from $82.8 million in 2013 to $87.9 million in 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	The increase in yield on investment securities incudes an increase in government sponsored agency residential mortgage backed securities and municipal securities as a percentage of total securities and an increase in market yields.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Interest income on other interest-earning assets, which totaled $137 thousand in 2014 and $124 thousand in 2013, primarily relates to interest on cash balances held at the Federal Reserve.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	Interest expense on deposits decreased by $84 thousand, or 14%, to $516 thousand for the twelve months ended December 31, 2014, down from $600 thousand in 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S1	Interest expense on time deposits declined by $69 thousand from $281 thousand during 2013 to $212 thousand at during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S2	Average time deposits declined by $6.9 million from $66.0 million during 2013 to $59.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S3	We attribute much of this decline to migration into other types of deposits given the low rates and lack of liquidity associated with time deposits.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S4	The average rate paid on time deposits decreased from 0.43% during 2013 to 0.36% during the current twelve month period.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P37_S5	This decrease primarily relates to a decline in market rates paid in the Company s service area and the maturity of higher rate time deposits.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	Interest expense on NOW accounts declined by $14 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	Rates paid on NOW accounts declined by 2 basis points from 0.11% during 2013 to 0.09% during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	Average balances decreased by $568 thousand from 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S3	Interest expense on money market accounts decreased by $17 thousand related to a decrease in rate paid on these accounts of 3 basis points from 0.17% during 2013 to 0.14% during 2014 and a decline in average balances from $48.7 million during 2013 to $46.7 million in 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S4	Interest expense on savings accounts increased by $16 thousand as we continued to experience strong growth in this category of deposits.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S5	Average savings deposits increased by $18.2 million from $84.5 million during 2013 to $102.7 million during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S6	The average rate paid on savings accounts during this same period declined from 17 basis points during 2013 to 16 basis points during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P38_S7	The decline in rates paid on deposits is consistent with a decline in competitive market rates in our service area.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	Interest expense on other interest-bearing liabilities increased by $243 thousand from $934 thousand during the twelve months ending December 31, 2013 to $1,177 thousand during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	This increase was mostly related to an increase of $215 thousand in interest expense on a $7.5 million subordinated debenture which was only outstanding for 8.5 months during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	The subordinated debt bears an interest rate of 7.5% per annum, has a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant (the Lender Warrant ) to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P39_S3	The effective yield on the debenture during 2014 was 10.3% which was in excess of the 7.5% rate due to amortization of a $75 thousand commitment fee and a discount recorded on issuance of $318 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	On October 24, 2013 the Bancorp issued a $3 million promissory note dated October 24, 2013 payable to an unrelated commercial bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	The note bears interest at the U.S.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	"Prime Rate" plus three-quarters percent per annum (currently 4%), has a term of 18 months and is secured by 100 shares of Plumas Bank stock representing the Company s 100% ownership interest in Plumas Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	Proceeds from this note were used to help fund the redemption of the remaining preferred shares during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S4	Interest expense on this note for 2013 totaled $23 thousand and for 2014 it totaled $111 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P40_S5	The increase relates mostly to an increase in average balance from $567 thousand in 2013 to $2.3 million during 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P41_S0	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which decreased by $10 thousand from 2013, fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	Interest on other borrowings, which during 2014 relates to repurchase agreements, totaled $7 thousand in 2014 and $57 thousand in 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P43_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2014 increased slightly to 4.05%, from 4.03% for 2013.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	The average loan balances were $321.2 million for 2013, up $19.4 million from the $301.8 million for 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	The largest areas of loan growth were in our commercial real estate and auto portfolios.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P46_S3	We have dedicated significant resources to our loan production activities and have emphasized the need for quality and diversified growth in the portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P47_S0	The average yields on loans were 5.66% for 2013 down from 5.77% for 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P47_S1	We attribute much of the decrease in yield to intense pricing competition in our service area.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	Interest on other borrowings, which totaled $57 thousand in 2013 and $83 thousand in 2012, primarily relates to interest paid on repurchase agreements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	Net interest margin is net interest income expressed as a percentage of average interest-earning assets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P55_S1	As a result of the changes noted above, the net interest margin for 2013 decreased 15 basis points to 4.03%, from 4.18% for 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2014 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $1.1 million, down $300 thousand from the $1.4 million provision recorded during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P56_S1	See Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses for further discussion of loan quality trends and the provision for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P57_S0	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that management believes will be appropriate to absorb inherent losses on existing loans based on an evaluation of the collectability of the loans and prior loan loss experience.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P57_S1	The evaluations take into consideration such factors as changes in the nature and volume of the portfolio, overall portfolio quality, review of specific problem loans, and current economic conditions that may affect the borrower s ability to repay their loan.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	The allowance for loan losses is based on estimates, and ultimate losses may vary from the current estimates.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	These estimates are reviewed periodically and, as adjustments become necessary, they are reported in earnings in the periods in which they become known.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	Based on information currently available, management believes that the allowance for loan losses is appropriate to absorb potential risks in the portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	However, no assurance can be given that the Company may not sustain charge-offs which are in excess of the allowance in any given period.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	The following table sets forth the components of non-interest income for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 non-interest income totaled $7.3 million an increase of $673 thousand from the twelve months ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P61_S1	The largest component of this increase was an increase of $196 thousand in service charge income which we attribute to growth in the Company s demand deposit accounts, an increase in debit card interchange income and a restructuring of our service charge fee structure beginning in August of 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P61_S2	During July and August 2014 we sold fourteen available-for- sale securities totaling $16.2 million recognizing a gain on sale of $128 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P61_S3	Loan servicing fees, which totaled $502 thousand for the 12 months ended December 31, 2014, increased by $179 thousand from 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	Loan servicing fees mostly relate to servicing income on the sold portion of government guaranteed small business administration loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P62_S1	Other non-interest income increased by $176 thousand mostly related to a $148 thousand gain on the sale of our credit card portfolio during the fourth quarter of 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P62_S2	Prior to the sale, credit card loans represented less than one-half of a percent of our loan portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2013 non-interest income totaled $6.6 million an increase of $46 thousand from 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	The largest component of this change was an increase of $295 thousand in service charges on deposit accounts which we attribute to growth in the Company s demand deposit accounts, an increase in debit card interchange income and a restructuring of our service charge fee schedule beginning in August of 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S2	Gains on sale of government guaranteed loans increased by $75 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S3	During 2012 we sold 53 loans receiving proceeds of $20.1 million on sale.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S4	Sales proceeds increased to $21.7 million in 2013 related to the sale of 55 loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P63_S5	During 2013 loan servicing income totaled $323 thousand an increase of $108 thousand from $215 thousand during 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	The largest decrease in non-interest income was $403 thousand in gain on sale of investment securities.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P64_S1	No investment securities were sold in 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P64_S2	During 2012 we sold twenty-five available-for-sale securities totaling $20.8 million recognizing a gain on sale of $403 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	The following table sets forth the components of other non-interest expense for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2014, total non-interest expense increased by $275 thousand, or 2%, to $17.8 million, up from $17.6 million for the comparable period in 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	The largest components of this increase were $745 thousand in salary and benefit expense, $187 thousand in outside service fees and $70 thousand related to reduction in gain on sale of OREO.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P66_S2	The largest declines in non-interest expense were $248 thousand in professional fees, $246 thousand in provision for OREO losses, $128 thousand in deposit premium amortization and $121 thousand in insurance expense.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	Salaries and employee benefits increased by $745 thousand primarily related to an increase in bonus expense of $350 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P67_S1	The Bank s bonus plan for 2014 provides for a bonus pool of 60% of the amount that pretax income exceeds budgeted pretax income with a cap of $600 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P67_S2	Bonus expense was $600 thousand for the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 and $250 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P67_S3	In both years the maximum allowed under the bonus plans was earned.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P67_S4	Salary expense, exclusive of commissions, increased by $265 thousand as a decline of four employees from 159 at December 31, 2013 to 155 at December 31, 2014 was offset by an increase in average salary per employee which includes the effect of merit and promotional increases.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	Other increases include, but were not limited to an $89 thousand increase in commissions, which relate to government guaranteed loan production, and a $67 thousand increase in payroll tax expense.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	Partially offsetting these items was an increase in deferred loan origination costs totaling $104 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	Of the $187 thousand increase in outside service fees, $96 thousand was related to the outsourcing of our item processing beginning in June of 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	This cost as been offset by savings in salary and benefit expense and software expense.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P69_S2	In addition we incurred an increase in costs for the management of our investment portfolio and an increase in costs related to an increase in debit card interchange transactions.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	Professional fees benefited from reductions in legal expense related to loan collection activities totaling $148 thousand, a reduction in corporate legal expense of $88 thousand mostly related the repurchase of the preferred stock in 2013 and a reduction in audit expense related to a change in audit firms beginning in 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	When other real estate is acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair market value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S1	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S2	The allowance is established through a provision for subsequent losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S3	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from impairment are recorded as incurred.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S4	The provision for OREO losses declined by $246 thousand from $486 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2013 to $240 thousand during the current period.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P71_S5	During the second quarter of 2013 we recorded a $300 thousand provision related to one land development property.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	Insurance expense benefited from a one-time adjustment to accrued life insurance costs.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	The deposit premium intangible asset was fully amortized at the end of September, 2013 resulting in a savings of $128 thousand during the comparison periods.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	Non-interest expense declined by $807 thousand from $18.4 million during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 to $17.6 million during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	Reductions of $239 thousand in salary and benefits expense, $421 thousand in the provision for changes in OREO, $187 thousand in gain/loss on sale of OREO, $149 thousand in occupancy and equipment, $44 thousand in professional fees, $178 thousand in deposit insurance and $53 thousand in postage were partially offset by increases in other expenses, the largest of which were outside service fees of $352 thousand and costs associated with OREO properties of $123 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	During June of 2012 we outsourced the processing of our account statements and notices and during June of 2013 we outsourced our item processing department resulting in savings in salary expense, occupancy and equipment costs, postage and stationary costs.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	The $178 thousand reduction in deposit insurance expense is related to a decline in the rate charged to Plumas Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P74_S2	The reduction in professional fees primarily relates to a decrease in consulting costs.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	Salaries and employee benefits decreased by $239 thousand primarily related to declines in salary continuation expense and stock compensation expense and an increase in deferred loan origination costs.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S1	Salary continuation expense declined by $188 thousand related to an adjustment in 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S2	During 2012, related to a significant reduction in long term market interest rates, we reduced the discount rates used in calculating the present value of our salary continuation liabilities.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S3	This had the effect of increasing salary continuation expense during 2012 by $195 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S4	Stock compensation expense decreased by $58 thousand from $93 thousand during 2012 to $35 thousand during the current period.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S5	During the first quarter of 2012 we had an adjustment to the estimated forfeiture rate resulting in an increase in stock compensation; no adjustment was required during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S6	The largest reduction in salary and benefits was related to an increase in deferred loan origination costs totaling $384 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S7	We attribute this increase in deferred loan origination costs to an increase in lending activity.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P75_S8	These items were partially offset by an increase in bonus expense of $250 thousand and salary expense of $173 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Bank s bonus plan for 2013 provided for a bonus pool of 50% of the amount that pretax income exceeds budgeted pretax income with a cap of $250 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P76_S1	The maximum amount was allocated under this formula.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P76_S2	There was no bonus plan in place and no bonuses were earned or paid in 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P76_S3	Salary expense increased by $173 thousand as savings related to the outsourcing of statement and item processing were offset by an increase in loan production personnel and salary increases.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	The $486 thousand OREO provision during 2013, a $421 thousand decline from 2012, resulted from declines in value of ten properties.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P77_S1	The $907 thousand in OREO provision during the 2012 was related to a decline in the value of twenty-one properties.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P77_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2013, we sold twenty-eight properties and a portion of another property recording a gain on sale of $171 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P77_S3	During 2012, we sold fourteen properties and a portion of two other properties recording a loss on sale of $16 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P78_S0	The increase in outside service fees was related to the outsourcing of our statement and notice processing in June of 2012, the outsourcing of our item processing beginning in June of 2013, an increase in costs related to monitoring and maintaining our ATMs and an increase in the cost of managing our investment portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P79_S0	During 2012 the Bank modernized its ATM network by purchasing new ATM machines which have the ability to accept currency and checks and provide an imaged receipt.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P79_S1	While these ATMs provide a significant increase in functionality, they are also more expensive to operate and maintain.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P80_S0	During the first half of 2012 we began to use a third party for assistance with the analysis and management of our investment securities portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P80_S1	The increase in cost during 2013 for this function was related to a full year of costs and an increase in the balance of our portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	OREO expense during the 2012 period benefited from $80 thousand in rental income net of operating expenses on an apartment building acquired in July 2011.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P81_S1	Both the rental income and the operating expenses are included under the category of OREO expense.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P81_S2	This building was sold during the third quarter of 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P81_S3	The remaining increase in OREO expense during 2013 primarily relates to an increase in legal expense as we are actively pursuing additional recoveries on selected OREO properties through legal channels.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	Provision for I ncome T axes.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P83_S0	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $3.1 million, or 39.4% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P83_S1	During 2013 the Company recorded an income tax provision of $2.2 million, or 38.7% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P83_S2	The percentages for 2014 and 2013 differ from the statutory rate as tax exempt income such as earnings on Bank owned life insurance, municipal loan interest and in 2013 state of California enterprise zone interest, decrease taxable income.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P84_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P84_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P85_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P85_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is "more likely than not" that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P85_S2	"More likely than not" is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P85_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P86_S0	Based upon the analysis of available evidence, management has determined that it is "more likely than not" that all deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S0	Net loans increased by $32.4 million, or 10%, from $334.4 million at December 31, 2013 to $366.8 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S1	The two largest areas of growth in the Company s loan portfolio were $14.3 million in automobile loans and $7.4 million in commercial real estate loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S2	Additionally, construction and land development loans increased by $6.8 million to $24.6 million and agricultural loans increased by $4.7 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S3	The Company continues to manage the mix of its loan portfolio consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financing needs of all sectors of the area it serves.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S4	Although the Company offers a broad array of financing options, it continues to concentrate its focus on small to medium sized commercial businesses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S5	These commercial loans offer diversification as to industries and types of businesses, thus limiting material exposure in any industry concentrations.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P87_S6	The Company offers both fixed and floating rate loans and obtains collateral in the form of real property, business assets and deposit accounts, but looks to business and personal cash flows as its primary source of repayment.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P88_S0	As shown in the following table the Company s largest lending categories are commercial real estate loans, auto loans, equity lines of credit, agricultural loans and commercial loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P89_S0	Construction and land development loans represented 6.6% and 5.3% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P89_S1	The construction and land development portfolio component has been identified by Management as a higher-risk loan category.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P89_S2	The quality of the construction and land development category is highly dependent on property values both in terms of the likelihood of repayment once the property is transacted by the current owner as well as the level of collateral the Company has securing the loan in the event of default.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P90_S0	Loans in this category are characterized by the speculative nature of commercial and residential development properties and can include property in various stages of development from raw land to finished lots.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P90_S1	The decline in these loans as a percentage of the Company s loan portfolio from over 21% at December 31, 2007 to less than 7% during the last two years reflects management s efforts, which began in 2009, to reduce its exposure to construction and land development loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P91_S0	The Company s real estate related loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction and land development loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate comprised 74% of the total loan portfolio at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P91_S1	Moreover, the business activities of the Company currently are focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta, Sierra and in Washoe County in Northern Nevada.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P91_S2	Consequently, the results of operations and financial condition of the Company are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P91_S3	In addition, the concentration of the Company s operations in these areas of Northeastern California and Northwestern Nevada exposes it to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P92_S0	The rates of interest charged on variable rate loans are set at specific increments in relation to the Company s lending rate or other indexes such as the published prime interest rate or U.S. Treasury rates and vary with changes in these indexes.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P92_S1	At December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, approximately 71% and 73%, respectively of the Company s loan portfolio was comprised of variable rate loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P92_S2	At December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, 42% and 40%, respectively of the variable loans were at their respective floor rate.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P93_S0	While real estate mortgage, commercial and consumer lending remain the foundation of the Company s historical loan mix, some changes in the mix have occurred due to the changing economic environment and the resulting change in demand for certain loan types.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P93_S1	The most significant change has been an increase in indirect auto lending with automobile loans increasing from 2.5% of gross loans at December 31, 2011 to 12.1% of gross loans at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P94_S0	The automobile portfolio provides diversification to the loan portfolio in terms of rate, term and balance as these loans tend to have a much shorter term and balance than commercial real-estate loans and are fixed rate.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P94_S1	In addition, the Company remains committed to the agricultural industry in Northeastern California and will continue to pursue high quality agricultural loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P94_S2	Agricultural loans include both commercial and commercial real estate loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P94_S3	The Company s agricultural loan balances totaled $35 million at December 31, 2014 and $31 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P95_S0	The following table sets forth the amounts of loans outstanding by category as of the dates indicated.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P96_S0	The following table sets forth the maturity of gross loan categories as of December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P96_S1	Also provided with respect to such loans are the amounts due after one year, classified according to sensitivity to changes in interest rates:
1168455_15_ITEM7_P97_S0	Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P98_S0	The Company attempts to minimize credit risk through its underwriting and credit review policies.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Company s credit review process includes internally prepared credit reviews as well as contracting with an outside firm to conduct periodic credit reviews.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P98_S2	The Company s management and lending officers evaluate the loss exposure of classified and impaired loans on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P99_S0	The Management Asset Resolution Committee (MARC) reviews the asset quality of criticized and past due loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P99_S1	In management s opinion, this loan review system helps facilitate the early identification of potential criticized loans.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P100_S0	The Company has implemented MARC to develop an action plan to significantly reduce nonperforming assets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P101_S0	It consists of the Bank s Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Credit Officer, and the activities are governed by a formal written charter.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P101_S1	The MARC meets at least monthly and reports to the Board of Directors.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P102_S0	More specifically, a formal plan to effect repayment and/or disposition of every significant nonperforming loan relationship is developed and documented for review and on-going oversight by the MARC.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P102_S1	Some of the strategies used include but are not limited to: 1) obtaining additional collateral, 2) obtaining additional investor cash infusion, 3) sale of the promissory note to an outside party, 4) proceeding with foreclosure on the underlying collateral, and 5) legal action against borrower/guarantors to encourage settlement of debt and/or collect any deficiency balance owed.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P102_S2	Each step includes a benchmark timeline to track progress.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P103_S0	MARC also provides guidance for the maintenance and timely disposition of OREO properties; including developing financing and marketing programs to incent individuals to purchase OREO.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P104_S0	The allowance for loan losses is established through charges to earnings in the form of the provision for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P104_S1	Loan losses are charged to and recoveries are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P104_S2	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level deemed appropriate by management to provide for known and inherent risks in the loan portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P104_S3	The adequacy of the allowance for loan losses is based upon management s continuing assessment of various factors affecting the collectability of loans; including current economic conditions, maturity of the portfolio, size of the portfolio, industry concentrations, borrower credit history, collateral, the existing allowance for loan losses, independent credit reviews, current charges and recoveries to the allowance for loan losses and the overall quality of the portfolio as determined by management, regulatory agencies, and independent credit review consultants retained by the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P105_S0	There is no precise method of predicting specific losses or amounts which may ultimately be charged off on particular segments of the loan portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P106_S0	The collectability of a loan is subjective to some degree, but must relate to the borrower s financial condition, cash flow, quality of the borrower s management expertise, collateral and guarantees, and state of the local economy.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P107_S0	Formula allocations are calculated by applying loss factors to outstanding loans with similar characteristics.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P107_S1	Loss factors are based on the Company s historical loss experience as adjusted for changes in the business cycle and may be adjusted for significant factors that, in management s judgment, affect the collectability of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P107_S2	Historical loss data from the beginning of the latest business cycle are incorporated in the loss factors.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P108_S0	The discretionary allocation is based upon management s evaluation of various loan segment conditions that are not directly measured in the determination of the formula and specific allowances.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P108_S1	The conditions may include, but are not limited to, general economic and business conditions affecting the key lending areas of the Company, credit quality trends, collateral values, loan volumes and concentrations, and other business conditions.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P109_S0	The following table provides certain information for the years indicated with respect to the Company s allowance for loan losses as well as charge-off and recovery activity.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P110_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2014 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $1.1 million down $300 thousand from the $1.4 million provision recorded during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P110_S1	Net charge-offs totaled $1.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2014 down $403 thousand from $1.6 million during 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P110_S2	Net charge-offs as a percentage of average loans decreased from 0.49% during 2013 to 0.33% during the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P111_S0	The following table provides a breakdown of the allowance for loan losses:
1168455_15_ITEM7_P112_S0	The allowance for loan losses totaled $5.5 million at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P112_S1	Specific reserves related to impaired loans decreased by $65 thousand from $629 thousand at December 31, 2013 to $564 thousand at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P113_S0	At least quarterly the Company evaluates each specific reserve and if it determines that the loss represented by the specific reserve is uncollectable it records a charge-off for the uncollectable portion.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P113_S1	General reserves were $4.9 million at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P113_S2	The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans decreased from 1.63% at December 31, 2013 to 1.47% at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P113_S3	The percentage of general reserves to unimpaired loans decreased from 1.49% at December 31, 2013 to 1.35% at December 31, 2014 primarily related to reductions in historical net charge-offs.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P114_S0	The Company places loans 90 days or more past due on nonaccrual status unless the loan is well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P114_S1	A loan is considered to be in the process of collection if, based on a probable specific event, it is expected that the loan will be repaid or brought current.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P114_S2	Generally, this collection period would not exceed 90 days.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P115_S0	When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status the Company s general policy is to reverse and charge against current income previously accrued but unpaid interest.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P115_S1	Interest income on such loans is subsequently recognized only to the extent that cash is received and future collection of principal is deemed by management to be probable.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P115_S2	Where the collectability of the principal or interest on a loan is considered to be doubtful by management, it is placed on nonaccrual status prior to becoming 90 days delinquent.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P116_S0	Impaired loans are measured based on the present value of the expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P116_S1	The amount of impaired loans is not directly comparable to the amount of nonperforming loans disclosed later in this section.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P117_S0	The primary difference between impaired loans and nonperforming loans is that impaired loan recognition considers not only loans 90 days or more past due, restructured loans and nonaccrual loans but also may include identified problem loans other than delinquent loans where it is considered probable that we will not collect all amounts due to us (including both principal and interest) in accordance with the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P118_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P119_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P120_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P121_S0	Loans restructured (TDRs) and not included in nonperforming loans in the following table totaled $2.0 million, $4.5 million, $5.4 million, $8.6 million and $2.0 million at December 31, 2014, 2013, 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P121_S1	For additional information related to restructured loans see Note 6 of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P122_S0	The following table sets forth the amount of the Company s nonperforming assets as of the dates indicated.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P123_S0	Nonperforming loans at December 31, 2014 were $6.6 million, an increase of $1.1 million from the $5.5 million balance at December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P123_S1	Specific reserves on nonaccrual loans totaled $522 thousand at December 31, 2014 and $578 thousand at December 31, 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P123_S2	Performing loans past due thirty to eighty-nine days increased by $0.1 million from $1.5 million at December 31, 2013 to $1.6 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P124_S0	A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P124_S1	Total substandard loans increased by $612 thousand from $7.5 million at December 31, 2013 to $8.1 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P124_S2	Loans classified as watch decreased by $1.4 million from $5.8 million at December 31, 2013 to $4.4 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P124_S3	At December 31, 2014, $1.6 million of performing loans were classified as substandard.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P124_S4	Further deterioration in the credit quality of individual performing substandard loans or other adverse circumstances could result in the need to place these loans on nonperforming status.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P125_S0	At December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, the Company s recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $8.6 million and $9.8 million, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P125_S1	The specific allowance for loan losses related to impaired loans totaled $564 thousand and $629 thousand at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P125_S2	Additionally, $0.7 million has been charged off against the impaired loans at December 31, 2014 and December 31 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P126_S0	It is the policy of management to make additions to the allowance for loan losses so that it remains appropriate to absorb the inherent risk of loss in the portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P126_S1	Management believes that the allowance at December 31, 2014 is appropriate.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P126_S2	However, the determination of the amount of the allowance is judgmental and subject to economic conditions which cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P126_S3	Accordingly, the Company cannot predict whether charge-offs of loans in excess of the allowance may occur in future periods.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S0	OREO represents real property acquired by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S1	Repossessed assets include vehicles and other commercial assets acquired under agreements with delinquent borrowers.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S2	OREO holdings represented fifteen properties totaling $3.6 million at December 31, 2014 and twenty-six properties totaling $6.4 million at December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S3	During June 2014 the Company sold its largest property in OREO, a land development property with an OREO value of $2.2 million which represented 36% of the total OREO balance prior to sale.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S4	A gain of $28 thousand was recorded on the sale of this property.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P127_S5	Nonperforming assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.90% at December 31, 2014 and 2.33% at December 31, 2013.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P129_S0	Investment Portfolio and Federal Funds Sold.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P129_S1	Total investment securities were $90.3 million as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P129_S2	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 we sold investment securities with a book balance of $16.2 million and recognized a gain on sale of $128 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P129_S3	The investment portfolio at December 31, 2014 consisted of $77.3 million in securities of U.S. Government-sponsored agencies, 52 municipal securities totaling $12.5 million and one corporate security totaling $0.5 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P129_S4	Included in the $90.3 million at December 31, 2013 were $89.0 million in securities of U.S. Government-sponsored agencies and six municipal securities totaling $1.3 million.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P130_S1	These balances currently earn 25 basis points.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P131_S2	Securities classified as available-for-sale may be sold to implement the Company s asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.

1168455_15_ITEM7_P135_S0	Expected maturities may differ from contractual maturities because the issuers may have the right to call or prepay obligations.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P136_S0	During 2013 and continuing into 2014 we have experienced strong core deposit growth and have benefited from the closing of two branches of a large national bank in our service area.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P136_S1	Total deposits increased by $18.5 million from $449 million at December 31, 2013 to $468 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P136_S2	Core deposit growth remained strong in 2014 as evidenced by increases of $17.8 million in demand deposits and $12.3 million in savings accounts.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P136_S3	Time deposits declined by $6.3 million, much of which we attribute to migration into other types of deposits given the low rates and lack of liquidity associated with time deposits.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P136_S4	Interest-bearing transaction accounts (NOW) declined by $0.5 million and money market accounts declined by $4.8 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P137_S0	The Company continues to manage the mix of its deposits consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financial needs of its customers.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P137_S1	The following table shows the distribution of deposits by type at December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P138_S0	Deposits represent the Bank s primary source of funds.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P138_S1	Deposits are primarily core deposits in that they are demand, savings and time deposits generated from local businesses and individuals.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P138_S2	These sources are considered to be relatively stable, long-term relationships thereby enhancing steady growth of the deposit base without major fluctuations in overall deposit balances.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P139_S0	The Company experiences, to a small degree, some seasonality with the slower growth period between November through April, and the higher growth period from May through October.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P139_S1	In order to assist in meeting any funding demands, the Company maintains a secured borrowing arrangement with the FHLB.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P139_S2	There were no brokered deposits at December 31, 2014 or 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P140_S0	The Company s time deposits of $100,000 or more had the following schedule of maturities at December 31, 2014:
1168455_15_ITEM7_P141_S0	Time deposits of $100,000 or more are generally from the Company s local business and individual customer base.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P141_S1	The potential impact on the Company s liquidity from the withdrawal of these deposits is discussed at the Company s asset and liability management committee meetings, and is considered to be minimal.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S0	S hort - term Borrowing Arrangements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S1	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $133,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $205,000,000.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S2	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S3	At December 31, 2014 and 2013, the Company held $2,380,000 and $2,226,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S4	Based on the level of stock holdings at December 31, 2014, the Company can borrow up to $50,600,000.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S5	To borrow the $133,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $3,900,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S6	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with three of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $11 million, $10 million and $10 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P142_S7	There were no outstanding borrowings to the FHLB or the correspondent banks under these agreements at December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S0	On October 24, 2013 the Bancorp issued a $3 million promissory note (the Note ) payable to an unrelated commercial bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S1	The note bears interest at the U.S.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S2	"Prime Rate" plus three-quarters percent per annum, 4.00% at December 31, 2014 and 2013, has a term of 18 months and is secured by 100 shares of Plumas Bank stock representing the Company s 100% ownership interest in Plumas Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S3	Interest expense related to this note for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 totaled $111,000 and $23,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S4	Under the Note the Bank is subject to several negative and affirmative covenants including, but not limited to providing timely financial information, maintaining specified levels of capital, restrictions on additional borrowings, and meeting or exceeding certain capital and asset quality ratios.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P143_S5	The Bank was in compliance with all such requirements at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P144_S0	On July 28, 2014, Plumas Bancorp entered into a Renewal, Extension, and Modification of Loan Agreement (the Agreement ) related to the Note.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P144_S1	This Agreement provides for the following changes, among others:
1168455_15_ITEM7_P145_S0	The maximum amount of the Note is $7.5 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P146_S0	The Company may borrow, repay, and reborrow up to the principal face amount of the Note.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P147_S0	The above provisions are subject to the following conditions:
1168455_15_ITEM7_P148_S0	An advance under the Note in excess of $3 million is subject to the lender completing a satisfactory loan review of the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P149_S0	The Company shall provide an assignment of Key Man life Policy(s) in a minimum amount of $3.5 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P150_S0	The Company shall not prepay the Company s Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures until the Note has been paid in full.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P151_S0	On August 26, 2014 the Company made a $2 million payment on the Note reducing the outstanding balance to $1 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P152_S0	In 2011 Plumas Bank introduced a new product for their larger business customers which use repurchase agreements as an alternative to interest-bearing deposits.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P152_S1	The balance in this product at December 31, 2014 was $9.6 million an increase of $0.5 million from the December 31, 2013 balance of $9.1 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P152_S2	Interest paid on this product is similar to that which is paid on the Bank s premium money market account; however, these are not deposits and are not FDIC insured.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P153_S0	On April 15, 2013, to help fund the repurchase of preferred stock during 2013, the Company issued a $7.5 million subordinated debenture.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P153_S1	The subordinated debt bears an interest rate of 7.5% per annum, has a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P153_S2	The effective yield on the debenture was 10.3% which was in excess of the 7.5% rate due to amortization of a $75 thousand commitment fee and a discount recorded on issuance of $318 thousand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P153_S3	Interest expense related to the subordinated debt for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 totaled $756,000 and $541,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P154_S0	The subordinated debt agreement provides that in the event of default with respect to the subordinated debt, the Bancorp will be subject to certain restrictions on the payment of dividends and distributions to shareholders, repurchase or redemption of the Bancorp s securities and payment on certain debts or guarantees.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P154_S1	The subordinated debenture agreement also provides that in the event of default, Lender will have the right to appoint a director to the Bancorp s board of directors and/or the Plumas Bank board in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P154_S2	Under current capital guidelines the subordinated debt qualifies as Tier 2 capital; however, under Basel III guidelines effective January 1, 2015 it does not qualify for regulatory capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P155_S0	Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures .
1168455_15_ITEM7_P156_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and II are Connecticut business trusts formed by the Company with capital of $304,000 and $161,000, respectively, for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities fully and unconditionally guaranteed by the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P157_S0	Under current applicable regulatory guidance, the amount of trust preferred securities (TRUPS) that is eligible as Tier 1 capital is limited to twenty-five percent of the Company s Tier 1 capital, as defined, on a pro forma basis.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P157_S1	At December 31, 2014, all of the trust preferred securities that have been issued qualify as Tier 1 capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P157_S2	Under Basel III guidelines the twenty-five percent limitation applies to Tier 1 capital exclusive of the TRUPS which we expect will result in a portion of the TRUPS not qualifying as Tier 1 capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P157_S3	The amount of the TRUPS that does not qualify as Tier 1 capital will be included in Tier 2 capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P158_S0	During 2002, Plumas Statutory Trust I issued 6,000 Floating Rate Capital Trust Pass-Through Securities ("Trust Preferred Securities"), with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $6,000,000.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P158_S1	During 2005, Plumas Statutory Trust II issued 4,000 Trust Preferred Securities with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $4,000,000.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P158_S2	The entire proceeds were invested by Trust I in the amount of $6,186,000 and Trust II in the amount of $4,124,000 in Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures (the "Subordinated Debentures") issued by the Company, with identical maturity, repricing and payment terms as the Trust Preferred Securities.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P158_S3	The Subordinated Debentures represent the sole assets of Trusts I and II.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P159_S0	Trust I s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 26, 2032, bear a current interest rate of 3.66% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P159_S1	Trust II s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 28, 2035, bear a current interest rate of 1.72% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P159_S2	The interest rate of the Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust I adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P159_S3	The Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust II adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P159_S4	Both Trusts I and II have the option to defer payment of the distributions for a period of up to five years, as long as the Company is not in default on the payment of interest on the Subordinated Debentures.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P160_S0	Interest expense recognized by the Company for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012 related to the subordinated debentures was $303,000, $313,000 and $344,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P161_S0	Total shareholders equity increased by $5.9 million from $30.6 million at December 31, 2013 to $36.5 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P161_S1	The $5.9 million includes earnings during the twelve month period totaling $4.7 million and a decrease in net unrealized loss on investment securities of $1.1 million with the balance of $0.1 million representing stock option activity.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P162_S0	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P162_S1	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P163_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_15_ITEM7_P163_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P164_S0	Banking regulations limit the amount of dividends that may be paid without prior approval of regulatory agencies.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P164_S1	No common cash dividends were paid during the last five years.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P165_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P166_S0	The Company uses a variety of measures to evaluate its capital adequacy, with risk-based capital ratios calculated separately for the Company and the Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P166_S1	Management reviews these capital measurements on a monthly basis and takes appropriate action to ensure that they are within established internal and external guidelines.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P167_S0	The FDIC has promulgated risk-based capital guidelines for all state non-member banks such as the Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P167_S1	These guidelines establish a risk-adjusted ratio relating capital to different categories of assets and off-balance sheet exposures.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P167_S2	There are two categories of capital under the guidelines: Tier 1 capital includes common stockholders equity, and qualifying trust-preferred securities (including notes payable to unconsolidated special purpose entities that issue trust-preferred securities), less goodwill and certain other deductions, notably the unrealized net gains or losses (after tax adjustments) on available-for-sale investment securities carried at fair market value; Tier 2 capital can include qualifying subordinated debt and the allowance for loan losses, subject to certain limitations.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P167_S3	The Series A Preferred Stock qualifies as Tier 1 capital for the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P168_S0	The following tables present the capital ratios for the Company and the Bank compared to the standards for bank holding companies and the regulatory minimum requirements for depository institutions as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 (amounts in thousands except percentage amounts).
1168455_15_ITEM7_P169_S0	Management believes that the Company and the Bank currently meet their entire capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P170_S0	The current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P170_S1	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized leverage, Tier 1 risk-based and total risk-based capital ratios of 5%, 6% and 10%, respectively, at all times.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S0	In July, 2013, the federal bank regulatory agencies approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S1	Under the final rules, minimum requirements will increase for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S2	The rules include a new common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets ratio of 4.5% and a common equity Tier 1 capital conservation buffer of 2.5% of risk-weighted assets.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S3	The final rules also raise the minimum ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets from 4.0% to 6.0% and require a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0%.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S4	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S5	Under current capital guidelines the Company s subordinated debt qualifies as Tier 2 capital; however, under Basel III guidelines effective January 1, 2015 it does not qualify for regulatory capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S6	Additionally, the Basel III rules have reduced the amount of TRUPS that is eligible for inclusion in Tier 1 capital which will we expect will result in a portion of the TRUPS not qualifying as Tier 1 capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P171_S7	The amount that does not qualify as Tier 1 capital will qualify as Tier 2 capital.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P172_S0	The phase-in period for the final rules begin on January 1, 2015, with full compliance with all of the final rule s requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P172_S1	As of January 1, 2015, the Company s and the Bank s capital levels remained well-capitalized under the new rules.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P173_S0	In the normal course of business, there are various commitments outstanding to extend credits that are not reflected in the financial statements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S1	Annual review of commercial credit lines, letters of credit and ongoing monitoring of outstanding balances reduces the risk of loss associated with these commitments.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S2	As of December 31, 2014, the Company had $89.7 million in unfunded loan commitments and no letters of credit.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S3	This compares to $84.2 million in unfunded loan commitments and $60 thousand in letters of credit at December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S4	Of the $89.7 million in unfunded loan commitments, $52.3 million and $37.4 million represented commitments to commercial and consumer customers, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S5	Of the total unfunded commitments at December 31, 2014, $41.7 million were secured by real estate, of which $14.8 million was secured by commercial real estate and $26.9 million was secured by residential real estate in the form of equity lines of credit.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S6	The commercial loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent business lines of credit, while the consumer loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent revolving credit card lines and overdraft protection lines.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P174_S7	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P175_S0	The Company leases one depository branch, three lending offices, one loan administration office and two non-branch automated teller machine locations.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P175_S1	Total rental expenses under all operating leases were $192,000 and $154,000 during the years ended December, 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P175_S2	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2015 and the last such lease expiring during 2016.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P176_S0	The Company manages its liquidity to provide the ability to generate funds to support asset growth, meet deposit withdrawals (both anticipated and unanticipated), fund customers borrowing needs, satisfy maturity of short-term borrowings and maintain reserve requirements.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P176_S1	The Company s liquidity needs are managed using assets or liabilities, or both.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P176_S2	On the asset side, in addition to cash and due from banks, the Company maintains an investment portfolio which includes unpledged U.S. Government-sponsored agency securities that are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P176_S3	On the liability side, liquidity needs are managed by charging competitive offering rates on deposit products and the use of established lines of credit.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P177_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $133,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $205,000,000.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P177_S1	See Short-term Borrowing Arrangements for additional information on our FHLB borrowing capacity.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P177_S2	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with three of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $11 million, $10 million and $10 million.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P177_S3	There were no outstanding borrowings under the FHLB or the correspondent bank borrowing lines at December 31, 2014 or 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P178_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P178_S1	Total deposits increased by $18.5 million from $449 million at December 31, 2013 to $468 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P179_S0	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P179_S1	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, FHLB advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P179_S2	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_15_ITEM7_P179_S3	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.
1168455_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	As a smaller reporting company we are not required to provide the information required by this item.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P0_S0	The following consolidated financial statements of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary, and report of the independent registered public accounting firm are included in the Annual Report of Plumas Bancorp to its shareholders for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2014 and the related consolidated statements of income and comprehensive income, changes in shareholders equity and cash flows for the year then ended.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P1_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audit.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P2_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary as of December 31, 2014 and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the year then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
