1168455_15_ITEM8_P14_S0	During 2002, Plumas Bancorp (the "Company") was incorporated as a bank holding company for the purpose of acquiring Plumas Bank (the "Bank") in a one bank holding company reorganization.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P14_S1	This corporate structure gives the Company and the Bank greater flexibility in terms of operation, expansion and diversification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P15_S0	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust I ("Trust I") for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 26, 2002.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P15_S1	The Company formed Plumas Statutory Trust II ("Trust II") for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities on September 28, 2005.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Bank operates eleven branches in California, including branches in Alturas, Chester, Fall River Mills, Greenville, Kings Beach, Portola, Quincy, Redding, Susanville, Tahoe City, and Truckee.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Bank s administrative headquarters is in Quincy, California.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P16_S2	In addition, the Bank operates a loan administrative office in Reno, Nevada, lending offices specializing in government-guaranteed lending in Auburn, California and Beaverton, Oregon and a commercial/agricultural lending office in Chico, California.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P17_S0	The Bank s primary source of revenue is generated from providing loans to customers who are predominately small and middle market businesses and individuals residing in the surrounding areas.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P18_S0	On February 15, 2012, the Bank received notice from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the California Department of Financial Institutions ( DFI ) that the Consent Order with the FDIC and the DFI which was effective on March 16, 2011 had been terminated.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P18_S1	Effective February 8, 2012, the Bank entered into an informal agreement with the FDIC and DFI which, among other things, requested that the Bank continue to maintain a Tier 1 Leverage Capital Ratio of 9% which is in excess of that required for well capitalized institutions and continue to reduce its level of classified asset balances that were outstanding as of September 30, 2011 to not more than 50% of Tier 1 Capital plus the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P18_S2	At December 31, 2012 this ratio was 32% and the Bank s Tier 1 Leverage Capital Ratio was 10.4%.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P18_S3	The FDIC and DFI terminated the informal agreement effective January 24, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P18_S4	Effective July 1, 2013, the California Department of Corporations and the DFI merged to form the Department of Business Oversight ( DBO ).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P19_S0	On July 28, 2011 the Company entered into an agreement with the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco (the "FRB Agreement").
1168455_15_ITEM8_P19_S1	Under the terms of the FRB Agreement, Plumas Bancorp agreed to take certain actions that were designed to maintain its financial soundness so that it may continue to serve as a source of strength to the Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P19_S2	Among other things, the FRB Agreement required prior written approval related to the payment or taking of dividends and distributions, making any distributions of interest, principal or other sums on subordinated debentures or trust preferred securities, incurrence of debt, and the purchase or redemption of stock.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P19_S3	On April 19, 2013 the Company received notice that the FRB Agreement had been terminated.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P20_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the consolidated accounts of its wholly-owned subsidiary, Plumas Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P20_S1	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P21_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and Trust II are not consolidated into the Company s consolidated financial statements and, accordingly, are accounted for under the equity method.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P21_S1	The Company s investment in Trust I of $304,000 and Trust II of $161,000 are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P21_S2	The junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures issued and guaranteed by the Company and held by Trust I and Trust II are reflected as debt on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P22_S0	The accounting and reporting policies of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary conform with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America and prevailing practices within the banking industry.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P23_S0	Certain reclassifications have been made to prior years balances to conform to the classifications used in 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P23_S1	These reclassifications had no impact on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or net change in cash and cash equivalents.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P24_S0	Management has determined that since all of the banking products and services offered by the Company are available in each branch of the Bank, all branches are located within the same economic environment and management does not allocate resources based on the performance of different lending or transaction activities, it is appropriate to aggregate the Bank branches and report them as a single operating segment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P25_S0	No customer accounts for more than 10 percent of revenues for the Company or the Bank.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P26_S0	To prepare financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America management makes estimates and assumptions based on available information.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P26_S1	These estimates and assumptions affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and the disclosures provided, and actual results could differ.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P26_S2	The allowance for loan losses, loan servicing rights, deferred tax assets, and fair values of financial instruments are particularly subject to change.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P27_S0	For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, cash and due from banks and Federal funds sold are considered to be cash equivalents.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P27_S1	Generally, Federal funds are sold for one day periods.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P27_S2	Cash held with other federally insured institutions in excess of FDIC limits as of December 31, 2014 was $12.0 million.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P27_S3	Net cash flows are reported for customer loans and deposit transactions and repurchase agreements.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P28_S0	Investments are classified into one of the following categories:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P29_S0	Available-for-sale securities reported at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported, net of taxes, as accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) within shareholders equity.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P30_S0	Held-to-maturity securities, which management has the positive intent and ability to hold, reported at amortized cost, adjusted for the accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P30_S1	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as held-to-maturity.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P31_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of its investments at the time of purchase and may only change the classification in certain limited circumstances.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P32_S0	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 the Company did not have any investment securities classified as trading and gains or losses on the sale of securities are computed on the specific identification method.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P32_S1	Interest earned on investment securities is reported in interest income, net of applicable adjustments for accretion of discounts and amortization of premiums accounted for by the level yield method with no pre-payment anticipated.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S0	An investment security is impaired when its carrying value is greater than its fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S1	Investment securities that are impaired are evaluated on at least a quarterly basis and more frequently when economic or market conditions warrant such an evaluation to determine whether such a decline in their fair value is other than temporary.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S2	Management utilizes criteria such as the magnitude and duration of the decline and the intent and ability of the Company to retain its investment in the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery in fair value, in addition to the reasons underlying the decline, to determine whether the loss in value is other than temporary.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S3	The term "other than temporary" is not intended to indicate that the decline is permanent, but indicates that the prospects for a near-term recovery of value is not necessarily favorable, or that there is a lack of evidence to support a realizable value equal to or greater than the carrying value of the investment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S4	Once a decline in value is determined to be other than temporary, and management does not intend to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will not be required to sell the security before recovery, only the portion of the impairment loss representing credit exposure is recognized as a charge to earnings, with the balance recognized as a charge to other comprehensive income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P33_S5	If management intends to sell the security or it is more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the security before recovering its forecasted cost, the entire impairment loss is recognized as a charge to earnings.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P34_S0	As a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) System, the Bank is required to maintain an investment in the capital stock of the FHLB.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P34_S1	The investment is carried at cost classified as a restricted security, and periodically evaluated for impairment based on ultimate recovery of par value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P34_S2	At December 31, 2014 and 2013, FHLB stock totaled $2,380,000 and $2,226,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P34_S3	On the consolidated balance sheet, FHLB stock is included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P35_S0	Included in the loan portfolio are loans which are 75% to 85% guaranteed by the Small Business Administration (SBA), US Department of Agriculture Rural Business Cooperative Service (RBS) and Farm Services Agency (FSA).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P35_S1	The guaranteed portion of these loans may be sold to a third party, with the Bank retaining the unguaranteed portion.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P35_S2	The Company can receive a premium in excess of the adjusted carrying value of the loan at the time of sale.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P36_S0	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 the Company had $3.0 million and $2.8 million, respectively in government guaranteed loans held for sale.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P36_S1	Loans held for sale are recorded at the lower of cost or fair value and therefore may be reported at fair value on a non-recurring basis.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P36_S2	The fair values for loans held for sale are based on either observable transactions of similar instruments or formally committed loan sale prices.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P37_S0	Government guaranteed loans with unpaid balances of $76,797,000 and $70,212,000 were being serviced for others at December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company accounts for the transfer and servicing of financial assets based on the fair value of financial and servicing assets it controls and liabilities it has assumed, derecognizes financial assets when control has been surrendered, and derecognizes liabilities when extinguished.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S0	Servicing rights acquired through 1) a purchase or 2) the origination of loans which are sold or securitized with servicing rights retained are recognized as separate assets or liabilities.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S1	Servicing assets or liabilities are recorded at fair value and are subsequently amortized in proportion to and over the period of the related net servicing income or expense.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S2	Servicing rights are evaluated for impairment based upon the fair value of the rights as compared to carrying amount.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S3	Impairment is determined by stratifying rights into groupings based on predominant risk characteristics, such as interest rate, loan type and investor type.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S4	Impairment is recognized through a valuation allowance for an individual grouping, to the extent that fair value is less than the carrying amount.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P39_S5	If the Company later determines that all or a portion of the impairment no longer exists for a particular grouping, a reduction of the allowance may be recorded as an increase to income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P40_S0	Changes in valuation allowances are reported with non-interest income on the statement of income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P40_S1	The fair values of servicing rights are subject to significant fluctuations as a result of changes in estimated and actual prepayment speeds and default rates and losses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Company s investment in the loan is allocated between the retained portion of the loan, the servicing asset, the interest-only (IO) strip, and the sold portion of the loan based on their fair values on the date the loan is sold.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P41_S1	The gain on the sold portion of the loan is recognized as income at the time of sale.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P42_S0	The carrying value of the retained portion of the loan is discounted based on the estimated value of a comparable non-guaranteed loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P42_S1	The servicing asset is recognized and amortized over the estimated life of the related loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P42_S2	Assets (accounted for as IO strips) are recorded at the fair value of the difference between note rates and rates paid to purchasers (the interest spread) and contractual servicing fees, if applicable.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P42_S3	IO strips are carried at fair value with gains or losses recorded as a component of shareholders equity, similar to available-for-sale investment securities.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P42_S4	Significant future prepayments of these loans will result in the recognition of additional amortization of related servicing assets and an adjustment to the carrying value of related IO strips.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P43_S0	Loans that management has the intent and ability to hold for foreseeable future or until maturity or payoff are reported at the principal balance outstanding, net of purchase premiums or discounts, deferred loan fees and costs, and an allowance for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P43_S1	Loans, if any, that are transferred from loans held for sale are carried at the lower of principal balance or market value at the date of transfer, adjusted for accretion of discounts.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P43_S2	Interest is accrued daily based upon outstanding loan balances.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P43_S3	However, when, in the opinion of management, loans are considered to be impaired and the future collectability of interest and principal is in serious doubt, loans are placed on nonaccrual status and the accrual of interest income is suspended.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P44_S0	Any interest accrued but unpaid is charged against income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P44_S1	Payments received are applied to reduce principal to the extent necessary to ensure collection.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P45_S0	A loan is moved to non-accrual status in accordance with the Company s policy, typically after 90 days of non-payment unless well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P46_S0	Past due status is based on the contractual terms of the loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P46_S1	Subsequent payments on these loans, or payments received on nonaccrual loans for which the ultimate collectability of principal is not in doubt, are applied first to earned but unpaid interest and then to principal.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P46_S2	Loans are returned to accrual status when all the principal and interest amounts contractually due are brought current and future payments are reasonably assured.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P47_S0	Loan origination fees, commitment fees, direct loan origination costs and purchased premiums and discounts on loans are deferred and recognized as an adjustment of yield, to be amortized to interest income over the contractual term of the loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P47_S1	The unamortized balance of deferred fees and costs is reported as a component of net loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Company may acquire loans through a business combination or a purchase for which differences may exist between the contractual cash flows and the cash flows expected to be collected due, at least in part, to credit quality.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P49_S0	When the Company acquires such loans, the yield that may be accreted (accretable yield) is limited to the excess of the Company s estimate of undiscounted cash flows expected to be collected over the Company s initial investment in the loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P49_S1	The excess of contractual cash flows over cash flows expected to be collected may not be recognized as an adjustment to yield, loss, or a valuation allowance.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P50_S0	Subsequent increases in cash flows expected to be collected generally should be recognized prospectively through adjustment of the loan s yield over its remaining life.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P50_S1	Decreases in cash flows expected to be collected should be recognized as an impairment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P51_S0	The Company may not "carry over" or create a valuation allowance in the initial accounting for loans acquired under these circumstances.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P51_S1	At December 31, 2014 and 2013, there were no such loans being accounted for under this policy.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P52_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of probable incurred credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P52_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P52_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P53_S0	Loan losses are charged against the allowance when management believes the uncollectibility of a loan balance is confirmed.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P53_S1	Subsequent recoveries, if any, are credited to the allowance.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P54_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are not impaired but collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P55_S0	A loan is considered impaired when, based on current information and events, it is probable that the Company will be unable to collect all amounts due, including principal and interest, according to the contractual terms of the original agreement.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P55_S1	Loans determined to be impaired are individually evaluated for impairment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P55_S2	When a loan is impaired, the Company measures impairment based on the present value of expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate, except that as a practical expedient, it may measure impairment based on a loan s observable market price, or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P56_S0	A loan is collateral dependent if the repayment of the loan is expected to be provided solely by the underlying collateral.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P57_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P58_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P59_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S0	The determination of the general reserve for loans that are not impaired is based on estimates made by management, to include, but not limited to, consideration of historical losses by portfolio segment from January 1, 2008 (the beginning of the latest business cycle as determined by management) to the most current balance sheet date, internal asset classifications, and qualitative factors to include economic trends in the Company s service areas, industry experience and trends, geographic concentrations, estimated collateral values, the Company s underwriting policies, the character of the loan portfolio, and probable incurred losses inherent in the portfolio taken as a whole.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S1	During 2012, the Company modified its method of estimating the allowance for loan losses for non-impaired loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S2	This modification incorporated historical losses from the beginning of the latest business cycle.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S3	Previously we utilized historical loss experience based on a rolling eight quarters ending with the most recently completed calendar quarter.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S4	This modification had the effect of increasing the required allowance related to the expanded historical loss period by $250,000.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P60_S5	The Company believes that, given the recent trend in historical losses, it was prudent to increase the period examined and that a full business cycle was the appropriate period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Company maintains a separate allowance for each portfolio segment (loan type).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P61_S1	These portfolio segments include commercial, agricultural, real estate construction (including land and development loans), commercial real estate mortgage, residential mortgage, home equity loans, automobile loans and other loans primarily consisting of consumer installment loans and credit card receivables.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P61_S2	The allowance for loan losses attributable to each portfolio segment, which includes both impaired loans and loans that are not impaired, is combined to determine the Company s overall allowance, and is included as a component of loans on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Company assigns a risk rating to all loans, with the exception of automobile and other loans and periodically, but not less than annually, performs detailed reviews of all such loans over $100,000 to identify credit risks and to assess the overall collectability of the portfolio.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P62_S1	These risk ratings are also subject to examination by independent specialists engaged by the Company and the Company s regulators.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P63_S0	During these internal reviews, management monitors and analyzes the financial condition of borrowers and guarantors, trends in the industries in which borrowers operate and the fair values of collateral securing these loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P64_S0	These credit quality indicators are used to assign a risk rating to each individual loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P65_S0	The risk ratings can be grouped into five major categories, defined as follows:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P66_S0	Pass A pass loan is a strong credit with no existing or known potential weaknesses deserving of management s close attention.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P67_S0	Watch A Watch loan has potential weaknesses that deserve management s close attention.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P67_S1	If left uncorrected, these potential weaknesses may result in deterioration of the repayment prospects for the loan or in the Company s credit position at some future date.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P68_S0	Watch loans are not adversely classified and do not expose the Company to sufficient risk to warrant adverse classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P69_S0	Substandard A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P70_S0	Loans classified as substandard have a well-defined weakness or weaknesses that jeopardize the liquidation of the debt.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P70_S1	Well defined weaknesses include a project s lack of marketability, inadequate cash flow or collateral support, failure to complete construction on time or the project s failure to fulfill economic expectations.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P70_S2	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Company will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P71_S0	Doubtful Loans classified doubtful have all the weaknesses inherent in those classified as substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P72_S0	Loss Loans classified as loss are considered uncollectible and charged off immediately.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P73_S0	The general reserve component of the allowance for loan losses associated with loans collectively evaluated for impairment also consists of reserve factors that are based on management s assessment of the following for each portfolio segment: (1) historical losses and (2) other qualitative factors, including inherent credit risk.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P73_S1	These reserve factors are inherently subjective and are driven by the repayment risk associated with each portfolio segment described on the next page.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P74_S0	Commercial Commercial loans are generally underwritten to existing cash flows of operating businesses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P74_S1	Debt coverage is provided by business cash flows and economic trends influenced by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P75_S0	Agricultural Loans secured by crop production and livestock are especially vulnerable to two risk factors that are largely outside the control of Company and borrowers: commodity prices and weather conditions.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P76_S0	Real estate Residential and H ome E quity L ines of C redit The degree of risk in residential real estate lending depends primarily on the loan amount in relation to collateral value, the interest rate and the borrower s ability to repay in an orderly fashion.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P76_S1	These loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P76_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P76_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P77_S0	R e al e state Commercial Commercial real estate mortgage loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments, except land and construction loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P77_S1	Adverse economic developments or an overbuilt market impact commercial real estate projects and may result in troubled loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P77_S2	Trends in vacancy rates of commercial properties impact the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P77_S3	High vacancy rates reduce operating revenues and the ability for properties to produce sufficient cash flow to service debt obligations.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P78_S0	Real estate Construction and Land Development Construction and land development loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P78_S1	A major risk arises from the necessity to complete projects within specified cost and time lines.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P78_S2	Trends in the construction industry significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as demand drives construction activity.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P78_S3	In addition, trends in real estate values significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as property values determine the economic viability of construction projects.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P79_S0	Automobile An automobile loan portfolio is usually comprised of a large number of smaller loans scheduled to be amortized over a specific period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P79_S1	Most automobile loans are made directly for consumer purchases, but business vehicles may also be included.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P79_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P79_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating .
1168455_15_ITEM8_P80_S0	Other Other loans primarily consist of consumer and credit card loans and are similar in nature to automobile loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P81_S0	Although management believes the allowance to be adequate, ultimate losses may vary from its estimates.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P81_S1	At least quarterly, the Board of Directors and management review the adequacy of the allowance, including consideration of the relative risks in the portfolio, current economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P81_S2	If the Board of Directors and management determine that changes are warranted based on those reviews, the allowance is adjusted.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P81_S3	In addition, the Company s primary regulators, the FDIC and DBO, as an integral part of their examination process, review the adequacy of the allowance.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P81_S4	These regulatory agencies may require additions to the allowance based on their judgment about information available at the time of their examinations.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Company also maintains a separate allowance for off-balance-sheet commitments.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P83_S0	Management estimates anticipated losses using historical data and utilization assumptions.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P83_S1	The allowance for these commitments totaled $141,000 at December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively and is included in accrued interest payable and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S0	Other real estate owned relates to real estate acquired in full or partial settlement of loan obligations, which was $3,590,000 ($5,884,000 less a valuation allowance of $2,294,000) at December 31, 2014 and $6,399,000 ($9,065,000 less a valuation allowance of $2,666,000) at December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S1	Proceeds from sales of other real estate owned totaled $3,399,000, $2,404,000 and $3,714,000 for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 the Company recorded gains on sale of other real estate owned of $101,000 and $171,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2012 the Company recorded a loss on sale of other real estate owned of $16,000.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S4	Other real estate owned is initially recorded at fair value less cost to sell when acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S5	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S6	The allowance is established through a provision for losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P84_S7	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are also recorded in other expenses as incurred.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P85_S0	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P86_S0	Intangible assets consist of core deposit intangibles related to branch acquisitions and are amortized using the straight-line method over ten years.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P86_S1	These assets were fully amortized as of December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P86_S2	The Company evaluates the recoverability and remaining useful life annually to determine whether events or circumstances warrant a revision to the intangible asset or the remaining period of amortization.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P86_S3	There were no such events or circumstances in 2013 or 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P87_S0	Premises and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P88_S0	Depreciation is determined using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P88_S1	The useful lives of premises are estimated to be twenty to thirty years.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P88_S2	The useful lives of furniture, fixtures and equipment are estimated to be two to ten years.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P89_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the life of the asset or the life of the related lease, whichever is shorter.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P89_S1	When assets are sold or otherwise disposed of, the cost and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts, and any resulting gain or loss is recognized in income for the period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P90_S0	The cost of maintenance and repairs is charged to expense as incurred.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P91_S0	The Company evaluates premises and equipment for financial impairment as events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be fully recoverable.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P92_S0	The Company has purchased life insurance policies on certain key executives.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P93_S0	Bank owned life insurance is recorded at the amount that can be realized under the insurance contract at the balance sheet date, which is the cash surrender value adjusted for other charges or other amounts due that are probable at settlement.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P94_S0	The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P95_S0	Income tax expense is the total of current year income tax due or refundable and the change in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P96_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P96_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are adjusted for the effects of changes in tax laws and rates on the date of enactment.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P96_S2	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P97_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P98_S0	When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P98_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P98_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P98_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P98_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P99_S0	Interest expense and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits, if any, are classified as income tax expense in the consolidated income statement.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P99_S1	There have been no significant changes to unrecognized tax benefits or accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P100_S0	Basic earnings per share (EPS), which excludes dilution, is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders (net income plus discount on redemption of preferred stock less preferred dividends and accretion) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P100_S1	Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P100_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted EPS.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P101_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P101_S1	Other comprehensive income includes unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale which are also recognized as separate components of equity.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P101_S2	There were no sales of available for sale investment securities during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P101_S3	The amount reclassified out of other accumulated comprehensive income relating to realized gains on securities available for sale was $128,000 and $403,000 for 2014 and 2012, with the related tax effect of $53,000 and $167,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P102_S0	Banking regulations require maintaining certain capital levels and may limit the dividend paid by the bank to the holding company or by the holding company to shareholders.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P103_S0	Fair values of financial instruments are estimated using relevant market information and other assumptions, as more fully disclosed in a separate note.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P103_S1	Fair value estimates involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment regarding interest rates, credit risk, prepayments, and other factors, especially in the absence of broad markets for particular items.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P103_S2	Changes in assumptions or in market conditions could significantly affect these estimates.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P104_S0	Compensation expense related to the Company s Stock Option Plans, net of related tax benefit, recorded in 2014, 2013 and 2012 totaled $75,000, $37,000 and $93,000 or $0.02, $0.01 and $0.02 per diluted share, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P104_S1	Compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period on a straight line accounting basis.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P105_S0	The Company determines the fair value of options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model that uses assumptions based on expected option life, expected stock volatility and the risk-free interest rate.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P105_S1	The expected volatility assumptions used by the Company are based on the historical volatility of the Company s common stock over the most recent period commensurate with the estimated expected life of the Company s stock options.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P105_S2	The Company bases its expected life assumption on its historical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock options it grants to employees.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P105_S3	The risk-free rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve for the periods within the contractual life of the options in effect at the time of the grant.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P106_S0	The Company also makes assumptions regarding estimated forfeitures that will impact the total compensation expenses recognized under the Plans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P107_S0	During 2014 the Company granted options to purchase 110,400 shares of common stock.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P107_S1	The fair value of each option was estimated on the date of grant using the following assumptions.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P108_S0	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P109_S0	In July 2013, the FASB issued ASU 2013-11, Income Taxes, Presentation of an Unrecognized Tax Benefit When a Net Operating Loss Carryforward, a Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P109_S1	The FASB issued ASU 2013-11 to eliminate the diversity in the presentation of unrecognized tax benefits in those instances.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P109_S2	The amendments in this update are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P109_S3	The Company has determined the provisions for ASU 2013-11 did not have a material impact on the financial statements.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P110_S0	In January 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-04, Reclassification of Residential Real Estate Collateralized Consumer Mortgage Loans upon Foreclosure.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P110_S1	The objective of this guidance is to clarify when an in substance repossession or foreclosure occurs, that is, when a creditor should be considered to have received physical possession of residential real estate property collateralizing a consumer mortgage loan such that the loan receivable should be derecognized and the real estate property recognized.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P111_S0	ASU No. 2014-04 states that an in substance repossession or foreclosure occurs, and a creditor is considered to have received physical possession of residential real estate property collateralizing a consumer mortgage loan, upon either (1) the creditor obtaining legal title to the residential real estate property upon completion of a foreclosure or (2) the borrower conveying all interest in the residential real estate property to the creditor to satisfy that loan through completion of a deed in lieu of foreclosure or through a similar legal agreement.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P111_S1	Additionally, ASU No. 2014-04 requires interim and annual disclosure of both (1) the amount of foreclosed residential real estate property held by the creditor and (2) the recorded investment in consumer mortgage loans collateralized by residential real estate property that are in the process of foreclosure according to local requirements of the applicable jurisdiction.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P111_S2	ASU No. 2014-04 is effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2014.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P111_S3	The adoption of ASU No. 2014-04 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s Financial Statements.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P112_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P112_S1	This update to the ASC is the culmination of efforts by the FASB and the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) to develop a common revenue standard for U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P112_S2	ASU 2014-09 supersedes Topic 605 Revenue Recognition and most industry-specific guidance.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P113_S0	The core principal of the guidance is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P113_S1	The guidance in ASU 2014-09 describes a 5-step process entities can apply to achieve the core principle of revenue recognition and requires disclosures sufficient to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing, and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers and the significant judgments used in determining that information.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P114_S0	The amendments in ASU 2014-9 are effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016, including interim periods within that reporting period and early application is not allowed.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P114_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the effects of ASU 2014-09 on its financial statements and disclosures, if any.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P115_S0	In June 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-11, Repurchase-to-Maturity Transactions, Repurchase Financings, and Disclosures.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P115_S1	The Update improves the financial reporting of repurchase agreements and other similar transactions through a change in accounting for repurchase-to-maturity transactions and repurchase financings, and the introduction of two new disclosure requirements.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P115_S2	New disclosures are required for (1) transfers accounted for as sales in transactions that are economically similar to repurchase agreements, in which the transferor retains substantially all of the exposure to the economic return on the transferred financial asset throughout the term of the transaction and (2) repurchase agreements, securities lending transactions, and repurchase-to-maturity transactions accounted for as secured borrowings about the nature of collateral pledged and the time to maturity of those transactions.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P115_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the effects of ASU 2014-011 on its financial statements and disclosures, if any.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P116_S0	The Company measures fair value under the fair value hierarchy described below.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P117_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active exchange markets.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P118_S0	Level 2: Quoted prices (unadjusted) for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-based valuation techniques for which all significant assumptions are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P119_S0	Level 3: Model based techniques that use one significant assumption not observable in the market.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P119_S1	These unobservable assumptions reflect the Company s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use on pricing the asset or liability.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P120_S0	Valuation techniques include management judgment and estimation which may be significant.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P121_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P121_S1	In such cases, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P121_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P122_S0	Management monitors the availability of observable market data to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P123_S0	Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value level to another.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P123_S1	In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P124_S0	Management evaluates the significance of transfers between levels based upon the nature of the financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total assets, total liabilities or total earnings.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P125_S0	The carrying amounts and estimated fair values of financial instruments, at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013 are as follows:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P126_S0	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated future business related to the instruments.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P126_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P127_S0	The following methods and assumptions were used by management to estimate the fair value of its financial instruments:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P128_S0	The carrying amounts of cash and short-term instruments approximate fair values and are classified as Level 1.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P129_S0	Investment securities: Fair values for securities available for sale are generally determined by matrix pricing, which is a mathematical technique widely used in the industry to value debt securities without relying exclusively on quoted prices for the specific securities but rather by relying on the securities relationship to other benchmark quoted securities (Level 2).
1168455_15_ITEM8_P130_S0	Loans: Fair values of loans, excluding loans held for sale, are estimated as follows:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P130_S1	For variable rate loans that reprice frequently and with no significant change in credit risk, fair values are based on carrying values resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P130_S2	Fair values for other loans are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered for loans with similar terms to borrowers of similar credit quality resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P131_S0	Impaired loans are valued at the lower of cost or fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P132_S0	The methods utilized to estimate the fair value of loans do not necessarily represent an exit price.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P133_S0	It was not practicable to determine the fair value of the FHLB stock due to restrictions placed on its transferability.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P134_S0	Deposits: The fair values disclosed for demand deposits, including interest and non-interest demand accounts, savings, and certain types of money market accounts are, by definition, equal to the carrying amount at the reporting date resulting in a Level 1 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P134_S1	Fair values for fixed rate certificates of deposit are estimated using a discounted cash flow calculation that applies interest rates currently being offered on certificates to a schedule of aggregated expected monthly maturities on time deposits resulting in a Level 2 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P135_S0	Repurchase agreements: The fair value of securities sold under repurchase agreements is estimated based on bid quotations received from brokers using observable inputs and are included as Level 2.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P136_S0	The fair value of the Company s Note Payable is estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P137_S0	Su bordinated debentures and Junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures : The fair values of the Company s Subordinated Debentures are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P138_S0	The carrying amounts of accrued interest approximate fair value and are considered to be linked in classification to the asset or liability for which they relate.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P139_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit: The fair value of commitments are estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements and are not significant and, therefore, not presented.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P139_S1	Commitments to extend credit are primarily for variable rate loans and letters of credit.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P140_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments and other factors.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P140_S1	Those estimates that are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and therefore cannot be determined with precision are included in Level 3.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P141_S0	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the fair values presented.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P142_S0	The following tables present information about the Company s assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non-recurring basis as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, and indicates the fair value hierarchy of the valuation techniques utilized by the Company to determine such fair value:

1168455_15_ITEM8_P144_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at December 31, 2013 are summarized below:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P145_S0	The fair value of securities available-for-sale equals quoted market price, if available.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P145_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair value is determined using quoted market prices for similar securities or matrix pricing.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P145_S2	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2014 or 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P145_S3	Transfers between hierarchy measurement levels are recognized by the Company as of the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P146_S0	Changes in fair market value are recorded in other comprehensive income.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P147_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2014 are summarized below:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P148_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2013 are summarized below:
1168455_15_ITEM8_P149_S0	The Company has no liabilities which are reported at fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P150_S0	The following methods were used to estimate fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P151_S0	Impaired Loans: The fair value of collateral dependent impaired loans with specific allocations of the allowance for loan losses or loans that have been subject to partial charge-offs are generally based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P151_S1	These appraisals may utilize a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P151_S2	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P151_S3	Such adjustments are usually significant and typically result in a Level 3 classification of the inputs for determining fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P152_S0	Total losses of $125,000 and $24,000 represent impairment charges recognized during the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, related to the above impaired loans.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P153_S0	Other Real Estate: Nonrecurring adjustments to certain commercial and residential real estate properties classified as other real estate owned (OREO) are measured at fair value, less costs to sell.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P153_S1	Fair values are based on recent real estate appraisals.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P153_S2	These appraisals may use a single valuation approach or a combination of approaches including comparable sales and the income approach.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P154_S0	Appraisals for both collateral-dependent impaired loans and other real estate are performed by certified general appraisers (for commercial properties) or certified residential appraisers (for residential properties) whose qualifications and licenses have been reviewed and verified by the Company.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P154_S1	Once received, a member of the Loan Administration Department reviews the assumptions and approaches utilized in the appraisal as well as the overall resulting fair value in comparison with independent data sources such as recent market data or industry-wide statistics.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P154_S2	On a quarterly basis, the Company compares the actual selling price of similar collateral that has been liquidated to the most recent appraised value for unsold properties to determine what additional adjustment, if any, should be made to the appraisal value to arrive at fair value.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P154_S3	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.

1168455_15_ITEM8_P164_S1	As of December 31, 2014, management does not have the intent to sell these securities nor does it believe it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell these securities before the recovery of its amortized cost basis.

1168455_15_ITEM8_P169_S5	Of these amounts, $31,000, $22,000 and $192,000 were recognized on the cash basis, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P170_S0	Included in impaired loans are troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P170_S1	A troubled debt restructuring is a formal restructure of a loan where the Company for economic or legal reasons related to the borrower s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the borrower.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P170_S2	The concessions may be granted in various forms to include one or a combination of the following: a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan; an extension of the maturity date at a stated rate of interest lower than the current market rate for new debt with similar risk; or a permanent reduction of the recorded investment in the loan.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P171_S0	In order to determine whether a borrower is experiencing financial difficulty, an evaluation is performed of the probability that the borrower will be in payment default on any of its debt in the foreseeable future without the modification.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P171_S1	This evaluation is performed under the Company s internal underwriting policy.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P172_S0	The carrying value of troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013 was $5,738,000 and $7,616,000, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P172_S1	The Company has allocated $319,000 and $284,000 of specific reserves on loans to customers whose loan terms have been modified in troubled debt restructurings as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P172_S2	The Company has not committed to lend additional amounts on loans classified as troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P173_S0	During the twelve month period ended December 31, 2014, the terms of certain loans were modified as troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P173_S1	Modifications involving a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan was for periods ranging from 1 month to 10 years.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P174_S0	During the twelve month period ended December 31, 2013, the terms of certain loans were modified as troubled debt restructurings.
1168455_15_ITEM8_P174_S1	Modifications involving a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan was for periods ranging from 1 month to 10 years.
