1168455_16_ITEM1_P79_S1	The DIF is funded primarily by FDIC assessments paid by each DIF member institution.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P79_S2	The amount of FDIC assessments paid by each DIF member institution is based on its relative risk of default as measured by regulatory capital ratios and other supervisory factors.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P79_S3	The Bank s FDIC insurance expense totaled $333 thousand for 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P80_S0	Additionally, all FDIC-insured institutions are required to pay assessments to the FDIC to fund interest payments on bonds issued by the Financing Corporation ( FICO ), an agency of the Federal government established to recapitalize the predecessor to the DIF.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P80_S1	The Bank s FICO assessments totaled $29 thousand for 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P80_S2	These assessments will continue until the FICO bonds mature in 2017.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P81_S0	The FDIC may terminate a depository institution s deposit insurance upon a finding that the institution s financial condition is unsafe or unsound or that the institution has engaged in unsafe or unsound practices that pose a risk to the DIF or that may prejudice the interest of the bank s depositors.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P81_S1	Under California law, the termination of deposit insurance for the Bank would result in a termination of the Bank s charter.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P82_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ), authorized national and state banks to establish branches in other states to the same extent as a bank chartered by that state would be permitted to branch.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P82_S1	Previously, banks could only establish branches in other states if the host state expressly permitted out-of-state banks to establish branches in that state.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P82_S2	Accordingly, banks may now enter new markets more freely.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P83_S0	The banking regulatory agencies are focusing greater attention on compliance with consumer protection laws and their implementing regulations.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P83_S1	Examination and enforcement have become more intense in nature, and insured institutions have been advised to monitor carefully compliance with such laws and regulations.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P83_S2	The Company is subject to many federal and state consumer protection and privacy statutes and regulations, including but not limited to the following:
1168455_16_ITEM1_P84_S0	The Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ) generally prohibits discrimination in any credit transaction, whether for consumer or business purposes, on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age (except in limited circumstances), receipt of income from public assistance programs, or good faith exercise of any rights under the Consumer Credit Protection Act.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P85_S0	The Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) is designed to ensure that credit terms are disclosed in a meaningful way so that consumers may compare credit terms more readily and knowledgeably.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P85_S1	As a result of the TILA, all creditors must use the same credit terminology to express rates and payments, including the annual percentage rate, the finance charge, the amount financed, the total of payments and the payment schedule, among other things.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P86_S0	As a result of the Dodd-Frank Act, Regulation Z promulgated under the TILA includes new limits on loan originator compensation for all closed-end mortgages.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P86_S1	These changes include, prohibiting certain payments to a mortgage broker or loan officer based on the transaction s terms or conditions, prohibiting dual compensation, and prohibiting a mortgage broker or loan officer from steering consumers to transactions not in their interest, to increase mortgage broker or loan officer compensation.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P87_S0	The Fair Housing Act ( FH Act ) regulates many practices, including making it unlawful for any lender to discriminate in its housing-related lending activities against any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap or familial status.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P87_S1	A number of lending practices have been found by the courts to be, or may be considered, illegal under the FH Act, including some that are not specifically mentioned in the FH Act itself.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P88_S0	The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act ( HMDA ), in response to public concern over credit shortages in certain urban neighborhoods, requires public disclosure of information that shows whether financial institutions are serving the housing credit needs of the neighborhoods and communities in which they are located.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P88_S1	The HMDA also includes a fair lending aspect that requires the collection and disclosure of data about applicant and borrower characteristics as a way of identifying possible discriminatory lending patterns and enforcing anti-discrimination statutes.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P89_S0	The Right to Financial Privacy Act ( RFPA ) imposes a new requirement for financial institutions to provide new privacy protections to consumers.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P89_S1	Financial institutions must provide disclosures to consumers of its privacy policy, and state the rights of consumers to direct their financial institution not to share their nonpublic personal information with third parties.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P90_S0	The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ) requires lenders to provide noncommercial borrowers with disclosures regarding the nature and cost of real estate settlements.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P90_S1	Also, RESPA prohibits certain abusive practices, such as kickbacks, and places limitations on the amount of escrow accounts.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P91_S0	Penalties for noncompliance or violations under the above laws may include fines, reimbursement and other penalties.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P91_S1	Due to heightened regulatory expectations related to compliance with generally, the Company may incur additional compliance costs.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P92_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act created a new, independent federal agency called the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which is granted broad rulemaking, supervisory and enforcement powers under various federal consumer financial protection laws.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P93_S0	The CFPB has examination and primary enforcement authority with respect to depository institutions with $10 billion or more in assets.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P93_S1	Smaller institutions, including the Bank, will be subject to rules promulgated by the CFPB but will continue to be examined and supervised by federal banking regulators for consumer compliance purposes. .
1168455_16_ITEM1_P94_S0	A series of banking laws and regulations beginning with the bank Secrecy Act in 1970 requires banks to prevent, detect, and report illicit or illegal financial activities to the federal government to prevent money laundering, international drug trafficking, and terrorism.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P95_S0	Under the US PATRIOT Act of 2001, financial institutions are subject to prohibitions against specified financial transactions and account relationships, requirements regarding the Customer Identification Program, as well as enhanced due diligence and know your customer standards in their dealings with high risk customers, foreign financial institutions, and foreign individuals and entities.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S0	The Gramm-Leach Bliley Act ( GLBA ) of 1999 imposes requirements on financial institutions with respect to consumer privacy.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S1	The GLBA generally prohibits disclosure of consumer information to non-affiliated third parties unless the consumer has been given the opportunity to object and has not objected to such disclosure.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S2	Financial institutions are further required to disclose their privacy policies to consumers annually.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S3	The GLBA also directs federal regulators, including the FDIC, to prescribe standards for the security of consumer information.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S4	The Bank is subject to such standards, as well as standards for notifying consumers in the event of a security breach.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S5	The Bank is required to have an information security program to safeguard the confidentiality and security of customer information and to ensure proper disposal of information that is no longer needed.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P96_S6	Customers must be notified when unauthorized disclosure involves sensitive customer information that may be misused.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P97_S0	Under federal law, the Bank and its institution-affiliated parties may be the subject of potential enforcement actions by the FDIC for unsafe and unsound practices in conducting their businesses, or for violations of any law, rule or regulation or provision, any consent order with any agency, any condition imposed in writing by the agency or any written agreement with the agency.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P97_S1	Enforcement actions may include the imposition of a conservator or receiver, cease-and-desist orders and written agreements, the termination of insurance of deposits, the imposition of civil money penalties, the payment of restitution and removal and prohibition orders against institution-affiliated parties.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P97_S2	The DBO also has authority to bring similar enforcement actions against the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P97_S3	The FRB has the authority to bring similar enforcement actions against the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P98_S0	From time to time, legislation is enacted which has the effect of increasing the cost of doing business, limiting or expanding permissible activities or affecting the competitive balance between banks and other financial institutions.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P98_S1	Proposals to change the laws and regulations governing the operations and taxation of banks, bank holding companies and other financial institutions are frequently made in Congress, in the California legislature and before various bank regulatory agencies.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P98_S2	Typically, the intent of this type of legislation is to strengthen the banking industry, even if it may on occasion prove to be a burden on management s plans.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P98_S3	No prediction can be made as to the likelihood of any major changes or the impact that new laws or regulations might have on us.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P99_S0	Our earnings and growth are affected not only by general economic conditions, but also by the fiscal and monetary policies of the federal government, particularly the FRB.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P99_S1	The FRB implements national monetary policy for such purposes as curbing inflation and combating recession, through its open market operations in U.S. Government securities, control of the discount rate applicable to borrowings from the FRB, and establishment of reserve requirements against certain deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P99_S2	These activities influence growth of bank loans, investments and deposits, and also affect interest rates charged on loans or paid on deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P100_S0	The Company s profitability, like most financial institutions, is primarily dependent on interest rate spreads.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P100_S1	In general, the difference between the interest rates paid by the Bank on interest-bearing liabilities, such as deposits and other borrowings, and the interest rates received by the Bank on interest-earning assets, such as loans extended to customers and securities held in the investment portfolio, will comprise the major portion of the Company s earnings.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P100_S2	These rates are highly sensitive to many factors that are beyond our control, such as inflation, recession and unemployment, the monetary and fiscal policies of the federal government and the policies of regulatory agencies, particularly the FRB and the impact which future changes in domestic and foreign economic conditions might have on us cannot be predicted.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P101_S0	The nature and impact of future changes in monetary policies and their impact on us cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_16_ITEM1_P102_S0	See Note 2 Summary of Significant Accounting Policies Adoption of New Accounting Standards of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K for information related to recent accounting pronouncements.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	A deterioration of national or local economic conditions could reduce the Company s profitability.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Company s lending operations and its customers are primarily located in the eastern region of Northern California.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	A significant downturn in the national economy or the local economy due to agricultural commodity prices, real estate prices, public policy decisions, natural disaster, drought or other factors could result in a decline in the local economy in general, which could in turn negatively impact the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The majority of the Company s assets are loans, which if not repaid would result in losses to the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Bank, like other lenders, is subject to credit risk, which is the risk of losing principal or interest due to borrowers failure to repay loans in accordance with their terms.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Underwriting and documentation controls cannot mitigate all credit risk.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S2	A downturn in the economy or the real estate market in the Company s market areas or a rapid increase in interest rates could have a negative effect on collateral values and borrowers ability to repay.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S3	To the extent loans are not paid timely by borrowers, the loans are placed on non-accrual status, thereby reducing interest income.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Further, under these circumstances, an additional provision for loan and lease losses or unfunded commitments may be required.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P4_S5	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses .
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	If the Company s allowance for loan losses is not sufficient to absorb actual loan losses, the Company s profitability could be reduced.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The risk of loan losses is inherent in the lending business.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for loan losses based upon the Company s actual losses over a relevant time period and management s assessment of all relevant qualitative factors that may cause future loss experience to differ from its historical loss experience.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Although the Company maintains a rigorous process for determining the allowance for loan losses, it can give no assurance that it will be sufficient to cover future loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P6_S3	If the allowance for loan losses is not adequate to absorb future losses, or if bank regulatory agencies require the Company to increase its allowance for loan losses, earnings could be significantly and adversely impacted.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	A deterioration in the real estate market could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	As of December 31, 2015, approximately 73% of the Company s total loan portfolio is secured by real estate, the majority of which is commercial real estate.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Increases in commercial and consumer delinquency levels or declines in real estate market values would require increased net charge-offs and increases in the allowance for loan losses, which could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations and prospects.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Fluctuations in interest rates could reduce profitability.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company s earnings depend largely upon net interest income, which is the difference between the total interest income earned on interest earning assets (primarily loans and investment securities) and the total interest expense incurred on interest bearing liabilities (primarily deposits and borrowed funds).
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P10_S1	The interest earned on assets and paid on liabilities are affected principally by direct competition, and general economic conditions at the state and national level and other factors beyond the Company s control such as actions of the FRB, the general supply of money in the economy, legislative tax policies, governmental budgetary matters, and other state and federal economic policies.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Although the Company maintains a rigorous process for managing the impact of possible interest rate fluctuations on earnings, the Company can provide no assurance that its management efforts will prevent earnings from being significantly and adversely impacted by changes in interest rates.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Company could be required to raise additional capital in the future, but that capital may not be available when it is needed or may not be available on terms that are favorable to the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Federal and state bank regulatory authorities require the Company and the Bank to maintain adequate levels of capital to support their operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The Company s ability to raise additional capital if and as needed depends on conditions in the capital markets, which are outside the Company s control, and on the Company s financial performance.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Accordingly, the Company may not be able to raise additional capital, if needed, on terms that are acceptable to the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P12_S3	If the Company is unable to raise additional capital when needed, it could be required to curtail its growth strategy or reduce the levels of assets owned.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P12_S4	In addition, although the Company and the Bank are currently well-capitalized under applicable regulatory frameworks, bank regulators are authorized and sometimes required to impose a wide range of requirements, conditions, and restrictions on banks and bank holding companies that fail to maintain adequate capital levels.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The continuing California drought could have an adverse impact on the Company s business.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	During 2015, California continued to experience a severe drought.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	A significant portion of the Company s borrowers are involved in or are dependent on the agricultural industry in California, which requires water.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P15_S1	As of December 31, 2015, approximately 10% of the Company s loans were categorized as agricultural loans.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	As a result of the drought, there have been governmental proposals concerning the distribution or rationing of water.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P16_S1	If the amount of water available to agriculture becomes scarcer due to drought or rationing, growers may not be able to continue to produce agricultural products profitably, which could force some out of business.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Although many of the Company s customers are not directly involved in agriculture, they could be impacted by difficulties in the agricultural industry because many jobs and businesses in the Company s market areas are related to the production of agricultural products.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P16_S3	Therefore, the drought could adversely impact the Company s loan portfolio, business, financial condition and results of operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The Company faces substantial competition from larger banks and other financial institutions.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The Company faces substantial competition for deposits and loans.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S1	Competition for deposits primarily comes from other commercial banks, savings institutions, thrift and loan associations, money market and mutual funds and other investment alternatives.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Competition for loans comes from other commercial banks, savings institutions, credit unions, mortgage banking firms, thrift and loan associations and other financial intermediaries.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S3	Larger competitors, by virtue of their larger capital resources, have substantially greater lending limits and marketing resources than the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S4	In addition, they have greater resources and may be able to offer longer maturities or lower rates.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S5	The Company s competitors may also provide certain services for their customers, including trust and international banking, that the Company is only able to offer indirectly through correspondent relationships.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P18_S6	Ultimately, competition can reduce the Company s profitability, as well as make it more difficult to increase the size of its loan portfolio and deposit base.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	There are risks associated with the Company s growth strategy.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	During the past year, the Company completed the purchase and assumption of a branch office in Redding, California, received regulatory approval to open a branch office in Reno, Nevada and established a loan production office in Scottsdale, Arizona.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P20_S1	The Company may engage in additional acquisition activity and open additional offices in the future to expand the Company s markets or further its growth strategy.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P20_S2	There is no assurance that future acquisitions or offices will be successful.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Further, growth may strain the Company s administrative, managerial, financial and operational resources and increase demands on its systems and controls.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P20_S4	If the Company pursues its growth strategy too aggressively, fails to attract qualified personnel, control costs or maintain asset quality, or if factors beyond management s control divert attention away from its business operations, the Company s pursuit of its growth strategy could have a material adverse impact on its existing business.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	The Company relies on key executives and personnel and the loss of any of them could have a material adverse impact on the Company s prospects.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Competition for qualified employees and personnel in the banking industry is intense and there are a limited number of qualified persons with knowledge of, and experience in, the California community banking industry.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P22_S1	The process of recruiting personnel with the combination of skills and attributes required to carry out the Company s strategies is often lengthy.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P22_S2	The Company s success depends to a significant degree upon its ability to attract and retain qualified management, loan origination, finance, administrative, marketing, compliance and technical personnel and upon the continued contributions of its management and personnel.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P22_S3	In particular, the Company s success has been and continues to be highly dependent upon the abilities of key executives and certain other employees.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Security breaches and technological disruptions could damage the Company s reputation and profitability.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The Company s business is highly reliant on third party vendors and its ability to manage the operational risks associated with outsourcing those services.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The Company s electronic banking activities expose it to possible liability and loss of reputation should an unauthorized party gain access to confidential customer information.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Despite its considerable efforts and investment to provide the security and authentication necessary to effect secure transmission of data, the Company cannot fully guarantee that these precautions will protect its systems from future compromises or breaches of its security measures.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Although the Company has developed systems and processes that are designed to recognize and assist in preventing security breaches (and periodically test its security), failure to protect against or mitigate breaches of security could adversely affect its ability to offer and grow its online services, constitute a breach of privacy or other laws, result in costly litigation and loss of customer relationships, negatively impact the Bank s reputation, and could have an adverse effect on its business, results of operations and financial condition.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P24_S3	The Company may also incur substantial increases in costs in an effort to minimize or mitigate cyber security risks and to respond to cyber incidents.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	The potential for operational risk exposure exists throughout the Company s business.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Integral to the Company s performance is the continued efficacy of the Company s technology and information systems, operational infrastructure and relationships with third parties and its colleagues in its day-to-day and ongoing operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Failure by any or all of these resources subjects us to risks that may vary in size, scale and scope.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	This includes, but is not limited to, operational or systems failures, disruption of client operations and activities, ineffectiveness or exposure due to interruption in third party support as expected, as well as, the loss of key colleagues or failure on the part of key colleagues to perform properly.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Additionally, the Company outsources a large portion of its data processing to third parties which may encounter technological or other difficulties that may significantly affect the Company s ability to process and account for customer transactions.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P27_S1	These vendors provide services that support its operations, including the storage and processing of sensitive consumer and business customer data, as well as its sales efforts.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P28_S0	A cyber security breach of a vendor s system may result in theft of the Company s data or disruption of business processes.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P28_S1	In most cases, the Company will remain primarily liable to its customers for losses arising from a breach of a vendor s data security system.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The Company relies on its outsourced service providers to implement and maintain prudent cyber security controls.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P29_S1	The loss of these vendor relationships could disrupt the services the Company provides to its customers and cause us to incur significant expense in connection with replacing these services.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The Company may incur fines, penalties and other negative consequences from regulatory violations, possibly even inadvertent or unintentional violations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	The Company is subject to significant federal and state regulation and supervision.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S1	In the past, the Company s business has been increasingly affected by these regulations, and this trend is likely to continue into the future.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Many of these laws are subject to interpretation and changing regulatory approaches to supervision and enforcement.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S3	The Company maintains systems and procedures designed to ensure that it complies with applicable laws and regulations, but there can be no assurance that these will be effective.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S4	The Company may incur fines, penalties and other negative consequences from regulatory violations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S5	The Company may also suffer other negative consequences resulting from findings of noncompliance with laws and regulations, that may also damage its reputation, and this in turn might materially affect its business and results of operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P31_S6	Further, some legal/regulatory frameworks provide for the imposition of fines, restitution or penalties for noncompliance even though the noncompliance was inadvertent or unintentional and even though there were in place at the time systems and procedures designed to ensure compliance.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The Company s disclosure controls and procedures may not prevent or detect all errors or acts of fraud.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P33_S0	The Company s disclosure controls and procedures are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed by us in reports it files under the Exchange Act is accurately accumulated and communicated to management, and recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P33_S1	The Company believes that any disclosure controls and procedures or internal controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, cannot provide absolute assurance that the objectives of the control system are met.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P34_S0	These inherent limitations include the realities that judgments in decision making can be faulty, that alternative reasoned judgments can be drawn, or that breakdowns can occur because of a simple error or mistake.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Additionally, controls can be circumvented by the individual acts of some persons, by collusion of two or more people or by an unauthorized override of the controls.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P34_S2	Accordingly, because of the inherent limitations in its control system, misstatements due to error or fraud may occur and not be detected, which could result in a material weakness in its internal controls over financial reporting and the restatement of previously filed financial statements.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The trading price of the Company s common stock may fluctuate as a result of a number of factors, many of which are outside its control.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Among the factors that could affect the Company s stock price are:
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P36_S0	domestic and international economic factors unrelated to its performance.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Significant decline in the Company s stock price could result in substantial losses for individual shareholders and could lead to costly and disruptive securities litigation.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P38_S0	The trading volume of the Company s common stock is limited.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Although the Company s common stock is traded on the Nasdaq Stock Market, trading to date has been relatively modest.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P39_S1	The limited trading market for the Company s common stock may lead to exaggerated fluctuations in market prices and possible market inefficiencies compared to more actively traded securities.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P39_S2	It may also make it more difficult for investors to sell the Company s common stock at desired prices, especially for holders seeking to dispose of a large number shares of stock.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P40_S0	The Company depends primarily on the operations of the Bank to repay its indebtedness.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P40_S1	The Company s ability to pay any dividends or repurchase any of its shares in the future will also depend on the success of the Bank s operations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P41_S0	The Company is a separate and distinct legal entity from its subsidiary, the Bank, and it receives substantially all of its revenue from dividends paid by the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P41_S1	There are legal limitations on the extent to which the Bank may extend credit, pay dividends or otherwise supply funds to, or engage in transactions with, the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P41_S2	The Company s inability to receive dividends from the Bank could adversely affect its business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Disruptions in market conditions may adversely impact the fair value of available-for-sale investment securities .
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ) require the Company to carry its available-for-sale investment securities at fair value on its balance sheet.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Unrealized gains or losses on these securities, reflecting the difference between the fair market value and the amortized cost, net of its tax effect, are reported as a component of shareholders equity.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P44_S0	In certain instances GAAP requires recognition through earnings of declines in the fair value of securities that are deemed to be other than temporarily impaired.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Changes in the fair value of these securities may result from a number of circumstances that are beyond the Company s control, such as changes in interest rates, the financial condition of government sponsored enterprises or insurers of municipal bonds, changes in demand for these securities as a result of economic conditions, or reduced market liquidity.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P44_S2	There can be no assurance that the declines in market value will not result in other than temporary impairments of these assets, which would lead to loss recognition that could have a material adverse effect on the Company s net income and capital levels.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Damage to the Company s reputation could significantly harm the Company s business and prospects.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The Company s reputation is an important asset.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The Company s relationship with many of its customers is predicated upon its reputation as a high quality provider of financial services that adheres to the highest standards of ethics, service quality and regulatory compliance.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P47_S0	The Company s ability to attract and retain customers, investors and employees depends upon external perceptions.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P47_S1	Damage to its reputation among existing and potential customers, investors and employees could cause significant harm to the Company s business and prospects and may arise from numerous sources, including litigation or regulatory actions, failing to deliver minimum standards of service and quality, lending practices, inadequate protection of customer information, sales and marketing efforts, compliance failures, unethical behavior and the misconduct of employees.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Adverse developments in the banking industry may also, by association, negatively impact the Company s reputation or result in greater regulatory or legislative scrutiny or litigation against us.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P47_S3	The Company has policies and procedures in place that seek to protect its reputation and promote ethical conduct, but these policies and procedures may not be fully effective.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P47_S4	Negative publicity regarding the Company s business, employees, or customers, with or without merit, may result in the loss of customers, investors, and employees, costly litigation, a decline in revenues and increased governmental regulation.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P48_S0	The markets in which the Company operates are subject to the risk of earthquakes and other natural disasters.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Most of the Company s offices are located in California.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Also, most of the real and personal properties securing the Company s loans are located in California.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P50_S0	California its prone to earthquakes, brush fires, flooding and other natural disasters.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P50_S1	In addition to possibly sustaining damage to its own properties, if there is a major earthquake, brush fires, flood or other natural disaster, the Company faces the risk that many of the Company s borrowers may experience uninsured property losses, or sustained job interruption and/or loss which may materially impair their ability to meet the terms of their loan obligations.
1168455_16_ITEM1A_P50_S2	Therefore, a major earthquake, brush fire, flood or other natural disaster in California could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	Of the Company s twelve depository branches, ten are owned and two are leased.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	The Company also leases three lending offices and owns four administrative facilities.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	(1) Non-branch administrative or credit administrative offices.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P2_S0	Total rental expenses under all leases totaled $233,000, $192,000 and $154,000, in 2015, 2014 and 2013 respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P2_S1	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2016 and the last such lease expiring during 2020.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P3_S0	Future minimum lease payments are as follows:
1168455_16_ITEM2_P4_S0	The Company maintains insurance coverage on its premises, leaseholds and equipment, including business interruption and record reconstruction coverage.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P4_S1	The branch properties and non-branch offices are adequate, suitable, in good condition and have adequate parking facilities for customers and employees.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P5_S0	The Company and Bank are limited in their investments in real property under Federal and state banking laws.
1168455_16_ITEM2_P5_S1	Generally, investments in real property are either for the Company and Bank use or are in real property and real property interests in the ordinary course of the Bank s business.
1168455_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time, the Company and/or its subsidiary are a party to claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
1168455_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of the Company s management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to such proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on the financial condition or results of operations of the Company taken as a whole.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock is quoted on the NASDAQ Capital Market under the ticker symbol "PLBC".
1168455_16_ITEM5_P0_S1	As of December 31, 2015, there were 4,835,432 shares of the Company s common stock outstanding held by approximately 1,300 shareholders of record as of the same date.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P0_S2	The following table shows the high and low sales prices for the common stock, for each quarter as reported by Yahoo Finance.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P1_S0	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P1_S1	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P2_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_16_ITEM5_P2_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule and in accordance with regulatory restrictions, if any, reviews the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P2_S2	No common cash dividends were paid in 2015 or 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P3_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_16_ITEM5_P3_S1	See Note 12 Shareholders Equity Dividend Restrictions of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K.

1168455_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following table presents a summary of selected financial data and should be read in conjunction with the Company s consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included under Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	We are a bank holding company for Plumas Bank, a California state-chartered commercial bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	We derive our income primarily from interest received on real estate related, commercial, automobile and consumer loans and, to a lesser extent, interest on investment securities, fees received in connection with servicing deposit and loan customers and fees from the sale of government guaranteed loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our major operating expenses are the interest we pay on deposits and borrowings and general operating expenses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P0_S3	We rely on locally-generated deposits to provide us with funds for making loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	We are subject to competition from other financial institutions and our operating results, like those of other financial institutions operating in California, are significantly influenced by economic conditions in California, including the strength of the real estate market.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	In addition, both the fiscal and regulatory policies of the federal and state government and regulatory authorities that govern financial institutions and market interest rates also impact the Bank s financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our accounting policies are integral to understanding the financial results reported.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	Our most complex accounting policies require management s judgment to ascertain the valuation of assets, liabilities, commitments and contingencies.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	We have established detailed policies and internal control procedures that are intended to ensure valuation methods are applied in an environment that is designed and operating effectively and applied consistently from period to period.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	The following is a brief description of our current accounting policies involving significant management valuation judgments.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The allowance for loan losses is an estimate of credit losses inherent in the Company s loan portfolio that have been incurred as of the balance-sheet date.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	The allowance is established through a provision for loan losses which is charged to expense.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	Additions to the allowance are expected to maintain the adequacy of the total allowance after credit losses and loan growth.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Credit exposures determined to be uncollectible are charged against the allowance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	Cash received on previously charged off amounts is recorded as a recovery to the allowance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	The overall allowance consists of two primary components, specific reserves related to impaired loans and general reserves for inherent losses related to loans that are collectively evaluated for impairment.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	We evaluate our allowance for loan losses quarterly.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	We believe that the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting estimate because it is based upon management s assessment of various factors affecting the collectability of the loans, including current economic conditions, past credit experience, delinquency status, the value of the underlying collateral, if any, and a continuing review of the portfolio of loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	We cannot provide you with any assurance that economic difficulties or other circumstances which would adversely affect our borrowers and their ability to repay outstanding loans will not occur which would be reflected in increased losses in our loan portfolio, which could result in actual losses that exceed reserves previously established.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Other real estate owned (OREO) represents properties acquired through foreclosure or physical possession.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	OREO is initially recorded at fair value less costs to sell when acquired.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	Write-downs to fair value at the time of transfer to OREO is charged to allowance for loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Subsequent to foreclosure, we periodically evaluate the value of OREO held for sale and record a valuation allowance for any subsequent declines in fair value less selling costs.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	Subsequent declines in value are charged to operations.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Fair value is based on our assessment of information available to us at the end of a reporting period and depends upon a number of factors, including our historical experience, economic conditions, and issues specific to individual properties.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	Our evaluation of these factors involves subjective estimates and judgments that may change.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	The following discussion is designed to provide a better understanding of significant trends related to the Company s financial condition, results of operations, liquidity and capital.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P11_S1	It pertains to the Company s financial condition, changes in financial condition and results of operations as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 and for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P11_S2	The discussion should be read in conjunction with the Company s audited consolidated financial statements and notes thereto and the other financial information appearing elsewhere herein.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	The Company recorded net income of $5.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, a 23% increase over net income of $4.7 million during the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	Pretax income increased by $1.7 million, or 22%, from to $9.5 million in 2015 from $7.8 million during the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Net interest income increased by $2.0 million to $21.4 million during 2015 from $19.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	This increase in net interest income resulted from an increase in interest income of $1.5 million and a decrease in interest expense of $489 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	Interest on loans increased by $1.3 million and interest on investment securities increased by $179 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	An increase of $2 thousand in interest expense on deposits was offset by a decrease in interest expense on borrowings of $491 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S4	The largest component of this decrease was a decrease of $537 thousand in interest expense related to the redemption of the Company s $7.5 million subordinated debenture in April, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P13_S5	The provision for loan losses was $1.1 million during 2015 and 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2015 non-interest income totaled $7.7 million an increase of $400 thousand from the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	The largest component of this increase was an increase in gain on sale of SBA loans of $546 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	Gains on sale of securities were $21 thousand during 2015 and $128 thousand in 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P14_S3	In addition, the 2014 quarter included a $148 thousand gain on sale of our credit card portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Non-interest expense increased by $646 thousand to $18.5 million during the twelve months ended December 31, 2015, up from $17.8 million during 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	The largest component of this increase was an increase in salary expense of $559 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	This increase includes an increase in loan production personnel costs, costs associated with our new Reno, Nevada branch, an increase in commissions earned on the sale of SBA loans, related to an increase in sales volume, and merit and promotional wage increases.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	The provision for income taxes increased by $631 thousand from $3.1 million in 2014 to $3.7 million during the year ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Total assets at December 31, 2015 were $599 million, an increase of $60.4 million from $539 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	This increase included increases of $22.6 million in cash and due from banks, $6.4 million in investment securities, $30.0 million in net loans, $0.6 million in premises and equipment, $0.3 million in bank owned life insurance and $2.3 million in other assets exclusive of OREO.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Loans increased by $30.6 million, or 8%, from $370.4 million at December 31, 2014 to $401.0 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	The increase in loan balances includes $28.8 million in commercial real estate loans, $5.6 million in commercial loans, $4.5 million in agricultural loans and $3.7 million in automobile loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	These increases were partially offset by declines of $8.4 million in construction and land development loans and $3.6 million in all other loan types.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P18_S3	Construction and land development loans, which management has identified as a higher-risk loan category, represented 4.0% and 6.6% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Total deposits increased by $59.4 million from $468 million at December 31, 2014 to $527 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	In addition to deposit growth from our branch network, we acquired approximately $10 million in deposits with our acquisition of the Redding, California, branch of Rabobank N.A. effective July 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P19_S2	No loans were acquired in this transaction.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	Core deposit growth remained strong in 2015 as evidenced by increases of $28.4 million in demand deposits, $19.6 million in savings accounts, $9.1 million in interest-bearing transaction accounts (NOW) and $6.4 million in money market accounts.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	Time deposits declined by $4.1 million, much of which we attribute to migration into other types of deposits given the low rates and lack of liquidity associated with time deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	The Company has no brokered deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	Total shareholders equity increased by $6.0 million from $36.5 million at December 31, 2014 to $42.5 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	The $6.0 million includes earnings during the twelve month period totaling $5.8 million with the balance of $0.2 million mostly representing stock option activity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	The return on average assets was 1.02% for 2015, up from 0.89% for 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P23_S1	The return on average equity was 14.6% for 2015, up from 14.0% for 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	The following table presents, for the years indicated, the distribution of consolidated average assets, liabilities and shareholders equity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Average balances are based on average daily balances.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	It also presents the amounts of interest income from interest-earning assets and the resultant yields expressed in both dollars and yield percentages, as well as the amounts of interest expense on interest-bearing liabilities and the resultant cost expressed in both dollars and rate percentages.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	Nonaccrual loans are included in the calculation of average loans while nonaccrued interest thereon is excluded from the computation of yields earned:
1168455_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	Interest income is reflected on an actual basis and is not computed on a tax-equivalent basis.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Net interest spread represents the average yield earned on interest-earning assets less the average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Net interest margin is computed by dividing net interest income by total average earning assets .
1168455_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	The following table sets forth changes in interest income and interest expense, for the years indicated and the amount of change attributable to variances in volume, rates and the combination of volume and rates based on the relative changes of volume and rates:
1168455_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	(1) The volume change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the previous year s rate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	(2) The rate change in net interest income represents the change in rate multiplied by the previous year s average balance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P30_S2	(3) The mix change in net interest income represents the change in average balance multiplied by the change in rate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	Net interest income is the difference between interest income and interest expense.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	Net interest income, on a nontax-equivalent basis, was $21.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, up $2.0 million, or 10.1%, from $19.4 million for 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P31_S2	The $2.0 million included an increase of $1.5 million, or 6.9% in interest income, from $21.1 million during 2014 to $22.6 million during the current year and a decrease of $489 thousand in interest expense.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	Interest and fees on loans increased by $1.3 million, interest on investment securities increased by $179 thousand and interest on deposits increased by $37 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	The increase in interest and fees on loans was related to an increase in average loan balances partially offset by a decline in yield.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P32_S2	Interest on investments securities benefited from both an increase in yield and an increase in average balance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Interest and fees on loans was $20.8 million during 2015 and $19.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	The average loan balances were $386.1 million for 2015, up $32.7 million from the $353.4 million for 2014.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	In addition, during the fourth quarter of 2014 the Company benefited from a prepayment fee of approximately $0.2 million on a large commercial real estate loan which increased overall loan yield by approximately 5 basis points.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P38_S6	The average rate paid on savings accounts during these same periods was 16 basis points.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	Interest expense on other interest-bearing liabilities decreased by $491 thousand from $1.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2014 to $686 thousand during the current twelve month period.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	On April 15, 2013, to help fund the repurchase of preferred stock during 2013, the Company issued a $7.5 million subordinated debenture.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	The subordinated debt bears an interest rate of 7.5% per annum, has a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant (the Lender Warrant ) to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Company s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	On April 16, 2015 we paid off the subordinated debenture resulting in a reduction in interest expense related to this debt of $537 thousand from $756 thousand during 2014 to $219 thousand during 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	The effective yield on the debenture during 2015 was 10.2% which was in excess of the 7.5% rate due to amortization of a $75 thousand commitment fee and a discount recorded on issuance of $318 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	Interest expense on the Company s note payable (see Financial Condition Note Payable ) increased by $44 thousand to $155 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	This increase was related to an increase in average borrowings on this note from $2.3 million during the 2014 period to $3.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	During April of 2015 we borrowed an additional $4 million on the note bringing the balance to $5 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P41_S3	This $4 million along with a dividend from Plumas Bank to Plumas Bancorp were used to fund the payoff of the subordinated debenture.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P41_S4	The average rate paid on the note payable was 4.02% during 2015 and 4.83% during the twelve months ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	Interest expense on junior subordinated debentures, which increased by $3 thousand to $306 thousand, fluctuates with changes in the 3-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) rate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	Interest on other borrowings, which mostly relates to repurchase agreements, totaled $6 thousand in 2015 and $7 thousand in 2014.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $1.1 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P57_S1	See Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses for further discussion of loan quality trends and the provision for loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that management believes will be appropriate to absorb inherent losses on existing loans based on an evaluation of the collectability of the loans and prior loan loss experience.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	The evaluations take into consideration such factors as changes in the nature and volume of the portfolio, overall portfolio quality, review of specific problem loans, and current economic conditions that may affect the borrower s ability to repay their loan.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	The allowance for loan losses is based on estimates, and ultimate losses may vary from the current estimates.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P59_S1	These estimates are reviewed periodically and, as adjustments become necessary, they are reported in earnings in the periods in which they become known.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	Based on information currently available, management believes that the allowance for loan losses is appropriate to absorb potential risks in the portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P60_S1	However, no assurance can be given that the Company may not sustain charge-offs which are in excess of the allowance in any given period.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	The following table sets forth the components of non-interest income for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2015 non-interest income totaled $7.7 million an increase of $400 thousand from the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	The largest component of this increase was an increase of $546 thousand in gains on the sale of government guaranteed SBA loans mostly related to an increase in the volume of loans originated and sold.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P62_S2	During 2015, proceeds from SBA loan sales totaled $29.4 million resulting in a gain on sale of $1.9 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P62_S3	This compares to proceeds of $21.6 million and a gain on sale of $1.4 million during 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	Loan servicing income, which increased by $60 thousand, represents servicing income received on the guaranteed portion of small business administration ( SBA ) loans sold into the secondary market.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S1	At December 31, 2015 we were servicing over $86 million in guaranteed portions of loans an increase of $10 million from over $76 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S2	Other non-interest income increased by $54 thousand to $894 thousand mostly related to an increase of $126 thousand in dividends received on Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco (FHLB) stock.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S3	Of the $126 thousand, $88 thousand was a one-time special dividend paid by the FHLB during June 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S4	The effect of the increase in FHLB dividends and increases in other items of other non-interest income were partially offset by a $148 thousand gain on the sale of our credit card portfolio during the fourth quarter of 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S5	The largest decrease in non-interest income was $154 thousand in service charge income most of which was related to a reduction in NSF and overcharge income which we attribute to improved economic conditions as well as working with our customers to help them reduce NSF activity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P63_S6	Additionally, gain on sale of investments declined by $107 thousand from $128 thousand during the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 to $21 thousand during 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 non-interest income totaled $7.3 million an increase of $673 thousand from the twelve months ended December 31, 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	The largest component of this increase was an increase of $196 thousand in service charge income which we attribute to growth in the Company s demand deposit accounts, an increase in debit card interchange income and a restructuring of our service charge fee structure beginning in August of 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S2	During July and August 2014 we sold fourteen available-for- sale securities totaling $16.2 million recognizing a gain on sale of $128 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S3	Loan servicing fees, which totaled $502 thousand for the 12 months ended December 31, 2014, increased by $179 thousand from 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S4	Other non-interest income increased by $176 thousand mostly related to a $148 thousand gain on the sale of our credit card portfolio during the fourth quarter of 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P64_S5	Prior to the sale, credit card loans represented less than one-half of a percent of our loan portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	The following table sets forth the components of other non-interest expense for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	Non-interest expense increased by $646 thousand to $18.5 million during the twelve months ended December 31, 2015, up from $17.8 million during 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	The largest components of this increase were $803 thousand in salary and benefit expense, $124 thousand professional fees, $104 thousand in insurance expense and $127 thousand in other operating expenses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P66_S2	The largest declines in non-interest expense were $180 thousand in OREO expenses, $161 thousand in the provision from change in OREO valuation and $120 thousand in occupancy and equipment expense.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	The increase in salary and benefits includes an increase in salary expense, exclusive of commissions, of $412 thousand mostly related to merit and promotion increases, new hires including three loan officers; one serving Reno, Nevada, one located in Chico, California and an SBA loan officer in Scottsdale Arizona, and a branch manager for our new Reno, Nevada location.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	Other significant increases in salary and benefit expense include an increase of $147 thousand in commission expense, $111 thousand in 401k plan contributions and a reduction of $104 thousand in the deferral of loan origination costs.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P67_S2	The increase in commission expense is mostly related to an increase in SBA activity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P67_S3	Effective January 1, 2015, we reestablished a 401k matching benefit resulting in $111 thousand in matching contributions.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P67_S4	During each of 2015 and 2014 the Company s bonus expense totaled $600 thousand, the maximum payable under the terms of the respective bonus plans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	The largest component of the increase in professional fees was an increase of $79 thousand in legal fees related to loan collection activities and general corporate matters including costs associated with our Redding branch acquisition and our future Reno, Nevada branch.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	The second largest increase in professional fees was an increase of $52 thousand in audit expense related to lending functions, including the cost of our semi-annual loan review, an annual review of our SBA loan operations by the SBA and a review of our loan compliance systems.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P68_S2	Insurance expense, during 2014, benefited from a one-time adjustment to accrued life insurance costs.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	The decline in OREO costs includes a decrease in OREO legal expense of $125 thousand and a decline in repair and maintenance costs of $54 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P69_S1	During 2014 we incurred $142 thousand in legal costs, related to OREO, pursuing additional recoveries on selected OREO properties through legal channels.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P69_S2	In addition, OREO repair expense during 2014 totaled $93 thousand much of which was used to fix up several properties in an effort to increase their marketability.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P69_S3	OREO repair costs were $62 thousand in 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P69_S4	OREO maintenance costs declined by $23 thousand related to a decline in OREO properties.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	OREO represents real property taken by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	When other real estate is acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair market value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S3	The allowance is established through a provision for subsequent losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S4	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or from impairment are recorded as incurred.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S5	The provision from change in OREO valuation declined by $161 thousand from $240 thousand during the year ended December 31, 2014 to $79 thousand during the current period.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S6	During the first three months of 2015 we recorded a net credit provision of $129 thousand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S7	The credit resulted from a significant increase in value of one OREO property based on a recent appraisal.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S8	This property was originally transferred to OREO at a value, net of estimated costs selling costs, of $1 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S9	Subsequently, based on declines in value it was written down to $0.7 million with a $0.3 million valuation allowance; however, recently the surrounding area in which the property is located has enjoyed significant new business activity and the value of this property has increased resulting in a reduction in the valuation allowance of $0.2 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P70_S10	The $0.2 million was offset by declines in value on other OREO properties.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	The decline in occupancy and equipment expense includes several reductions the largest of which was a savings of $49 thousand in equipment expense and maintenance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	During 2014 equipment expense was high as we chose to replace all of our personal computers running Windows XP with machines running Windows 7.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	During the twelve months ended December 31, 2014, total non-interest expense increased by $275 thousand, or 2%, to $17.8 million, up from $17.6 million for the comparable period in 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	The largest components of this increase were $745 thousand in salary and benefit expense, $187 thousand in outside service fees and $70 thousand related to reduction in gain on sale of OREO.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P72_S2	The largest declines in non-interest expense were $248 thousand in professional fees, $246 thousand in provision for OREO losses, $128 thousand in deposit premium amortization and $121 thousand in insurance expense.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	During the second quarter of 2013 we recorded a $300 thousand provision related to one land development property.
