1168455_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	Provision for I ncome T axes.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $3.7 million, or 39.0% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	During 2014 the Company recorded an income tax provision of $3.1 million, or 39.4% of pre-tax income for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P80_S2	The percentages for 2015 and 2014 differ from the statutory rate as tax exempt income such as earnings on Bank owned life insurance and interest on qualified municipal securities.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P81_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is "more likely than not" that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	"More likely than not" is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P82_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	Based upon the analysis of available evidence, management has determined that it is "more likely than not" that all deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	Net loans increased by $30 million, or 8%, from $367 million at December 31, 2014 to $397 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S1	The two largest areas of growth in the Company s loan portfolio were $28.8 million in commercial real estate loans and $5.6 million in commercial loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S2	Additionally, agricultural loans increased by $4.5 million and automobile loans increased $3.7 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S3	The largest decrease in any loan category was a decline of $8.4 million in construction and land development loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S4	The Company continues to manage the mix of its loan portfolio consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financing needs of all sectors of the area it serves.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S5	Although the Company offers a broad array of financing options, it continues to concentrate its focus on small to medium sized commercial businesses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S6	These loans offer diversification as to industries and types of businesses, thus limiting material exposure in any industry concentrations.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P84_S7	The Company offers both fixed and floating rate loans and obtains collateral in the form of real property, business assets and deposit accounts, but looks to business and personal cash flows as its primary source of repayment.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	As shown in the following table the Company s largest lending categories are commercial real estate loans, auto loans, equity lines of credit, agricultural loans and commercial loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	Construction and land development loans represented 4.0% and 6.6% of the loan portfolio as of December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	The construction and land development portfolio component has been identified by Management as a higher-risk loan category.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P86_S2	The quality of the construction and land development category is highly dependent on property values both in terms of the likelihood of repayment once the property is transacted by the current owner as well as the level of collateral the Company has securing the loan in the event of default.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Loans in this category are characterized by the speculative nature of commercial and residential development properties and can include property in various stages of development from raw land to finished lots.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	The decline in these loans as a percentage of the Company s loan portfolio from over 21% at December 31, 2007 to less than 7% during the last two years reflects management s efforts, which began in 2009, to reduce its exposure to construction and land development loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company s real estate related loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction and land development loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate comprised 73% of the total loan portfolio at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P88_S1	Moreover, the business activities of the Company currently are focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta, Sierra and in Washoe County in Northern Nevada.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P88_S2	Consequently, the results of operations and financial condition of the Company are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P88_S3	In addition, the concentration of the Company s operations in these areas of Northeastern California and Northwestern Nevada exposes it to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	The rates of interest charged on variable rate loans are set at specific increments in relation to the Company s lending rate or other indexes such as the published prime interest rate or U.S. Treasury rates and vary with changes in these indexes.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	The frequency in which variable rate loans reprice can vary from one day to several years.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	At December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, approximately 72% and 71%, respectively of the Company s loan portfolio was comprised of variable rate loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	At December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, 39% and 42%, respectively of the variable loans were at their respective floor rate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	While real estate mortgage, commercial and consumer lending remain the foundation of the Company s historical loan mix, some changes in the mix have occurred due to the changing economic environment and the resulting change in demand for certain loan types.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	The most significant change has been an increase in indirect auto lending with automobile loans increasing from 2.5% of gross loans at December 31, 2011 to 12.1% of gross loans at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	The automobile portfolio provides diversification to the loan portfolio in terms of rate, term and balance as these loans tend to have a much shorter term and balance than commercial real-estate loans and are fixed rate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	In addition, the Company remains committed to the agricultural industry in Northeastern California and will continue to pursue high quality agricultural loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P92_S2	Agricultural loans include both commercial and commercial real estate loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P92_S3	The Company s agricultural loan balances totaled $40 million at December 31, 2015 and $35 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	The following table sets forth the amounts of loans outstanding by category as of the dates indicated.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	The following table sets forth the maturity of gross loan categories as of December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P94_S1	Also provided with respect to such loans are the amounts due after one year, classified according to sensitivity to changes in interest rates:
1168455_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	The Company attempts to minimize credit risk through its underwriting and credit review policies.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P96_S1	The Company s credit review process includes internally prepared credit reviews as well as contracting with an outside firm to conduct periodic credit reviews.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P96_S2	The Company s management and lending officers evaluate the loss exposure of classified and impaired loans on a quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	The Management Asset Resolution Committee (MARC) reviews the asset quality of criticized and past due loans on a monthly basis and reports the findings to the full Board of Directors.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P97_S1	In management s opinion, this loan review system helps facilitate the early identification of potential criticized loans.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	The Company has implemented MARC to develop an action plan to significantly reduce nonperforming assets.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	It consists of the Bank s Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Credit Officer, and the activities are governed by a formal written charter.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	The MARC meets at least monthly and reports to the Board of Directors.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	More specifically, a formal plan to effect repayment and/or disposition of every significant nonperforming loan relationship is developed and documented for review and on-going oversight by the MARC.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	Some of the strategies used include but are not limited to: 1) obtaining additional collateral, 2) obtaining additional investor cash infusion, 3) sale of the promissory note to an outside party, 4) proceeding with foreclosure on the underlying collateral, and 5) legal action against borrower/guarantors to encourage settlement of debt and/or collect any deficiency balance owed.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P100_S2	Each step includes a benchmark timeline to track progress.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	MARC also provides guidance for the maintenance and timely disposition of OREO properties; including developing financing and marketing programs to incent individuals to purchase OREO.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	The allowance for loan losses is established through charges to earnings in the form of the provision for loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P102_S1	Loan losses are charged to and recoveries are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P102_S2	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level deemed appropriate by management to provide for known and inherent risks in the loan portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P102_S3	The adequacy of the allowance for loan losses is based upon management s continuing assessment of various factors affecting the collectability of loans; including current economic conditions, maturity of the portfolio, size of the portfolio, industry concentrations, borrower credit history, collateral, the existing allowance for loan losses, independent credit reviews, current charges and recoveries to the allowance for loan losses and the overall quality of the portfolio as determined by management, regulatory agencies, and independent credit review consultants retained by the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	There is no precise method of predicting specific losses or amounts which may ultimately be charged off on particular segments of the loan portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	The collectability of a loan is subjective to some degree, but must relate to the borrower s financial condition, cash flow, quality of the borrower s management expertise, collateral and guarantees, and state of the local economy.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	Formula allocations are calculated by applying loss factors to outstanding loans with similar characteristics.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	Loss factors are based on the Company s historical loss experience as adjusted for changes in the business cycle and may be adjusted for significant factors that, in management s judgment, affect the collectability of the portfolio as of the evaluation date.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P105_S2	Historical loss data from the beginning of the latest business cycle are incorporated in the loss factors.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	The discretionary allocation is based upon management s evaluation of various loan segment conditions that are not directly measured in the determination of the formula and specific allowances.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P106_S1	The conditions may include, but are not limited to, general economic and business conditions affecting the key lending areas of the Company, credit quality trends, collateral values, loan volumes and concentrations, and other business conditions.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	The following table provides certain information for the years indicated with respect to the Company s allowance for loan losses as well as charge-off and recovery activity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P108_S0	During each of the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 we recorded a provision for loan losses of $1.1 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P108_S1	Net charge-offs totaled $473 thousand during the year ended December 31, 2015 down $693 thousand from $1.2 million during 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P108_S2	Net charge-offs as a percentage of average loans decreased from 0.33% during 2014 to 0.12% during the year ended December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P109_S0	The following table provides a breakdown of the allowance for loan losses:
1168455_16_ITEM7_P110_S0	The allowance for loan losses totaled $6.1 million at December 31, 2015 and $5.5 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P110_S1	Specific reserves related to impaired loans increased by $187 thousand from $564 thousand at December 31, 2014 to $751 thousand at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P111_S0	At least quarterly the Company evaluates each specific reserve and if it determines that the loss represented by the specific reserve is uncollectable it records a charge-off for the uncollectable portion.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P111_S1	General reserves were $5.3 million at December 31, 2015 and $4.9 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P111_S2	The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans increased from 1.47% at December 31, 2014 to 1.52% at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P111_S3	The percentage of general reserves to unimpaired loans totaled 1.35% at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P112_S0	The Company places loans 90 days or more past due on nonaccrual status unless the loan is well secured and in the process of collection.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P112_S1	A loan is considered to be in the process of collection if, based on a probable specific event, it is expected that the loan will be repaid or brought current.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P112_S2	Generally, this collection period would not exceed 90 days.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P113_S0	When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status the Company s general policy is to reverse and charge against current income previously accrued but unpaid interest.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P113_S1	Interest income on such loans is subsequently recognized only to the extent that cash is received and future collection of principal is deemed by management to be probable.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P113_S2	Where the collectability of the principal or interest on a loan is considered to be doubtful by management, it is placed on nonaccrual status prior to becoming 90 days delinquent.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P114_S0	Impaired loans are measured based on the present value of the expected future cash flows discounted at the loan s effective interest rate or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P114_S1	The amount of impaired loans is not directly comparable to the amount of nonperforming loans disclosed later in this section.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P115_S0	The primary difference between impaired loans and nonperforming loans is that impaired loan recognition considers not only loans 90 days or more past due, restructured loans and nonaccrual loans but also may include identified problem loans other than delinquent loans where it is considered probable that we will not collect all amounts due to us (including both principal and interest) in accordance with the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P116_S0	A restructuring of a debt constitutes a troubled debt restructuring (TDR) if the Company, for economic or legal reasons related to the debtor s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the debtor that it would not otherwise consider.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P117_S0	Restructured workout loans typically present an elevated level of credit risk as the borrowers are not able to perform according to the original contractual terms.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P118_S0	Loans that are reported as TDRs are considered impaired and measured for impairment as described above.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P119_S0	Loans restructured (TDRs) and not included in nonperforming loans in the following table totaled $2.0 million, $2.0 million, $4.5 million, $5.4 million and $8.6 million at December 31, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P119_S1	For additional information related to restructured loans see Note 5 of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P120_S0	The following table sets forth the amount of the Company s nonperforming assets as of the dates indicated.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P121_S0	Nonperforming loans at December 31, 2015 were $4.5 million, a decrease of $2.1 million from the $6.6 million balance at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P121_S1	Specific reserves on nonaccrual loans totaled $683 thousand at December 31, 2015 and $522 thousand at December 31, 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P121_S2	Performing loans past due thirty to eighty-nine days were $1.5 million at December 31, 2015 and $1.6 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P122_S0	A substandard loan is not adequately protected by the current sound worth and paying capacity of the borrower or the value of the collateral pledged, if any.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P122_S1	Total substandard loans decreased by $2.1 million from $8.1 million at December 31, 2014 to $6.0 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P122_S2	Loans classified as watch decreased by $0.3 million from $4.4 million at December 31, 2014 to $4.1 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P122_S3	At December 31, 2015, $1.5 million of performing loans were classified as substandard.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P122_S4	Further deterioration in the credit quality of individual performing substandard loans or other adverse circumstances could result in the need to place these loans on nonperforming status.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P123_S0	At December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, the Company s recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $6.5 million and $8.6 million, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P123_S1	The specific allowance for loan losses related to impaired loans totaled $751 thousand and $564 thousand at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P123_S2	Additionally, $0.7 million has been charged off against the impaired loans at December 31, 2015 and December 31 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P124_S0	It is the policy of management to make additions to the allowance for loan losses so that it remains appropriate to absorb the inherent risk of loss in the portfolio.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P124_S1	Management believes that the allowance at December 31, 2015 is appropriate.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P124_S2	However, the determination of the amount of the allowance is judgmental and subject to economic conditions which cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P124_S3	Accordingly, the Company cannot predict whether charge-offs of loans in excess of the allowance may occur in future periods.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P125_S0	OREO represents real property acquired by the Bank either through foreclosure or through a deed in lieu thereof from the borrower.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P125_S1	Repossessed assets include vehicles and other commercial assets acquired under agreements with delinquent borrowers.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P125_S2	OREO holdings represented seven properties totaling $1.8 million at December 31, 2015 and fifteen properties totaling $3.6 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P125_S3	Nonperforming assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.06% at December 31, 2015 and 1.90% at December 31, 2014.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S0	Investment Portfolio and Federal Funds Sold.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S1	Total investment securities were $96.7 million as of December 31, 2015 and $90.3 million as of December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2015 the Company sold fifteen available-for-sale investment securities for total proceeds of $12,260,000 recording a $21,000 net gain on sale.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S3	The investment portfolio at December 31, 2015 consisted of $74.3 million in securities of U.S. Government-sponsored agencies and 83 municipal securities totaling $22.4 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2014 the Company sold fourteen available-for-sale investment securities for total proceeds of $16,325,000 recording a $128,000 gain on sale.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S5	The investment portfolio at December 31, 2014 consisted of $77.3 million in securities of U.S. Government-sponsored agencies, 52 municipal securities totaling $12.5 million and one corporate security totaling $0.5 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S6	There were no Federal funds sold at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014; however, the Bank maintained interest earning balances at the Federal Reserve Bank totaling $47.6 million at December 31, 2015 and $22.9 million at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P127_S7	The balances, at December 31, 2015, earn interest at the rate of 0.5%.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P128_S0	The Company classifies its investment securities as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P128_S1	Currently all securities are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P128_S2	Securities classified as available-for-sale may be sold to implement the Company s asset/liability management strategies and in response to changes in interest rates, prepayment rates and similar factors.

1168455_16_ITEM7_P132_S0	Expected maturities may differ from contractual maturities because the issuers may have the right to call or prepay obligations.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S0	Total deposits increased by $59.4 million from $468 million at December 31, 2014 to $527 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S1	In addition to deposit growth from our branch network, we acquired approximately $10 million in deposits with our acquisition of the Redding, California, branch of Rabobank N.A. effective July 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S2	Core deposit growth remained strong in 2015 as evidenced by increases in all major deposit categories with the exception of time.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S3	The two largest increases were $28.4 million in non-interest bearing demand deposits and $19.6 million in savings accounts.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S4	Time deposits declined by $4.1 million, much of which we attribute to migration into other types of deposits given the low rates and lack of liquidity associated with time deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P133_S5	The Company continues to manage the mix of its deposits consistent with its identity as a community bank serving the financial needs of its customers.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P134_S0	The following table shows the distribution of deposits by type at December 31, 2015 and 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P135_S0	Deposits represent the Bank s primary source of funds.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P135_S1	Deposits are primarily core deposits in that they are demand, savings and time deposits generated from local businesses and individuals.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P135_S2	These sources are considered to be relatively stable, long-term relationships thereby enhancing steady growth of the deposit base without major fluctuations in overall deposit balances.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P136_S0	The Company experiences, to a small degree, some seasonality with the slower growth period between November through April, and the higher growth period from May through October.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P136_S1	In order to assist in meeting any funding demands, the Company maintains a secured borrowing arrangement with the FHLB.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P136_S2	There were no brokered deposits at December 31, 2015 or 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P137_S0	The Company s time deposits of $100,000 or more had the following schedule of maturities at December 31, 2015:
1168455_16_ITEM7_P138_S0	Time deposits of $100,000 or more are generally from the Company s local business and individual customer base.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P138_S1	The potential impact on the Company s liquidity from the withdrawal of these deposits is discussed at the Company s asset and liability management committee meetings, and is considered to be minimal.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S0	S hort - term Borrowing Arrangements.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S1	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $154,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $231,000,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S2	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S3	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company held $2,380,000 of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S4	Based on this level of stock holdings at December 31, 2015, the Company can borrow up to $88,159,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S5	To borrow the $154,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $1,787,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S6	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with three of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $20 million, $11 million and $10 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P139_S7	There were no outstanding borrowings to the FHLB or the correspondent banks under these agreements at December 31, 2015 and 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P140_S0	On October 24, 2013 the Company issued a $3.0 million promissory note (the Note ) payable to an unrelated commercial bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P140_S1	As originally issued, the Note provided for an interest rate of U.S. Prime Rate plus three-quarters percent per annum, 4.00% at December 31, 2014 and 2013, had a term of 18 months and subjected the Bank to several negative and affirmative covenants including, but not limited to providing timely financial information, maintaining specified levels of capital, restrictions on additional borrowings, and meeting or exceeding certain capital and asset quality ratios.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P140_S2	The Note is secured by 100 shares of the Bank s stock representing the 100% of the Company s ownership interest in the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P141_S0	On July 28, 2014, the Company and the borrower modified the Note to (1) extend the maturity date to October 24, 2015, (2) increase the maximum principal amount to $7.5 million and (3) permit the Company to borrow, repay and reborrow up to the maximum principal amount of the Note, among other things.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P142_S0	On October 1, 2015, the Company and the borrower further modified the Note to (1) extend the maturity date to October 1, 2016, (2) reduce the maximum principal amount to $2.5 million and (3) change the interest rate to U.S. "Prime Rate" plus one-half percent per annum.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P143_S0	Concurrently, with entering into the second modification of the note on October 1, 2015, the Company entered into a $5.0 million term loan (the Term Loan ), which matures on October 1, 2018.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P143_S1	The Term Loan requires quarterly principal payments of $125,000 plus accrued interest.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P143_S2	Both the Term Loan and the Note bear interest at a rate of the U.S.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P143_S3	"Prime Rate" plus one-half percent per annum and are secured by 100 shares of Plumas Bank stock representing the Company s 100% ownership interest in Plumas Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S0	Under the Term Loan and the Note, the Bank is subject to several negative and affirmative covenants similar to the covenants under the original Note but in several cases less restrictive.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S1	The Bank was in compliance with all such covenants related to the Note and the Term Loan at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S2	Interest expense related to the Note and the Term Loan for the years ended December 31, 2015, December 31, 2014 and 2013 totaled $155,000, $111,000 and $23,000, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S3	The ending balance of the Note at December 31, 2014 was $1,000,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S4	There was no balance outstanding on the Note at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P144_S5	The balance of the Term Loan was $4,875,000 at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P145_S0	In 2011 the Bank introduced a new product for its larger business customers which use repurchase agreements as an alternative to interest-bearing deposits.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P145_S1	The balance in this product at December 31, 2015 was $7.7 million, a decrease of $1.9 million from the December 31, 2014 balance of $9.6 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P145_S2	Interest paid on this product is similar to that which is paid on the Bank s premium money market account; however, these are not deposits and are not FDIC insured.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P146_S0	On April 15, 2013 the Company issued a $7.5 million subordinated debenture ( subordinated debt ).
1168455_16_ITEM7_P146_S1	The subordinated debt was issued to an unrelated third-party ( Lender ) pursuant to a subordinated debenture purchase agreement, subordinated debenture note, and stock purchase warrant.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P146_S2	On April 16, 2015 the Company paid off the subordinated debt.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P146_S3	Interest expense related to the subordinated debt for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 totaled $219,000, $756,000 and $541,000, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P147_S0	The subordinated debt had an interest rate of 7.5% per annum and a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P148_S0	Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures .
1168455_16_ITEM7_P149_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and II are business trust subsidiaries formed by the Company with capital of $311,000 and $163,000, respectively, for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities fully and unconditionally guaranteed by the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P150_S0	During 2002, Trust I issued 6,000 Floating Rate Capital Trust Pass-Through Securities ("Trust Preferred Securities"), with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $6,000,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P150_S1	During 2005, Trust II issued 4,000 Trust Preferred Securities with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $4,000,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P150_S2	The entire proceeds were invested by Trust I in the amount of $6,186,000 and Trust II in the amount of $4,124,000 in Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures (the "Subordinated Debentures") issued by the Company, with identical maturity, repricing and payment terms as the Trust Preferred Securities.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P150_S3	The Subordinated Debentures represent the sole assets of Trusts I and II.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P151_S0	Trust I s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 26, 2032, bear a current interest rate of 4.00% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P151_S1	Trust II s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 28, 2035, bear a current interest rate of 1.99% (based on 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P151_S2	The interest rate of the Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust I adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 3.40%.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P151_S3	The Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust II adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3-month LIBOR plus 1.48%.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P151_S4	Both Trusts I and II have the option to defer payment of the distributions for a period of up to five years, as long as the Company is not in default on the payment of interest on the Subordinated Debentures.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P152_S0	Interest expense recognized by the Company for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 related to the subordinated debentures was $306,000, $303,000 and $313,000, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P153_S0	Total shareholders equity increased by $6.0 million from $36.5 million at December 31, 2014 to $42.5 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P153_S1	The $6.0 million includes earnings during the twelve month period totaling $5.8 million with the balance of $0.2 million mostly representing stock option activity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P154_S0	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P154_S1	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P155_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P155_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule, review the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P156_S0	Banking regulations limit the amount of dividends that may be paid without prior approval of regulatory agencies.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P156_S1	No common cash dividends were paid during the last seven years.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P157_S0	The Company is subject to various restrictions on the payment of dividends.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P158_S0	The Company uses a variety of measures to evaluate its capital adequacy.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P158_S1	Management reviews these capital measurements on a monthly basis and takes appropriate action to ensure that they are within established internal and external guidelines.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P159_S0	The FDIC has promulgated risk-based capital guidelines for all state non-member banks such as the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P159_S1	These guidelines establish a risk-adjusted ratio relating capital to different categories of assets and off-balance sheet exposures.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S0	In July, 2013, the federal bank regulatory agencies approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S1	The phase-in period for the final rules began on January 1, 2015, with full compliance with all of the final rule s requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S2	Under the final rules, minimum requirements increased for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S3	The rules include a new common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets ratio of 4.5% and a capital conservation buffer of 2.5% of risk-weighted assets.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S4	The final rules also raise the minimum ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets from 4.0% to 6.0% and require a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0%.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P160_S5	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P161_S0	The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has adopted final amendments to the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement (Regulation Y, Appendix C) ( the Policy Statement ) that, among other things, raised from $500 million to $1 billion the asset threshold to qualify for the Policy Statement.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P161_S1	Plumas Bancorp qualifies for treatment under the Policy Statement and is no longer subject to consolidated capital rules at the bank holding company level.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P162_S0	The following table sets forth the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios (dollar amounts in thousands):
1168455_16_ITEM7_P163_S0	Management believes that Plumas Bank currently meets all its capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P164_S0	The current and projected capital positions of the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P164_S1	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized ratios at all times.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P165_S0	In the normal course of business, there are various commitments outstanding to extend credits that are not reflected in the financial statements.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S1	Annual review of commercial credit lines, letters of credit and ongoing monitoring of outstanding balances reduces the risk of loss associated with these commitments.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S2	As of December 31, 2015, the Company had $83.0 million in unfunded loan commitments and $265 thousand in letters of credit.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S3	This compares to $89.7 million in unfunded loan commitments and no letters of credit at December 31, 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S4	Of the $83.0 million in unfunded loan commitments, $46.1 million and $36.9 million represented commitments to commercial and consumer customers, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S5	Of the total unfunded commitments at December 31, 2015, $42.6 million were secured by real estate, of which $16.0 million was secured by commercial real estate and $26.6 million was secured by residential real estate in the form of equity lines of credit.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S6	The commercial loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent business lines of credit, while the consumer loan commitments not secured by real estate primarily represent revolving credit card lines and overdraft protection lines.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P166_S7	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P167_S0	The Company leases two depository branches and three lending offices and two non-branch automated teller machine locations.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P167_S1	Total rental expenses under all operating leases were $233,000 and $192,000 during the years ended December, 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P167_S2	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2016 and the last such lease expiring during 2020.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P168_S0	The Company manages its liquidity to provide the ability to generate funds to support asset growth, meet deposit withdrawals (both anticipated and unanticipated), fund customers borrowing needs, satisfy maturity of short-term borrowings and maintain reserve requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P168_S1	The Company s liquidity needs are managed using assets or liabilities, or both.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P168_S2	On the asset side, in addition to cash and due from banks, the Company maintains an investment portfolio which includes unpledged U.S. Government-sponsored agency securities that are classified as available-for-sale.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P168_S3	On the liability side, liquidity needs are managed by charging competitive offering rates on deposit products and the use of established lines of credit.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P169_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $154,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $231,000,000.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P169_S1	See Short-term Borrowing Arrangements for additional information on our FHLB borrowing capacity.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P169_S2	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with three of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $20 million, $11 million and $10 million.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P169_S3	There were no outstanding borrowings under the FHLB or the correspondent bank borrowing lines at December 31, 2015 or 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P170_S0	Customer deposits are the Company s primary source of funds.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P170_S1	Total deposits increased by $59.4 million from $468 million at December 31, 2014 to $527 million at December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P171_S0	Deposits are held in various forms with varying maturities.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P171_S1	The Company s securities portfolio, Federal funds sold, FHLB advances, and cash and due from banks serve as the primary sources of liquidity, providing adequate funding for loans during periods of high loan demand.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P171_S2	During periods of decreased lending, funds obtained from the maturing or sale of investments, loan payments, and new deposits are invested in short-term earning assets, such as cash held at the FRB, Federal funds sold and investment securities, to serve as a source of funding for future loan growth.
1168455_16_ITEM7_P171_S3	Management believes that the Company s available sources of funds, including borrowings, will provide adequate liquidity for its operations in the foreseeable future.

1168455_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	The following consolidated financial statements of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary, and report of the independent registered public accounting firm are included in the Annual Report of Plumas Bancorp to its shareholders for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 and the related consolidated statements of income and comprehensive income, changes in shareholders equity and cash flows for the years then ended.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P1_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1168455_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P2_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P2_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P2_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Plumas Bancorp and Subsidiary as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
