1168455_16_ITEM8_P213_S1	Future minimum lease payments are as follows:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P214_S0	Rental expense included in occupancy and equipment expense totaled $233,000, $192,000 and $154,000 for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P215_S0	The Company is a party to financial instruments with off-balance-sheet risk in the normal course of business in order to meet the financing needs of its customers.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P215_S1	These financial instruments include commitments to extend credit and letters of credit.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P215_S2	These instruments involve, to varying degrees, elements of credit and interest rate risk in excess of the amount recognized on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P216_S0	The Company s exposure to credit loss in the event of nonperformance by the other party for commitments to extend credit and letters of credit is represented by the contractual amount of those instruments.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P216_S1	The Company uses the same credit policies in making commitments and letters of credit as it does for loans included on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P217_S0	The following financial instruments represent off-balance-sheet credit risk:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P218_S0	Commitments to extend credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P218_S1	Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates or other termination clauses and may require payment of a fee.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P218_S2	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon, the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P219_S0	The Company evaluates each customer s creditworthiness on a case-by-case basis.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P219_S1	The amount of collateral obtained, if deemed necessary by the Company upon extension of credit, is based on management s credit evaluation of the borrower.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P219_S2	Collateral held varies, but may include accounts receivable, crops, inventory, equipment, income-producing commercial properties, farm land and residential properties.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P220_S0	Letters of credit are conditional commitments issued by the Company to guarantee the performance of a customer to a third party.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P220_S1	The credit risk involved in issuing letters of credit is essentially the same as that involved in extending loans to customers.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P220_S2	The fair value of the liability related to these letters of credit, which represents the fees received for issuing the guarantees, was not significant at December 31, 2015 and 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P220_S3	The Company recognizes these fees as revenues over the term of the commitment or when the commitment is used.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P221_S0	At December 31, 2015, consumer loan commitments represent approximately 12% of total commitments and are generally unsecured.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P221_S1	Commercial and agricultural loan commitments represent approximately 41% of total commitments and are generally secured by various assets of the borrower.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P221_S2	Real estate loan commitments, including consumer home equity lines of credit, represent the remaining 47% of total commitments and are generally secured by property with a loan-to-value ratio not to exceed 80%.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P221_S3	In addition, the majority of the Company s commitments have variable interest rates.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P222_S0	The Company grants real estate mortgage, real estate construction, commercial, agricultural and consumer loans to customers throughout Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Sierra, Shasta and Modoc counties in California and Washoe county in Northern Nevada.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P223_S0	Although the Company has a diversified loan portfolio, a substantial portion of its portfolio is secured by commercial and residential real estate.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P223_S1	A continued substantial decline in the economy in general, or a continued decline in real estate values in the Company s primary market areas in particular, could have an adverse impact on the collectability of these loans.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P223_S2	However, personal and business income represents the primary source of repayment for a majority of these loans.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P224_S0	The Company is subject to legal proceedings and claims which arise in the ordinary course of business.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P224_S1	In the opinion of management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to such actions will not materially affect the financial position or results of operations of the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P225_S0	The Company s ability to pay cash dividends is dependent on dividends paid to it by the Bank and limited by California corporation law.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P225_S1	Under California law, the holders of common stock of the Company are entitled to receive dividends when and as declared by the Board of Directors, out of funds legally available, subject to certain restrictions.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P225_S2	The California general corporation law permits a California corporation such as the Company to make a distribution to its shareholders if its retained earnings equal at least the amount of the proposed distribution or if after giving effect to the distribution, the value of the corporation s assets exceed the amount of its liabilities plus the amount of shareholders preferences, if any, and certain other conditions are met.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P226_S0	Dividends from the Bank to the Company are restricted under California law to the lesser of the Bank s retained earnings or the Bank s net income for the latest three fiscal years, less dividends previously declared during that period, or, with the approval of the DBO, to the greater of the retained earnings of the Bank, the net income of the Bank for its last fiscal year, or the net income of the Bank for its current fiscal year.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P226_S1	As of December 31, 2015, the maximum amount available for dividend distribution under this restriction was approximately $5,100,000.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P226_S2	In addition the Company s ability to pay dividends is subject to certain covenants contained in the indentures relating to the Trust Preferred Securities issued by the business trusts (see Note 10 for additional information related to the Trust Preferred Securities).
1168455_16_ITEM8_P227_S0	On January 30, 2009 the Company entered into a Letter Agreement (the Purchase Agreement ) with the United States Department of the Treasury ( Treasury ), pursuant to which the Bancorp issued and sold (i) 11,949 shares Series A Preferred Stock and (ii) a warrant (the Warrant ) to purchase 237,712 shares of the Bancorp s common stock, no par value (the Common Stock ), for an aggregate purchase price of $11,949,000 in cash.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S0	On April 11, 2013, the Treasury announced its intent to sell its investment in the Bancorp s Series A Preferred Stock along with similar investments the Treasury had made in seven other financial institutions, principally to qualified institutional buyers.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S1	Using a modified Dutch auction methodology that establishes a market price by allowing investors to submit bids at specified increments during the period of April 15, 2013 through April 18, 2013, the U.S. Treasury auctioned all of the Bancorp s 11,949 Series A Preferred Stock.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S2	The Company sought and obtained regulatory permission to participate in the auction.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S3	The Company successfully bid to repurchase 7,000 shares of the 11,949 outstanding shares.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S4	This repurchase resulted in a discount of approximately 7% on the face value of the Series A Preferred Stock plus related outstanding dividends.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P228_S5	The remaining 4,949 shares were purchased at auction by third party private investors.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P229_S0	On June 27, 2013 the Bancorp repurchased 1,566 shares of the Series A Preferred Stock at $1,000 per share from certain of those third party private investors and on September 16, 2013 the Bancorp repurchased 250 shares at $985 per share from another one of the third party investors leaving 3,133 shares outstanding as of September 30, 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P229_S1	On October 25, 2013, Plumas Bancorp repurchased the remaining 3,133 shares of the Series A Preferred Stock from a third party private investor.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P229_S2	The Company paid $3,101,670 plus accrued dividends of $30,453.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P229_S3	This represents a discount of 1% from the liquidation value of the Preferred Stock.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P229_S4	On May 22, 2013 the Bancorp repurchased the Warrant from the Treasury at a cost of $234,500.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P230_S0	Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P230_S1	Diluted earnings per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P230_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted earnings per share.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P231_S0	Shares of common stock issuable under stock options and warrants for which the exercise prices were greater than the average market prices were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share due to their antidilutive effect.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P231_S1	Stock options and warrants not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share, due to shares not being in the-money and having an antidilutive effect, were 53,000, 238,000 and 172,000 for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P231_S2	At December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 one stock warrant was outstanding to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P232_S0	In 2001, the Company established a Stock Option Plan for which 192,893 shares of common stock remain reserved for issuance to employees and directors and no shares are available for future grants as of December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P233_S0	As of December 31, 2015, all remaining shares in this plan have vested and no compensation cost remains unrecognized.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P234_S0	The total fair value of options vested was $49,000 for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P234_S1	The total intrinsic value of options at time of exercise was $240,000 and $51,000 for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S0	In May 2013, the Company established the 2013 Stock Option Plan for which 500,000 shares of common stock are reserved and 396,800 shares are available for future grants as of December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S1	The 2013 Plan requires that the option price may not be less than the fair market value of the stock at the date the option is granted, and that the stock must be paid in full at the time the option is exercised.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S2	Payment in full for the option price must be made in cash, with Company common stock previously acquired by the optionee and held by the optionee for a period of at least six months, in options of the Optionee that are fully vested and exercisable or in any combination of the foregoing.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S3	The options expire on dates determined by the Board of Directors, but not later than ten years from the date of grant.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S4	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P235_S5	During the year ended December 31, 2014,110,400 options were granted.

1168455_16_ITEM8_P236_S1	That cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 2.3 years.

1168455_16_ITEM8_P240_S0	The Bank is subject to certain regulatory capital requirements administered by the FDIC.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P240_S1	Failure to meet these minimum capital requirements can initiate certain mandatory and possibly additional discretionary, actions by regulators that, if undertaken, could have a direct material effect on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P241_S0	Under capital adequacy guidelines, the Bank must meet specific capital guidelines that involved quantitative measures of their assets, liabilities and certain off-balance sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting practices.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P241_S1	These quantitative measures are established by regulation and require that minimum amounts and ratios of total and Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets and of Tier 1 capital to average assets be maintained.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P241_S2	Capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the regulators about components, risk weightings and other factors.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P242_S0	The Bank is also subject to additional capital guidelines under the regulatory framework for prompt corrective action.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P242_S1	To be categorized as well capitalized, the Bank must maintain total risk-based, Tier 1 risk-based and Tier 1 leverage ratios as set forth in the table on the following page and cannot be subject to a written agreement, order or capital directive issued by the FDIC.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S0	In July, 2013, the federal bank regulatory agencies approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S1	The phase-in period for the final rules began on January 1, 2015, with full compliance with all of the final rule s requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S2	Under the final rules, minimum requirements increased for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S3	The rules include a new common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets ratio of 4.5% and a capital conservation buffer of 2.5% of risk-weighted assets.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S4	The final rules also raise the minimum ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets from 4.0% to 6.0% and require a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0%.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P243_S5	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P244_S0	The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has adopted final amendments to the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement (Regulation Y, Appendix C) ( the Policy Statement ) that, among other things, raised from $500 million to $1 billion the asset threshold to qualify for the Policy Statement.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P244_S1	Plumas Bancorp qualifies for treatment under the Policy Statement and is no longer subject to consolidated capital rules at the bank holding company level.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P245_S0	The following table sets forth the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios (dollar amounts in thousands):
1168455_16_ITEM8_P246_S0	The current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long-term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P246_S1	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized ratios at all times.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P246_S2	Management believes that the Bank currently meets all its capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P247_S0	Other expenses consisted of the following:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P248_S0	The provision for income taxes for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 consisted of the following:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P249_S0	Deferred tax assets (liabilities) consisted of the following:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P250_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P250_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P251_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P251_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is "more likely than not" that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P251_S2	"More likely than not" is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P251_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P252_S0	At December 31, 2015 total deferred tax assets were approximately $4,603,000 and total deferred tax liabilities were approximately $1,680,000 for a net deferred tax asset of $2,923,000.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P252_S1	The Company s deferred tax assets primarily relate timing differences in the tax deductibility of impairment charges on other real estate owned, deprecation on premises and equipment, the provision for loan losses and deferred compensation.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P252_S2	Based upon our analysis of available evidence, management of the Company determined that it is "more likely than not" that all of our deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P253_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P254_S0	The provision for income taxes differs from amounts computed by applying the statutory Federal income tax rate to operating income before income taxes.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P254_S1	The significant items comprising these differences consisted of the following:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P255_S0	At year-end 2015, the Company had state operating loss carry-forwards of approximately $62,000 which expire at various dates from 2029 to 2031.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P256_S0	Deferred tax assets are recognized for net operating losses because the benefit is more likely than not to be realized.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P257_S0	The Company and its subsidiary file income tax returns in the U.S. federal and California jurisdictions.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P258_S0	The Company conducts all of its business activities in the states of California and Nevada.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P258_S1	There are currently no pending U.S. federal, state, and local income tax or non-U.S. income tax examinations by tax authorities.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P259_S0	With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to tax examinations by U.S. Federal taxing authorities for years ended before December 31, 2012, and by state and local taxing authorities for years ended before December 31, 2011.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P260_S0	The unrecognized tax benefits and changes therein and the interest and penalties accrued by the Company as of or during the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 were not significant.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P260_S1	The Company does not expect the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits to significantly increase or decrease in the next twelve months.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P261_S0	During the normal course of business, the Company enters into transactions with related parties, including executive officers and directors.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P261_S1	The following is a summary of the aggregate activity involving related party borrowers during 2015:
1168455_16_ITEM8_P262_S0	The Plumas Bank Profit Sharing Plan commenced April 1, 1988 and is available to employees meeting certain service requirements.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P262_S1	Under the Plan, employees are able to defer a selected percentage of their annual compensation.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P262_S2	Included under the Plan s investment options is the option to invest in Company stock.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P262_S3	During 2015, the Company s contribution consisted of a matching amount of 25% of the employee s contribution up to a total of 2% of the employee s compensation totaling $111,000.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P262_S4	No contribution was made for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P263_S0	Salary continuation and retirement agreements are in place for the Company s president and seven members of the Board of Directors as well as five former executives and four former directors.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P263_S1	Under these agreements, the directors and executives will receive monthly payments for twelve to fifteen years, respectively, after retirement.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P263_S2	The estimated present value of these future benefits is accrued over the period from the effective dates of the agreements until the participants expected retirement dates.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P263_S3	The expense recognized under these plans for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 totaled $258,000, $289,000 and $286,000, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P263_S4	Accrued compensation payable under these plans totaled $3,973,000 and $4,007,000 at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P264_S0	In connection with these agreements, the Bank purchased single premium life insurance policies with cash surrender values totaling $12,187,000 and $11,845,000 at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM8_P264_S1	Income earned on these policies, net of expenses, totaled $342,000, $341,000 and $344,000 for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	As of the end of the period covered by this report, we conducted an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on this evaluation, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in Securities and Exchange Commission rules and forms.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P0_S2	There was no change in our internal control over financial reporting during our most recently completed fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The management of Plumas Bancorp and subsidiary (the Company ), is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management, including the undersigned Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting presented in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America as of December 31, 2015.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	In conducting its assessment, management used the criteria established by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in the 2013 Internal Control Integrated Framework.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on this assessment, management concluded that, as of December 31, 2015, our internal control over financial reporting was effective based on those criteria.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s independent registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1168455_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s independent registered public accounting firm pursuant to the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.
