1168455_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Plumas Bancorp is a California corporation registered as a bank holding company under the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, as amended, and is headquartered in Quincy, California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company was incorporated in January 2002 and acquired all of the outstanding shares of Plumas Bank (the Bank ) in June 2002.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company s principal subsidiary is the Bank, and the Company exists primarily for the purpose of holding the stock of the Bank and of such other subsidiaries it may acquire or establish.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	At the present time, the Company s only other subsidiaries are Plumas Statutory Trust I and Plumas Statutory Trust II, which were formed in 2002 and 2005 solely to facilitate the issuance of trust preferred securities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Company s principal source of income is dividends from the Bank, but the Company may explore supplemental sources of income in the future.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	The cash outlays of the Company, including (but not limited to) the payment of dividends to shareholders, if and when declared by the Board of Directors, costs of repurchasing Company common stock and the cost of servicing debt will generally be paid from dividends paid to the Company by the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	At December 31, 201 6, the Company had consolidated assets of $658 million, deposits of $582 million, other liabilities of $28 million and shareholders equity of $48 million.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company s other liabilities include $10.3 million in junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures and a $2.4 million note payable.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P3_S2	These items are described in detail later in this section.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	References herein to the Company, we, us and our refer to Plumas Bancorp and its consolidated subsidiary, unless the context indicates otherwise.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our operations are conducted at 35 South Lindan Avenue, Quincy, California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P5_S1	Our annual, quarterly and other reports, required under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, (the SEC ) are posted and are available at no cost on the Company s website, www.plumasbank.com , as soon as reasonably practicable after the Company files such documents with the SEC.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P5_S2	These reports are also available through the SEC s website at www.sec.gov .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Bank is a California state-chartered bank that was incorporated in July 1980 and opened for business in December 1980.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	The Bank is not a member of the Federal Reserve System.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Bank s Administrative Office is located at 35 South Lindan Avenue, Quincy, California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	At December 31, 2016 the Bank had approximately $657 million in assets, $457 million in net loans and $583 million in deposits (including deposits of $0.3 million from the Bancorp).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	It is currently the largest independent bank headquartered in Plumas County.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Bank s deposit accounts are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (the FDIC ) up to maximum insurable amounts.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Bank s primary service area covers the Northeastern portion of California, with Lake Tahoe to the south and the Oregon border to the north.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Bank, through its twelve branch network, serves Washoe County in Nevada and the seven contiguous California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Sierra, Placer, Lassen, Modoc and Shasta.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P9_S2	The branches are located in the California communities of Quincy, Portola, Greenville, Truckee, Fall River Mills, Alturas, Susanville, Chester, Tahoe City, Kings Beach and Redding; in addition, during December, 2015 the Bank opened a branch in Reno, Nevada.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Bank maintains sixteen automated teller machines ( ATMs ) tied in with major statewide and national networks.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P10_S1	In addition to its branch network, the Bank operates lending offices specializing in government-guaranteed lending in Auburn, California Seattle, Washington and Phoenix, Arizona and commercial/agricultural lending offices located in Chico, California and Klamath Falls, Oregon.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P10_S2	The Bank s primary business is servicing the banking needs of these communities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P10_S3	Its marketing strategy stresses its local ownership and commitment to serve the banking needs of individuals living and working in the Bank s primary service areas.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	With a predominant focus on personal service, the Bank has positioned itself as a multi-commu nity independent bank serving the financial needs of individuals and businesses within the Bank s geographic footprint.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	Our principal retail lending services include consumer, automobile and home equity loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P11_S2	Our principal commercial lending services include term real estate, commercial and industrial term loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P11_S3	In addition, we provide government-guaranteed and agricultural loans as well as credit lines.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P11_S4	We provide land development and construction loans on a limited basis.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	The Bank s government-guaranteed lending center headquartered in Auburn, California with additional personnel in Truckee, California, Seattle , Washington and Phoenix, Arizona , provide Small Business Administration (SBA) and USDA Rural Development loans to qualified borrowers throughout Northern California, Washington, Arizona, Oregon and Northern Nevada.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	During 2007 the Bank was granted nationwide Preferred Lender status with the U.S. Small Business Administration and we expect government-guaranteed lending to continue to be an important part of our overall lending operation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P12_S2	During 2016 proceeds from the sale of government-guaranteed loans totaled $30.7 million and we generated a gain on sale of $1.8 million.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P12_S3	During 2015 proceeds from the sale of government-guaranteed loans totaled $29.4 million and we generated a gain on sale of $1.9 million.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	The Agricultural Credit Centers located in Susanville, Chico, and Alturas, California and Klamath Falls, Oregon provide a complete line of credit services in support of the agricultural activities which are key to the continued economic development of the communities we serve.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	Ag lending clients include a full range of individual farming customers, small to medium-sized business farming organizations and corporate farming units.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	As of December 31, 2016, the principal areas to which we have directed our lending activities, and the percentage of our total loan portfolio comprised by each, were as follows: (i) commercial real estate 49.0%; (ii) commercial and industrial loans 9.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P15_S1	0%; (iii) consumer loans (including residential equity lines of credit and automobile loans) 21.6%; (iv) agricultural loans (including agricultural real estate loans) 11.1%; (v) residential real estate 4.6%; and (vi) construction and land development 4.7% .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	In addition to the lending activities noted above, we offer a wide range of deposit products for the retail and commercial banking markets including checking, interest-bearing and premium interest-bearing checking, business sweep, public funds sweep, savings, time deposit and retirement accounts, as well as remote deposit, telephone and mobile banking, including mobile deposit, and internet banking with bill-pay options.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	Interest bearing deposits include high yield sweep accounts designed for our commercial customers and for public entities such as municipalities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	As of December 31, 2016, the Bank had 30,591 deposit accounts with balances totaling approximately $583 million, compared to 29 ,518 deposit accounts with balances totaling approximately $528 million at December 31, 2015 .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P16_S3	We attract deposits through our customer-oriented product mix, competitive pricing, convenient locations, mobile and internet banking and remote deposit operations, all provided with a high level of customer service.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	Most of our deposits are attracted from individuals, business-related sources and smaller municipal entities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P17_S1	This mix of deposit customers resulted in a relatively modest average deposit balance of approximately $19.0 thousand at December 31, 2016 .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P17_S2	However, it makes us less vulnerable to adverse effects from the loss of depositors who may be seeking higher yields in other markets or who may otherwise draw down balances for cash needs.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	We also offer a variety of other products and services to comp lement the lending and deposit services previously reviewed.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P18_S1	These include cashier s checks, bank-by-mail, ATMs, night depository, safe deposit boxes, direct deposit, electronic funds transfers and other customary banking services.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Through our offering of a Remote Deposit product our business customers are able to make non-cash deposits remotely from their physical location.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P19_S1	With this product, we have extended our service area and can now meet the deposit needs of customers who may not be located within a convenient distance of one of our branch offices.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	T he Bank has devoted a substantial amount of time and capital to the improvement of existing Bank services .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P20_S1	We added mobile banking services during the first quarter of 2010.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P20_S2	During 2015 we enhanced our mobile banking services and began offering mobile deposit services.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P20_S3	During the first quarter of 2012 we replaced our ATMs with new state of the art machines that are ADA compliant and capable of accepting check and cash deposits without a deposit envelope.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	The officers and employees of the Bank are continually engaged in marketing activities, including the evaluation and development of new products and services, to enable the Bank to retain and improve its competitive position in its service area.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	We hold no patents or licenses (other than licenses required by appropriate bank regulatory agencies or local governments), franchises, or concessions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P22_S1	Our business has a modest seasonal component due to the heavy agricultural and tourism orientation of some of the communities we serve.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P22_S2	We are not dependent on a single customer or group of related customers for a material portion of our deposits.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P22_S3	The Company s management has established loan concentration guidelines as a percentage of capital and evaluates loan concentration levels within a single industry or group of related industries on quarterly basis, or more frequently as loan conditions change.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	There has been no material effect upon our capital expenditures, earnings, or competitive position as a result of federal, state, or local environmental regulation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	The Board of Directors and Management believe that the Company plays an important role in the economic well-being of the communities it serves.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	Our Bank has a continuing responsibility to provide a wide range of lending and deposit services to both individuals and businesses.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P24_S2	These services are tailored to meet the needs of the communities served by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	We offer various loan products which encourage job growth and support community economic development.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P25_S1	Types of loans offered range from personal and commercial loans to real estate, construction, agricultura l, automobile and government-guaranteed loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P25_S2	Many banking decisions are made locally with the goal of maintaining customer satisfaction through the timely delivery of high quality products and services.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	On July 31, 2015 the Bank completed its acquisition of the Redding, California, branch of Rabobank N.A.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	The transaction included the acquisition of approximately $10 million in deposits.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S2	The branch, located at 1335 Hilltop Dr. in Redding, now operates as a branch of the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S3	The Bank has consolidated its Civic Center Drive branch into this location.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S4	The Civic Center Drive facility was sold to an unrelated third party in December, 2015.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S5	In December, 2015 the Bank opened a full-service branch located at 5050 Meadowood Mall Circle, Reno, Nevada.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S6	This is the Bank s first branch location outside of California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S7	Also in December, 2015 the Bank opened a SBA lending office in Scottsdale, Arizona.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S8	In September, 2016 we relocated this office to Phoenix, Arizona.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P26_S9	In March, 2016 we opened a SBA lending office in Seattle, Washington.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	On October 20, 2016 the Company announced that its Board of Directors approved the reinstatement of a semi-annual cash dividend.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P27_S1	The dividend , in the amount of $0.10 per share, was paid on November 21, 2016 to shareholders of record at the close of business day on November 7, 2016.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	During the third quarter of 2002, the Company formed a wholly owned Connecticut statutory business trust, Plumas Statutory Trust I (the Trust I ).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P28_S1	On September 26, 2002, the Company issued to the Trust I, Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures due 2032 (the Debentures ) in the aggregate principal amount of $6,186,000.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P28_S2	In exchange for these debentures the Trust I paid the Company $6,186,000.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	The Trust I funded its purchase of debentures by issuing $6,000,000 in floating rate capital securities ( trust preferred securities ), which were sold to a third party.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P29_S1	These trust preferred securities qualify as Tier I capital under current Federal Reserve Board guidelines.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P29_S2	The Debentures are the only asset of the Trust I.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P30_S0	The interest rate and terms on both instruments are substantially the same.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P30_S1	The rate is based on the three-month LIBOR (London Interbank Offered Rate) plus 3.40%, not to exceed 11.9%, adjustable quarterly.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P31_S0	The proceeds from the sale of the Debentures were primarily used by the Company to inject capital into the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P32_S0	During the third quarter of 2005, the Company formed a wholly owned Delaware stat utory business trust, Plumas Statutory Trust II (the Trust II ).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P32_S1	On September 28, 2005, the Company issued to the Trust II, Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures due 2035 (the Debentures ) in the aggregate principal amount of $4,124,000.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P32_S2	In exchange for these debentures the Trust II paid the Company $4,124,000.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P33_S0	The Trust II funded its purchase of debentures by issuing $4,000,000 in floating rate capital securities ( trust preferred securities ), which were sold to a third party.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P33_S1	These trust preferred securities qualify as Tier I capital under current Federal Reserve Board guidelines.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P33_S2	The Debentures are the only asset of the Trust II.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P34_S0	The interest rate and terms on both instruments are substantially the same.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P35_S0	The rate is based on the three-month LIBOR (London Interbank Offered Rate) plus 1.48%, adjustable quarterly.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P35_S1	The proceeds from the sale of the Debentures were primarily used by the Company to inject capital into the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P36_S0	The trust preferred securities are mandatorily redeem able upon maturity of the Debentures on September 26, 2032 for Trust I and September 28, 2035 for Trust II, or upon earlier redemption as provided in the indenture.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P37_S0	Neither Trust I nor Trust II are consolidated into the Company s consolidated financial statements and, accordingly, both entities are accounted for under the equity method and the junior subordinated debentures are reflected as debt on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P38_S0	On April 15, 2013 the Bancorp issued a $7.5 million subordinated debenture.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P38_S1	The subordinated debt was issued to an unrelated third-party ( Lender ) pursuant to a subordinated debenture purchase agreement, subordinated debenture note, and stock purchase warrant.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P38_S2	On April 16, 2015 the Company paid off the subordinated debt.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P39_S0	The subordinated debt had an interest rate of 7.5% per annum and a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight-year warrant to purchase up to 300,000 shares of th e Bancorp s common stock at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P39_S1	In May of 2016 the Company repurchased a portion of the warrant, representing the right to purchase 150,000 shares of the registrant s common stock at a cost of $862,000.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P39_S2	The remaining warrant represents the right to purchase 150,000 shares of Plumas Bancorp common stock at an exercise price of $5.25 per share.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P39_S3	Interest expense related to the subordinated debt for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 totaled $ 0, $219,000 and $756 ,000, respectively.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P40_S0	The Company has a $2.4 million note payable outstanding at December 31, 2016 with an unrelated commercial bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P40_S1	In addition, the Company has the ability to borrow an additional $2.6 million from this same bank under a line of credit agreement.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P40_S2	There were no outstanding borrowings on the line of credit at December 31, 2016.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P40_S3	MANAGEMENT S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Financial Condition Note Payable for detail information related to these borrowing agreements.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P41_S0	No individual or single group of related customer accounts is considered material in relation to the Bank s assets or deposits, or in relation to our overall business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P41_S1	However, at December 31, 2016 approximately 72% of the Bank s total loan portfolio consisted of real estate-secured loans, including real estate mortgage loans, real estate construction loans, consumer equity lines of credit, and agricultural loans secured by real estate.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P41_S2	Moreover, our business activities are currently focused in the California counties of Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Modoc, Shasta and Sierra and Washoe County in Nevada.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P41_S3	Consequently, our results of operations and financial condition are dependent upon the general trends in these economies and, in particular, the residential and commercial real estate markets.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P41_S4	In addition, the concentration of our operations in these areas of California and Nevada exposes us to greater risk than other banking companies with a wider geographic base in the event of catastrophes, such as earthquakes, fires and floods in these regions in California and Nevada.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P42_S0	With respect to commercial bank competitors, the business is largely dominated by a relatively small number of major banks with many offices operating over a wide geographical area.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P42_S1	These banks have, among other advantages, the ability to finance wide-ranging and effective advertising campaigns and to allocate their resources to regions of highest yield and demand.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P43_S0	Many of the major banks operating in the area offer certain services that we do not offer directly but may offer indirectly through correspondent institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P43_S1	By virtue of their greater total capitalization, such banks also have substantially higher lending limits than we do.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P43_S2	For customers whose loan demands exceed our legal lending limit, we attempt to arrange for such loans on a participation basis with correspondent or other banks.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P44_S0	In addi tion to other banks, our competitors include savings institutions, credit unions, and numerous non-banking institutions such as finance companies, leasing companies, insurance companies, brokerage firms, and investment banking firms.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P44_S1	In recent years, increased competition has also developed from specialized finance and non-finance companies that offer wholesale finance, credit card, and other consumer finance services, including on-line banking services and personal financial software.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P45_S0	Strong competition for deposit and loan products affects the rates of those products as well as the terms on which they are offered to customers.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P45_S1	Mergers between financial institutions have placed additional competitive pressure on banks within the industry to streamline their operations, reduce expenses, and increase revenues.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P45_S2	Competition has also intensified due to federal and state interstate banking laws enacted in the mid-1990 s, which permit banking organizations to expand into other states.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P46_S0	The relatively large California market has been particularly attractive to out-of-state institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P46_S1	The Financial Modernization Act, which became effective March 11, 2000, has made it possible for full affiliations to occur between banks and securities firms, insurance companies, and other financial companies, and has also intensified competitive conditions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P47_S0	Currently, within towns in which the Bank has a branch there are 106 banking branch offices of competing institutions (excluding credit unions, but including savings banks), including 71 branches of 10 banks having assets in excess of $10 billion.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P47_S1	As of June 30, 2016, the FDIC estimated the Bank s market share of insured deposits within the communities it serves to be as follows: Greenville and Portola 100%, Chester 64%, Alturas 63%, Q uincy 53%, Fall River Mills 34%, Kings Beach 29%, Susanville 28%, Truckee 15%, Tahoe City 12%, Redding 1% and Reno less than 1%.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P48_S0	Technological innovations have also resulted in increased competition in financial services markets.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P48_S1	Such innovation has, for example, made it possible for non-depository institutions to offer customers automated transfer payment services that previously were considered traditional banking products.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P48_S2	In addition, many customers now expect a choice of delivery systems and channels, including home computer, mobile, remote deposit, telephone, ATMs, mail, full-service branches and/or in-store branches.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P48_S3	The sources of competition in such products include traditional banks as well as savings associations, credit unions, brokerage firms, money market and other mutual funds, asset management groups, finance and insurance companies, internet-only financial intermediaries, and mortgage banking firms.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P49_S0	For many years we have countered rising competition by providing our own style of community-oriented, personalized service.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P49_S1	We rely on local promotional activity, personal contacts by our officers, directors, employees, and shareholders, automated 24-hour banking, and the individualized service that we can provide through our flexible policies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P49_S2	This approach appears to be well-received by our customers who appreciate a more personal and customer-oriented environment in which to conduct their financial transactions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P49_S3	To meet the needs of customers who prefer to bank electronically, we offer telephone banking, mobile banking, remote deposit, mobile deposit and internet banking with bill payment capabilities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P49_S4	This high tech and high touch approach allows the customers to tailor their access to our services based on their particular preference.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P50_S0	At December 31, 2016, the Company and its subsidiary employed 155 persons.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P50_S1	On a full-time equivalent basis, we employed 142 persons.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P50_S2	None of the Company s employees are represented by a labor union, and management considers its relations with employees to be good.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P51_S0	The Board of Directors has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics for directors, officers (including the Company s principal executive officer and principal financial officer) and financial personnel, known as the Corporate Governance Code of Ethics.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P51_S1	This Code of Ethics is available on the Company s website at www.plumasbank.com.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P51_S2	Shareholders may request a free copy of the Code of Ethics Policy from Plumas Bancorp, Ms. Elizabeth Kuipers, Investor Relations, 35 S. Lindan Avenue, Quincy, California 95971.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S0	We are extensively regulated under federal and state law.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S1	These laws and regulations are generally intended to protect depositors and customers, not shareholders.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S2	To the extent that the following information describes statutory or regulatory provisions, it is qualified in its entirety by reference to the particular statute or regulation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S3	Our operations may be affected by legislative changes and by the policies of various regulatory authorities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S4	Any change in applicable laws or regulations may have a material effect on our business and prospects.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P52_S5	We cannot accurately predict the nature or the extent of the effects on our business and earnings that fiscal or monetary policies, or new federal or state legislation may have in the future.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P53_S0	We are a registered bank holding company under the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, as amended, and are subject to the supervision of, and regulation by, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (the FRB ).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P53_S1	We are required to file reports with the FRB and the FRB periodically examines the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P54_S0	A bank holding company is required to serve as a source of financial and managerial strength to its subsidiary bank and, under appropriate circumstances, to commit resources to support the subsidiary bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P54_S1	FRB regulations require the Company to meet or exceed certain capital requirements and regulate provisions of certain bank holding company debt.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P54_S2	The Company is also a bank holding company within the meaning of Section 3700 of the California Financial Code.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P54_S3	Therefore, the Company and any of its subsidiaries are subject to supervision and examination by, and may be required to file reports with, the California Department of Business Oversight ( DBO ).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P55_S0	As a California-chartered commercial bank with deposits insured by the FDIC, the Bank is subject to the supervision and regulation of the DBO and the FDIC, as well as certain of the regulations of the FRB and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P55_S1	The DBO and the FDIC regularly examine the Bank and may prohibit the Bank from engaging in what they believe constitute unsafe or unsound banking practices.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P56_S0	The Company is subject to the disclosure and regulatory requirements of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, both as administered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P57_S0	As a listed company on NASDAQ, we are subject to NASDAQ rules for listed companies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P58_S0	The FDIC has risk-based capital adequacy guidelines intended to provide a measure of capital adequacy that reflects the degree of risk associated with a banking organization s operations for both transactions reported on the balance sheet as assets, and transactions, such as letters of credit and recourse arrangements, which are reported as off-balance-sheet items.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P58_S1	Under these guidelines, nominal dollar amounts of assets and credit equivalent amounts of off-balance-sheet items are multiplied by one of several risk adjustment percentages, which range from 0% for assets with low credit risk, such as certain U.S. government securities, to 100% for assets with relatively higher credit risk, such as business loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P59_S0	A banking organization s risk-based capital ratios are obtained by dividing its qualifying capital by its total risk-adjusted assets and off-balance-sheet items.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P59_S1	The regulators measure risk-adjusted assets and off-balance-sheet items against both total qualifying capital (the sum of Tier 1 capital and limited amounts of Tier 2 capital) and Tier 1 capital.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P59_S2	Tier 1 capital consists of common stock, retained earnings, noncumulative perpetual preferred stock and minority interests in certain subsidiaries, less most other intangible assets.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P59_S3	Tier 2 capital may consist of a limited amount of the allowance for loan and lease losses and certain other instruments with some characteristics of equity.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P59_S4	The inclusion of elements of Tier 2 capital is subject to certain other requirements and limitations of the federal banking agencies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P60_S0	A bank that does not achieve and maintain the required capital levels may be issued a capital directive by the FDIC and/or the DBO to ensure the maintenance of required capital levels.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S0	In July, 2013, the federal bank regulatory agencies approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks, sometimes called Basel III .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S1	The phase-in period for the final rules began in 2015, with certain of the rules requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S2	Under the final rules minimum requirements increased for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S3	The new capital rules include a new minimum common equity Tier 1 ratio of 4.5%, a Tier 1 capital ratio of 6.0% (increased from 4.0%), a total risk-based capital ratio of 8.0%, and a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0% (calculated as Tier 1 capital to average consolidated assets).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S4	The effective date of these requirements was January 1, 2015.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S5	In addition, the new capital rules include a capital conservation buffer of 2.5% above each of these levels (to be phased in over three years which beginning at 0.625% on January 1, 2016 and increasing by that amount on each subsequent January 1, until reaching 2.5% on January 1, 2019) will be required for banking institutions to avoid restrictions on their ability to pay dividends, repurchase stock or pay discretionary bonuses.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S6	Including the capital conservation buffer of 2.5%, the New Capital Rules would result in the following minimum ratios to be considered well capitalized: (i) a Tier 1 capital ratio of 8.5%, (ii) a common equity Tier 1 capital ratio of 7.0%, and (iii) a total capital ratio of 10.5%.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P61_S7	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P62_S0	The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has adopted final amendments to the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement (Regulation Y, Appendix C) ( the Policy Statement ) that, among other things, raised from $500 million to $1 billion the asset threshold to qualify for the Policy Statement.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P62_S1	The Company qualifies for treatment under the Policy Statement and is no longer subject to consolidated capital rules at the bank holding company level.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P63_S0	For additional information, see Item 7.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P64_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Capital Standards.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P65_S0	The Company s ability to pay cash dividends is dependent on dividends paid to it by the Bank and limited by California corporation law.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P65_S1	Under California law, the holders of common stock of the Company are entitled to receive dividends when and as declared by the Board of Directors, out of funds legally available, subject to certain restrictions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P65_S2	The California general corporation law permits a California corporation such as the Company to make a distribution to its shareholders if its retained earnings equal at least the amount of the proposed distribution or if after giving effect to the distribution, the value of the corporation s assets exceed the amount of its liabilities plus the amount of shareholders preferences, if any, and certain other conditions are met.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P66_S0	It is the Federal Reserve s policy that bank holding companies should generally pay dividends on common stock only out of income available over the past year, and only if prospective earnings support the organization s expected future needs and financial condition.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P66_S1	Further, it is the FRB s policy that bank holding companies should not maintain dividend levels that undermine their ability to be a source of strength to its banking subsidiaries.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P66_S2	The Federal Reserve also discourages dividend payment ratios that are at maximum allowable levels unless both asset quality and capital are very strong.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P67_S0	The Bank is a legal entity that is separate and distinct from its holding company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P67_S1	The Company is dependent on the performance of the Bank for funds which may be received as dividends from the Bank for use in the operation of the Company and the ability of the Company to pay dividends to shareholders.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P67_S2	Future cash dividends by the Bank will also depend upon management s assessment of future capital requirements, contractual restrictions, and other factors.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P68_S0	Dividends from the Bank to the Company are rest ricted under California law to the lesser of the Bank s retained earnings or the Bank s net income for the latest three fiscal years, less dividends previously declared during that period, or, with the approval of the DBO, to the greater of the retained earnings of the Bank, the net income of the Bank for its last fiscal year, or the net income of the Bank for its current fiscal year.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P68_S1	As of December 31, 2016, the maximum amount available for dividend distribution under this restriction was approximately $9.9 million.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P68_S2	In addition the Company s ability to pay dividends is subject to certain covenants contained in the indentures relating to the trust preferred securities issued by the Company s business trust subsidiaries.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P69_S0	The Community Reinvestment Act ( CRA ) requires that, in connection with examinations of financial institutions within its jurisdiction, the FDIC evaluate the record of the financial institutions in meeting the credit needs of their local communities, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods, consistent with the safe and sound operation of those institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P69_S1	These factors are also considered in evaluating mergers, acquisitions and applications to open a branch or new facility.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P69_S2	A less than Satisfactory rating would likely result in the suspension of any growth of the Bank through acquisitions or opening de novo branches until the rating is improved.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P69_S3	As of the most recent report of examination the Bank s CRA rating was Satisfactory.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P70_S0	Banks are also subject to certain restrictions imposed by the Federal Reserve Act on extensions of credit to executive officers, directors, principal shareholders (including the Company) or any related interest of such persons.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P70_S1	Extensions of credit must be made on substantially the same terms, including interest rates and collateral as, and follow credit underwriting procedures that are not less stringent than, those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with persons not affiliated with the bank, and must not involve more than the normal risk of repayment or present other unfavorable features.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P70_S2	Banks are also subject to certain lending limits and restrictions on overdrafts to such persons.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P70_S3	A violation of these restrictions may result in the assessment of substantial civil monetary penalties on the affected bank or any officer, director, employee, agent or other person participating in the conduct of the affairs of that bank, the imposition of a cease and desist order, and other regulatory sanctions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P71_S0	The Federal Reserve Act and the FRB s Regulation W limit the amount of certain loan and investment transactions between the Bank and its affiliates, require certain levels of collateral for such loans, and limit the amount of advances to third parties that may be collateralized by the securities of the Company or its subsidiaries.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P71_S1	Regulation W requires that certain transactions between the Bank and its affiliates be on terms substantially the same, or at least as favorable to the Bank, as those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with or involving nonaffiliated companies or, in the absence of comparable transactions, on terms and under circumstances, including credit standards, that in good faith would be offered to or would apply to nonaffiliated companies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P71_S2	The Company and its subsidiaries have adopted an Affiliate Transactions Policy and have entered into various affiliate agreements in compliance with Regulation W.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P72_S0	The FRB and the FDIC have adopted non-capital safety and soundness standards for institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P72_S1	These standards cover internal controls, information and internal audit systems, loan documentation, credit underwriting, interest rate exposure, asset growth, compensation, fees and benefits, and standards for asset quality, earnings and stock valuation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P72_S2	An institution that fails to meet these standards must develop a plan acceptable to the agency, specifying the steps that it will take to meet the standards.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P72_S3	Failure to submit or implement such a plan may subject the institution to regulatory sanctions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P73_S0	In addition to supervising and regulating state chartered non-member banks, the FDIC insures the Bank s deposits, up to prescribed statutory limits, through the Deposit Insurance Fund (the DIF ), currently $250,000 per depositor per institution.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P73_S1	The DIF is funded primarily by FDIC assessments paid by each DIF member institution.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P73_S2	The amount of FDIC assessments paid by each DIF member institution is based on its relative risk of default as measured by regulatory capital ratios and other supervisory factors.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P73_S3	The Bank s FDIC insurance expense totaled $255 thousand for 2016 .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P74_S0	Additionally, all FDIC-insured institutions are required to pay assessments to the FDIC to fund interest payments on bonds issued by the Financing Corporation ( FICO ), an agency of the Federal government established to recapitalize the predecessor to the DIF.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P74_S1	The Bank s FICO assessments totaled $30 thousand for 2016.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P74_S2	These assessments will continue until the FICO bonds mature in 2017 through 2019 .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P75_S0	The FDIC may terminate a depository institution s deposit insurance upon a finding that the institution s financial condition is unsafe or unsound or that the institution has engaged in unsafe or unsound practices that pose a risk to the DIF or that may prejudice the interest of the bank s depositors.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P75_S1	Under California law, the termination of deposit insurance for the Bank would result in a termination of the Bank s charter.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P76_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ), authorized national and state banks to establish branches in other states to the same extent as a bank chartered by that state would be permitted to branch.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P76_S1	Previously, banks could only establish branches in other states if the host state expressly permitted out-of-state banks to establish branches in that state.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P76_S2	Accordingly, banks may now enter new markets more freely.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P77_S0	The banking regulatory agencies are focusing greater attention on compliance with consumer protection laws and their implementing regulations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P77_S1	Examination and enforcement have become more intense in nature, and insured institutions have been advised to monitor carefully compliance with such laws and regulations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P77_S2	The Company is subject to many federal and state consumer protection and privacy statutes and regulations, including but not limited to the following:
1168455_17_ITEM1_P78_S0	The Equal Credit Opportunity Act generally p rohibits discrimination in any credit transaction, whether for consumer or business purposes, on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age (except in limited circumstances), receipt of income from public assistance programs, or good faith exercise of any rights under the Consumer Credit Protection Act.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P79_S0	The Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) is designed to ensure that credit terms are disclosed in a meaningful way so that consumers may compare credit terms more readily and knowledgeably.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P79_S1	As a result of the TILA, all creditors must use the same credit terminology to express rates and payments, including the annual percentage rate, the finance charge, the amount financed, the total of payments and the payment schedule, among other things.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P80_S0	As a result of the Dodd-Frank Act, Regulation Z promulgated under the TILA includes new limits on loan originator compensation for all closed-end mortgages.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P80_S1	These changes include, prohibiting certain payments to a mortgage broker or loan officer based on the transaction s terms or conditions, prohibiting dual compensation, and prohibiting a mortgage broker or loan officer from steering consumers to transactions not in their interest, to increase mortgage broker or loan officer compensation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P81_S0	The Fair Housing Act ( FH Act ) regulates many practices, including making it unlawful for any lender to discriminate in its housing-related lending activities against any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap or familial status.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P81_S1	A number of lending practices have been found by the courts to be, or may be considered, illegal under the FH Act, including some that are not specifically mentioned in the FH Act itself.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P82_S0	The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act ( HMDA ), in response to public concern over credit shortages in certain urban neighborhoods, requires public disclosure of information that shows whether financial institutions are serving the housing credit needs of the neighborhoods and communities in which they are located.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P82_S1	The HMDA also includes a fair lending aspect that requires the collection and disclosure of data about applicant and borrower characteristics as a way of identifying possible discriminatory lending patterns and enforcing anti-discrimination statutes.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P83_S0	The Right to Financial Privacy Act imposes a new requirement for financial institutions to provide new privacy protections to consumers.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P83_S1	Financial institutions must provide disclosures to consumers of its privacy policy, and state the rights of consumers to direct their financial institution not to share their nonpublic personal information with third parties.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P84_S0	The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ) requires lenders to provide noncommercial borrowers with disclosures regarding the nature and cost of real estate settlements.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P84_S1	Also, RESPA prohibits certain abusive practices, such as kickbacks, and places limitations on the amount of escrow accounts.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P85_S0	Penalties for noncompliance or violations under the above laws may include fines, reimbursement and other penalties.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P85_S1	Due to heightened regulatory expectations related to compliance generally, the Company may incur additional compliance costs.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P86_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act created a new, independent federal agency cal led the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), which is granted broad rulemaking, supervisory and enforcement powers under various federal consumer financial protection laws.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P86_S1	The CFPB has examination and primary enforcement authority with respect to depository institutions with $10 billion or more in assets.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P86_S2	Smaller institutions, including the Bank, will be subject to rules promulgated by the CFPB but will continue to be examined and supervised by federal banking regulators for consumer compliance purposes. .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P87_S0	A series of banking laws and regulations beginning with the bank Secrecy Act in 1970 requires banks to prevent, detect, and report illicit or illegal financial activities to the federal government to prevent money laundering, international drug trafficking, and terrorism.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P88_S0	Under the US PATRIOT Act of 2001, financial institutions are subject to prohibitions against specified financial transactions and account relationships, requirements regarding the Customer Identification Program, as well as enhanced due diligence and know your customer standards in their dealings with high risk customers, foreign financial institutions, and foreign individuals and entities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S0	The Gramm-Leach Bliley Act ( GLBA ) of 1999 imposes requirements on financial institutions with respect to consumer privacy.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S1	The GLBA generally prohibits disclosure of consumer information to non-affiliated third parties unless the consumer has been given the opportunity to object and has not objected to such disclosure.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S2	Financial institutions are further required to disclose their privacy policies to consumers annually.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S3	The GLBA also directs federal regulators, including the FDIC, to prescribe standards for the security of consumer information.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S4	The Bank is subject to such standards, as well as standards for notifying consumers in the event of a security breach.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S5	The Bank is required to have an information security program to safeguard the confidentiality and security of customer information and to ensure proper disposal of information that is no longer needed.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P89_S6	Customers must be notified when unauthorized disclosure involves sensitive customer information that may be misused.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P90_S0	Under federal law, the Bank and its institution-affiliated parties may be the subject of potential enforcement actions by the FDIC for unsafe and unsound practices in conducting their businesses, or for violations of any law, rule or regulation or provision, any consent order with any agency, any condition imposed in writing by the agency or any written agreement with the agency.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P90_S1	Enforcement actions may include the imposition of a conservator or receiver, cease-and-desist orders and written agreements, the termination of insurance of deposits, the imposition of civil money penalties, the payment of restitution and removal and prohibition orders against institution-affiliated parties.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P90_S2	The DBO also has authority to bring similar enforcement actions against the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P90_S3	The FRB has the authority to bring similar enforcement actions against the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P91_S0	From time to time, legislation is enacted which has the effect of increasing the cost of doing business, limiting or expanding permissible activities or affecting the competitive balance between banks and other financial institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P91_S1	Proposals to change the laws and regulations governing the operations and taxation of banks, bank holding companies and other financial institutions are frequently made in Congress, in the California legislature and before various bank regulatory agencies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P91_S2	Typically, the intent of this type of legislation is to strengthen the banking industry, even if it may on occasion prove to be a burden on management s plans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P91_S3	No prediction can be made as to the likelihood of any major changes or the impact that new laws or regulations might have on us.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P92_S0	Our earnings and growth are affected not only by general economic conditions, but also by the fiscal and monetary policies of the federal government, particularly the FRB.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P92_S1	The FRB implements national monetary policy for such purposes as curbing inflation and combating recession, through its open market operations in U.S. Government securities, control of the discount rate applicable to borrowings from the FRB, and establishment of reserve requirements against certain deposits.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P92_S2	These activities influence growth of bank loans, investments and deposits, and also affect interest rates charged on loans or paid on deposits.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P93_S0	The Company s profitability, like most financial institutions, is primarily dependent on interest rate spreads.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P93_S1	In general, the difference between the interest rates paid by the Bank on interest-bearing liabilities, such as deposits and other borrowings, and the interest rates received by the Bank on interest-earning assets, such as loans extended to customers and securities held in the investment portfolio, will comprise the major portion of the Company s earnings.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P93_S2	These rates are highly sensitive to many factors that are beyond our control, such as inflation, recession and unemployment, the monetary and fiscal policies of the federal government and the policies of regulatory agencies, particularly the FRB and the impact which future changes in domestic and foreign economic conditions might have on us cannot be predicted.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P94_S0	The nature and impact of future changes in monetary policies and their impact on us cannot be predicted with certainty.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P95_S0	See Note 2 Summary of Significant Accounting Policies Adoption of New Accounting Standards of the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 Financial Statements and Supplementary Data of this Annual Report on Form 10K for information related to recent accounting pronouncements.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P96_S0	A deterioration of national or local economic conditions could reduce the Company s profitability.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P97_S0	The Company s lending operations and its customers are primarily located in the eastern region of Northern California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P98_S0	A significant downturn in the national economy or the local economy due to agricultural commodity prices, real estate prices, public policy decisions, natural disaster, drought or other factors could result in a decline in the local economy in general, which could in turn negatively impact the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P99_S0	The majority of the Company s assets are loans, which if not repaid would result in losses to the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S0	The Bank, like other lenders, is subject to credit risk, which is the risk of losing principal or interest due to borrowers failure to repay loans in accordance with their terms.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S1	Underwriting and documentation controls cannot mitigate all credit risk.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S2	A downturn in the economy or the real estate market in the Company s market areas or a rapid increase in interest rates could have a negative effect on collateral values and borrowers ability to repay.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S3	To the extent loans are not paid timely by borrowers, the loans are placed on non-accrual status, thereby reducing interest income.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S4	Further, under these circumstances, an additional provision for loan and lease losses or unfunded commitments may be required.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P100_S5	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Analysis of Asset Quality and Allowance for Loan Losses .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P101_S0	If the Company s allowance for loan losses is not sufficient to absorb actual loan losses, the Company s profitability could be reduced.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P102_S0	The risk of loan losses is inherent in the lending business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P102_S1	The Company maintains an allowance for loan losses based upon the Company s actual losses over a relevant time period and management s assessment of all relevant qualitative factors that may cause future loss experience to differ from its historical loss experience.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P102_S2	Although the Company maintains a rigorous process for determining the allowance for loan losses, it can give no assurance that it will be sufficient to cover future loan losses.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P102_S3	If the allowance for loan losses is not adequate to absorb future losses, or if bank regulatory agencies require the Company to increase its allowance for loan losses, earnings could be significantly and adversely impacted.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P103_S0	A deterioration in the real estate market could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P104_S0	As of December 31, 2016, approximately 72% of the Company s total loan portfolio is secured by real estate, the majority of which is commercial real estate.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P104_S1	Increases in commercial and consumer delinquency levels or declines in real estate market values would require increased net charge-offs and increases in the allowance for loan losses, which could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition and results of operations and prospects.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P105_S0	Fluctuations in interest rates could reduce profitability.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P106_S0	The Company s earnings depend largely upon net interest income, which is the difference between the total interest income earned on interest earning assets (primarily loans and investment securities) and the total interest expense incurred on interest bearing liabilities (primarily deposits and borrowed funds).
1168455_17_ITEM1_P106_S1	The interest earned on assets and paid on liabilities are affected principally by direct competition, and general economic conditions at the state and national level and other factors beyond the Company s control such as actions of the FRB, the general supply of money in the economy, legislative tax policies, governmental budgetary matters, and other state and federal economic policies.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P106_S2	Although the Company maintains a rigorous process for managing the impact of possible interest rate fluctuations on earnings, the Company can provide no assurance that its management efforts will prevent earnings from being significantly and adversely impacted by changes in interest rates.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P107_S0	The Company could be required to raise additional capital in the future, but that capital may not be available when it is needed or may not be available on terms that are favorable to the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P108_S0	Federal and state bank regulatory authorities require the Company and the Bank to maintain adequate levels of capital to support their operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P108_S1	The Company s ability to raise additional capital if and as needed depends on conditions in the capital markets, which are outside the Company s control, and on the Company s financial performance.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P108_S2	Accordingly, the Company may not be able to raise additional capital, if needed, on terms that are acceptable to the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P108_S3	If the Company is unable to raise additional capital when needed, it could be required to curtail its growth strategy or reduce the levels of assets owned.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P108_S4	In addition, although the Company and the Bank are currently well-capitalized under applicable regulatory frameworks, bank regulators are authorized and sometimes required to impose a wide range of requirements, conditions, and restrictions on banks and bank holding companies that fail to maintain adequate capital levels.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P109_S0	D rought conditions in California could have an adverse impact on the Company s business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P110_S0	In recent years, California has experienced a severe drought, though much of California has recently experienced significant rain during 2016 and the beginning of 2017.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P111_S0	A significant portion of the Company s borrowers are involved in or are dependent on the agricultural industry in California, which requires water.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P111_S1	As of December 31, 2016, approximately 11% of the Company s loans were categorized as agricultural loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P112_S0	As a result of the drought, there have been governmental proposals concerning the distribution or rationing of water.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P112_S1	If the amount of water available to agriculture becomes scarcer due to drought or rationing, growers may not be able to continue to produce agricultural products profitably, which could force some out of business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P112_S2	Although many of the Company s customers are not directly involved in agriculture, they could be impacted by difficulties in the agricultural industry because many jobs and businesses in the Company s market areas are related to the production of agricultural products.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P112_S3	Therefore, the drought could adversely impact the Company s loan portfolio, business, financial condition and results of operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P113_S0	The Company faces substantial competition from larger banks and other financial institutions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S0	The Company faces subst antial competition for deposits and loans.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S1	Competition for deposits primarily comes from other commercial banks, savings institutions, thrift and loan associations, money market and mutual funds and other investment alternatives.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S2	Competition for loans comes from other commercial banks, savings institutions, credit unions, mortgage banking firms, thrift and loan associations and other financial intermediaries.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S3	Larger competitors, by virtue of their larger capital resources, have substantially greater lending limits and marketing resources than the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S4	In addition, they have greater resources and may be able to offer longer maturities or lower rates.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S5	The Company s competitors may also provide certain services for their customers, including trust and international banking that the Company is only able to offer indirectly through correspondent relationships.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P114_S6	Ultimately, competition can reduce the Company s profitability, as well as make it more difficult to increase the size of its loan portfolio and deposit base.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P115_S0	There are risks associated with the Company s growth strategy.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P116_S0	During the past two years, the Company completed the purchase and assumption of a branch office in Redding, California, opened a branch office in Reno, Nevada and established loan production offices in Phoenix, Arizona, Seattle Washington and Klamath Falls Oregon.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P116_S1	The Company may engage in additional acquisition activity and open additional offices in the future to expand the Company s markets or further its growth strategy.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P116_S2	There is no assurance that future acquisitions or offices will be successful.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P116_S3	Further, growth may strain the Company s administrative, managerial, financial and operational resources and increase demands on its systems and controls.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P116_S4	If the Company pursues its growth strategy too aggressively, fails to attract qualified personnel, control costs or maintain asset quality, or if factors beyond management s control divert attention away from its business operations, the Company s pursuit of its growth strategy could have a material adverse impact on its existing business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P117_S0	The Company relies on key executives and personnel and the loss of any of them could have a material adverse impact on the Company s prospects.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P118_S0	Competition for qualified employees and personnel in the banking industry is intense and there are a limited number of qualified persons with knowledge of, and experience in, the California community banking industry.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P118_S1	The process of recruiting personnel w ith the combination of skills and attributes required to carry out the Company s strategies is often lengthy.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P118_S2	The Company s success depends to a significant degree upon its ability to attract and retain qualified management, loan origination, finance, administrative, marketing, compliance and technical personnel and upon the continued contributions of its management and personnel.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P118_S3	In particular, the Company s success has been and continues to be highly dependent upon the abilities of key executives and certain other employees.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P119_S0	Security breaches and technological disruptions could damage the Company s reputation and profitability.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P119_S1	The Company s business is highly reliant on third party vendors and its ability to manage the operational risks associated with outsourcing those services.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P120_S0	The Company s electronic banking activities expose it to possible liability and loss of reputation should an unauthorized party gain access to confidential customer information.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P120_S1	Despite its considerable efforts and investment to provide the security and authentication necessary to effect secure transmission of data, the Company cannot fully guarantee that these precautions will protect its systems from future compromises or breaches of its security measures.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P120_S2	Although the Company has developed systems and processes that are designed to recognize and assist in preventing security breaches (and periodically test its security), failure to protect against or mitigate breaches of security could adversely affect its ability to offer and grow its online services, constitute a breach of privacy or other laws, result in costly litigation and loss of customer relationships, negatively impact the Bank s reputation, and could have an adverse effect on its business, results of operations and financial condition.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P120_S3	The Company may also incur substantial increases in costs in an effort to minimize or mitigate cyber security risks and to respond to cyber incidents.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P121_S0	The potential for operational risk exposure exists throughout the Company s business.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P121_S1	Integral to the Company s performance is the continued efficacy of the Company s technology and information systems, operational infrastructure and relationships with third parties and its colleagues in its day-to-day and ongoing operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P122_S0	Failure by any or all of these resources subjects us to risks that may vary in size, scale and scope.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P122_S1	This includes, but is not limited to, operational or systems failures, disruption of client operations and activities, ineffectiveness or exposure due to interruption in third party support as expected, as well as, the loss of key colleagues or failure on the part of key colleagues to perform properly.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P123_S0	Additionally, the Company outsources a large portion of its data processing to third parties which may encounter t echnological or other difficulties that may significantly affect the Company s ability to process and account for customer transactions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P123_S1	These vendors provide services that support its operations, including the storage and processing of sensitive consumer and business customer data, as well as its sales efforts.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P124_S0	A cyber security breach of a vendor s system may result in theft of the Company s data or disruption of business processes.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P124_S1	In most cases, the Company will remain primarily liable to its customers for losses arising from a breach of a vendor s data security system.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P125_S0	The Company relies on its outsourced service providers to implement and maintain prudent cyber security controls.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P125_S1	The loss of these vendor relationships could disrupt the services the Company provides to its customers and cause us to incur significant expense in connection with replacing these services.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P126_S0	The Company may incur fines, penalties and other negative consequences from regulatory violations, possibly even inadvertent or unintent ional violations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S0	The Company is subject to significant federal and state regulation and supervision.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S1	In the past, the Company s business has been increasingly affected by these regulations, and this trend is likely to continue into the future.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S2	Many of these laws are subject to interpretation and changing regulatory approaches to supervision and enforcement.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S3	The Company maintains systems and procedures designed to ensure that it complies with applicable laws and regulations, but there can be no assurance that these will be effective.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S4	The Company may incur fines, penalties and other negative consequences from regulatory violations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S5	The Company may also suffer other negative consequences resulting from findings of noncompliance with laws and regulations, that may also damage its reputation, and this in turn might materially affect its business and results of operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P127_S6	Further, some legal/regulatory frameworks provide for the imposition of fines, restitution or penalties for noncompliance even though the noncompliance was inadvertent or unintentional and even though there were in place at the time systems and procedures designed to ensure compliance.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P128_S0	The Company s disclosure controls and procedures may not prevent or detect all errors or acts of fraud.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P129_S0	The Company s disclosure controls and procedures are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed by us in reports it files under the Exchange Act is accurately accumulated and communicated to management, and recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P129_S1	The Company believes that any disclosure controls and procedures or internal controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, cannot provide absolute assurance that the objectives of the control system are met.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P130_S0	These inherent limitations include the realities that judgments in decision making can be faulty, that alternative reasoned judgments can be drawn, or that breakdowns can occur because of a simple error or mistake.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P130_S1	Additionally, controls can be circumvented by the individual acts of some persons, by collusion of two or more people or by an unauthorized override of the controls.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P130_S2	Accordingly, because of the inherent limitations in its control system, misstatements due to error or fraud may occur and not be detected, which could result in a material weakness in its internal controls over financial reporting and the restatement of previously filed financial statements.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P131_S0	The trading price of the Company s common stock may fluctuate as a result of a number of factors, many of which are outside its control.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P131_S1	Among the factors that could affect the Company s stock price are:
1168455_17_ITEM1_P132_S0	domestic and international economic factors unrelated to its performance.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P133_S0	Significant decline in the Company s stock price could result in substantial losses for individual shareholders and could lead to costly and disruptive securities litigation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P134_S0	The trading volume of the Company s common stock is limited.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P135_S0	Although the Company s common stock is traded on the Nasdaq Stock Market, trading volume to date has been relatively modest.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P135_S1	The limited trading market for the Company s common stock may lead to exaggerated fluctuations in market prices and possible market inefficiencies compared to more actively traded securities.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P135_S2	It may also make it more difficult for investors to sell the Company s common stock at desired prices, especially for holders seeking to dispose of a large number of shares of stock.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P136_S0	The Company depends primarily on the operations of the Bank to repay its indebtedness and fund its operations .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P136_S1	The Company s ability to pay any dividends or repurchase any of its shares in the future will also depend on the success of the Bank s operations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P137_S0	The Company is a separate and di stinct legal entity from its subsidiary, the Bank, and it receives substantially all of its revenue from dividends paid by the Bank.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P137_S1	There are legal limitations on the extent to which the Bank may extend credit, pay dividends or otherwise supply funds to, or engage in transactions with, the Company.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P137_S2	The Company s inability to receive dividends from the Bank could adversely affect its business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P138_S0	Disruptions in market conditions may adversely impact th e fair value of available-for-sale investment securities .
1168455_17_ITEM1_P139_S0	Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ) require the Company to carry its available-for-sale investment securities at fair value on its balance sheet.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P139_S1	Unrealized gains or losses on these securities, reflecting the difference between the fair market value and the amortized cost, net of its tax effect, are reported as a component of shareholders equity.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P140_S0	In certain instances GAAP requires recognition through earnings of declines in the fair value of securities that are deemed to be other than temporarily impaired.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P140_S1	Changes in the fair value of these securities may result from a number of circumstances that are beyond the Company s control, such as changes in interest rates, the financial condition of government sponsored enterprises or insurers of municipal bonds, changes in demand for these securities as a result of economic conditions, or reduced market liquidity.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P140_S2	There can be no assurance that the declines in market value will not result in other than temporary impairments of these assets, which would lead to loss recognition that could have a material adverse effect on the Company s net income and capital levels.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P141_S0	Damage to the Company s reputation could significantly harm the Company s business and prospects.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P142_S0	The Company s reputation is an important asset.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P142_S1	The Company s relationship with many of its customers is predicated upon its reputation as a high quality provider of financial services that adheres to the highest standards of ethics, service quality and regulatory compliance.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P143_S0	The Company s ability to attract and retain customers, investors and employees depends upon external perceptions.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P143_S1	Damage to its reputation among existing and potential customers, investors and employees could cause significant harm to the Company s business and prospects and may arise from numerous sources, including litigation or regulatory actions, failing to deliver minimum standards of service and quality, lending practices, inadequate protection of customer information, sales and marketing efforts, compliance failures, unethical behavior and the misconduct of employees.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P143_S2	Adverse developments in the banking industry may also, by association, negatively impact the Company s reputation or result in greater regulatory or legislative scrutiny or litigation against us.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P143_S3	The Company has policies and procedures in place that seek to protect its reputation and promote ethical conduct, but these policies and procedures may not be fully effective.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P143_S4	Negative publicity regarding the Company s business, employees, or customers, with or without merit, may result in the loss of customers, investors, and employees, costly litigation, a decline in revenues and increased governmental regulation.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P144_S0	The markets in which the Company operates are subject to the risk of earthquakes and other natural disasters.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P145_S0	Most of the Company s offices are located in California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P145_S1	Also, most of the real and personal properties securing the Company s loans are located in California.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P146_S0	California is prone to earthquakes, brush fires, flooding and other natural disasters.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P146_S1	In addition to possibly sustaining damage to its own properties, if there is a major earthquake, brush fires, flood or other natural disaster, the Company faces the risk that many of the Company s borrowers may experience uninsured property losses, or sustained job interruption and/or loss which may materially impair their ability to meet the terms of their loan obligations.
1168455_17_ITEM1_P146_S2	Therefore, a major earthquake, brush fire, flood or other natural disaster in California could have a material adverse effect on the Company s business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P0_S0	Of the Company s twelve depository branches, ten are owned and two are leased.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P0_S1	The Company also leases five lending offices and owns four administrative facilities.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P1_S0	(1) Non-branch administrative or credit administrative offices.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P2_S0	Total rental expenses under all leases totaled $2 76,000, $233,000 and $192,000, in 2016, 2015 and 2014 respectively.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P2_S1	The expiration dates of the leases vary, with the first such lease expiring during 2017 and the last such lease expiring during 2021.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P3_S0	Future minimum lease payments are as follows:
1168455_17_ITEM2_P4_S0	The Company maintains insurance coverage on its premises, leaseholds and equipment, including business interruption and record reconstruction coverage.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P4_S1	The branch properties and non-branch offices are adequate, suitable, in good condition and have adequate parking facilities for customers and employees.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P5_S0	The Company and Bank are limited in their investments in real property under Federal and state banking laws.
1168455_17_ITEM2_P5_S1	Generally, investments in real property are either for the Company and Bank use or are in real property and real property interests in the ordinary course of the Bank s business.
1168455_17_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time, the Company and/or it s subsidiary are a party to claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
1168455_17_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of the Company s management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to such proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on the financial condition or results of operations of the Company taken as a whole.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock is quoted on the NASDAQ Capital Market under the ticker symbol PLBC .
1168455_17_ITEM5_P0_S1	As of December 31, 2016, there were 4,896 ,875 shares of the Company s common stock outstanding held by approximately 1,400 shareholders of record as of the same date.

1168455_17_ITEM5_P1_S0	It is the policy of the Company to periodically distribute excess retained earnings to the shareholders through the payment of cash dividends.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P1_S1	Such dividends help promote shareholder value and capital adequacy by enhancing the marketability of the Company s stock.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P2_S0	All authority to provide a return to the shareholders in the form of a cash or stock dividend or split rests with the Board of Directors (the Board).
1168455_17_ITEM5_P2_S1	The Board will periodically, but on no regular schedule and in accordance with regulatory restrictions, if any, reviews the appropriateness of a cash dividend payment.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P2_S2	On October 20, 2016 the Company announced that its Board of Directors approved the reinstatement of a semi-annual cash dividend.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P2_S3	The dividend, in the amount of $0.10 per share, was paid on November 21, 2016 to shareholders of record at the close of business day on November 7, 2016.
1168455_17_ITEM5_P2_S4	No common cash dividends were paid in 2015.
