1168455_18_ITEM8_P72_S1	Well defined weaknesses include a project s lack of marketability, inadequate cash flow or collateral support, failure to complete construction on time or the project s failure to fulfill economic expectations.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P72_S2	They are characterized by the distinct possibility that the Company will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P73_S0	Doubtful Loans classified doubtful have all the weaknesses inherent in those classified as substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P74_S0	Loans not meeting the criteria above that are analyzed individually as part of the above described process are considered to be pass-rated loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P75_S0	The general reserve component of the allowance for loan losses associated with loans collectively evaluated for impairment also consists of reserve factors that a re based on management s assessment of the following for each portfolio segment: ( 1 ) historical losses and ( 2 ) other qualitative factors, including inherent credit risk.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P75_S1	These reserve factors are inherently subjective and are driven by the repayment risk associated with each portfolio segment described below .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P76_S0	Commercial Commercial loans are generally underwritten to existing cash flows of operating businesses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P76_S1	Debt coverage is provided by business cash flows and economic trends influenced by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P77_S0	Agricultural Loans secured by crop production and livestock are especially vulnerable to two risk factors that are largely outside the control of Company and borrowers: commodity prices and weather conditions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P78_S0	Real e state Residential and Home Equity Lines of Credit The degree of risk in residential real estate lending depends primarily on the loan amount in relation to collateral value, the interest rate and the borrower s ability to repay in an orderly fashion.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P78_S1	These loans generally possess a lower inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P78_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P78_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P79_S0	Real estate Commercial Commercial real estate mortgage loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments, except land and construction loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P79_S1	Adverse economic developments or an overbuilt market impact commercial real estate projects and may result in troubled loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P79_S2	Trends in vacancy rates of commercial properties impact the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P79_S3	High vacancy rates reduce operating revenues and the ability for properties to produce sufficient cash flow to service debt obligations.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P80_S0	Real estate Construction and Land Development Construction and land development loans generally possess a higher inherent risk of loss than other real estate portfolio segments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P80_S1	A major risk arises from the necessity to complete projects within specified cost and time lines.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P80_S2	Trends in the construction industry significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as demand drives construction activity.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P80_S3	In addition, trends in real estate values significantly impact the credit quality of these loans, as property values determine the economic viability of construction projects.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P81_S0	Automobile An automobile loan portfolio is usually comprised of a large number of smaller loans scheduled to be amortized over a specific period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P81_S1	Most automobile loans are made directly for consumer purchases, but business vehicles may also be included.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P81_S2	Economic trends determined by unemployment rates and other key economic indicators are closely correlated to the credit quality of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P81_S3	Weak economic trends indicate that the borrowers capacity to repay their obligations may be deteriorating.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P82_S0	Other Other loans primarily consist of consumer loans and are similar in nature to automobile loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P83_S0	Although management believes the allowance to be adequate, ulti mate losses may vary from its estimates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P83_S1	At least quarterly, the Board of Directors and management review the adequacy of the allowance, including consideration of the relative risks in the portfolio, current economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P83_S2	If the Board of Directors and management determine that changes are warranted based on those reviews, the allowance is adjusted.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P83_S3	In addition, the Company s primary regulators, the FDIC and DBO, as an integral part of their examination process, review the adequacy of the allowance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P83_S4	These regulatory agencies may require additions to the allowance based on their judgment about information available at the time of their examinations.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P84_S0	The Company also maintains a separate allowance for off-balance-sheet commitments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P85_S0	M anagement estimates anticipated losses using historical data and utilization assumptions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P85_S1	The allowance for these commitments totaled $200,000 at December 31, 2017 and 2016 and is included in accrued interest payable and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S0	Other real estate owned relates to real estate acquired in full or partial settlement of loan obligations, which was $1,344,000 ( $2,642,000 less a valuation allowance of $1,298,000 ) at December 31, 2017 and $735,000 ( $2,005,000 less a valuation allowance of $1,270,000 ) at December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S1	Of these amounts $110,000 at December 31, 2017 and 84,000 at December 31, 2016 represent foreclosed residential real estate property.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S2	No consumer mortgage loans secured by residential real estate properties were in the process of foreclosure at December 31, 2017.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S3	There were four consumer mortgage loans with a balance of $335 thousand secured by residential real estate properties for which formal foreclosure proceedings were in process at December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S4	Proceeds from sales of other real estate owned totaled $689,000, $2,245,000 and $2,281,000 for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 the Company recorded gains on sale of other real estate owned of $13 0,000, $60,000 and $198,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S6	Other real estate owned is initially recorded at fair value less cost to sell when acquired, any excess of the Bank s recorded investment in the loan balance and accrued interest income over the estimated fair value of the property less costs to sell is charged against the allowance for loan losses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S7	A valuation allowance for losses on other real estate is maintained to provide for temporary declines in value.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S8	The allowance is established through a provision for losses on other real estate which is included in other expenses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P86_S9	Subsequent gains or losses on sales or write-downs resulting from permanent impairment are also recorded in other expenses as incurred.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P87_S0	The following table provides a summary of the change in the OREO balance for the years ended December 31, 201 7 and 2016:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P88_S0	Intangible assets consist of core deposit intangibles related to branch acquisitions and are amortized using the straight-line method over a period not to exceed fifteen years.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P88_S1	The Company evaluates the recoverability and remaining useful life annually to determine whether events or circumstances warrant a revision to the intangible asset or the remaining period of amortization.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P88_S2	There were no such events or circumstances during the periods presented.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P89_S0	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, intangible assets totaled $81,000 and $87,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P90_S0	Premises and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P91_S0	Depreciation is determined using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P91_S1	The useful lives of premises are estimated to be twenty to thirty years.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P91_S2	The useful lives of furniture, fixtures and equipment are estimated to be two to ten years.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P92_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the life of the asset or the life of the related lease, whichever is shorter.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P92_S1	When assets are sold or otherwise disposed of, the cost and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are removed from the accounts, and any resulting gain or loss is recognized in income for the period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P93_S0	The cost of maintenance and repairs is charged to expense as incurred.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P94_S0	The Company evaluates premises and equipment for financial impairment as events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be fully recoverable.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P95_S0	The Company has purchased life insurance policies on certain key executives.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P96_S0	Bank owned life insurance is recorded at the amount that can be realized under the insurance contract at the balance sheet date, which is the cash surrender value adjusted for ot her charges or other amounts due that are probable at settlement.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P97_S0	The Company files its income taxes on a consolidated basis with its subsidiary.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P98_S0	Income tax expense is the total of current year income tax due or refundable and the change in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P99_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P99_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are adjusted for the effects of changes in tax laws and rates on the date of enactment.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P99_S2	A valuation allowance is recognized if, based on the weight of available evidence management believes it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P100_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P101_S0	When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain that some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty about the merits of the position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P101_S1	The benefit of a tax position is recognized in the financial statements in the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes, if any.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P101_S2	Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P101_S3	Tax positions that meet the more-likely-than- not recognition threshold are measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely of being realized upon settlement with the applicable taxing authority.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P101_S4	The portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the amount measured as described above is reflected as a liability for unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying balance sheet along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the taxing authorities upon examination.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P102_S0	Interest expense and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits, if any, are classified as income tax expense in the consolidated income statement.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P102_S1	There have been no significant changes to unrecognized tax benefits or accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P103_S0	Basic earnings per share (EPS), which excludes d ilution, is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders (net income plus discount on redemption of preferred stock less preferred dividends and accretion) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P103_S1	Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P103_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted EPS.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P104_S0	Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P104_S1	Other comprehensive income includes unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale which are also recognized as separate components of equity.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P104_S2	The amount reclassifie d out of other accumulated comprehensive income relating to realized (losses) gains on securities available for sale was $( 158,000 ) , $( 32 ,000 ) and $21,000 for 2017, 2016 and 2015, with the related tax effect of $( 65,000 ), $( 13 ,000 ) and $9,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P105_S0	In February 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018 - 02, Reclassification of Certain Tax Effects from Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income ( AOCI ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P105_S1	The Company early adopted this new standard in the current year.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P106_S0	ASU 2018 - 02 allows entities to elect to reclassify stranded tax effects on items within AOCI, resulting from the new tax bill signed into law on December 22, 2017, to retained earnings.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P107_S0	Banking regulations require maintaining certain capital levels and may limit the dividend paid by the bank to the holding company or by the holding company to shareholders.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P108_S0	Fair values of financial instruments are estimated using relevant market information and other assumptions, as more fully disclosed in a separate note.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P108_S1	Fair value estimates involve uncertainties and matters of signifi cant judgment regarding interest rates, credit risk, prepayments, and other factors, especially in the absence of broad markets for particular items.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P108_S2	Changes in assumptions or in market conditions could significantly affect these estimates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P109_S0	Compensation expense related to the Company s Stock Option Plans, net of related tax benefit, recorded in 2017, 2016 and 2015 totaled $141,000, $103,000 and $63,000 or $0.03, $0.02 and $0.01 per diluted share, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P109_S1	Compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period on a straight line accounting basis.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P110_S0	The Company determines the fair value of options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model that uses assumptions based on expected option life, expected stock volatility and the risk-free interest rate.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P110_S1	The expected volatility assumptions used by the Company are based on the historical volatility of the Company s common stock over the most recent period commensurate with the estimated expected life of the Company s stock options.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P110_S2	The Company bases its expected life assumption on its historical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock options it grants to employees.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P110_S3	The risk-free rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve for the periods within the contractual life of the options in effect at the time of the grant.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P111_S0	During 2016 the Company granted options to purchase 108,000 shares of common stock, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P111_S1	The fair value of each option was estimated on the date of grant using the following assumptions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P112_S0	No options were granted during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2015.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P113_S0	On March 30, 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016 - 09, Compensation Stock Compensation: Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting, which is intended to simplify several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities, and classification on the statement of cash flows.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P113_S1	ASU 2016 - 09 is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P113_S2	The Company adopted ASU No. 2016 - 09 on January 1, 2017 and elected to recognize forfeitures as they occur.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P113_S3	The cumulative effect adjustment from the modified retrospective transition of the forfeitures and the classification of awards did not have a material effect on the Company s financial statements or disclosures.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P113_S4	The Company expects adoption of ASU No. 2016 - 09 could result in increased volatility to reported income tax expense related to excess tax benefits .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P114_S0	In February 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018 - 02, Reclassification of Certain Tax Effects from Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income ( AOCI ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P114_S1	ASU 2018 - 02 allows entities to elect to reclassify stranded tax effects on items within AOCI, resulting from the new tax bill signed into law on December 22, 2017, to retained earnings.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P114_S2	The Company elected to early adopt this new standard in 2017 and recorded a reclassification from AOCI to retained earnings in the amount of $94,000 .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P115_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014 - 09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P115_S1	This update to the ASC is the culmination of e fforts by the FASB and the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) to develop a common revenue standard for U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P115_S2	ASU 2014 - 09 supersedes Topic 605 Revenue Recognition and most industry-specific guidance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P116_S0	The core principal of the guidance is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P116_S1	The guidance in ASU 2014 - 09 describes a 5 -step process entities can apply to achieve the core principle of revenue recognition and requires disclosures sufficient to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing, and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers and the significant judgments used in determining that information.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P117_S0	This update was originally effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2016 and interim periods therein and requires expanded disclosures.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P117_S1	In July 2015 the FASB issued a deferral of ASU 2014 - 09 of one year making it effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2017 while also providing for early adoption but not before the original effective date.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P117_S2	Since the guidance does not apply to revenue associated with financial instruments, including loans and securities that are accounted for under other GAAP, the Company does not expect the new guidance to have a material impact on revenue most closely associated with financial instruments, including interest income.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P117_S3	The Company plans to adopt ASU No. 2014 - 09 on January 1, 2018 utilizing the modified retrospective approach.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P118_S0	On January 5, 2 016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2016 - 01, Financial Instruments Overall: Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P118_S1	Changes made to the current measurement model primarily affect the accounting for equity securities with readily determinable fair values, where changes in fair value will impact earnings instead of other comprehensive income.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P118_S2	The accounting for other financial instruments, such as loans, investments in debt securities, and financial liabilities is largely unchanged.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P118_S3	The Update also changes the presentation and disclosure requirements for financial instruments including a requirement that public business entities use exit price when measuring the fair value of financial instruments measured at amortized cost for disclosure purposes.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P118_S4	This Update is generally effective for public business entities in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P119_S0	The Company has performed a preliminary evaluation of the provisions of ASU No. 2016 - 01.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P119_S1	Based on this evaluation, the Company has determined that ASU No. 2016 - 01 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements; however, the Company will continue to closely monitor developments and additional guidance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P120_S0	On February 25, 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016 - 02, Leases.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P120_S1	The most significant change for lessees is the requirement under the new guidance to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for all leases not considered short-term leases, which is generally defined as a lease term of less than 12 months.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P120_S2	This change will result in lessees recognizing right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for most leases currently accounted for as operating leases under current lease accounting guidance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P120_S3	ASU 2016 - 02 is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2018.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P121_S0	The Company has several lease agreements, including two branch locations, which are currently considered operating leases, and therefore, not recognized on the Company s consolidated statements of condition.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P121_S1	The Company expects the new guidance will require some of these lease agreements to now be recognized on the consolidated statements of condition as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding lease liability.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P121_S2	Therefore, the Company s preliminary evaluation indicates the provisions of ASU No. 2016 - 02 are expected to impact the Company s consolidated statements of condition.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P121_S3	However, the Company continues to evaluate the extent of potential impact the new guidance will have on the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016 - 13, Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S1	ASU No. 2016 - 13 significantly changes how entities will measure credit losses for most financial assets and certai n other instruments that aren t measured at fair value through net income.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S2	The standard will replace today s incurred loss approach with an expected loss model.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S3	The new model, referred to as the current expected credit loss ( CECL ) model, will apply to: ( 1 ) financial assets subject to credit losses and measured at amortized cost, and ( 2 ) certain off-balance sheet credit exposures.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S4	This includes, but is not limited to, loans, leases, held-to-maturity securities, loan commitments, and financial guarantees.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S5	The CECL model does not apply to available-for-sale ( AFS ) debt securities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S6	For AFS debt securities with unrealized losses, entities will measure credit losses in a manner similar to what they do today, except that the losses will be recognized as allowances rather than reductions in the amortized cost of the securities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S7	The ASU also simplifies the accounting model for purchased credit-impaired debt securities and loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S8	ASU No. 2016 - 13 also expands the disclosure requirements regarding an entity s assumptions, models, and methods for estimating the allowance for loan and lease losses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P122_S9	ASU No. 2016 - 13 is effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2019; early adoption is permitted for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2018.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P123_S0	Entities will apply the standard s provisions as a cumulative-effect adjustment to retained earnings as of the beginning of the first reporting period in which the guidance is effective (i.e., modified retrospective approach).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P124_S0	The Company has begun its implementation efforts by establishing an implementation team chaired by the Company s Chief Lending Officer and composed of members of the Company s credit administration and accounting departments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P124_S1	The Company s preliminary evaluation indicates the provisions of ASU No. 2016 - 13 are expected to impact the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements, in particular the level of the reserve for credit losses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P124_S2	However, the Company continues to evaluate the extent of the potential impact.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P125_S0	On March 30, 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017 - 08, Receivables Non-Refundable Fees and Other Costs: Premium Amortization on Purchased Callable Debt Securities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P125_S1	This ASU amends the amortization period for certain purchased callable debt securities held at a premium, shortening such period to the earliest call date.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P125_S2	The amendments do not require an accounting change for securities held at a discount; the discount continues to be amortized to maturity.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P126_S0	ASU 2017 - 08 is effective for public business entities for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2018.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P126_S1	Entities will apply the standard s provisions as a cumulative-effect adjustment to retained earnings as of the beginning of the first reporting period in which the guidance is effective (i.e., modified retrospective approach).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P127_S0	The Company has performed a preliminary evaluation of the provisions of ASU No. 2017 - 08.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P127_S1	Based on this evaluation, the Company has determined that ASU No. 2017 - 08 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P128_S0	The Company measures fair value under the fair value hierarchy described below.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P129_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active exchange markets.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P130_S0	Level 2: Quoted prices (unadjusted) for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model-based valuation techniques for which all significant assumptions are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P131_S0	Level 3: Model based techniques that use one significant assumption not observable in the market.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P131_S1	These unobservable assumptions reflect the Company s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use on pricing the asset or liability.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P132_S0	Valuation techniques include management judgment and estimation which may be significant.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P133_S0	In certain cases, the inputs used to measure fair value may fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P133_S1	In such cases, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P133_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P134_S0	Management monitors the availability of observable market data to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P135_S0	Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value level to another.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P135_S1	In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P136_S0	Management evaluates the significance of transfers between levels based upon th e nature of the financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total assets, total liabilities or total earnings.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P137_S0	The carrying amounts and estimated fair values of financial instruments, at December 31, 201 7 are as follows:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P138_S0	The carrying amounts and estimated fair values of financial instruments, at December 31, 2016 are as follows:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P139_S0	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated futu re business related to the instruments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P139_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P140_S0	The followin g methods and assumptions were used by management to estimate the fair value of its financial instruments:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P141_S0	The carrying amounts of cash and short-term instruments approximate fair values and are classified as Level 1.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P142_S0	Investment securities: Fair values for securities available for sale are generally determined by matrix pricing, which is a mathematical technique widely used in the industry to value debt securities without relying exclusively on quoted prices for the specific securities but rather by relying on the securities relationship to other benchmark quoted securities (Level 2 ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P143_S0	Loans: Fair values of loans, excluding loans held for sale, are estimated as follows:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P143_S1	For variable rate loans that reprice frequently and with no significant change in credit risk, fair values are based on carrying values resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P143_S2	Fair values for other loans are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses, using interest rates currently being offered for loans with similar terms to borrowers of similar credit quality resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P144_S0	Impaired loans are valued at the lower of cost or fair value.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P145_S0	The methods utilized to estimate the fair value of loans do not necessarily represent an exit price.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P146_S0	It was not practicable to determine the fair value of the FHLB stock due to restrictions placed on its transferability.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P147_S0	Deposits: The fair values disclosed for demand deposits, including interest and non-interest demand accounts, savings, and certain types of money market accounts are, by definition, equal to the carrying amount at the reporting date resulting in a Level 1 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P147_S1	Fair values for fixed rate certificates of deposit are estimated using a discounted cash flow calculation that applies interest rates currently being offered on certificates to a schedule of aggregated expected monthly maturities on time deposits resulting in a Level 2 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P148_S0	Repurchase agreements: The fair value of securities sold under repurchase agreements is estimated based on bid quotations received from brokers using observable inputs and are included as Level 2.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P149_S0	Payable is estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P150_S0	Junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures: The fair values of the Company s Subordinated Debentures are estimated using discounted cash flow analyses based on the current borrowing rates for similar types of borrowing arrangements resulting in a Level 3 classification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P151_S0	The carrying amounts of accrued interest approximate fair value and are considered to be linked in classification to the asset or liability for which they relate.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P152_S0	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit: The fair value of commitments are estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements and are not significant and, therefore, not presented.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P152_S1	Commitments to extend credit are primarily for variable rate loans and letters of credit.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P153_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instru ments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments and other factors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P153_S1	Those estimates that are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and therefore cannot be determined with precision are included in Level 3.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P154_S0	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the fair values presented.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P155_S0	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument for sale at one time, nor do they attempt to estimate the value of anticipated future business related to the instruments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P155_S1	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in any of these estimates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P156_S0	The following tables present information about the Company s assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring and non-recurring basis as of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016, and indicates the fair value hierarchy of the valuation techniques utilized by the Company to determine such fair value:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P157_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at December 31, 2017 are summarized below:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P158_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at December 31, 2016 are summarized below:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P159_S0	The fair value of securities available-for-sale equals quoted market price, if available.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P159_S1	If quoted market prices are not available, fair value is determined using quoted market prices for similar securities or matrix pricing.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P159_S2	There were no changes in the valuation techniques used during 2017 or 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P160_S0	Transfers between hierarchy measurement levels are recognized by the Company as of the beginning of the reporting period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P161_S0	Changes in fair market value are recorded in other comprehensive income.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P162_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 2017 are summarized below:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P163_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a non-recurring basis at December 31, 201 6 are summarized below:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P164_S0	The Company has no liabilities which are reported at fair value.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P165_S0	The following methods were used to estimate fair value.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P166_S0	Collateral-Dependent Impaired Loans : The Bank does not record loans at fair value on a recurring basis.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P166_S1	However, from time to time, fair value adjustments are recorded on these loans to reflect partial write-downs, through charge-offs or specific reserve allowances, that are based on fair value estimates of the underlying collateral.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P166_S2	The fair value estimates for collateral-dependent impaired loans are generally based on recent real estate appraisals or broker opinions, obtained from independent third parties, which are frequently adjusted by management to reflect current conditions and estimated selling costs (Level 3 ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P166_S3	Net gains (losses) of $7,000 and $( 75 ,000 ) represent impairment charges recognized during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively, related to the above impaired loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P167_S0	Other Real Estate: Nonrecurring adjustments to certain real estate properties classified as other real estate owned are measured at the lower of carrying amount or fair value, less costs to sell.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P167_S1	In cases where the carrying amount exceeds the fair value, less costs to sell, an impairment loss is recognized.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P168_S0	Fair values are generally based on third party appraisals of the property which are commonly adjusted by management to reflect current conditions and selling costs (Level 3 ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P169_S0	Appraisals for both collateral-dependent impaired loans and oth er real estate are performed by certified general appraisers (for commercial properties) or certified residential appraisers (for residential properties) whose qualifications and licenses have been reviewed and verified by the Company.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P169_S1	Once received, a member of the Loan Administration Department reviews the assumptions and approaches utilized in the appraisal as well as the overall resulting fair value in comparison with independent data sources such as recent market data or industry-wide statistics.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P169_S2	On a quarterly basis, the Company compares the actual selling price of similar collateral that has been liquidated to the most recent appraised value for unsold properties to determine what additional adjustment, if any, should be made to the appraisal value to arrive at fair value.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P169_S3	Adjustments are routinely made in the appraisal process by the independent appraisers to adjust for differences between the comparable sales and income data available.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P177_S0	At December 31, 201 7, the Company held 192 securities of which 92 were in a loss position.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P177_S1	Of the securities in a loss position, 56 were in a loss position for less than twelve months.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P177_S2	Of the 192 securities 77 are U.S. Government-sponsored agencies collateralized by residential mortgage obligations and 115 were obligations of states and political subdivisions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P177_S3	The unrealized losses relate principally to market rate conditions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P177_S4	All of the securities continue to pay as scheduled.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P178_S0	When analyzing an issuer s financial condition, management considers the length of time and extent to which the market value has been less than cost; the historical and implied volatility of the security; the financial condition of the issuer of the security; and the Company s intent and ability to hold the security to recovery.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P178_S1	As of December 31, 2017, management does not have the intent to sell these securities nor does it believe it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell these securities before the recovery of its amortized cost basis.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P178_S2	Based on the Company s evaluation of the above and other relevant factors, the Company does not believe the securities that are in an unrealized loss position as of December 31, 2017 are other than temporarily impaired.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P179_S0	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of investment securities at Dece mber 31, 2017 by contractual maturity are shown below.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P180_S0	Expected maturities will differ from contractual maturities because the issuers of the securities may have the right to call or prepay obligations with or without call or prepayment penalties.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P183_S0	Changes in the allowance for loan losses were as follows:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P184_S0	The recorded investment in impaired loans totaled $2,270,000 and $5,442,000 at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P184_S1	The Company had specific allowances for loan losses of $82,000 on impaired loans of $475,000 at December 31, 2017 as compared to specific allowances for loan losses of $366,000 on impaired loans of $1,534,000 at December 31, 2016.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P184_S5	Of these amounts $ 0, $29,000 and $0 were recognized on the cash basis, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P185_S0	Included in impaired loans are troubled debt restructurings .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P185_S1	A troubled debt restructuring is a formal restructure of a loan where the Company for economic or legal reasons related to the borrower s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the borrower.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P185_S2	The concessions may be granted in various forms to include one or a combination of the following: a reduction of the stated interest rate of the loan; an extension of the maturity date at a stated rate of interest lower than the current market rate for new debt with similar risk; or a permanent reduction of the recorded investment in the loan.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P186_S0	In order to determine whether a borrower is experiencing financial difficulty, an evaluation is performed of the probability that the borrower will be in payment default on any of its debt in the foreseeable future without the modification.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P186_S1	This evaluation is performed under the Company s internal underwriting policy.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P187_S0	The carrying value of troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 201 7 and December 31, 2016 was $1,111 ,000 and $4,616,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P187_S1	The Company has allocated $63 ,000 and $342,000 of specific reserves on loans to customers whose loan terms have been modified in troubled debt restructurings as of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P187_S2	The Company has not committed to lend additional amounts on loans classified as troubled debt restructurings at December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P188_S0	There were no new troubled debt restructurings during the twelve months ending December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P189_S0	There were no troubled debt restructurings for which there was a payment d efault within twelve months following the modification during the twelve months ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S0	At December 31, 201 7 and 2016 , nonaccrual loans totaled $1,226,000 and $2,724,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S1	Interest foregone on nonaccrual loans totaled $50,000, $164 ,000 and $303 ,000 for the twelve months ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S2	The Company recognized $ 0, $29,000 and $ 0 in interest income on nonaccrual loans during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S3	At December 31, 2017 were three loans to one customer totaling $1.8 million that were 90 days past due and still accruing interest.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S4	These loans were well secured and in process of collection at December 31, 2017.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P190_S5	There were no loans past due 90 days or more and on accrual status at December 31, 2016.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S0	The Company is a member of the FHLB and can borrow up to $206,000,000 from the FHLB secured by commercial and residential mortgage loans with carrying values totaling $322,000,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S1	The Company is required to hold FHLB stock as a condition of membership.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S2	At December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016, the Company held $2,685,000 and $2,438,000, respectively of FHLB stock which is recorded as a component of other assets.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S3	Based on this level of stock holdings at December 31, 2017, the Company can borrow up to $99,448,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S4	To borrow the $206,000,000 in available credit the Company would need to purchase $2,884,000 in additional FHLB stock.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S5	In addition to its FHLB borrowing line, the Company has unsecured short-term borrowing agreements with three of its correspondent banks in the amounts of $20 million, $11 million and $10 million.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P204_S6	There were no outstanding borrowings to the FHLB or the correspondent banks under these agreements at December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P205_S0	On October 1, 2015, the Company entered into a $5.0 million term loan (the Term Loan ), which was scheduled to mature on October 1, 2018.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P205_S1	On April 20, 2017 Plumas Bancorp paid off the $2,250,000 remaining balance on the Term Loan.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P205_S2	The payment was funded through a $4 million dividend from Plumas Bank.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P205_S3	The balance of this Term Loan was $2,375,000 at December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S0	On October 1, 201 7 the Company renewed its line of credit, for a one year term, with the same lender (the Note ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S1	The maximum amount outstanding at any one time on the Note cannot exceed $5 million.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S2	There were no balances outstanding on the Note as of December 31, 2017 or December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S3	The Note bears interest at a rate of the U.S. Prime Rate plus one -quarter percent per annum and is secured by 100 shares of Plumas Bank stock representing the Company s 100% ownership interest in Plumas Bank.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S4	Under the Note, the Bank is subject to several negative and affirmative covenants including, but not limited to providing timely financial information, maintaining specified levels of capital, restrictions on additional borrowings, and meeting or exceeding certain capital and asset quality ratios.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S5	The Bank was in compliance with all such covenants related to the Note at December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P206_S6	Interest expense related to the Note and the Term Loan for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 totaled $28 thousand, $133 thousand and $155 thousand, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P207_S0	On April 15, 20 13 the Company issued a $7.5 million subordinated debenture ( subordinated debt ).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P207_S1	The subordinated debt was issued to an unrelated third -party ( Lender ) pursuant to a subordinated debenture purchase agreement, subordinated debenture note, and stock purchase warrant.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P207_S2	On April 16, 2015 the Bancorp paid off the subordinated debt.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P207_S3	Interest expense related to the subordinated debt for the year ended December 31, 2015 totaled $219,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P208_S0	The subordinated debt had an interest rate of 7.5% per annum and a term of 8 years with no prepayment allowed during the first two years and was made in conjunction with an eight -year warrant (the Warrant ) to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Company s common stock, no par value at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P209_S0	In May of 2016 the Company repurchased a portion of the warrant, representing the right to purchase 150,000 shares of the registrant s common stock at a cost of $862,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P209_S1	The remaining warrant represented the right to purchase 150,000 shares of Plumas Bancorp common stock at an exercise price of $5.25 per share was scheduled to expire on April 15, 2021.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P209_S2	In May, 2017 the warrant was exercised in a cashless exercise resulting in the issuance of 108,112 common shares.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P210_S0	Plumas Statutory Trust I and II are business trusts formed by the Company with capital of $3 28,000 and $169,000, respectively, for the sole purpose of issuing trust preferred securities fully and unconditionally guaranteed by the Company.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P211_S0	During 2002, Plumas Statutory Trust I issued 6,000 Floating Rate Capital Trust Pass-Through Securities ( Trust Preferred Securities ), with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $6,000,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P211_S1	During 2005, Plumas Statutory Trust II issued 4,000 Trust Preferred Securities with a liquidation value of $1,000 per security, for gross proceeds of $4,000,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P211_S2	The entire proceeds were invested by Trust I in the amount of $6,186,000 and Trust II in the amount of $4,124,000 in Floating Rate Junior Subordinated Deferrable Interest Debentures (the Subordinated Debentures ) issued by the Company, with identical maturity, repricing and payment terms as the Trust Preferred Securities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P211_S3	The Subordinated Debentures represent the sole assets of Trusts I and II.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P212_S0	Trust I s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 26, 2032, bear a current interest rate of 5.07% (based on 3 -month LIBOR plus 3.40% ), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P212_S1	Trust II s Subordinated Debentures mature on September 28, 2035, bear a current interest rate of 3.07% (based on 3 -month LIBOR plus 1.48% ), with repricing and payments due quarterly.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P212_S2	The Subordinated Debentures are redeemable by the Company, subject to receipt by the Company of prior approval from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, on any quarterly anniversary date on or after the 5 -year anniversary date of the issuance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P212_S3	The redemption price is par plus accrued and unpaid interest, except in the case of redemption under a special event which is defined in the debenture.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P212_S4	The Trust Preferred Securities are subject to mandatory redemption to the extent of any early redemption of the Subordinated Debentures and upon maturity of the Subordinated Debentures on September 26, 2032 for Trust I and September 28, 2035 for Trust II.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P213_S0	Holders of the Trust Preferred Securities are entitled to a cumulative cash distribution on the liquidation amount of $1,000 per security.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P213_S1	The interest rate of the Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust I adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3 -month LIBOR plus 3.40%.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P213_S2	The Trust Preferred Securities issued by Trust II adjust on each quarterly anniversary date to equal the 3 -month LIBOR plus 1.48%.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P213_S3	Both Trusts I and II have the option to defer payment of the distributions for a period of up to five years, as long as the Company is not in default on the payment of interest on the Subordinated Debentures.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P214_S0	The Trus t Preferred Securities were sold and issued in private transactions pursuant to an exemption from registration under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P214_S1	The Company has guaranteed, on a subordinated basis, distributions and other payments due on the Trust Preferred Securities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P215_S0	Interest expense recognized by the Company for the years ended December 31, 201 7, 2016 and 2015 related to the subordinated debentures was $401,000, $348,000 and $306,000, respectively.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P218_S0	The Company is a party to financial instruments with off-balance-sheet risk in the normal course of business in order to meet the financin g needs of its customers.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P218_S1	These financial instruments include commitments to extend credit and letters of credit.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P218_S2	These instruments involve, to varying degrees, elements of credit and interest rate risk in excess of the amount recognized on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P219_S0	The Company s exposure to credit loss in the event of nonperformance by the other party for commitments to extend credit and letters of credit is represented by the contractual amount of those instruments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P219_S1	The Company uses the same credi t policies in making commitments and letters of credit as it does for loans included on the consolidated balance sheet.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P220_S0	The following financial instruments represent off-balance-sheet credit risk:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P221_S0	Commitments to extend credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any condition established in the contract.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P221_S1	Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates or other termination clauses and may require payment of a fee.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P221_S2	Since some of the commitments are expected to expire without being drawn upon, the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P222_S0	The Company evaluates each customer s creditworthiness on a case-by-case basis.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P222_S1	The amount of collateral obtained, if deemed necessary by the Company upon extension of credit, is based on management s credit evaluation of the borrower.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P222_S2	Collateral held varies, but may include accounts receivable, crops, inventory, equipment, income-producing commercial properties, farm land and residential properties.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P223_S0	Letters of credit are conditional commitments issued by the Company to guarantee the pe rformance of a customer to a third party.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P223_S1	The credit risk involved in issuing letters of credit is essentially the same as that involved in extending loans to customers.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P223_S2	The fair value of the liability related to these letters of credit, which represents the fees received for issuing the guarantees, was not significant at December 31, 2017 and 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P223_S3	The Company recognizes these fees as revenues over the term of the commitment or when the commitment is used.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P224_S0	At December 31, 201 7, consumer loan commitments represent approximately 1 0% of total commitments and are generally unsecured.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P224_S1	Commercial and agricultural loan commitments represent approximately 38% of total commitments and are generally secured by various assets of the borrower.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P224_S2	Real estate loan commitments, including consumer home equity lines of credit, represent the remaining 52% of total commitments and are generally secured by property with a loan-to-value ratio not to exceed 80%.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P224_S3	In addition, the majority of the Company s commitments have variable interest rates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P225_S0	The Company grants real estate mortgage, real estate construction, commercial, agricultural and consumer loans to customers throughout Plumas, Nevada, Placer, Lassen, Sierra, Shasta and Modoc counties in California and Washoe county in Northern Nevada.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P226_S0	Although the Company has a diversified loan portfolio, a substantia l portion of its portfolio is secured by commercial and residential real estate.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P226_S1	A continued substantial decline in the economy in general, or a continued decline in real estate values in the Company s primary market areas in particular, could have an adverse impact on the collectability of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P226_S2	However, personal and business income represents the primary source of repayment for a majority of these loans.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P227_S0	The Company is subject to legal proceedings and claims which arise in the ord inary course of business.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P227_S1	In the opinion of management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to such actions will not materially affect the financial position or results of operations of the Company.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P228_S0	The Company s ability to pay cash dividends is dependent on dividends paid to it by the Bank and limited by California corporation law.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P228_S1	Under California law, the holders of common stock of the Company are entitled to receive dividends when a nd as declared by the Board of Directors, out of funds legally available, subject to certain restrictions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P228_S2	The California general corporation law permits a California corporation such as the Company to make a distribution to its shareholders if its retained earnings equal at least the amount of the proposed distribution or if after giving effect to the distribution, the value of the corporation s assets exceed the amount of its liabilities plus the amount of shareholders preferences, if any, and certain other conditions are met.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P229_S0	Dividends from the Bank to the Company are restricted under California law to the lesser of the Bank s retained earnings or the Bank s net income for the latest three fiscal years, less dividends previously declared during that per iod, or, with the approval of the DBO, to the greater of the retained earnings of the Bank, the net income of the Bank for its last fiscal year, or the net income of the Bank for its current fiscal year.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P229_S1	As of December 31, 2017, the maximum amount available for dividend distribution under this restriction was approximately $11,281,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P229_S2	In addition the Company s ability to pay dividends is subject to certain covenants contained in the indentures relating to the Trust Preferred Securities issued by the business trusts (see Note 10 for additional information related to the Trust Preferred Securities).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P230_S0	On October 20, 2016 the Company announced that its Board of Directors approved the reinstatement of a semi-annual cash dividend.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P230_S1	The dividend in the amount of $0.10 per share was paid on November 21, 2016 to shareholders of record at the close of business day on November 7, 2016.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P230_S2	On May 15, 2017 and November 15, 2017 the Company paid semi-annual cash dividends each of which totaled $0.14 per share.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P231_S0	Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P231_S1	Diluted earnings per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock, such as stock options, result in the issuance of common stock which shares in the earnings of the Company.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P231_S2	The treasury stock method has been applied to determine the dilutive effect of stock options in computing diluted earnings per share.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P232_S0	Shares of common stock issuable under stock options and warrants for which the exercise prices were greater than the average market prices were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share due to their antidilutive effect.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P232_S1	Stock options a nd warrants not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share, due to shares not being in the-money and having an antidilutive effect, were 0, 63,000 and 53,000 for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P232_S2	At December 31, 2016 one stock warrant was outstanding to purchase up to 150,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P232_S3	At December 31, 2015 one stock warrant was outstanding to purchase up to 300,000 shares of the Bancorp s common stock at an exercise price, subject to anti-dilution adjustments, of $5.25 per share.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P237_S0	In May 2013, the Company established the 2013 Stock Option Plan for which 466 ,200 shares of common stock are reserved and 305,600 shares are available for future grants as of December 31, 2017.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P237_S1	The 2013 Plan requires that the option price may not be less than the fair market value of the stock at the date the option is granted, and that the stock must be paid in full at the time the option is exercised.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P237_S2	Payment in full for the option price must be made in cash, with Company common stock previously acquired by the optionee and held by the optionee for a period of at least six months, in options of the Optionee that are fully vested and exercisable or in any combination of the foregoing.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P237_S3	The options expire on dates determined by the Board of Directors, but not later than ten years from the date of grant.

1168455_18_ITEM8_P243_S0	The Bank is subject to certain regulatory capital requirements administered by the FDIC.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P243_S1	Failure to meet these minimum capital requirements can initiate certain mandatory and poss ibly additional discretionary, actions by regulators that, if undertaken, could have a direct material effect on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P244_S0	Under capital adequacy guidelines, the Bank must meet specific capital guidelines that invo lved quantitative measures of their assets, liabilities and certain off-balance sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting practices.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P244_S1	These quantitative measures are established by regulation and require that minimum amounts and ratios of total and Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets and of Tier 1 capital to average assets be maintained.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P244_S2	Capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the regulators about components, risk weightings and other factors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P245_S0	The Bank is also subject to additional capital guidelines under the regulatory framework for prompt corrective action.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P245_S1	To be categorized as well capitalized, the Bank must maintain total risk-based, Tier 1 risk-based and Tier 1 leverage ratios as set forth in the table on the following page and cannot be subject to a written agreement, order or capital directive issued by the FDIC.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S0	In July, 2013, the federal bank regulatory agencies approved the final rules implementing the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision s capital guidelines for U.S. banks, sometimes called Basel III .
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S1	The phase-in period for the final rules began in 2015, with certain of the rules requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S2	Under the final rules minimum requirements increased for both the quantity and quality of capital held by the Company and the Bank.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S3	The new capital rules include a new minimum common equity Tier 1 ratio of 4.5%, a Tier 1 capital ratio of 6.0% (increased from 4.0% ), a total risk-based capital ratio of 8.0%, and a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0% (calculated as Tier 1 capital to average consolidated assets).
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S4	The effective date of these requirements was January 1, 2015.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S5	In addition, the new capital rules include a capital conservation buffer of 2.5% above each of these levels (to be phased in over three years which beginning at 0.625% on January 1, 2016 and increasing by that amount on each subsequent January 1, until reaching 2.5% on January 1, 2019) will be required for banking institutions to avoid restrictions on their ability to pay dividends, repurchase stock or pay discretionary bonuses.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S6	Including the capital conservation buffer of 2.5%, the New Capital Rules would result in the following minimum ratios to be considered well capitalized: (i) a Tier 1 capital ratio of 8.5%, (ii) a common equity Tier 1 capital ratio of 7.0%, and (iii) a total capital ratio of 10.5%.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P246_S7	The final rules also implement strict eligibility criteria for regulatory capital instruments.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P247_S0	The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has adopted final amendments to the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement (Re gulation Y, Appendix C) ( the Policy Statement ) that, among other things, raised from $500 million to $1 billion the asset threshold to qualify for the Policy Statement.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P247_S1	Plumas Bancorp qualifies for treatment under the Policy Statement and is no longer subject to consolidated capital rules at the bank holding company level.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P248_S0	The following table sets forth the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios (dollar amounts in thousands):
1168455_18_ITEM8_P249_S0	T he current and projected capital positions of the Company and the Bank and the impact of capital plans and long- term strategies are reviewed regularly by management.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P249_S1	The Company policy is to maintain the Bank s ratios above the prescribed well-capitalized ratios at all times.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P249_S2	Management believes that the Bank currently meets all its capital adequacy requirements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P250_S0	Other expenses consisted of the following:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P251_S0	The provision for income taxes for the years ended December 31, 201 7, 2016 and 2015 consisted of the following:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P252_S0	Income tax expense for 2017 includes a downward adjustment of net deferred tax assets in the amount of $1,419,000, recorded as a result of the enactment of H.R.1 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act on December 22, 2017.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P252_S1	The Act reduced the corporate Federal tax rate from 34% to 21% effective January 1, 2018.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P253_S0	Deferred tax assets (liabilities) consisted of the following:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P254_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the tax consequences of temporary differences between the reported amount of assets and liabilities and their tax bases.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P254_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expect ed to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P255_S0	The determination of the amount of deferred income tax assets which are more likely than not to be realized is primarily dependent on projections of future earnings, which are subject to uncertainty and estimates that may change given economic conditions and other factors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P255_S1	The realization of deferred income tax assets is assessed and a valuation allowance is recorded if it is more likely than not that all or a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P255_S2	More likely than not is defined as greater than a 50% chance.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P255_S3	All available evidence, both positive and negative is considered to determine whether, based on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P256_S0	At December 31, 201 7 total deferred tax assets were approximately $4,739,000 and total deferred tax liabilities were approximately $1,450,000 for a net deferred tax asset of $3,289,000.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P256_S1	The Company s deferred tax assets primarily relate timing differences in the tax deductibility of impairment charges on other real estate owned, deprecation on premises and equipment, the provision for loan losses and deferred compensation.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P256_S2	Based upon our analysis of available evidence, management of the Company determined that it is more likely than not that all of our deferred income tax assets as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 will be fully realized and therefore no valuation allowance was recorded.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P257_S0	On the consolidated balance sheet, net deferred tax assets are included in accrued interest receivable and other assets.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P258_S0	The provision for income taxes differs from amounts computed by applying the statutory Federal income tax rate to operating income before income taxes.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P258_S1	The significant items comprising these differences consisted of the following:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P259_S0	The Company and its subsidiary file income tax returns in the U.S. federal and applicable state jurisdictions.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P260_S0	The Company conducts all of its business activities in the states of California, Nevada and Oregon.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P260_S1	There are currently no pending U.S. federal, state, and local income tax or non-U.S. income tax examinations by tax authorities.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P261_S0	With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to tax examinations by U.S. Federal taxing authorities for years ended before December 31, 2014, and by state and local taxing authorities for years ended before December 31, 2013.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P262_S0	The unrecognized tax benefits and changes therein and the interest and penalties accrued by the Company as of or during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 were not significant.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P262_S1	The Company does not expect the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits to significantly increase or decrease in the next twelve months.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P263_S0	During the normal course of business, the Company enters in to transactions with related parties, including executive officers and directors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P263_S1	The following is a summary of the aggregate activity involving related party borrowers during 2017:
1168455_18_ITEM8_P264_S0	The Plumas Bank Profit Sharing Plan commenced April 1, 1988 and is available to employees meeting certain service requirements.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P264_S1	Under the Plan, employees are able to defer a selected percentage of their annual compensation.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P264_S2	Included under the Plan s inves tment options is the option to invest in Company stock.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P264_S3	During 2017, the Company s contribution totaled $150,000 consisting of a matching amount of 30% of the employee s contribution up to a total of 2.4% of the employee s compensation.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P264_S4	During 2016 and 2015, the Company s contribution consisted of a matching amount of 25% of the employee s contribution up to a total of 2% of the employee s compensation totaling $114,000 and $111,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P265_S0	Salary c ontinuation and retirement agreements are in place for the Company s president, its current executive vice presidents, six members of the Board of Directors as well as five former executives and four former directors.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P265_S1	Under these agreements, the directors and executives will receive monthly payments for periods ranging from ten to fifteen years, after retirement.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P265_S2	The estimated present value of these future benefits is accrued over the period from the effective dates of the agreements until the participants expected retirement dates.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P265_S3	The expense recognized under these plans for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 totaled $307,000, $269,000 and $258,000, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P265_S4	Accrued compensation payable under these plans totaled $3,855,000 and $3,889,000 at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P266_S0	In connection with some of these agreements, the Bank purchased single premium life insurance policies with cash surrender values totaling $12,866,000 and $12,528,000 at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM8_P266_S1	Income earned on these policies, net of expenses, totaled $338,000, $341,000 and $342,000 for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1168455_18_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of the Company s management, including the Company s CEO and the Company s CFO, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures at the end of the period covered by this report pursuant to Exchange Act Rule 13a-15.
1168455_18_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the Company s CEO and CFO concluded the Company s disclosure controls and procedures are effective in ensuring that information relating to the Company, including its consolidated subsidiaries, required to be disclosed in reports that it files under the Exchange Act is (1) recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms; and (2) accumulated and communicated to our management, including our CEO and CFO, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1168455_18_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting .
1168455_18_ITEM9A_P1_S1	During the fourth quarter of 2017, no change in the Company s internal control over financial reporting was identified in connection with this evaluation that has materially affected or is reasonably likely to materially affect internal control over financial reporting.
